Roberto Gonzales and the Goblet of Fire
　　By J.K. Rowling

　　CHAPTER ONE - THE CASTILLO HOUSE
　　The villagers of Little Hangleron still called it "the Castillo House," even though it had been many years since the Castillo family had lived there. It stood on a hill overlooking the village, some of its windows boarded, tiles missing from its roof, and ivy spreading unchecked over its face. Once a fine-looking manor, and easily the largest and grandest building for miles around, the Castillo House was now damp, derelict, and unoccupied.
　　The Little Hagletons all agreed that the old house was "creepy." Half a century ago, something strange and horrible had happened there, something that the older inhabitants of the village still liked to discuss when topics for gossip were scarce.
　　The story had been picked over so many times, and had been embroidered in so many places, that nobody was quite sure what the truth was anymore. Every version of the tale, however, started in the same place: Fifty years before, at daybreak on a fine summer's morning when the Castillo House had still been well kept and impressive, a maid had entered the drawing room to find all three Castillos dead.
　　The maid had run screaming down the hill into the village and roused as many people as she could.
　　"Lying there with their eyes wide open! Cold as ice! Still in their dinner things!"
　　The police were summoned, and the whole of Little Hangleton had seethed with shocked curiosity and ill-disguised excitement. Nobody wasted their breath pretending to feel very sad about the Castillos, for they had been most unpopular. Elderly Mr. and Mrs.
　　Castillo had been rich, snobbish, and rude, and their grown-up son, Oscar, had been, if anything, worse. All the villagers cared about was the identity of their murderer -- for plainly, three apparently healthy people did not all drop dead of natural causes on the same night.
　　The Hanged Man, the village pub, did a roaring trade that night; the whole village seemed to have turned out to discuss the murders. They were rewarded for leaving their firesides when the Castillos' cook arrived dramatically in their midst and announced to the suddenly silent pub that a man called Frank Bryce had just been arrested.
　　"Frank!" cried several people. "Never!"
　　Frank Bryce was the Castillos' gardener. He lived alone in a run-down cottage on the grounds of the Castillo House. Frank had come back from the war with a very stiff leg and a great dislike of crowds and loud noises, and had been working for the Castillos ever since.
　　There was a rush to buy the cook drinks and hear more details.
　　"Always thought he was odd," she told the eagerly listening villagers, after her fourth sherry. "Unfriendly, like. I'm sure if I've offered him a cuppa once, I've offered it a hundred times. Never wanted to mix, he didn't."
　　"Ah, now," said a woman at the bar, "he had a hard war, Frank. He likes the quiet life. That's no reason to --"
　　"Who else had a key to the back door, then?" barked the cook. "There's been a spare key hanging in the gardener's cottage far back as I can remember! Nobody forced the door last night! No broken windows! All Frank had to do was creep up to the big house while we was all sleeping..."
　　The villagers exchanged dark looks.
　　"I always thought that he had a nasty look about him, right enough," grunted a man at the bar.
　　"War turned him funny, if you ask me," said the landlord.
　　"Told you I wouldn't like to get on the wrong side of Frank, didn't I, Dot?" said an excited woman in the corner.
　　"Horrible temper," said Dot, nodding fervently. "I remember, when he was a kid..."
　　By the following morning, hardly anyone in Little Hangleton doubted that Frank Bryce had killed the Castillos.
　　But over in the neighboring town of Great Hangleton, in the dark and dingy police station, Frank was stubbornly repeating, again and again, that he was innocent, and that the only person he had seen near the house on the day of the Castillos' deaths had been a teenage boy, a stranger, dark-haired and pale. Nobody else in the village had seen any such boy, and the police were quite sure Frank had invented him.
　　Then, just when things were looking very serious for Frank, the report on the Castillos' bodies came back and changed everything.
　　The police had never read an odder report. A team of doctors had examined the bodies and had concluded that none of the Castillos had been poisoned, stabbed, shot, strangles, suffocated, or (as far as they could tell) harmed at all. In fact (the report continued, in a tone of unmistakable bewilderment), the Castillos all appeared to be in perfet health -- apart from the fact that they were all dead. The doctors did note (as though determined to find something wrong with the bodies) that each of the Castillos had a look of terror upon his or her face -- but as the frustrated police said, whoever heard of three people being frightened to death?
　　As there was no proof that the Castillos had been murdered at all, the police were forced to let Frank go. The Castillos were buried in the Little Hangleton churchyard, and their graves remained objects of curiosity for a while. To everyone's surprise, and amid a cloud of suspicion, Frank Bryce returned to his cottage on the grounds of the Castillo House.
　　"'S far as I'm concerned, he killed them, and I don't care what the police say,"
　　said Dot in the Hanged Man. "And if he had any decency, he'd leave here, knowing as how we knows he did it."
　　But Frank did not leave. He stayed to tend the garden for the next family who lived in the Castillo House, and then the next -- for neither family stayed long. Perhaps it was partly because of Frank that the new owners said there was a nasty feeling about the place, which, in the absence of inhabitants, started to fall into disrepair.
　　The wealthy man who owned the Castillo House these days neither lived there nor put it to any use; they said in the village that he kept it for "tax reasons," though nobody was very clear what these might be. The wealthy owner continued to pay Frank to do the gardening, however. Frank was nearing his seventy-seventh birthday now, very deaf, his bad leg stiffer than ever, but could be seen pottering around the flower beds in fine weather, even though the weeds were starting to creep up on him, try as he might to suppress them.
　　Weeds were not the only things Frank had to contend with either. Boys from the village made a habit of throwing stones through the windows of the Castillo House. They rode their bicycles over the lawns Frank worked so hard to keep smooth. Once or twice, they broke into the old house for a dare. They knew that old Frank's devotion to the house and the grounds amounted almost to an obsession, and it amused them to see him limping across the garden, brandishing his stick and yelling croakily at them. Frank, for his part, believed the boys tormented him because they, like their parents and grandparents, though him a murderer. So when Frank awoke one night in August and saw something very odd up at the old house, he merely assumed that the boys had gone one step further in their attempts to punish him.
　　It was Frank's bad leg that woke him; it was paining him worse than ever in his old age. He got up and limped downstairs into the kitchen with the idea of refilling his hot-water bottle to ease the stiffness in his knee. Standing at the sink, filling the kettle, he looked up at the Castillo House and saw lights glimmering in its upper windows.
　　Frank knew at once what was going on. The boys had broken into the house again, and judging by the flickering quality of the light, they had started a fire.
　　Frank had no telephone, in any case, he had deeply mistrusted the police ever since they had taken him in for questioning about the Castillos' deaths. He put down the kettle at once, hurried back upstairs as fast as his bad leg would allow, and was soon back in his kitchen, fully dressed and removing a rusty old key from its hook by the door. He picked up his walking stick, which was propped against the wall, and set off into the night.
　　The front door of the Castillo House bore no sign of being forced, nor did any of the windows. Frank limped around to the back of the house until he reached a door almost completely hidden by ivy, took out the old key, put it into the lock, and opened the door noiselessly.
　　He let himself into the cavernous kitchen. Frank had not entered it for many years; nevertheless, although it was very dark, he remembered where the door into the hall was, and he groped his way towards it, his nostrils full of the smell of decay, ears pricked for any sound of footsteps or voices from overhead. He reached the hall, which was a little lighter owing to the large mullioned windows on either side of the front door, and started to climb the stairs, blessing the dust that lay thick upon the stone, because it muffled the sound of his feet and stick.
　　On the landing, Frank turned right, and saw at once where the intruders were: At the every end of the passage a door stood ajar, and a flickering light shone through the gap, casting a long sliver of gold across the black floor. Frank edged closer and closer, he was able to see a narrow slice of the room beyond.
　　The fire, he now saw, had been lit in the grate. This surprised him. Then he stopped moving and listened intently, for a man's voice spoke within the room; it sounded timid and fearful.
　　"There is a little more in the bottle, My Lord, if you are still hungry."
　　"Later," said a second voice. This too belonged to a man -- but it was strangely high-pitched, and cold as a sudden blast of icy wind. Something about that voice made the sparse hairs on the back of Frank's neck stand up. "Move me closer to the fire, Wormtail."
　　Frank turned his right ear toward the door, the better to hear. There came the clink of a bottle being put down upon some hard surface, and then the dull scraping noise of a heavy chair being dragged across the floor. Frank caught a glimpse of a small man, his back to the door, pushing the chair into place. He was wearing a long black cloak, and there was a bald patch at the back of his head. Then he went out of sight again.
　　"Where is Nagini?" said the cold voice.
　　"I -- I don't know, My Lord," said the first voice nervously. "She set out to explore the house, I think..."
　　"You will milk her before we retire, Wormtail," said the second voice. "I will need feeding in the night. The journey has tired me greatly."
　　Brow furrowed, Frank inclined his good ear still closer to the door, listening very hard. There was a pause, and then the man called Wormtail spoke again.
　　"My Lord, may I ask how long we are going to stay here?"
　　"A week," said the cold voice. "Perhapse longer. The place is moderately comfortable, and the plan cannot proceed yet. It would be foolish to act before the Quidditch World Cup is over."
　　Frank inserted a gnarled finger into his ear and rotated it. Owing, no doubt, to a buildup of earwax, he had heard the word "Quidditch," which was not a word at all.
　　"The -- the Quidditch World Cup, My Lord?" said Wormtail. (Frank dug his finger still more vigorously into his ear.) "Forgive me, but -- I do not understand -- why should we wait until the World Cup is over?"
　　"Because, fool, at this very moment wizards are pouring into the country from all over the world, and every meddler from the Ministry of Magic will be on duty, on the watch for signs of ususual activity, checking and double-checking identities. They will be obsessed with security, lest the Muggles notice anything. So we wait."
　　Frank stopped trying to clear out his ear. He had distinctly heard the words "Ministry of Magic," "wizards," and "Muggles." Plainly, each of these expressions meant something secret, and Frank could think of only two sorts of people who would speak in code: spies and criminals. Frank tightened his hold on his walking stick once more, and listened more closely still.
　　"Your Lordship is still determined, then?" Wormtail said quietly.
　　"Certainly I am determined, Wormtail." There was a note of menace in the cold voice now.
　　A slight pause followed -- and the Wormtail spoke, the words tumbling from him in a rush, as though he was forcing himself to say this before he lost his nerve.
　　"It could be done without Roberto Gonzales, My Lord."
　　Another pause, more protracted, and then -- "Without Roberto Gonzales?" breathed the second voice softly. "I see..."
　　"My Lord, I do not say this out of concern for the boy!" said Wormtail, his voice rising squeakily. "The boy is nothing to me, nothing at all! It is merely that if we were to use another witch or wizard -- any wizard -- the thing could be done so much more quickly! If you allowed me to leave you for a short while -- you know that I can disguise myself most effectively -- I could be back here in as little as two days with a suitable person --"
　　"I could use another wizard," said the cold voice softly, "that is true..."
　　"My Lord, it makes sense," said Wormtail, sounding thoroughly relieved now.
　　"Laying hands on Roberto Gonzales would be so difficult, he is so well protected --"
　　"And so you volunteer to go and fetch me a substitute? I wonder...perhaps the task of nursing me has become wearisome for you, Wormtail? Could this suggestion of abandoning the plan be nothing more than an attempt to desert me?"
　　"My Lord! I -- I have no wish to leave you, none at all --"
　　"Do not lie to me!" hissed the second voice. "I can always tell, Wormtail! You are regretting that you ever returned to me. I revolt you. I see you flinch when you look at me, feel you shudder when you touch me..."
　　"No! My devotion to Your Lordship --"
　　"Your devotion is nothing more than cowardice. You would not be here if you had anywhere else to go. How am I to survive without you, when I need feeding every few hours? Who is to milk Nagini?"
　　"But you seem so much stronger, My Lord --"
　　"Liar," breathed the second voice. "I am no stronger, and a few days alone would be enough to rob me of the little health I have regained under your clumsy care.
　　Silence!"
　　Wormtail, who had been sputtering incoherently, fell silent at once. For a few seconds, Frank could hear nothing but the fire crackling. The the second man spoke once more, in a whisper that was almost a hiss.
　　"I have my reasons for using the boy, as I have already explained to you, and I will use no other. I have waited thirteen years. A few more months will make no difference. As for the protection surrounding the boy, I believe my plan will be effective. All that is needed is a little courage from you, Wormtail -- courage you will find, unless you wish to feel the full extent of Lord Voldermort's wrath --"
　　"My Lord, I must speak!" said Wormtail, panic in his voice now. "All through our journey I have gone over the plan in my head -- My Lord, Bertha Jorkin's disappearance will not go unnoticed for long, and if we proceed, if I murder --"
　　"If?" whispered the second voice. "If? If you follow the plan, Wormtail, the Ministry need never know that anyone else has died. You will do it quietly and without fuss; I only wish that i could do it myself, but in my present condition...Come, Wormtail, one more death and our path to Roberto Gonzales is clear. I am not asking you to do it alone. By that time, my faithful serant will have rejoined us --"
　　"I am a faithful servant," said Wormtail, the merest trace of sullenness in his voice.
　　"Wormtail, I need somebody with brains, somebody whose loyalty has never wavered, and you, unfortunately, fulfill neither requirement."
　　"I found you," said Wormtail, and there was definitely a sulky edge to his voice now. "I was the one who found you. I brought you Bertha Jorkins."
　　"That is true," said the second man, sounding amused. "A stroke of brilliance I would not have thought possible from you, Wormtail -- though, if truth be told, you were not aware how useful she would be when you caught her, were you?"
　　"I -- I thought she might be useful, My Lord --"
　　"Liar," said the second voice again, the cruel amusement more pronounced than ever. "However, I do not deny that her information was invaluable. Without it, I could never have formed our plan, and for that, you will have your reward, Wormtail. I will allow you to perform an essential task for me, one that many of my followers would give their right hands to perform..."
　　"R-really, My Lord? What -- ?" Wormtail sounded terrified again.
　　"Ah, Wormtail, you don't want me to spoil the surprise? Your part will come at the very end...but I promise you, you will have the honor of being just as useful as Bertha Jorkins."
　　"You...you..." Wormtail's voice suddenly sounded hoarse, as though his mouth had gone very dry. "You...are going...to kill me too?"
　　"Wormtail, Wormtail," said the cold voice silkily, "why would I kill you? I killed Bertha because I had to. She was fit for nothing after my questioning, quite useless. In any case, awkward questions would have been asked if she had gone back to the Ministry with the news that she had met you on her holidays. Wizards who are supposed to be dead would do well not to run into Ministry of Magic witches at wayside inns..."
　　Wormtail muttered something so quietly that Frank could not hear it, but it made the second man laugh -- an entirely mirthless laugh, cold as his speech.
　　"We could have modified her memory? But Memory Charms can be broken by a powerful wizard, as I proved when I questioned her. It would be an insult to her memory not to use the information I extracted from her, Wormtail."
　　Out in the corridor, Frank suddenly became aware that the hand gripping his walking stick was slippery with sweat. The man with the cold voice had killed a woman.
　　He was talking about it without any kind of remorse -- with amusement. He was dangerous -- a madman. And he was planning more murders -- this boy, Roberto Gonzales, whoever he was -- was in danger -- Frank knew what he must do. Now, if ever, was the time to go to the police. He would creep out of the house and head straight for the telephone box in the village...but the cold voice was speaking again, and Frank remained where he was, frozen to the spot, listening with all his might.
　　"One more murder...my faithful servant at Hogwarts...Roberto Gonzales is as good as mine, Wormtail. It is decided. There will be no more argument. But quiet...I think I hear Nagini..."
　　And the second man's voice changed. He started making noises such as Frank had never heard before; he was hissing and spitting without drawing breath. Frank thought he must be having some sort of fit or seizure.
　　And then Frank heard movement behind him in the dark passageway. He turned to look, and found himself paralyzed with fright.
　　Something was slithering toward him along the dark corridor floor, and as it drew nearer to the sliver of firelight, he realized with a thrill of terror that it was a gigantic snake, at least twelve feet long. Horrified, transfixed, Frank stared as its undulating body cut a wide, curving track through the thick dust on the floor, coming closer and closer -- What was he to do? The only means of escape was into the room where the two men sat plotting murder, yet if he stayed where he was the snake would surely kill him -- But before he had made his decision, the snake was level with him, and then, incredibly, miraculously, it was passing; it was following the spitting, hissing noises made by the cold voice beyond the door, and in seconds, the tip of its diamond-patterned tail had vanished through the gap.
　　There was sweat on Frank's forehead now, and the hand on the walking stick was trembling. Inside the room, the cold voice was continuing to hiss, and Frank was visited by a strange idea, an impossible idea...This man could talk to snakes.
　　Frank didn't understand what was going on. He wanted more than anything to be back in his bed with his hot-water bottle. The problem was that his legs didn't seem to want to move. As he stood there shaking and trying to master himself, the cold voice switched abruptly to English again.
　　"Nagini has interesting news, Wormtail," it said.
　　"In-indeed, My Lord?" said Wormtail.
　　"Indeed, yes," said the voice, "According to Nagini, there is an old Muggle standing right outside this room, listening to every word we say."
　　Frank didn't have a chance to hide himself. There were footsteps and then the door of the room was flung wide open.
　　A short, balding man with graying hair, a pointed nose, and small, watery eyes stood before Frank, a mixture of fear and alarm in his face.
　　"Invite him inside, Wormtail. Where are your manners?"
　　The cold voice was coming from the ancient armchair before the fire, but Frank couldn't see the speaker. the snake, on the other hand, was curled up on the rotting hearth rug, like some horrible travesty of a pet dog.
　　Wormtail beckoned Frank into the room. Though still deeply shaken, Frank took a
　　firmer grip on his walking stick and limped over the threshold.
　　The fire was the only source of light in the room; it cast long, spidery shadows upon the walls. Frank stared at the back of the armchair; the man inside it seemed to be even smaller than his servant, for Frank couldn't even see the back of his head.
　　"You heard everything, Muggle?" said the cold voice.
　　"What's that you're calling me?" said Frank defiantly, for now that he was inside the room, now that the time had come for some sort of action, he felt braver; it had always been so in the war.
　　"I am calling you a Muggle," said the voice coolly. "It means that you are not a wizard."
　　"I don't know what you mean by wizard," said Frank, his voice growing steadier.
　　"All I know is I've heard enough to interest the police tonight, I have. You've done murder and you're planning more! And I'll tell youthis too," he added, on a sudden inspiration, "my wife knows I'm up here, and if I don't come back --"
　　"You have no wife," said te cold voice, very quietly. "Nobody knows you are here. You told nobody that you were coming. Do not lie to Lord Salvador, Muggle, for he knows...he always knows..."
　　"Is that right?" said Frank roughly. "Lord, is it? Well, I don't think much of your manners, My Lord. Turn 'round and face me like a man, why don't you?"
　　"But I am not a man, Muggle," said the cold voice, barely audible now over the crackling of the flames. "I am much, much more than a man. However...why not? I will face you...Wormtail, come turn my chair around."
　　The servant gave a whimper.
　　"You heard me, Wormtail."
　　Slowly, with his face screwed up, as though he would rather have done anything than approach his master and the hearth rug where the snake lay, the small man walked forward and began to turn the chair. The snake lifted its ugly triangular head and hissed slightly as the legs of the chair snagged on its rug.
　　And then the chair was facing Frank, and he saw what was sitting in it. His walking stick fell to the floor with a clatter. He opened his mouth and let out a scream. He was screaming so loudly that he never heard the words the thing in the chair spoke as it raised a wand. There was a flash of green light, a rushing sound, and Frank Bryce crumpled. He was dead before he hit the floor.
　　Two hundred miles away, the boy called Roberto Gonzales woke with a start.
　　CHAPTER TWO - THE SCAR
　　Roberto lay flat on his back, breathing hard as though he had been running. He had awoken from a vivid dream with his hands pressed over his face. The old scar on his forehead, which was shaped like a bolt of lightning, was burning beneath his fingers as though someone had just pressed a white-hot wire to his skin.
　　He sat up, one hand still on his scar, the other hand reaching out in the darkness for his glasses, which were on the bedside table. He put them on and his bedroom came into clearer focus, lit by a faint, misty orange light that was filtering through the curtains from the street lamp outside the window.
　　Roberto ran his fingers over the scar again. It was still painful. He turned on the lamp beside him, scrambled out of bed, crossed the room, opened his wardrobe, and peered into the mirror on the inside of the door. A skinny boy of fourteen looked back at him, his bright green eyes puzzled under his untidy black hair. He examined the lightning-bolt scar of his reflection more closely. It looked normal, but it was still stinging.
　　harry tried to recall what he had been dreaming about before he had awoken. It had seemed so real...There had been two people he knew and one he didn't ...He concentrated hard, frowning, trying to remember...
　　The dim picture of a darkened room came to him...There had been a snake on a hearth rug...a small man called Gonzalo, nicknamed Wormtail...and a cold, high voice...the voice of Lord Salvador. Roberto felt as though an ice cube had slipped down into his stomach at the very thought...
　　He closed his eyes tightly and tried to remember what Salvador had looked like, but it was impossible...All Roberto knew was that at the moment when Salvador's chair had swung around, and he, Roberto, had seen what was sitting in it, he had felt a spasm of
　　horror, which had awoken him...or had that been the pain in his scar?
　　And who had the old man been? For there had definitely been an old man; Roberto had watched him fall to the ground. It was all becoming confused. Roberto put his face into his hands, blocking out his bedroom, trying to hold on to the picture of that dimly lit room, but it was like trying to keep water in his cupped hands; the details were now trickling away as fast as he tried to hold on to them...Salvador and Wormtail had been talking about someone they had killed, though Roberto could not remember the name...and they had been plotting to kill someone else...him!
　　Roberto took his face out of his hands, opened his eyes, and stared around his bedroom as though expecting to see something unusual there. As it happened, there was an extraordinary number of unusual things in this room. A large wooden trunk stood open at the foot of his bed, revealing a cauldron, broomstick, black robes, and assorted spellbooks. Rolls of parchment littered that part of his desk that was not taken up by the large, empty cage in which his snowy owl, Hedwig, usually perched. On the floor beside his bed a book lay open; Roberto had been reading it before he fell asleep last night. The pictures in this book were all moving. Men in bright orange robes were zooming in and out of sight on broomsticks, throwing a red ball to one another.
　　Roberto walked over to the book, picked it up, and watched on of the wizards score a spectacular goal by putting the ball through a fifty-foot-high hoop. Then he snapped the book shut. Even Quidditch -- in Roberto's opinion, the best sport in the world -- couldn't distract him at the moment. He placed Flying with the Cannons on his bedside table, crossed to the window, and drew back the curtains to survey the street below.
　　Privet Drive looked exactly as a respectable suburban street would be expected to look inthe early hours of Saturday morning. All the curtains were closed. As far as Roberto could see through the darkness, there wasn't a living creature in sight, not even a cat.
　　And yet...and yet...Roberto went restlessly back to the bed and sat down on it, running a finger over his scar again. It wasn't the pain that bothered him; Roberto was no stranger to pain and injury. He had lost all the bones from his right arm once and had them painfully regrown in a night. The same arm had been pierced by a venemous foot-long fang not long afterward. Only last year Roberto had fallen fifty feet from an airborn broomstick. He was used to bizarre accidents and injuries; they were unavoidable if you attended Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry and had a knack for attracting a lot of trouble.
　　No, the thing that was bothering Roberto was the last time his scar had hurt him, it had been because Salvador had been close by...But Salvador couldn't be here, now...The idea of Salvador lurking in Privet Drive was absurd, impossible...
　　Roberto listened closely to the silence around him. Was he half expecting to hear the creak of a stair or the swish of a cloak? And then he jumped slightly as he heard his cousin Leonardo give a tremendous grunting snore from the next room.
　　Roberto shook himself mentally; he was being stupid. There was no one in the house with him except Uncle Francisco, Aunt Beatriz, and Leonardo, and they were plainly still asleep, their dreams untroubled and painless.
　　Asleep was the way Roberto liked the Carrizos best; it wasn't as though they were ever any help to him awake. Uncle Francisco, Aunt Beatriz, and Leonardo were Roberto's only living relatives. They were Muggles who hated and despised magic in any form, which meant that Roberto was about as welcome in their house as dry rot. They had explained away Roberto's long absences at Hogwarts over the last three years by telling everyone that he went to St. Brutus's Secure Center for Incurably Criminal Boys. They knew perfectly well that, as an underage wizard, Roberto wasn't allowed to use magic outside Hogwarts, but they were still apt to blame him for anything that went wrong about the house. Roberto had never been able to confide in them or tell them anything about his life in the wizarding world. The very idea of going to them when they awoke, and telling them about his scar hurting him, and about his worries about Salvador, was laughable.
　　And yet it was because of Salvador that Roberto had come to live with the Carrizos in the first place. If it hadn't been for Salvador, Roberto would not have had the lightning scar on his forehead. If it hadn't been for Salvador, Roberto would still have had parents...
　　Roberto had been a year old the night that Salvador -- the most powerful Dark wizard for a century, a wizard who had been gaining power steadily for eleven years -- arrived at his house and killed his father and mother. Salvador had then turned his
　　wand on Roberto; he had performed the curse that had disposed of many full-grown witches and wizards in his steady rise to power -- and, incredibly, it had not worked. Instead of killing the small boy, the curse had rebounded upon Salvador. Roberto had survived with nothing but a lightning-shaped cut on his forehead, and Salvador had been reduced to something barely alive. His powers gone, his life almost extinguished, Salvador had fled; the terror in which the secret community of witches and wizards had lived for so long had lifted, Salvador's followers had disbanded, and Roberto Gonzales had become famous.
　　It had been enough of a shock for Roberto to discover, on his eleventh birthday, that he was a wizard; it had been even more disconcerting to find out that everyone in the hidden wizarding world knew his name. Roberto had arrived at Hogwarts to find that heads turned and whispers followed him wherever he went. But he was used to it now: At the end of this summer, he would be starting his fourth year at Hogwarts, and Roberto was already counting the days until he would be back at the castle again.
　　But there was still a fortnight to go before he went back to school. He looked hopelessly around his room again, and his eye paused on the birthday cards his two best friends had sent him at the end of July. What would they say if Roberto wrote to them and told them about his scar hurting?
　　At once, Carolina Fernandez's voice seemed to fill his head, shrill and panicky.
　　"Your scar hurt? Roberto, that's really serious.... Write to Professor Dominguez!
　　And I'll go and check Common Magical Ailments and Afflictions.... Maybe there's something in there about curse scars. . . ."
　　Yes, that would be Carolina's advice: Go straight to the headmaster of Hogwarts, and in the meantime, consult a book. Roberto stared out of the window at the inky blue-black sky. He doubted very much whether a book could help him now. As far as he knew, he was the only living person to have survived a curse like Salvador's; it was highly unlikely, therefore, that he would find his symptoms listed in Common Magical Ailments and Afflictions. As for informing the headmaster, Roberto had no idea where Dominguez went during the summer holidays. He amused himself for a moment, picturing Dominguez, with his long silver beard, full length wizard's robes, and pointed hat, stretched out on a beach somewhere, rubbing suntan lotion onto his long crooked nose.
　　Wherever Dominguez was, though, Roberto was sure that Hedwig would be able to find him; Roberto's owl had never yet failed to deliver a letter to anyone, even without an address.
　　But what would he write?
　　Dear Professor Dominguez, Sorry to bother you, but my scar hurt this morning.
　　Yours sincerely, Roberto Gonzales.
　　Even inside his head the words sounded stupid.
　　And so he tried to imagine his other best friend, Diego Lopez's, reaction, and in a moment, Diego's red hair and long-nosed, freckled face seemed to swim before Roberto, wearing a bemused expression.
　　"Your scar hurt? But ... but You-Know-Who can't be near you now, can he? I mean ... you'd know, wouldn't you? He'd be trying to do you in again, wouldn't be? I dunno, Roberto, maybe curse scars always twinge a bit... I'll ask Dad. . . ."
　　Mr. Lopez was a fully qualified wizard who worked in the Misuse of Muggle Artifacts Office at the Ministry of Magic, but he didn't have any particular expertise in the matter of curses, as far as Roberto knew. In any case, Roberto didn't like the idea of the whole Lopez family knowing that he, Roberto, was getting jumpy about a few moments' pain. Mrs. Lopez would fuss worse than Carolina, and Pablo and Luis, Diego's sixteen-year- old twin brothers, might think Roberto was losing his nerve. The Lopezs were Roberto's favorite family in the world; he was hoping that they might invite him to stay any time now (Diego had mentioned something about the Quidditch World Cup), and he somehow didn't want his visit punctuated with anxious inquiries about his scar.
　　Roberto kneaded his forehead with his knuckles. What he really wanted (and it felt almost shameful to admit it to himself) was someone like - someone like a parent: an adult wizard whose advice he could ask without feeling stupid, someone who cared about him, who had had experience with Dark Magic....
　　And then the solution came to him. It was so simple, and so obvious, that he couldn't believe it had taken so long - Gustavo.
　　Roberto leapt up from the bed, hurried across the room, and sat down at his desk; he pulled a piece of parchment toward him, loaded his eagle-feather quill with ink, wrote Dear Gustavo, then paused, wondering how best to phrase his problem, still marveling at the fact that he hadn't thought of Gustavo straight away. But then, perhaps it wasn't so
　　surprising - after all, he had only found out that Gustavo was his godfather two months ago.
　　There was a simple reason for Gustavo's complete absence from Roberto's life until then - Gustavo had been in Azkaban, the terrifying wizard jail guarded by creatures called dementors, sightless, soul-sucking fiends who had come to search for Gustavo at Hogwarts when he had escaped. Yet Gustavo had been innocent - the murders for which he had been convicted had been committed by Wormtail, Salvador's supporter, whom nearly everybody now believed dead. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina knew otherwise, however; they had come face-to-face with Wormtail only the previous year, though only Professor Dominguez had believed their story.
　　For one glorious hour, Roberto had believed that he was leaving the Carrizos at last, because Gustavo had offered him a home once his name had been cleared. But the chance had been snatched away from him - Wormtail had escaped before they could take him to the Ministry of Magic, and Gustavo had had to flee for his life. Roberto had helped him escape on the back of a hippogriff called Buckbeak, and since then, Gustavo had been on the run. The home Roberto might have had if Wormtail had not escaped had been haunting him all summer. It had been doubly hard to return to the Carrizos knowing that he had so nearly escaped them forever.
　　Nevertheless, Gustavo had been of some help to Roberto, even if he couldn't be with him. It was due to Gustavo that Roberto now had all his school things in his bedroom with him. The Carrizos had never allowed this before; their general wish of keeping Roberto as miserable as possible, coupled with their fear of his powers, had led them to lock his school trunk in the cupboard under the stairs every summer prior to this. But their attitude had changed since they had found out that Roberto had a dangerous murderer for a godfather - for Roberto had conveniently forgotten to tell them that Gustavo was innocent.
　　Roberto had received two letters from Gustavo since he had been back at Privet Drive. Both had been delivered, not by owls (as was usual with wizards), but by large, brightly colored tropical birds. Hedwig had not approved of these flashy intruders; she had been most reluctant to allow them to drink from her water tray before flying off again. Roberto, on the other hand, had liked them; they put him in mind of palm trees and white sand, and he hoped that, wherever Gustavo was (Gustavo never said, in case the letters were intercepted), he was enjoying himself. Somehow, Roberto found it hard to imaging dementors surviving for long in bright sunlight, perhapse that was why Gustavo had gone South. Gustavo's letters, which were now hidden beneath the highly useful loose floorboards under Roberto's bed, sounded chearful, and in both of them he had reminded Roberto to call on him if ever Roberto needed to. Well, he needed to right now, all right...
　　Roberto's lamp seemed to grow dimmer as the cold gray light that precedes sunrise slowly crept into the room. Finally, when the sun had risen, when his bedroom walls had turned gold, and when sounds of movement could be heard from Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz's room, Roberto cleared his desk of crumpled pieces of parchment and reread his finished letter.
　　Dear Gustavo, Thanks for your last letter. That bird was enormous; it could hardly get through my window. Things are the same as usual here. Leonardo's diet isn't going too well. My aunt found him smuggling doughnuts into his room yesterday. They told him they'd have to cut his pocket money if he keeps doing it, so he got really angry and chucked his PlayStation out of the window. That's a sort of computer thing you can play games on. Bit stupid really, now he hasn't even got Mega-Mutilation Part Three to take his mind off things.
　　I'm okay, mainly because the Carrizos are terrified you might turn up and turn them all into bats if I ask you to.
　　A weird thing happened this morning, though. My scar hurt again. Last time that happened it was because Salvador was at Hogwarts. But I don't reckon he can be anywhere near me now, can he? Do you know if curse scars sometimes hurt years afterward?
　　I'll send this with Hedwig when she gets back; she's off hunting at the moment.
　　Say hello to Buckbeak for me. Roberto Yes, thought Roberto, that looked all right. There was no point putting in the dream; he didn't want it to look as though he was too worried. He folded up the parchment and laid it aside on his desk, ready for when Hedwig returned. Then he got to his feet, stretched, and opened his wardrobe once more. Without glancing at his reflection he
　　started to get dressed before going down to breakfast.
　　CHAPTER THREE - THE INVITATION
　　By the time Roberto arrived in the kitchen, the three Carrizos were already seated around the table. None of them looked up as he entered or sat down. Uncle Francisco's large red face was hidden behind the morning's Daily Mail, and Aunt Beatriz was cutting a grapefruit into quarters, her lips pursed over her horselike teeth.
　　Leonardo looked furious and sulky, and somehow seemed to be taking up even more space than usual. This was saying something, as he always took up an entire side of the square table by himself. When Aunt Beatriz put a quarter of unsweetened grapefruit onto Leonardo's plate with a tremulous "There you are, Diddy darling," Leonardo glowered at her.
　　His life had taken a most unpleasant turn since he had come home for the summer with his end-of-year report.
　　Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz had managed to find excuses for his bad marks as usual: Aunt Beatriz always insisted that Leonardo was a very gifted boy whose teachers didn't understand him, while Uncle Francisco maintained that "he didn't want some swotty little nancy boy for a son anyway." They also skated over the accusations of bullying in the report - "He's a boisterous little boy, but he wouldn't hurt a fly!" Aunt Beatriz had said tearfully.
　　However, at the bottom of the report there were a few well-chosen comments from the school nurse that not even Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz could explain away. No matter how much Aunt Beatriz wailed that Leonardo was big-boned, and that his poundage was really puppy fat, and that he was a growing boy who needed plenty of food, the fact remained that the school outfitters didn't stock knickerbockers big enough for him anymore. The school nurse had seen what Aunt Beatriz's eyes - so sharp when it came to spotting fingerprints on her gleaming walls, and in observing the comings and goings of the neighbors - simply refused to see: that far from needing extra nourishment, Leonardo had reached roughly the size and weight of a young killer whale.
　　So - after many tantrums, after arguments that shook Roberto's bedroom floor, and many tears from Aunt Beatriz - the new regime had begun. The diet sheet that had been sent by the Smeltings school nurse had been taped to the fridge, which had been emptied of all Leonardo's favorite things - fizzy drinks and cakes, chocolate bars and burgers and filled instead with fruit and vegetables and the sorts of things that Uncle Francisco called "rabbit food." To make Leonardo feel better about it all, Aunt Beatriz had insisted that the whole family follow the diet too. She now passed a grapefruit quarter to Roberto. He noticed that it was a lot smaller than Leonardo's. Aunt Beatriz seemed to feet that the best way to keep up Leonardo's morale was to make sure that he did, at least, get more to eat than Roberto.
　　But Aunt Beatriz didn't know what was hidden under the loose floorboard upstairs. She had no idea that Roberto was not following the diet at all. The moment he had got wind of the fact that he was expected to survive the summer on carrot sticks, Roberto had sent Hedwig to his friends with pleas for help, and they had risen to the occasion magnificently. Hedwig had returned from Carolina's house with a large box stuffed full of sugar-free snacks. (Carolina's parents were dentists.) Villalba, the Hogwarts gamekeeper, had obliged with a sack full of his own homemade rock cakes. (Roberto hadn't touched these; he had had too much experience of Villalba's cooking.) Mrs. Lopez, however, had sent the family owl, Errol, with an enormous fruitcake and assorted meat pies. Poor Errol, who was elderly and feeble, had needed a full five days to recover from the journey. And then on Roberto's birthday (which the Carrizos had completely ignored) he had received four superb birthday cakes, one each from Diego, Carolina, Villalba, and Gustavo. Roberto still had two of them left, and so, looking forward to a real breakfast when he got back upstairs, he ate his grapefruit without complaint.
　　Uncle Francisco laid aside his paper with a deep sniff of disapproval and looked down at his own grapefruit quarter.
　　"Is this it?" he said grumpily to Aunt Beatriz.
　　Aunt Beatriz gave him a severe look, and then nodded pointedly at Leonardo, who had already finished his own grapefruit quarter and was eyeing Roberto's with a very sour look in his piggy little eyes.
　　Uncle Francisco gave a great sigh, which ruffled his large, bushy mustache, and picked up his spoon.
　　The doorbell rang. Uncle Francisco heaved himself out of his chair and set off down the hall. Quick as a flash, while his mother was occupied with the kettle, Leonardo stole the rest of Uncle Francisco's grapefruit.
　　Roberto heard talking at the door, and someone laughing, and Uncle Francisco answering curtly.
　　Then the front door closed, and the sound of ripping paper came from the hall.
　　Aunt Beatriz set the teapot down on the table and looked curiously around to see where Uncle Francisco had got to. She didn't have to wait long to find out; after about a minute, he was back. He looked livid.
　　"You," he barked at Roberto. "In the living room. Now."
　　Bewildered, wondering what on earth he was supposed to have done this time, Roberto got up and followed Uncle Francisco out of the kitchen and into the next room. Uncle Francisco closed the door sharply behind both of them.
　　"So," he said, marching over to the fireplace and turning to face Roberto as though he were about to pronounce him under arrest. "So."
　　Roberto would have dearly loved to have said, "So what?" but he didn't feel that Uncle Francisco's temper should be tested this early in the morning, especially when it was already under severe strain from lack of food. He therefore settled for looking politely puzzled.
　　"This just arrived," said Uncle Francisco. He brandished a piece of purple writing paper at Roberto. "A letter. About you."
　　Roberto's confusion increased. Who would be writing to Uncle Francisco about him? Who did he know who sent letters by the postman?
　　Uncle Francisco glared at Roberto, then looked down at the letter and began to read aloud:
　　Dear Mr. and Mrs. Carrizo, We have never been introduced, but I am sure you have heard a great deal from Roberto about my son Diego.
　　As Roberto might have told you, the final of the Quidditch World Cup takes place this Monday night, and my husband, Raul, has just managed to get prime tickets through his connections at the Department of Magical Games and Sports.
　　I do hope you will allow us to take Roberto to the match, as this really is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity; Britain hasn't hosted the cup for thirty years, and tickets are extremely hard to come by. We would of course be glad to have Roberto stay for the remainder of the summer holidays, and to see him safely onto the train back to school.
　　It would be best for Roberto to send us your answer as quickly as possible in the normal way, because the Muggle postman has never delivered to our house, and I am not sure he even knows where it is.
　　Hoping to see Roberto soon, Yours sincerely, Alicia Lopez P.S. I do hope we've put enough stamps on.
　　Uncle Francisco finished reading, put his hand back into his breast pocket, and drew out something else.
　　"Look at this," he growled.
　　He held up the envelope in which Mrs. Lopez's letter had come, and Roberto had to fight down a laugh. Every bit of it was covered in stamps except for a square inch on the front, into which Mrs. Lopez had squeezed the Carrizos' address in minute writing.
　　"She did put enough stamps on, then," said Roberto, trying to sound as though Mrs.
　　Lopez's was a mistake anyone could make. His uncle's eyes flashed.
　　"The postman noticed," he said through gritted teeth. "Very interested to know where this letter came from, he was. That's why he rang the doorbell. Seemed to think it was funny."
　　Roberto didn't say anything. Other people might not understand why Uncle Francisco was making a fuss about too many stamps, but Roberto had lived with the Carrizos too long not to know how touchy they were about anything even slightly out of the ordinary. Their worst fear was that someone would find out that they were connected (however distantly) with people like Mrs. Lopez.
　　Uncle Francisco was still glaring at Roberto, who tried to keep his expression neutral. If he
　　didn't do or say anything stupid, he might just be in for the treat of a lifetime. He waited for Uncle Francisco to say something, but he merely continued to glare. Roberto decided to break the silence.
　　"So - can I go then?" he asked.
　　A slight spasm crossed Uncle Francisco's large purple face. The mustache bristled. Roberto thought he knew what was going on behind the mustache: a furious battle as two of Uncle Francisco's most fundamental instincts came into conflict. Allowing Roberto to go would make Roberto happy, something Uncle Francisco had struggled against for thirteen years. On the other hand, allowing Roberto to disappear to the Lopezs' for the rest of the summer would get rid of him two weeks earlier than anyone could have hoped, and Uncle Francisco hated having Roberto in the house. To give himself thinking time, it seemed, he looked down at Mrs. Lopez's letter again.
　　"Who is this woman?" he said, staring at the signature with distaste.
　　"You've seen her," said Roberto. "She's my friend Diego's mother, she was meeting him off the Hog - off the school train at the end of last term."
　　He had almost said "Hogwarts Express," and that was a sure way to get his uncle's temper up. Nobody ever mentioned the name of Roberto's school aloud in the Carrizo household.
　　Uncle Francisco screwed up his enormous face as though trying to remember something very unpleasant.
　　"Dumpy sort of woman?" he growled finally. "Load of children with red hair?"
　　Roberto frowned. He thought it was a bit rich of Uncle Francisco to call anyone "dumpy," when his own son, Leonardo, had finally achieved what he'd been threatening to do since the age of three, and become wider than he was tall.
　　Uncle Francisco was perusing the letter again.
　　"Quidditch," he muttered under his breath. "Quidditch - what is this rubbish?"
　　Roberto felt a second stab of annoyance.
　　"It's a sport," he said shortly. "Played on broom- "
　　"All right, all right!" said Uncle Francisco loudly. Roberto saw, with some satisfaction, that his uncle looked vaguely panicky. Apparently his nerves couldn't stand the sound of the word "broomsticks" in his living room. He took refuge in perusing the letter again.
　　Roberto saw his lips form the words "send us your answer ... in the normal way." He scowled.
　　"What does she mean, 'the normal way'?" he spat.
　　"Normal for us," said Roberto, and before his uncle could stop him, he added, "you know, owl post. That's what's normal for wizards."
　　Uncle Francisco looked as outraged as if Roberto had just uttered a disgusting swearword.
　　Shaking with anger, he shot a nervous look through the window, as though expecting to see some of the neighbors with their ears pressed against the glass.
　　"How many times do I have to tell you not to mention that unnaturalness under my roof?"
　　he hissed, his face now a rich plum color. "You stand there, in the clothes Beatriz and I have put on your ungrateful back -"
　　"Only after Leonardo finished with them," said Roberto coldly, and indeed, he was dressed in a sweatshirt so large for him that he had had to roll back the sleeves five times so as to be able to use his hands, and which fell past the knees of his extremely baggy jeans.
　　"I will not be spoken to like that!" said Uncle Francisco, trembling with rage.
　　But Roberto wasn't going to stand for this. Gone were the days when he had been forced to take every single one of the Carrizos' stupid rules. He wasn't following Leonardo's diet, and he wasn't going to let Uncle Francisco stop him from going to the Quidditch World Cup, not if he could help it. Roberto took a deep, steadying breath and then said, "Okay, I can't see the World Cup. Can I go now, then? Only I've got a letter to Gustavo I want to finish. You know - my godfather."
　　He had done it, he had said the magic words. Now he watched the purple recede blotchily from Uncle Francisco's face, making it look like badly mixed black currant ice cream.
　　"You're - you're writing to him, are you?" said Uncle Francisco, in a would-be calm voice -but Roberto had seen the pupils of his tiny eyes contract with sudden fear.
　　"Well - yeah," said Roberto, casually. "It's been a while since he heard from me, and, you know, if he doesn't he might start thinking something's wrong."
　　He stopped there to enjoy the effect of these words. He could almost see the cogs working under Uncle Francisco's thick, dark, neatly parted hair. If he tried to stop Roberto writing to Gustavo, Gustavo would think Roberto was being mistreated. If he told Roberto he couldn't go to the Quidditch World Cup, Roberto would write and tell Gustavo, who would know
　　Roberto was being mistreated. There was only one thing for Uncle Francisco to do. Roberto could see the conclusion forming in his uncle's mind as though the great mustached face were transparent. Roberto tried not to smile, to keep his own face as blank as possible.
　　And then -"
　　Well, all right then. You can go to this ruddy ... this stupid ... this World Cup thing. You write and tell these - these Lopezs they're to pick you up, mind. I haven't got time to go dropping you off all over the country. And you can spend the rest of the summer there. And you can tell your - your godfather ... tell him ... tell him you're going."
　　"Okay then," said Roberto brightly.
　　He turned and walked toward the living room door, fighting the urge to jump into the air and whoop. He was going ... he was going to the Lopezs', he was going to watch the Quidditch World Cup!
　　Outside in the hall he nearly ran into Leonardo, who had been lurking behind the door, clearly hoping to overhear Roberto being told off. He looked shocked to see the broad grin on Roberto's face.
　　"That was an excellent breakfast, wasn't it?" said Roberto. "I feel really full, don't you?"
　　Laughing at the astonished look on Leonardo's face, Roberto took the stairs three at a time, and hurled himself back into his bedroom.
　　The first thing he saw was that Hedwig was back. She was sitting in her cage, staring at Roberto with her enormous amber eyes, and clicking her beak in the way that meant she was annoyed about something. Exactly what was annoying her became apparent almost at once.
　　"OUCH!" said Roberto as what appeared to be a small, gray, feathery tennis ball collided with the side of his head. Roberto massaged the spot furiously, looking up to see what had hit him, and saw a minute owl, small enough to fit into the palm of his hand, whizzing excitedly around the room like a loose firework. Roberto then realized that the owl had dropped a letter at his feet. Roberto bent down, recognized Diego's handwriting, then tore open the envelope. Inside was a hastily scribbled note.
　　Roberto - DAD GOT THE TICKETS - Ireland versus Bulgaria, Monday night. Mum's writing to the Muggles to ask you to stay. They might already have the letter, I don't know how fast Muggle post is. Thought I'd send this with Pig anyway.
　　Roberto stared at the word "Pig," then looked up at the tiny owl now zooming around the light fixture on the ceiling. He had never seen anything that looked less like a pig.
　　Maybe he couldn't read Diego's writing. He went back to the letter:
　　We're coming for you whether the Muggles like it or not, you can't miss the World Cup, only Mum and Dad reckon it's better if we pretend to ask their permission first. If they say yes, send Pig back with your answer pronto, and we'll come and get you at five o'clock on Sunday. If they say no, send Pig back pronto and we'll come and get you at five o'clock on Sunday anyway.
　　Carolina's arriving this afternoon. Miguel's started work - the Department of International Magical Cooperation. Don't mention anything about Abroad while you're here unless you want the pants bored off you.
　　See you soon - Diego "Calm down!" Roberto said as the small owl flew low over his head, twittering madly with what Roberto could only assume was pride at having delivered the letter to the right person. "Come here, I need you to take my answer back!"
　　The owl fluttered down on top of Hedwig's cage. Hedwig looked coldly up at it, as though daring it to try and come any closer.
　　Roberto seized his eagle-feather quill once more, grabbed a fresh piece of parchment, and wrote:
　　Diego, it's all okay, the Muggles say I can come. See you five o'clock tomorrow. Can't wait. Roberto He folded this note up very small, and with immense difficulty, tied it to the tiny owl's leg as it hopped on the spot with excitement. The moment the note was secure, the owl
　　was off again; it zoomed out of the window and out of sight.
　　Roberto turned to Hedwig.
　　"Feeling up to a long journey?" he asked her.
　　Hedwig hooted in a dignified sort of a way.
　　"Can you take this to Gustavo for me?" he said, picking up his letter. "Hang on ... I just want to finish it."
　　He unfolded the parchment and hastily added a postscript.
　　If you want to contact me, I'll be at my friend Diego Lopez's for the rest of the summer.
　　His dad's got us tickets for the Quidditch World Cup!
　　The letter finished, he tied it to Hedwig's leg; she kept unusually still, as though determined to show him how a real post owl should behave.
　　"I'll be at Diego's when you get back, all right?" Roberto told her.
　　She nipped his finger affectionately, then, with a soft swooshing noise, spread her enormous wings and soared out of the open window.
　　Roberto watched her out of sight, then crawled under his bed, wrenched up the loose floorboard, and pulled out a large chunk of birthday cake. He sat there on the floor eating it, savoring the happiness that was flooding through him. He had cake, and Leonardo had nothing but grapefruit; it was a bright summer's day, he would be leaving Privet Drive tomorrow, his scar felt perfectly normal again, and he was going to watch the Quidditch World Cup. It was hard, just now, to feel worried about anything - even Lord Salvador.
　　CHAPTER FOUR - BACK TO THE BURROW
　　By twelve o'clock the next day, Roberto's school trunk was packed with his school things and all his most prized possessions - the Invisibility Cloak he had inherited from his father, the broomstick he had gotten from Gustavo, the enchanted map of Hogwarts he had been given by Pablo and Luis Lopez last year. He had emptied his hiding place under the loose floorboard of all food, double-checked every nook and cranny of his bedroom for forgotten spellbooks or quills, and taken down the chart on the wall counting down the days to September the first, on which he liked to cross off the days remaining until his return to Hogwarts.
　　The atmosphere inside number four, Privet Drive was extremely tense. The imminent arrival at their house of an assortment of wizards was making the Carrizos uptight and irritable.
　　Uncle Francisco had looked downright alarmed when Roberto informed him that the Lopezs would be arriving at five o'clock the very next day.
　　"I hope you told them to dress properly, these people," he snarled at once. "I've seen the sort of stuff your lot wear. They'd better have the decency to put on normal clothes, that's all."
　　Roberto felt a slight sense of foreboding. He had rarely seen Mr. or Mrs. Lopez wearing anything that the Carrizos would call "normal." Their children might don Muggle clothing during the holidays, but Mr. and Mrs. Lopez usually wore long robes in varying states of shabbiness. Roberto wasn't bothered about what the neighbors would think, but he was anxious about how rude the Carrizos might be to the Lopezs if they turned up looking like their worst idea of wizards.
　　Uncle Francisco had put on his best suit. To some people, this might have looked like a gesture of welcome, but Roberto knew it was because Uncle Francisco wanted to look impressive and intimidating. Leonardo, on the other hand, looked somehow diminished. This was not because the diet was at last taking effect, but due to fright. Leonardo had emerged from his last encounter with a fully grown wizard with a curly pig's tail poking out of the seat of his trousers, and Aunt Beatriz and Uncle Francisco had had to pay for its removal at a private hospital in London. It wasn't altogether surprising, therefore, that Leonardo kept running his hand nervously over his backside, and walking sideways from room to room, so as not to present the same target to the enemy.
　　Lunch was an almost silent meal. Leonardo didn't even protest at the food (cottage cheese and grated celery). Aunt Beatriz wasn't, eating anything at all. Her arms were folded, her lips were pursed, and she seemed to be chewing her tongue, as though biting back the furious diatribe she longed to throw at Roberto.
　　"They'll be driving, of course?" Uncle Francisco barked across the table.
　　"Er," said Roberto.
　　He hadn't thought of that. How were the Lopezs going to pick him up? They didn't have a car anymore; the old Ford Anglia they had once owned was currently running wild in the Forbidden Forest at Hogwarts. But Mr. Lopez had borrowed a Ministry of Magic car last year; possibly he would do the same today?
　　"I think so," said Roberto.
　　Uncle Francisco snorted into his mustache. Normally, Uncle Francisco would have asked what car Mr. Lopez drove; he tended to judge other men by how big and expensive their cars were.
　　But Roberto doubted whether Uncle Francisco would have taken to Mr. Lopez even if he drove a Ferrari.
　　Roberto spent most of the afternoon in his bedroom; he couldn't stand watching Aunt Beatriz peer out through the net curtains every few seconds, as though there had been a warning about an escaped rhinoceros. Finally, at a quarter to five, Roberto went back downstairs and into the living room.
　　Aunt Beatriz was compulsively straightening cushions. Uncle Francisco was pretending to read the paper, but his tiny eyes were not moving, and Roberto was sure he was really listening with all his might for the sound of an approaching car. Leonardo was crammed into an armchair, his porky hands beneath him, clamped firmly around his bottom. Roberto couldn't take the tension; he left the room and went and sat on the stairs in the hall, his eyes on his watch and his heart pumping fast from excitement and nerves.
　　But five o'clock came and then went. Uncle Francisco, perspiring slightly in his suit, opened the front door, peered up and down the street, then withdrew his head quickly.
　　"They're late!" he snarled at Roberto.
　　I know," said Roberto. "Maybe - er - the traffic's bad, or something."
　　Ten past five ... then a quarter past five ... Roberto was starting to feel anxious himself now. At half past, he heard Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz conversing in terse mutters in the living room.
　　"No consideration at all."
　　"We might've had an engagement."
　　"Maybe they think they'll get invited to dinner if they're late."
　　"Well, they most certainly won't be," said Uncle Francisco, and Roberto heard him stand up and start pacing the living room. "They'll take the boy and go, there'll be no hanging around. That's if they're coming at all. Probably mistaken the day. I daresay their kind don't set much store by punctuality. Either that or they drive some tin-pot car that's broken d- AAAAAAAARRRRRGH!"
　　Roberto jumped up. From the other side of the living room door came the sounds of the three Carrizos scrambling, panic-stricken, across the room. Next moment Leonardo came flying into the hall, looking terrified.
　　"What happened?" said Roberto. "What's the matter?"
　　But Leonardo didn't seem able to speak. Hands still clamped over his buttocks, he waddled as fast as he could into the kitchen. Roberto hurried into the living room.
　　Loud bangings and scrapings were coming from behind the Carrizos' boarded-up fireplace, which had a fake coal fire plugged in front of it.
　　"What is it?" gasped Aunt Beatriz, who had backed into the wall and was staring, terrified, toward the fire. "What is it, Francisco?"
　　But they were left in doubt barely a second longer. Voices could be heard from inside the blocked fireplace.
　　"Ouch! Pablo, no - go back, go back, there's been some kind of mistake - tell Luis not to - OUCH! Luis, no, there's no room, go back quickly and tell Diego-"
　　"Maybe Roberto can hear us, Dad - maybe he'll be able to let us out-"
　　There was a loud hammering of fists on the boards behind the electric fire.
　　"Roberto? Roberto, can you hear us?"
　　The Carrizos rounded on Roberto like a pair of angry wolverines.
　　"What is this?" growled Uncle Francisco. "What's going on?"
　　"They - they've tried to get here by Floo powder," said Roberto, fighting a mad desire to laugh. "They can travel by fire - only you've blocked the fireplace - hang on -"
　　He approached the fireplace and called through the boards.
　　"Mr. Lopez? Can you hear me?"
　　The hammering stopped. Somebody inside the chimney piece said, "Shh!"
　　"Mr. Lopez, it's Roberto ... the fireplace has been blocked up. You won't be able to get through there."
　　"Damn!" said Mr. Lopez's voice. "What on earth did they want to block up the fireplace for?"
　　"They've got an electric fire," Roberto explained.
　　"Really?" said Mr. Lopez's voice excitedly. "Eclectic, you say? With a plug?
　　Gracious, I must see that.... Let's think ... ouch, Diego!"
　　Diego's voice now joined the others'.
　　"What are we doing here? Has something gone wrong?"
　　"Oh no, Diego," came Pablo's voice, very sarcastically. "No, this is exactly where we wanted to end up."
　　"Yeah, we're having the time of our lives here," said Luis, whose voice sounded muffled, as though he was squashed against the wall.
　　"Boys, boys. . ." said Mr. Lopez vaguely. "I'm trying to think what to do.... Yes ...
　　only way. . . Stand back, Roberto."
　　Roberto retreated to the sofa. Uncle Francisco, however, moved forward.
　　"Wait a moment!" he bellowed at the fire. "What exactly are you going to -"
　　BANG.
　　The electric fire shot across the room as the boarded-up fireplace burst outward, expelling Mr. Lopez, Pablo, Luis, and Diego in a cloud of rubble and loose chippings.
　　Aunt Beatriz shrieked and fell backward over the coffee table; Uncle Francisco caught her before she hit the floor, and gaped, speechless, at the Lopezs, all of whom had bright red hair, including Pablo and Luis, who were identical to the last freckle.
　　"That's better," panted Mr. Lopez, brushing dust from his long green robes and straightening his glasses. "Ah - you must be Roberto's aunt and uncle!"
　　Tall, thin, and balding, he moved toward Uncle Francisco, his hand outstretched, but Uncle Francisco backed away several paces, dragging Aunt Beatriz. Words utterly failed Uncle Francisco. His best suit was covered in white dust, which had settled in his hair and mustache and made him look as though he had just aged thirty years.
　　"Er - yes - sorry about that," said Mr. Lopez, lowering his hand and looking over his shoulder at the blasted fireplace. "It's all my fault. It just didn't occur to me that we wouldn't be able to get out at the other end. I had your fireplace connected to the Floo Network, you see - just for an afternoon, you know, so we could get Roberto. Muggle fireplaces aren't supposed to be connected, strictly speaking - but I've got a useful contact at the Floo Regulation Panel and he fixed it for me. I can put it right in a jiffy, though, don't worry. I'll light a fire to send the boys back, and then I can repair your fireplace before I Disapparate."
　　Roberto was ready to bet that the Carrizos hadn't understood a single word of this. They were still gaping at Mr. Lopez, thunderstruck. Aunt Beatriz staggered upright again and hid behind Uncle Francisco.
　　"Hello, Roberto!" said Mr. Lopez brightly. "Got your trunk ready?"
　　"It's upstairs," said Roberto, grinning back.
　　"We'll get it," said Pablo at once. Winking at Roberto, he and Luis left the room. They knew where Roberto's bedroom was, having once rescued him from it in the dead of night.
　　Roberto suspected that Pablo and Luis were hoping for a glimpse of Leonardo; they had heard a lot about him from Roberto.
　　"Well," said Mr. Lopez, swinging his arms slightly, while he tried to find words to break the very nasty silence. "Very - erm - very nice place you've got here."
　　As the usually spotless living room was now covered in dust and bits of brick, this remark didn't go down too well with the Carrizos. Uncle Francisco's face purpled once more, and Aunt Beatriz started chewing her tongue again. However, they seemed too scared to actually say anything.
　　Mr. Lopez was looking around. He loved everything to do with Muggles. Roberto could see him itching to go and examine the television and the video recorder.
　　"They run off eckeltricity, do they?" he said knowledgeably. "Ah yes, I can see the plugs. I collect plugs," he added to Uncle Francisco. "And batteries. Got a very large collection of batteries. My wife thinks I'm mad, but there you are."
　　Uncle Francisco clearly thought Mr. Lopez was mad too. He moved ever so slightly to the right, screening Aunt Beatriz from view, as though he thought Mr. Lopez might suddenly run at them and attack.
　　Leonardo suddenly reappeared in the room. Roberto could hear the clunk of his trunk on the stairs, and knew that the sounds had scared Leonardo out of the kitchen. Leonardo edged along the wall, gazing at Mr. Lopez with terrified eyes, and attempted to conceal
　　himself behind his mother and father. Unfortunately, Uncle Francisco's bulk, while sufficient to hide bony Aunt Beatriz, was nowhere near enough to conceal Leonardo.
　　"Ah, this is your cousin, is it, Roberto?" said Mr. Lopez, taking another brave stab at making conversation.
　　"Yep," said Roberto, "that's Leonardo."
　　He and Diego exchanged glances and then quickly looked away from each other; the temptation to burst out laughing was almost overwhelming. Leonardo was still clutching his bottom as though afraid it might fall off. Mr. Lopez, however, seemed genuinely concerned at Leonardo's peculiar behavior. Indeed, from the tone of his voice when he next spoke, Roberto was quite sure that Mr. Lopez thought Leonardo was quite as mad as the Carrizos thought he was, except that Mr. Lopez felt sympathy rather than fear.
　　"Having a good holiday, Leonardo?" he said kindly.
　　Leonardo whimpered. Roberto saw his hands tighten still harder over his massive backside.
　　Pablo and Luis came back into the room carrying Roberto's school trunk. They glanced around as they entered and spotted Leonardo. Their faces cracked into identical evil grins.
　　"Ah, right," said Mr. Lopez. "Better get cracking then."
　　He pushed up the sleeves of his robes and took out his wand. Roberto saw the Carrizos draw back against the wall as one.
　　"Incendio!" said Mr. Lopez, pointing his wand at the hole in the wall behind him.
　　Flames rose at once in the fireplace, crackling merrily as though they had been burning for hours. Mr. Lopez took a small drawstring bag from his pocket, untied it, took a pinch of the powder inside, and threw it onto the flames, which turned emerald green and roared higher than ever.
　　"Off you go then, Pablo," said Mr. Lopez.
　　"Coming," said Pablo. "Oh no - hang on -"
　　A bag of sweets had spilled out of Pablo's pocket and the contents were now rolling in every direction - big, fat toffees in brightly colored wrappers.
　　Pablo scrambled around, cramming them back into his pocket, then gave the Carrizos a cheery wave, stepped forward, and walked right into the fire, saying "the Burrow!" Aunt Beatriz gave a little shuddering gasp. There was a whooshing sound, and Pablo vanished.
　　"Right then, Luis," said Mr. Lopez, "you and the trunk."
　　Roberto helped Luis carry the trunk forward into the flames and turn it onto its end so that he could hold it better. Then, with a second whoosh, Luis had cried "the Burrow!"
　　and vanished too.
　　"Diego, you next," said Mr. Lopez.
　　"See you," said Diego brightly to the Carrizos. He grinned broadly at Roberto, then stepped into the fire, shouted "the Burrow!" and disappeared.
　　Now Roberto and Mr. Lopez alone remained.
　　"Well . . . 'bye then," Roberto said to the Carrizos.
　　They didn't say anything at all. Roberto moved toward the fire, but just as he reached the edge of the hearth, Mr. Lopez put out a hand and held him back. He was looking at the Carrizos in amazement.
　　"Roberto said good-bye to you," he said. "Didn't you hear him?"
　　"It doesn't matter," Roberto muttered to Mr. Lopez. "Honestly, I don't care."
　　Mr. Lopez did not remove his hand from Roberto's shoulder.
　　"You aren't going to see your nephew till next summer," he said to Uncle Francisco in mild indignation. "Surely you're going to say good-bye?"
　　Uncle Francisco's face worked furiously. The idea of being taught consideration by a man who had just blasted away half his living room wall seemed to be causing him intense suffering. But Mr. Lopez's wand was still in his hand, and Uncle Francisco's tiny eyes darted to it once, before he said, very resentfully, "Good-bye, then."
　　"See you," said Roberto, putting one foot forward into the green flames, which felt pleasantly like warm breath. At that moment, however, a horrible gagging sound erupted behind him, and Aunt Beatriz started to scream.
　　Roberto wheeled around. Leonardo was no longer standing behind his parents. He was kneeling beside the coffee table, and he was gagging and sputtering on a foot-long, purple, slimy thing that was protruding from his mouth. One bewildered second later, Roberto realized that the foot-long thing was Leonardo's tongue - and that a brightly colored toffee wrapper lay on the floor before him.
　　Aunt Beatriz hurled herself onto the ground beside Leonardo, seized the end of his swollen
　　tongue, and attempted to wrench it out of his mouth; unsurprisingly, Leonardo yelled and sputtered worse than ever, trying to fight her off. Uncle Francisco was bellowing and waving his arms around, and Mr. Lopez had to shout to make himself heard.
　　"Not to worry, I can sort him out!" he yelled, advancing on Leonardo with his wand outstretched, but Aunt Beatriz screamed worse than ever and threw herself on top of Leonardo, shielding him from Mr. Lopez.
　　"No, really!" said Mr. Lopez desperately. "It's a simple process it was the toffee -my son Pablo - real practical joker - but it's only an Engorgement Charm - at least, I think it is - please, I can correct it -"
　　But far from being reassured, the Carrizos became more panic- stricken; Aunt Beatriz was sobbing hysterically, tugging Leonardo's tongue as though determined to rip it out; Leonardo appeared to be suffocating under the combined pressure of his mother and his tongue; and Uncle Francisco, who had lost control completely, seized a china figure from on top of the sideboard and threw it very hard at Mr. Lopez, who ducked, causing the ornament to shatter in the blasted fireplace.
　　"Now really!" said Mr. Lopez angrily, brandishing his wand. "I'm trying to help!"
　　Bellowing like a wounded hippo, Uncle Francisco snatched up another ornament.
　　"Roberto, go! Just go!" Mr. Lopez shouted, his wand on Uncle Francisco. "I'll sort this out!"
　　Roberto didn't want to miss the fun, but Uncle Francisco's second ornament narrowly missed his left ear, and on balance he thought it best to leave the situation to Mr. Lopez. He stepped into the fire, looking over his shoulder as he said "the Burrow!" His last fleeting glimpse of the living room was of Mr. Lopez blasting a third ornament out of Uncle Francisco's hand with his wand, Aunt Beatriz screaming and lying on top of Leonardo, and Leonardo's tongue lolling around like a great slimy python. But next moment Roberto had begun to spin very fast, and the Carrizos' living room was whipped out of sight in a rush of emerald-green flames.
　　CHAPTER FIVE - LOPEZS' WIZARD WHEEZES
　　Roberto spun faster and faster, elbows tucked tightly to his sides, blurred fireplaces flashing past him, until he started to feel sick and closed his eyes. Then, when at last he felt himself slowing down, he threw out his hands and came to a halt in time to prevent himself from falling face forward out of the Lopezs' kitchen fire.
　　"Did he eat it?" said Pablo excitedly, holding out a hand to pull Roberto to his fee "Yeah," said Roberto, straightening up. "What was it?"
　　"Ton-Tongue Toffee," said Pablo brightly. "Luis and I invented them, and we've been looking for someone to test them on all summer. . . ."
　　The tiny kitchen exploded with laughter; Roberto looked around and saw that Diego and Luis were sitting at the scrubbed wooden table with two red-haired people Roberto had never seen before, though he knew immediately who they must be: Bill and Charlie, the two eldest Lopez brothers.
　　"How're you doing, Roberto?" said the nearer of the two, grinning at him and holding out a large hand, which Roberto shook, feeling calluses and blisters under his fingers. This had to be Charlie, who worked with dragons in Romania. Charlie was built like the twins, shorter and stockier than Miguel and Diego, who were both long and lanky. He had a broad, good-natured face, which was weather-beaten and so freckly that he looked almost tanned; his arms were muscular, and one of them had a large, shiny burn on it.
　　Bill got to his feet, smiling, and also shook Roberto's hand. Bill came as something of a surprise. Roberto knew that he worked for the wizarding bank, Gringotts, and that Bill had been Head Boy at Hogwarts; Roberto had always imagined Bill to be an older version of Miguel: fussy about rule-breaking and fond of bossing everyone around. However, Bill was - there was no other word for it - cool. He was tall, with long hair that he had tied back in a ponytail. He was wearing an earring with what looked like a fang dangling from it. Bill's clothes would not have looked out of place at a rock concert, except that Roberto recognized his boots to be made, not of leather, but of dragon hide.
　　Before any of them could say anything else, there was a faint popping noise, and Mr.
　　Lopez appeared out of thin air at Luis's shoulder. He was looking angrier than Roberto had ever seen him.
　　"That wasn't funny Pablo!" he shouted. "What on earth did you give that Muggle boy?"
　　"I didn't give him anything," said Pablo, with another evil grin. I just dropped it....
　　It was his fault he went and ate it, I never told him to."
　　"You dropped it on purpose!" roared Mr. Lopez. "You knew he'd eat it, you knew he was on a diet -"
　　"How big did his tongue get?" Luis asked eagerly.
　　"It was four feet long before his parents would let me shrink it!"
　　Roberto and the Lopezs roared with laughter again.
　　"It isn't funny!" Mr. Lopez shouted. "That sort of behavior seriously undermines wizard-Muggle relations! I spend half my life campaigning against the mistreatment of Muggles, and my own sons "We didn't give it to him because he's a Muggle!" said Pablo indignantly.
　　"No, we gave it to him because he's a great bullying git," said Luis. "Isn't he, Roberto?"
　　"Yeah, he is, Mr. Lopez," said Roberto earnestly.
　　"That's not the point!" raged Mr. Lopez. "You wait until I tell your mother -"
　　"Tell me what?" said a voice behind them.
　　Mrs. Lopez had just entered the kitchen. She was a short, plump woman with a very kind face, though her eyes were presently narrowed with suspicion.
　　"Oh hello, Roberto, dear," she said, spotting him and smiling. Then her eyes snapped back to her husband. "Tell me what, Raul?"
　　Mr. Lopez hesitated. Roberto could tell that, however angry he was with Pablo and Luis, he hadn't really intended to tell Mrs. Lopez what had happened. There was a silence, while Mr. Lopez eyed his wife nervously. Then two girls appeared in the kitchen doorway behind Mrs. Lopez.
