　　"Oh no, really?" said Carolina, shooting a repressive look at Diego, who, staring at Villalba's odd hairstyle, had just opened his mouth to say something about it.
　　"Yeah," said Villalba sadly. "S' okay, though, I've got 'em in separate boxes now. Still got abou' twenty."
　　"Well, that's lucky," said Diego. Villalba missed the sarcasm.
　　Villalba's cabin comprised a single room, in one corner of which was a gigantic bed covered in a patchwork quilt. A similarly enormous wooden table and chairs stood in front of the fire beneath the quantity of cured hams and dead birds hanging from the ceiling. They sat down at the table while Villalba started to make tea, and were soon immersed in yet more discussion of the Triwizard Tournament. Villalba seemed quite as excited about it as they were.
　　"You wait," he said, grinning. "You jus' wait. Yer going ter see some stuff yeh've never seen before. Firs' task. . . ah, but I'm not supposed ter say."
　　"Go on, Villalba!" Roberto, Diego, and Carolina urged him, but he just shook his head, grinning.
　　"I don' want ter spoil it fer yeh," said Villalba. "But it's gonna be spectacular, I'll tell yeh that. Them champions're going ter have their work cut out. Never thought I'd live ter see the Triwizard Tournament played again!"
　　They ended up having lunch with Villalba, though they didn't eat much - Villalba had made what he said was a beef casserole, but after Carolina unearthed a large talon in hers, she, Roberto, and Diego rather lost their appetites. However, they enjoyed themselves trying to make Villalba tell them what the tasks in the tournament were going to be, speculating which of the entrants were likely to be selected as champions, and wondering whether Pablo and Luis were beardless yet.
　　A light rain had started to fall by midafternoon; it was very cozy sitting by the fire, listening to the gentle patter of the drops on the window, watching Villalba darning his socks and arguing with Carolina about house-elves - for he flatly refused to join S.P.E.W. when she showed him her badges.
　　"It'd be doin' 'em an unkindness, Carolina," he said gravely, threading a massive bone needle with thick yellow yarn. "It's in their nature ter look after humans, that's what they like, see? Yeh'd be makin' 'em unhappy ter take away their work, an' insutin' 'em if yeh tried ter pay 'em."
　　"But Roberto set Dobby free, and he was over the moon about it!" said Carolina. "And we heard he's asking for wages now!"
　　"Yeah, well, yeh get weirdos in every breed. I'm not sayin' there isn't the odd elf who'd take freedom, but yeh'll never persuade most of 'em ter do it - no, nothin' doin', Carolina."
　　Carolina looked very cross indeed and stuffed her box of badges back into her cloak pocket.
　　By half past five it was growing dark, and Diego, Roberto, and Carolina decided it was time to get back up to the castle for the Halloween feast - and, more important, the announcement of the school champions.
　　"I'll come with yeh," said Villalba, putting away his darning. "Jus' give us a sec."
　　Villalba got up, went across to the chest of drawers beside his bed, and began searching for something inside it. They didn't pay too much attention until a truly horrible smell reached their nostrils. Coughing, Diego said, "Villalba, what's that?"
　　"Eh?" said Villalba, turning around with a large bottle in his hand. "Don' yeh like it?"
　　"Is that aftershave?" said Carolina in a slightly choked voice.
　　"Er - eau de cologne," Villalba muttered. He was blushing.
　　"Maybe it's a bit much," he said gruffly. "I'll go take it off, hang on..."
　　He stumped out of the cabin, and they saw him washing himself vigorously in the water barrel outside the window.
　　"Eau de cologne?" said Carolina in amazement. "Villalba?"
　　"And what's with the hair and the suit?" said Roberto in an undertone.
　　"Look!" said Diego suddenly, pointing out of the window. Villalba had just straightened up and turned 'round. If he had been blushing before, it was nothing to what he was doing now. Getting to their feet very cautiously, so that Villalba wouldn't spot them, Roberto, Diego, and Carolina peered through the window and saw that Madame Maxime and the Beauxbatons students had just emerged from their carriage, clearly about to set off for the feast too. They couldn't hear what Villalba was saying, but he was talking to Madame
　　Maxime with a rapt, misty-eyed expression Roberto had only ever seen him wear once before -when he had been looking at the baby dragon, Norbert.
　　"He's going up to the castle with her!" said Carolina indignantly. "I thought he was waiting for us!"
　　Without so much as a backward glance at his cabin, Villalba was trudging off up the grounds with Madame Maxime, the Beaux-batons students following in their wake, jogging to keep up with their enormous strides.
　　"He fancies her!" said Diego incredulously. "Well, if they end up having children, they'll be setting a world record - bet any baby of theirs would weigh about a ton."
　　They let themselves out of the cabin and shut the door behind them. It was surprisingly dark outside. Drawing their cloaks more closely around themselves, they set off up the sloping lawns.
　　"Ooh it's them, look!" Carolina whispered.
　　The Durmstrang party was walking up toward the castle from the lake. Viktor Krum was walking side by side with Morales, and the other Durmstrang students were straggling along behind them. Diego watched Krum excitedly, but Krum did not look around as he reached the front doors a little ahead of Carolina, Diego, and Roberto and proceeded through them.
　　When they entered the candlelit Great Hall it was almost full. The Goblet of Fire had been moved; it was now standing in front of Dominguez's empty chair at the teachers' table. Pablo and Luis - clean-shaven again - seemed to have taken their disappointment fairly well.
　　"Hope it's Angelina," said Pablo as Roberto, Diego, and Carolina sat down.
　　"So do I!" said Carolina breathlessly. "Well, we'll soon know!"
　　The Halloween feast seemed to take much longer than usual. Perhaps because it was their second feast in two days, Roberto didn't seem to fancy the extravagantly prepared food as much as he would have normally. Like everyone else in the Hall, judging by the constantly craning necks, the impatient expressions on every face, the fidgeting, and the standing up to see whether Dominguez had finished eating yet, Roberto simply wanted the plates to clear, and to hear who had been selected as champions.
　　At long last, the golden plates returned to their original spotless state; there was a sharp upswing in the level of noise within the Hall, which died away almost instantly as Dominguez got to his feet. On either side of him, Professor Morales and Madame Maxime looked as tense and expectant as anyone. Ludo Bagman was beaming and winking at various students. Mr. Crouch, however, looked quite uninterested, almost bored.
　　"Well, the goblet is almost ready to make its decision," said Dominguez. "I estimate that it requires one more minute. Now, when the champions' names are called, I would ask them please to come up to the top of the Hall, walk along the staff table, and go through into the next chamber" - he indicated the door behind the staff table - "where they will be receiving their first instructions."
　　He took out his wand and gave a great sweeping wave with it; at once, all the candles except those inside the carved pumpkins were extinguished, plunging them into a state of semidarkness. The Goblet of Fire now shone more brightly than anything in the whole Hall, the sparkling bright, bluey-whiteness of the flames almost painful on the eyes.
　　Everyone watched, waiting. . . . A few people kept checking their watches. . .
　　"Any second," Lee Jordan whispered, two seats away from Roberto.
　　The flames inside the goblet turned suddenly red again. Sparks began to fly from it.
　　Next moment, a tongue of flame shot into the air, a charred piece of parchment fluttered out of it - the whole room gasped.
　　Dominguez caught the piece of parchment and held it at arm's length, so that he could read it by the light of the flames, which had turned back to blue-white.
　　"The champion for Durmstrang," he read, in a strong, clear voice, "will be Viktor Krum."
　　"No surprises there!" yelled Diego as a storm of applause and cheering swept the Hall.
　　Roberto saw Viktor Krum rise from the Slytherin table and slouch up toward Dominguez; he turned right, walked along the staff table, and disappeared through the door into the next chamber.
　　"Bravo, Viktor!" boomed Morales, so loudly that everyone could hear him, even over all the applause. "Knew you had it in you!"
　　The clapping and chatting died down. Now everyone's attention was focused again on the goblet, which, seconds later, turned red once more. A second piece of parchment shot out of it, propelled by the flames.
　　"The champion for Beauxbatons," said Dominguez, "is Camila Saenz!"
　　"It's her, Diego!" Roberto shouted as the girl who so resembled a veela got gracefully to her feet, shook back her sheet of silvery blonde hair, and swept up between the Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff tables.
　　"Oh look, they're all disappointed," Carolina said over the noise, nodding toward the remainder of the Beauxbatons party. "Disappointed" was a bit of an understatement, Roberto thought. Two of the girls who had not been selected had dissolved into tears and were sobbing with their heads on their arms.
　　When Camila Saenz too had vanished into the side chamber, silence fell again, but this time it was a silence so stiff with excitement you could almost taste it. The Hogwarts champion next...
　　And the Goblet of Fire turned red once more; sparks showered out of it; the tongue of flame shot high into the air, and from its tip Dominguez pulled the third piece of parchment.
　　"The Hogwarts champion," he called, "is Nicolas Ortega!"
　　"No! " said Diego loudly, but nobody heard him except Roberto; the uproar from the next table was too great. Every single Hufflepuff had jumped to his or her feet, screaming and stamping, as Nicolas made his way past them, grinning broadly, and headed off toward the chamber behind the teachers' table. Indeed, the applause for Nicolas went on so long that it was some time before Dominguez could make himself heard again.
　　"Excellent!" Dominguez called happily as at last the tumult died down. "Well, we now have our three champions. I am sure I can count upon all of you, including the remaining students from Beauxbatons and Durmstrang, to give your champions every ounce of support you can muster. By cheering your champion on, you will contribute in a very real --"
　　But Dominguez suddenly stopped speaking, and it was apparent to everybody what had distracted him.
　　The fire in the goblet had just turned red again. Sparks were flying out of it. A long flame shot suddenly into the air, and borne upon it was another piece of parchment.
　　Automatically, it seemed, Dominguez reached out a long hand and seized the parchment. He held it out and stared at the name written upon it. There was a long pause, during which Dominguez stared at the slip in his hands, and everyone in the room stared at Dominguez. And then Dominguez cleared his throat and read out - "Roberto Gonzales."
　　CHAPTER SEVENTEEN - THE FOUR CHAMPIONS
　　Roberto sat there, aware that every head in the Great Hall had turned to look at him. He was stunned. He felt numb. He was surely dreaming. He had not heard correctly.
　　There was no applause. A buzzing, as though of angry bees, was starting to fill the Hall; some students were standing up to get a better look at Roberto as he sat, frozen, in his seat.
　　Up at the top table, Professor Romero had got to her feet and swept past Ludo Bagman and Professor Morales to whisper urgently to Professor Dominguez, who bent his ear toward her, frowning slightly.
　　Roberto turned to Diego and Carolina; beyond them, he saw the long Gryffindor table all watching him, openmouthed.
　　"I didn't put my name in," Roberto said blankly. "You know I didn't."
　　Both of them stared just as blankly back.
　　At the top table, Professor Dominguez had straightened up, nodding to Professor Romero.
　　"Roberto Gonzales!" he called again. "Roberto! Up here, if you please!"
　　"Go on," Carolina whispered, giving Roberto a slight push.
　　Roberto got to his feet, trod on the hem of his robes, and stumbled slightly. He set off up the gap between the Gryffindor and Hufflepuff tables. It felt like an immensely long walk; the top table didn't seem to be getting any nearer at all, and he could feel hundreds and hundreds of eyes upon him, as though each were a searchlight. The buzzing grew louder and louder. After what seemed like an hour, he was right in front of Dominguez, feeling the stares of all the teachers upon him.
　　"Well.. . through the door, Roberto," said Dominguez. He wasn't smiling.
　　Roberto moved off along the teachers' table. Villalba was seated right at
　　the end. He did not wink at Roberto, or wave, or give any of his usual signs of greeting.
　　He looked completely astonished and stared at Roberto as he passed like everyone else.
　　Roberto went through the door out of the Great Hall and found himself in a smaller room, lined with paintings of witches and wizards. A handsome fire was roaring in the fireplace opposite him.
　　The faces in the portraits turned to look at him as he entered. He saw a wizened witch flit out of the frame of her picture and into the one next to it, which contained a wizard with a walrus mustache. The wizened witch started whispering in his ear.
　　Viktor Krum, Nicolas Ortega, and Camila Saenz were grouped around the fire. They looked strangely impressive, silhouetted against the flames. Krum, hunched-up and brooding, was leaning against the mantelpiece, slightly apart from the other two. Nicolas was standing with his hands behind his back, staring into the fire. Camila Saenz looked around when Roberto walked in and threw back her sheet of long, silvery hair.
　　"What is it?" she said. "Do zey want us back in ze Hall?"
　　She thought he had come to deliver a message. Roberto didn't know how to explain what had just happened. He just stood there, looking at the three champions. It struck him how very tall all of them were.
　　There was a sound of scurrying feet behind him, and Ludo Bagman entered the room. He took Roberto by the arm and led him forward.
　　"Extraordinary!" he muttered, squeezing Roberto's arm. "Absolutely extraordinary!
　　Gentlemen. . . lady," he added, approaching the fireside and addressing the other three.
　　"May I introduce - incredible though it may seem - the fourth Triwizard champion?"
　　Viktor Krum straightened up. His surly face darkened as he surveyed Roberto. Nicolas looked nonplussed. He looked from Bagman to Roberto and back again as though sure he must have misheard what Bagman had said. Camila Saenz, however, tossed her hair, smiling, and said, "Oh, vairy funny joke, Meester Bagman."
　　"Joke?" Bagman repeated, bewildered. "No, no, not at all! Roberto's name just came out of the Goblet of Fire!"
　　Krum's thick eyebrows contracted slightly. Nicolas was still looking politely bewildered.
　　Camila frowned.
　　"But evidently zair 'as been a mistake," she said contemptuously to Bagman. "E cannot compete. 'E is too young."
　　"Well. . . it is amazing," said Bagman, rubbing his smooth chin and smiling down at Roberto. "But, as you know, the age restriction was only imposed this year as an extra safety measure. And as his name's come out of the goblet.. . I mean, I don't think there can be any ducking out at this stage. . . . It's down in the rules, you're obliged. . .
　　Roberto will just have to do the best he --"
　　The door behind them opened again, and a large group of people came in: Professor Dominguez, followed closely by Mr. Crouch, Professor Morales, Madame Maxime, Professor Romero, and Professor Peralta. Roberto heard the buzzing of the hundreds of students on the other side of the wall, before Professor Romero closed the door.
　　"Madame Maxime!" said Camila at once, striding over to her headmistress. "Zey are saying zat zis little boy is to compete also!"
　　Somewhere under Roberto's numb disbelief he felt a ripple of anger. Little boy?
　　Madame Maxime had drawn herself up to her full, and considerable, height. The top of her handsome head brushed the candle-filled chandelier, and her gigantic black-satin bosom swelled.
　　"What is ze meaning of zis, Dumbly-dorr?" she said imperiously. "I'd rather like to know that myself, Dominguez," said Professor Morales. He was wearing a steely smile, and his blue eyes were like chips of ice. "Two Hogwarts champions? I don't remember anyone telling me the host school is allowed two champions - or have I not read the rules carefully enough?"
　　He gave a short and nasty laugh.
　　"C'est impossible," said Madame Maxime, whose enormous hand with its many superb opals was resting upon Camila's shoulder. "Ogwarts cannot 'ave two champions. It is most injust."
　　"We were under the impression that your Age Line would keep out younger contestants, Dominguez," said Morales, his steely smile still in place, though his eyes were colder than ever. "Otherwise, we would, of course, have brought along a wider selection of candidates from our own schools."
　　"It's no one's fault but Gonzales's, Morales," said Peralta softly. His black eyes were alight with malice. "Don't go blaming Dominguez for Gonzales's determination to break rules. He has been crossing lines ever since he arrived here -"
　　"Thank you, Carlos," said Dominguez firmly, and Peralta went quiet, though his eyes still glinted malevolently through his curtain of greasy black hair.
　　Professor Dominguez was now looking down at Roberto, who looked right back at him, trying to discern the expression of the eyes behind the half-moon spectacles.
　　"Did you put your name into the Goblet of Fire, Roberto?" he asked calmly.
　　"No," said Roberto. He was very aware of everybody watching him closely. Peralta made a soft noise of impatient disbelief in the shadows.
　　"Did you ask an older student to put it into the Goblet of Fire for you?" said Professor Dominguez, ignoring Peralta.
　　"No," said Roberto vehemently.
　　"Ah, but of course 'e is lying!" cried Madame Maxime. Peralta was now shaking his head, his lip curling.
　　"He could not have crossed the Age Line," said Professor Romero sharply. "I am sure we are all agreed on that -"
　　"Dumbly-dorr must 'ave made a mistake wiz ze line," said Madame Maxime, shrugging.
　　"It is possible, of course," said Dominguez politely.
　　"Dominguez, you know perfectly well you did not make a mistake!" said Professor Romero angrily. "Really, what nonsense! Roberto could not have crossed the line himself, and as Professor Dominguez believes that he did not persuade an older student to do it for him, I'm sure that should be good enough for everybody else!"
　　She shot a very angry look at Professor Peralta.
　　"Mr. Crouch.. . Mr. Bagman," said Morales, his voice unctuous once more, "you are our -er - objective judges. Surely you will agree that this is most irregular?"
　　Bagman wiped his round, boyish face with his handkerchief and looked at Mr. Crouch, who was standing outside the circle of the firelight, his face half hidden in shadow. He looked slightly eerie, the half darkness making him look much older, giving him an almost skull-like appearance. When he spoke, however, it was in his usual curt voice.
　　"We must follow the rules, and the rules state clearly that those people whose names come out of the Goblet of Fire are bound to compete in the tournament."
　　"Well, Barty knows the rule book back to front," said Bagman, beaming and turning back to Morales and Madame Maxime, as though the matter was now closed.
　　"I insist upon resubmitting the names of the rest of my students," said Morales. He had dropped his unctuous tone and his smile now. His face wore a very ugly look indeed.
　　"You will set up the Goblet of Fire once more, and we will continue adding names until each school has two champions. It's only fair, Dominguez."
　　"But Morales, it doesn't work like that," said Bagman. "The Goblet of Fire's just gone out - it won't reignite until the start of the next tournament -"
　　"- in which Durmstrang will most certainly not be competing!" exploded Morales. "After all our meetings and negotiations and compromises, I little expected something of this nature to occur! I have half a mind to leave now!"
　　"Empty threat, Morales," growled a voice from near the door. "You can't leave your champion now. He's got to compete. They've all got to compete. Binding magical contract, like Dominguez said. Convenient, eh?"
　　Acosta had just entered the room. He limped toward the fire, and with every right step he took, there was a loud clunk.
　　"Convenient?" said Morales. "I'm afraid I don't understand you, Acosta."
　　Roberto could tell he was trying to sound disdainful, as though what Acosta was saying was barely worth his notice, but his hands gave him away; they had balled themselves into fists.
　　"Don't you?" said Acosta quietly. "It's very simple, Morales. Someone put Gonzales's name in that goblet knowing he'd have to compete if it came out."
　　"Evidently, someone 'oo wished to give 'Ogwarts two bites at ze apple!" said Madame Maxime.
　　"I quite agree, Madame Maxime," said Morales, bowing to her. "I shall be lodging complaints with the Ministry of Magic and the International Confederation of Wizards -"
　　"If anyone's got reason to complain, it's Gonzales," growled Acosta, "but. . . funny thing.
　　. . I don't hear him saying a word. . .
　　"Why should 'e complain?" burst out Camila Saenz, stamping her foot. "E 'as ze chance
　　to compete, 'asn't 'e? We 'ave all been 'oping to be chosen for weeks and weeks! Ze honor for our schools! A thousand Galleons in prize money - zis is a chance many would die for!"
　　"Maybe someone's hoping Gonzales is going to die for it," said Acosta, with the merest trace of a growl.
　　An extremely tense silence followed these words. Ludo Bagman, who was looking very anxious indeed, bounced nervously up and down on his feet and said, "Acosta, old man. . .
　　what a thing to say!"
　　"We all know Professor Acosta considers the morning wasted if he hasn't discovered six plots to murder him before lunchtime," said Morales loudly. "Apparently he is now teaching his students to fear assassination too. An odd quality in a Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, Dominguez, but no doubt you had your reasons.
　　"Imagining things, am I?" growled Acosta. "Seeing things, eh? It was a skilled witch or wizard who put the boy's name in that goblet. . .
　　"Ah, what evidence is zere of zat?" said Madame Maxime, throwing up her huge hands.
　　"Because they hoodwinked a very powerful magical object!" said Acosta. "It would have needed an exceptionally strong Confundus Charm to bamboozle that goblet into forgetting that only three schools compete in the tournament.. . . I'm guessing they submitted Gonzales's name under a fourth school, to make sure he was the only one in his category.. .
　　."
　　"You seem to have given this a great deal of thought, Acosta," said Morales coldly, "and a very ingenious theory it is - though of course, I heard you recently got it into your head that one of your birthday presents contained a cunningly disguised basilisk egg, and smashed it to pieces before realizing it was a carriage clock. So you'll understand if we don't take you entirely seriously. . . ."
　　"There are those who'll turn innocent occasions to their advantage," Acosta retorted in a menacing voice. "It's my job to think the way Dark wizards do, Morales - as you ought to remember...
　　"Alastor!" said Dominguez warningly. Roberto wondered for a moment whom he was speaking to, but then realized "Mad-Eye" could hardly be Acosta's real first name. Acosta fell silent, though still surveying Morales with satisfaction - Morales's face was burning.
　　"How this situation arose, we do not know," said Dominguez, speaking to everyone gathered in the room. "It seems to me, however, that we have no choice but to accept it.
　　Both Nicolas and Roberto have been chosen to compete in the Tournament. This, therefore, they will do. . .
　　"Ah, but Dumbly-dorr -"
　　"My dear Madame Maxime, if you have an alternative, I would be delighted to hear it."
　　Dominguez waited, but Madame Maxime did not speak, she merely glared. She wasn't the only one either. Peralta looked furious; Morales livid; Bagman, however, looked rather excited.
　　"Well, shall we crack on, then?" he said, rubbing his hands together and smiling around the room. "Got to give our champions their instructions, haven't we? Barty, want to do the honors?"
　　Mr. Crouch seemed to come out of a deep reverie.
　　"Yes," he said, "instructions. Yes . . . the first task . . ."
　　He moved forward into the firelight. Close up, Roberto thought he looked ill. There were dark shadows beneath his eyes and a thin, papery look about his wrinkled skin that had not been there at the Quidditch World Cup.
　　"The first task is designed to test your daring," he told Roberto, Nicolas, Camila, and Viktor, "so we are not going to be telling you what it is. Courage in the face of the unknown is an important quality in a wizard. . . very important.
　　"The first task will take place on November the twenty-fourth, in front of the other students and the panel of judges.
　　"The champions are not permitted to ask for or accept help of any kind from their teachers to complete the tasks in the tournament. The champions will face the first challenge armed only with their wands. They will receive information about the second task when the first is over. Owing to the demanding and time-consuming nature of the tournament, the champions are exempted from end-of-year tests."
　　Mr. Crouch turned to look at Dominguez.
　　"I think that's all, is it, Alfonso?"
　　"I think so," said Dominguez, who was looking at Mr. Crouch with mild concern. "Are you sure you wouldn't like to stay at Hogwarts tonight, Barty?"
　　"No, Dominguez, I must get back to the Ministry," said Mr. Crouch. "It is a very busy, very difficult time at the moment.... I've left young Weatherby in charge.. . . Very enthusiastic. . . a little overenthusiastic, if truth be told. . .
　　"You'll come and have a drink before you go, at least?" said Dominguez.
　　"Come on, Barry, I'm staying!" said Bagman brightly. "It's all happening at Hogwarts now, you know, much more exciting here than at the office!"
　　"I think not, Ludo," said Crouch with a touch of his old impatience.
　　"Professor Morales - Madame Maxime - a nightcap?" said Dominguez.
　　But Madame Maxime had already put her arm around Camila's shoulders and was leading her swiftly out of the room. Roberto could hear them both talking very fast in French as they went off into the Great Hall. Morales beckoned to Krum, and they, too, exited, though in silence.
　　"Roberto, Nicolas, I suggest you go up to bed," said Dominguez, smiling at both of them. "I am sure Gryffindor and Hufflepuff are waiting to celebrate with you, and it would be a shame to deprive them of this excellent excuse to make a great deal of mess and noise."
　　Roberto glanced at Nicolas, who nodded, and they left together.
　　The Great Hall was deserted now; the candles had burned low, giving the jagged smiles of the pumpkins an eerie, flickering quality.
　　"So," said Nicolas, with a slight smile. "We're playing against each other again!"
　　"I s'pose," said Roberto. He really couldn't think of anything to say. The inside of his head seemed to be in complete disarray, as though his brain had been ransacked.
　　"So. . . tell me. . ." said Nicolas as they reached the entrance hall, which was now lit only by torches in the absence of the Goblet of Fire. "How did you get your name in?"
　　"I didn't," said Roberto, staring up at him. "I didn't put it in. I was telling the truth."
　　"Ah. . . okay," said Nicolas. Roberto could tell Nicolas didn't believe him. "Well . . .
　　see you, then."
　　Instead of going up the marble staircase, Nicolas headed for a door to its right. Roberto stood listening to him going down the stone steps beyond it, then, slowly, he started to climb the marble ones.
　　Was anyone except Diego and Carolina going to believe him, or would they all think he'd put himself in for the tournament? Yet how could anyone think that, when he was facing competitors who'd had three years' more magical education than he had - when he was now facing tasks that not only sounded very dangerous, but which were to be performed in front of hundreds of people? Yes, he'd thought about it. . . he'd fantasized about it..
　　. but it had been a joke, really, an idle sort of dream. . . he'd never really, seriously considered entering. .
　　But someone else had considered it. . . someone else had wanted him in the tournament, and had made sure he was entered. Why? To give him a treat? He didn't think so, somehow...
　　To see him make a fool of himself? Well, they were likely to get their wish. .
　　But to get him killed?
　　Was Acosta just being his usual paranoid self? Couldn't someone have put Roberto's name in the goblet as a trick, a practical joke? Did anyone really want him dead?
　　Roberto was able to answer that at once. Yes, someone wanted him dead, someone had wanted him dead ever since he had been a year old. . . Lord Salvador. But how could Salvador have ensured that Roberto's name got into the Goblet of Fire? Salvador was supposed to be far away, in some distant country, in hiding, alone. . . feeble and powerless....
　　Yet in that dream he had had, just before he had awoken with his scar hurting, Salvador had not been alone. . . he had been talking to Wormtail.. . plotting Roberto's murder.
　　Roberto got a shock to find himself facing the Fat Lady already. He had barely noticed where his feet were carrying him. It was also a surprise to see that she was not alone in her frame. The wizened witch who had flitted into her neighbor's painting when he had joined the champions downstairs was now sitting smugly beside the Fat Lady. She must have dashed through every picture lining seven staircases to reach here before him. Both she and the Fat Lady were looking down at him with the keenest interest.
　　"Well, well, well," said the Fat Lady, "Violet's just told me everything. Who's just been chosen as school champion, then?"
　　"Balderdash," said Roberto dully.
　　"It most certainly isn't!" said the pale witch indignantly.
　　"No, no, Vi, it's the password," said the Fat Lady soothingly, and she swung forward on her hinges to let Roberto into the common room.
　　The blast of noise that met Roberto's ears when the portrait opened almost knocked him backward. Next thing he knew, he was being wrenched inside the common room by about a dozen pairs of hands, and was facing the whole of Gryffindor House, all of whom were screaming, applauding, and whistling.
　　"You should've told us you'd entered!" bellowed Pablo; he looked half annoyed, half deeply impressed.
　　"How did you do it without getting a beard? Brilliant!" roared Luis.
　　"I didn't," Roberto said. "I don't know how -"
　　But Angelina had now swooped down upon him; "Oh if it couldn't be me, at least it's a Gryffindor -"
　　"You'll be able to pay back Ortega for that last Quidditch match, Roberto!" shrieked Katie Bell, another of the Gryffindor Chasers.
　　"We've got food, Roberto, come and have some -"
　　"I'm not hungry, I had enough at the feast -"
　　But nobody wanted to hear that he wasn't hungry; nobody wanted to hear that he hadn't put his name in the goblet; not one single person seemed to have noticed that he wasn't at all in the mood to celebrate. . . . Lee Jordan had unearthed a Gryffindor banner from somewhere, and he insisted on draping it around Roberto like a cloak. Roberto couldn't get away; whenever he tried to sidle over to the staircase up to the dormitories, the crowd around him closed ranks, forcing another butterbeer on him, stuffing crisps and peanuts into his hands. . . . Everyone wanted to know how he had done it, how he had tricked Dominguez's Age Line and managed to get his name into the goblet....
　　"I didn't," he said, over and over again, "I don't know how it happened."
　　But for all the notice anyone took, he might just as well not have answered at all.
　　"I'm tired!" he bellowed finally, after nearly half an hour. "No, seriously, Luis -I'm going to bed -"
　　He wanted more than anything to find Diego and Carolina, to find a bit of sanity, but neither of them seemed to be in the common room. Insisting that he needed to sleep, and almost flattening the little Creevey brothers as they attempted to waylay him at the foot of the stairs, Roberto managed to shake everyone off and climb up to the dormitory as fast as he could.
　　To his great relief, he found Diego was lying on his bed in the otherwise empty dormitory, still fully dressed. He looked up when Roberto slammed the door behind him.
　　"Where've you been?" Roberto said.
　　"Oh hello," said Diego.
　　He was grinning, but it was a very odd, strained sort of grin. Roberto suddenly became aware that he was still wearing the scarlet Gryffindor banner that Lee had tied around him. He hastened to take it off, but it was knotted very tightly. Diego lay on the bed without moving, watching Roberto struggle to remove it.
　　"So," he said, when Roberto had finally removed the banner and thrown it into a corner.
　　"Congratulations."
　　"What d'you mean, congratulations?" said Roberto, staring at Diego. There was definitely something wrong with the way Diego was smiling: It was more like a grimace.
　　"Well. . . no one else got across the Age Line," said Diego. "Not even Pablo and Luis.
　　What did you use - the Invisibility Cloak?"
　　"The Invisibility Cloak wouldn't have got me over that line," said Roberto slowly.
　　"Oh right," said Diego. "I thought you might've told me if it was the cloak. . . because it would've covered both of us, wouldn't it? But you found another way, did you?"
　　"Listen," said Roberto, "I didn't put my name in that goblet. Someone else must've done it."
　　Diego raised his eyebrows.
　　"What would they do that for?"
　　"I dunno," said Roberto. He felt it would sound very melodramatic to say, "To kill me."
　　Diego's eyebrows rose so high that they were in danger of disappearing into his hair.
　　"It's okay, you know, you can tell me the truth," he said. "If you don't want everyone else to know, fine, but I don't know why you're bothering to lie, you didn't get into trouble for it, did you? That friend of the Fat Lady's, that Violet, she's already told us all Dominguez's letting you enter. A thousand Galleons prize money, eh? And you don't have to do end-of-year tests either. . ."
　　"I didn't put my name in that goblet!" said Roberto, starting to feel angry.
　　"Yeah, okay," said Diego, in exactly the same sceptical tone as Nicolas. "Only you said this morning you'd have done it last night, and no one would've seen you.. . . I'm not stupid, you know."
　　"You're doing a really good impression of it," Roberto snapped.
　　"Yeah?" said Diego, and there was no trace of a grin, forced or otherwise, on his face now.
　　"You want to get to bed, Roberto. I expect you'll need to be up early tomorrow for a photo-call or something."
　　He wrenched the hangings shut around his four-poster, leaving Roberto standing there by the door, staring at the dark red velvet curtains, now hiding one of the few people he had been sure would believe him.
　　CHAPTER EIGHTEEN - THE WEIGHING OF THE WANDS
　　When Roberto woke up on Sunday morning, it took him a moment to remember why he felt so miserable and worried. Then the memory of the previous night rolled over him. He sat up and ripped back the curtains of his own four-poster, intending to talk to Diego, to force Diego to believe him - only to find that Diego's bed was empty; he had obviously gone down to breakfast.
　　Roberto dressed and went down the spiral staircase into the common room.
　　The moment he appeared, the people who had already finished breakfast broke into applause again. The prospect of going down into the Great Hall and facing the rest of the Gryffindors, all treating him like some sort of hero, was not inviting; it was that, however, or stay here and allow himself to be cornered by the Creevey brothers, who were both beckoning frantically to him to join them. He walked resolutely over to the portrait hole, pushed it open, climbed out of it, and found himself face-to-face with Carolina.
　　"Hello," she said, holding up a stack of toast, which she was carrying in a napkin. "I brought you this. . . . Want to go for a walk?"
　　"Good idea," said Roberto gratefully.
　　They went downstairs, crossed the entrance hall quickly without looking in at the Great Hall, and were soon striding across the lawn toward the lake, where the Durmstrang ship was moored, reflected blackly in the water. It was a chilly morning, and they kept moving, munching their toast, as Roberto told Carolina exactly what had happened after he had left the Gryffindor table the night before. To his immense relief, Carolina accepted his story without question.
　　"Well, of course I knew you hadn't entered yourself," she said when he'd finished telling her about the scene in the chamber off the Hall. "The look on your face when Dominguez read out your name! But the question is, who did put it in? Because Acosta's right, Roberto... I don't think any student could have done it. . . they'd never be able to fool the Goblet, or get over Dominguez's -"
　　"Have you seen Diego?" Roberto interrupted.
　　Carolina hesitated.
　　"Erm. . . yes. . . he was at breakfast," she said.
　　"Does he still think I entered myself?"
　　"Well. . . no, I don't think so . . . not really," said Carolina awkwardly.
　　"What's that supposed to mean, 'not really'?"
　　"Oh Roberto, isn't it obvious?" Carolina said despairingly. "He's jealous!"
　　"Jealous?" Roberto said incredulously. "Jealous of what? He wants to make a prat of himself in front of the whole school, does he?"
　　"Look," said Carolina patiently, "it's always you who gets all the attention, you know it is. I know it's not your fault," she added quickly, seeing Roberto open his mouth furiously. "I know you don't ask for it.. . but - well - you know, Diego's got all those brothers to compete against at home, and you're his best friend, and you're really famous - he's always shunted to one side whenever people see you, and he puts up with it, and he never mentions it, but I suppose this is just one time too many. . .
　　"Great," said Roberto bitterly. "Really great. Tell him from me I'll swap any time he wants. Tell him from me he's welcome to it.... People gawping at my forehead everywhere I go. . ."
　　"I'm not teiling him anything," Carolina said shortly. "Tell him yourself. It's the only way to sort this out."
　　"I'm not running around after him trying to make him grow up!" Roberto said, so loudly
　　that several owls in a nearby tree took flight in alarm. "Maybe he'll believe I'm not enjoying myself once I've got my neck broken or -"
　　"That's not funny," said Carolina quietly. "That's not funny at all." She looked extremely anxious. "Roberto, I've been thinking - you know what we've got to do, don't you? Straight away, the moment we get back to the castle?"
　　"Yeah, give Diego a good kick up the -"
　　"Write to Gustavo. You've got to tell him what's happened. He asked you to keep him posted on everything that's going on at Hogwarts. . . . It's almost as if he expected something like this to happen. I brought some parchment and a quill out with me -"
　　"Come off it," said Roberto, looking around to check that they couldn't be overheard, but the grounds were quite deserted. "He came back to the country just because my scar twinged. He'll probably come bursting right into the castle if I tell him someone's entered me in the Triwizard Tournament -"
　　"He'd want you to tell him," said Carolina sternly. "He's going to find out anyway."
　　"How?"
　　"Roberto, this isn't going to be kept quiet," said Carolina, very seriously. "This tournament's famous, and you're famous. I'll be really surprised if there isn't anything in the Daily Prophet about you competing. . . . You're already in half the books about You-Know-Who, you know.. . and Gustavo would rather hear it from you, I know he would."
　　"Okay, okay, I'll write to him," said Roberto, throwing his last piece of toast into the lake. They both stood and watched it floating there for a moment, before a large tentacle rose out of the water and scooped it beneath the surface. Then they returned to the castle.
　　"Whose owl am I going to use?" Roberto said as they climbed the stairs. "He told me not to use Hedwig again."
　　"Ask Diego if you can borrow -"
　　"I'm not asking Diego for anything," Roberto said flatly.
　　"Well, borrow one of the school owls, then, anyone can use them," said Carolina.
　　They went up to the Owlery. Carolina gave Roberto a piece of parchment, a quill, and a bottle of ink, then strolled around the long lines of perches, looking at all the different owls, while Roberto sat down against a wall and wrote his letter.
　　Dear Gustavo, You told me to keep you posted on what's happening at Hogwarts, so here goes - I don't know if you've heard, but the Triwizard Tournament's happening this year and on Saturday night I got picked as a fourth champion. I don't who put my name in the Goblet of Fire, because I didn't. The other Hogwarts champion is Nicolas Ortega, from Hufflepuff He paused at this point, thinking. He had an urge to say something about the large weight of anxiety that seemed to have settled inside his chest since last night, but he couldn't think how to translate this into words, so he simply dipped his quill back into the ink bottle and wrote, Hope you're okay, and Buckbeak - Roberto "Finished," he told Carolina, getting to his feet and brushing straw off his robes. At this, Hedwig fluttered down onto his shoulder and held out her leg.
　　"I can't use you," Roberto told her, looking around for the school owls.
　　"I've got to use one of these."
　　Hedwig gave a very loud hoot and took off so suddenly that her talons cut into his shoulder. She kept her back to Roberto all the time he was tying his letter to the leg of a large barn owl. When the barn owl had flown off, Roberto reached out to stroke Hedwig, but she clicked her beak furiously and soared up into the rafters out of reach.
　　"First Diego, then you," Roberto said angrily. "This isn't my fault."
　　If Roberto had thought that matters would improve once everyone got used to the idea of him being champion, the following day showed him how mistaken he was. He could no longer avoid the rest of the school once he was back at lessons - and it was clear that the rest of the school, just like the Gryffindors, thought Roberto had entered himself for the
　　tournament. Unlike the Gryffindors, however, they did not seem impressed.
　　The Hufflepuffs, who were usually on excellent terms with the Gryffindors, had turned remarkably cold toward the whole lot of them. One Herbology lesson was enough to demonstrate this. It was plain that the Hufflepuffs felt that Roberto had stolen their champion's glory; a feeling exacerbated, perhaps, by the fact that Hufflepuff House very rarely got any glory, and that Nicolas was one of the few who had ever given them any, having beaten Gryffindor once at Quidditch. Ernie Macmillan and Justin FinchFletchley, with whom Roberto normally got on very well, did not talk to him even though they were repotting Bouncing Bulbs at the same tray - though they did laugh rather unpleasantly when one of the Bouncing Bulbs wriggled free from Roberto's grip and smacked him hard in the face. Diego wasn't talking to Roberto either. Carolina sat between them, making very forced conversation, but though both answered her normally, they avoided making eye contact with each other. Roberto thought even Professor Sprout seemed distant with him -but then, she was Head of Hufflepuff House.
　　He would have been looking forward to seeing Villalba under normal circumstances, but Care of Magical Creatures meant seeing the Slytherins too - the first time he would come face-to-face with them since becoming champion.
　　Predictably, Sosa arrived at Villalba's cabin with his familiar sneer firmly in place.
　　"Ah, look, boys, it's the champion," he said to Crabbe and Goyle the moment he got within earshot of Roberto. "Got your autograph books? Better get a signature now, because I doubt he's going to be around much longer. . . . Half the Triwizard champions have died..
　　. how long d'you reckon you're going to last, Gonzales? Ten minutes into the first task's my bet."
　　Crabbe and Goyle guffawed sycophantically, but Sosa had to stop there, because Villalba emerged from the back of his cabin balancing a teetering tower of crates, each containing a very large Blast-Ended Skrewt. To the class's horror, Villalba proceeded to explain that the reason the skrewts had been killing one another was an excess of pent-up energy, and that the solution would be for each student to fix a leash on a skrewt and take it for a short walk. The only good thing about this plan was that it distracted Sosa completely.
　　"Take this thing for a walk?" he repeated in disgust, staring into one of the boxes.
　　"And where exactly are we supposed to fix the leash? Around the sting, the blasting end, or the sucker?"
　　"Roun' the middle," said Villalba, demonstrating. "Er - yeh might want ter put on yer dragon-hide gloves, jus' as an extra precaution, like. Roberto - you come here an' help me with this big one....
　　Villalba's real intention, however, was totalk to Roberto away from the rest of the class. He waited until everyone else had set off with their skrewts, then turned to Roberto and said, very seriously, "So - yer competin', Roberto. In the tournament. School champion."
　　"One of the champions," Roberto corrected him.
　　Villalba's beetle-black eyes looked very anxious under his wild eyebrows.
　　"No idea who put yeh in fer it, Roberto?"
　　"You believe I didn't do it, then?" said Roberto, concealing with difficulty the rush of gratitude he felt at Villalba's words.
　　"Course I do," Villalba grunted. "Yeh say it wasn' you, an' I believe yeh - an' Dominguez believes yer, an' all."
　　"Wish I knew who did do it," said Roberto bitterly.
　　The pair of them looked out over the lawn; the class was widely scattered now, and all in great difficulty. The skrewts were now over three feet long, and extremely powerful. No longer shell-less and colorless, they had developed a kind of thick, grayish, shiny armor. They looked like a cross between giant scorpions and elongated crabs - but still without recognizable heads or eyes. They had become immensely strong and very hard to control.
　　"Look like they're havin' fun, don' they?" Villalba said happily. Roberto assumed he was talking about the skrewts, because his classmates certainly weren't; every now and then, with an alarming bang, one of the skrewts' ends would explode, causing it to shoot forward several yards, and more than one person was being dragged along on their stomach, trying desperately to get back on their feet.
　　"Ah, I don' know, Roberto," Villalba sighed suddenly, looking back down at him with a worried expression on his face. "School champion. . . everythin' seems ter happen ter you, doesn' it?"
　　Roberto didn't answer. Yes, everything did seem to happen to him. . . that was more or less what Carolina had said as they had walked around the lake, and that was the reason, according to her, that Diego was no longer talking to him.
　　The next few days were some of Roberto's worst at Hogwarts. The closest he had ever come to feeling like this had been during those months, in his second year, when a large part of the school had suspected him of attacking his fellow students. But Diego had been on his side then. He thought he could have coped with the rest of the school's behavior if he could just have had Diego back as a friend, but he wasn't going to try and persuade Diego to talk to him if Diego didn't want to. Nevertheless, it was lonely with dislike pouring in on him from all sides.
　　He could understand the Hufflepuffs' attitude, even if he didn't like it; they had their own champion to support. He expected nothing less than vicious insults from the Slytherins - he was highly unpopular there and always had been, because he had helped Gryffindor beat them so often, both at Quidditch and in the Inter-House Championship.
　　But he had hoped the Ravenclaws might have found it in their hearts to support him as much as Nicolas. He was wrong, however. Most Ravenclaws seemed to think that he had been desperate to earn himself a bit more fame by tricking the goblet into accepting his name.
　　Then there was the fact that Nicolas looked the part of a champion so much more than he did. Exceptionally handsome, with his straight nose, dark hair, and gray eyes, it was hard to say who was receiving more admiration these days, Nicolas or Viktor Krum. Roberto actually saw the same sixth-year girls who had been so keen to get Krum's autograph begging Nicolas to sign their school bags one lunchtime.
　　Meanwhile there was no reply from Gustavo, Hedwig was refusing to come anywhere near him, Professor Trelawney was predicting his death with even more certainty than usual, and he did so badly at Summoning Charms in Professor Flitwick's class that he was given extra homework - the only person to get any, apart from Mauricio.
　　"It's really not that difficult, Roberto," Carolina tried to reassure him as they left Flitwick's class - she had been making objects zoom across the room to her all lesson, as though she were some sort of weird magnet for board dusters, wastepaper baskets, and lunascopes. "You just weren't concentrating properly -"
　　"Wonder why that was," said Roberto darkly as Nicolas Ortega walked past, surrounded by a large group of simpering girls, all of whom looked at Roberto as though he were a particularly large Blast-Ended Skrewt. "Still - never mind, eh? Double Potions to look forward to this afternoon. . ."
　　Double Potions was always a horrible experience, but these days it was nothing short of torture. Being shut in a dungeon for an hour and a half with Peralta and the Slytherins, all of whom seemed determined to punish Roberto as much as possible for daring to become school champion, was about the most unpleasant thing Roberto could imagine. He had already struggled through one Friday's worth, with Carolina sitting next to him intoning "ignore them, ignore them, ignore them" under her breath, and he couldn't see why today should be any better.
　　When he and Carolina arrived at Peralta's dungeon after lunch, they found the Slytherins waiting outside, each and every one of them wearing a large badge on the front of his or her robes. For one wild moment Roberto thought they were S.P.E.W. badges - then he saw that they all bore the same message, in luminous red letters that burnt brightly in the dimly lit underground passage:
　　SUPPORT NICOLAS ORTEGA-- THE REAL HOGWARTS CHAMPION!
　　"Like them, Gonzales?" said Sosa loudly as Roberto approached. "And this isn't all they do - look!"
　　He pressed his badge into his chest, and the message upon it vanished, to be replaced by another one, which glowed green:
　　GONZALES STINKS!
　　The Slytherins howled with laughter. Each of them pressed their badges too, until the message GONZALES STINKS was shining brightly all around Roberto. He felt the heat rise in his face and neck.
　　"Oh very funny," Carolina said sarcastically to Pansy Parkinson and her gang of Slytherin girls, who were laughing harder than anyone, "really witty."
　　Diego was standing against the wall with Dean and Seamus. He wasn't laughing, but he wasn't sticking up for Roberto either.
　　"Want one, Fernandez?" said Sosa, holding out a badge to Carolina. "I've got loads. But don't touch my hand, now. I've just washed it, you see; don't want a Mudblood sliming it up."
　　Some of the anger Roberto had been feeling for days and days seemed to burst through a dam in his chest. He had reached for his wand before he'd thought what he was doing. People all around them scrambled out of the way, backing down the corridor.
　　"Roberto!" Carolina said warningly.
　　"Go on, then, Gonzales," Sosa said quietly, drawing out his own wand. "Acosta's not here to look after you now - do it, if you've got the guts -"
　　For a split second, they looked into each other's eyes, then, at exactly the same time, both acted.
　　"Funnunculus!" Roberto yelled.
　　"Densaugeo!" screamed Sosa.
　　Jets of light shot from both wands, hit each other in midair, and ricocheted off at angles -- Roberto's hit Goyle in the face, and Sosa's hit Carolina.
　　Goyle bellowed and put his hands to his nose, where great ugly boils were springing up -Carolina, whimpering in panic, was clutching her mouth.
　　"Carolina!"
　　Diego had hurried forward to see what was wrong with her; Roberto turned and saw Diego dragging Carolina's hand away from her face. It wasn't a pretty sight.
　　Carolina's front teeth - already larger than average - were now growing at an alarming rate; she was looking more and more like a beaver as her teeth elongated, past her bottom lip, toward her chin - panic-stricken, she felt them and let out a terrified cry.
　　"And what is all this noise about?" said a soft, deadly voice.
　　Peralta had arrived. The Slytherins clamored to give their explanations; Peralta pointed a long yellow finger at Sosa and said, "Explain."
　　"Gonzales attacked me, sir -"
　　"We attacked each other at the same time!" Roberto shouted.
　　"- and he hit Goyle - look -"
　　Peralta examined Goyle, whose face now resembled something that would have been at home in a book on poisonous fungi.
　　"Hospital wing, Goyle," Peralta said calmly.
　　"Sosa got Carolina!" Diego said. "Look!"
　　He forced Carolina to show Peralta her teeth - she was doing her best to hide them with her hands, though this was difficult as they had now grown down past her collar. Pansy Parkinson and the other Slytherin girls were doubled up with silent giggles, pointing at Carolina from behind Peralta's back.
　　Peralta looked coldly at Carolina, then said, "I see no difference.".
　　Carolina let out a whimper; her eyes filled with tears, she turned on her heel and ran, ran all the way up the corridor and out of sight.
　　It was lucky, perhaps, that both Roberto and Diego started shouting at Peralta at the same time; lucky their voices echoed so much in the stone corridor, for in the confused din, it was impossible for him to hear exactly what they were calling him. He got the gist, however.
　　"Let's see," he said, in his silkiest voice. "Fifty points from Gryffindor and a detention each for Gonzales and Lopez. Now get inside, or it'll be a week's worth of detentions."
　　Roberto's ears were ringing. The injustice of it made him want to curse Peralta into a thousand slimy pieces. He passed Peralta, walked with Diego to the back of the dungeon, and slammed his bag down onto the table. Diego was shaking with anger too - for a moment, it felt as though everything was back to normal between them, but then Diego turned and sat down with Dean and Seamus instead, leaving Roberto alone at his table. On the other side of the dungeon, Sosa turned his back on Peralta and pressed his badge, smirking. GONZALES STINKS flashed once more across the room.
　　Roberto sat there staring at Peralta as the lesson began, picturing horrific things happening to him. . . . If only he knew how to do the Cruciatus Curse. . . he'd have Peralta flat on his back like that spider, jerking and twitching.
　　"Antidotes!" said Peralta, looking around at them all, his cold black eyes glittering unpleasantly. "You should all have prepared your recipes now. I want you to brew them carefully, and then, we will be selecting someone on whom to test one. . ."
　　Peralta's eyes met Roberto's, and Roberto knew what was coming. Peralta was going to poison him.
　　Roberto imagined picking up his cauldron, and sprinting to the front of the class, and bringing it down on Peralta's greasy head - And then a knock on the dungeon door burst in on Roberto's thoughts.
　　It was Colin Creevey; he edged into the room, beaming at Roberto, and walked up to Peralta's desk at the front of the room.
　　"Yes?" said Peralta curtly.
　　"Please, sir, I'm supposed to take Roberto Gonzales upstairs." Peralta stared down his hooked nose at Colin, whose smile faded from his eager face.
　　"Gonzales has another hour of Potions to complete," said Peralta coldly. "He will come upstairs when this class is finished."
　　Colin went pink.
　　"Sir - sir, Mr. Bagman wants him," he said nervously. "All the champions have got to go, I think they want to take photographs. . ."
　　Roberto would have given anything he owned to have stopped Colin saying those last few words. He chanced half a glance at Diego, but Diego was staring determinedly at the ceiling.
　　"Very well, very well," Peralta snapped. "Gonzales, leave your things here, I want you back down here later to test your antidote."
　　"Please, sir - he's got to take his things with him," squeaked Cohn. "All the champions..."
　　"Very well!" said Peralta. "Gonzales - take your bag and get out of my sight!"
　　Roberto swung his bag over his shoulder, got up, and headed for the door. As he walked through the Slytherin desks, GONZALES STINKS flashed at him from every direction.
　　"It's amazing, isn't it, Roberto?" said Colin, starting to speak the moment Roberto had closed the dungeon door behind him. "Isn't it, though? You being champion?"
　　"Yeah, really amazing," said Roberto heavily as they set off toward the steps into the entrance hall. "What do they want photos for, Colin?"
　　"The Daily Prophet, I think!"
　　"Great," said Roberto dully. "Exactly what I need. More publicity."
　　"Good luck!" said Colin when they had reached the right room. Roberto knocked on the door and entered.
　　He was in a fairly small classroom; most of the desks had been pushed away to the back of the room, leaving a large space in the middle; three of them, however, had been placed end-to-end in front of the blackboard and covered with a long length of velvet. Five chairs had been set behind the velvet-covered desks, and Ludo Bagman was sitting in one of them, talking to a witch Roberto had never seen before, who was wearing magenta robes.
　　Viktor Krum was standing moodily in a corner as usual and not talking to anybody. Nicolas and Fheur were in conversation. Fheur looked a good deal happier than Roberto had seen her so far; she kept throwing back her head so that her long silvery hair caught the light.
　　A paunchy man, holding a large black camera that was smoking slightly, was watching Camila out of the corner of his eye.
　　Bagman suddenly spotted Roberto, got up quickly, and bounded forward.
　　"Ah, here he is! Champion number four! In you come, Roberto, in you come.. . nothing to worry about, it's just the wand weighing ceremony, the rest of the judges will be here in a moment -"
　　"Wand weighing?" Roberto repeated nervously.
　　"We have to check that your wands are fully functional, no problems, you know, as they're your most important tools in the tasks ahead," said Bagman. "The expert's upstairs now with Dominguez. And then there's going to be a little photo shoot. This is Rita Skeeter," he added, gesturing toward the witch in magenta robes. "She's doing a small piece on the tournament for the Daily Prophet. .. ."
　　"Maybe not that small, Ludo," said Rita Skeeter, her eyes on Roberto.
　　Her hair was set in elaborate and curiously rigid curls that contrasted oddly with her heavy-jawed face. She wore jeweled spectacles. The thick fingers clutching her crocodile-skin handbag ended in two-inch nails, painted crimson.
　　"I wonder if I could have a little word with Roberto before we start?" she said to Bagman, but still gazing fixedly at Roberto. "The youngest champion, you know. . . to add a bit of color?"
　　"Certainly!" cried Bagman. "That is - if Roberto has no objection?"
　　"Er -" said Roberto.
　　"Lovely," said Rita Skeeter, and in a second, her scarlet-taloned fingers had Roberto's upper arm in a surprisingly strong grip, and she was steering him out of the room again and opening a nearby door.
　　"We don't want to be in there with all that noise," she said. "Let's see . . . ah, yes, this is nice and cozy."
　　It was a broom cupboard. Roberto stared at her.
　　"Come along, dear - that's right - lovely," said Rita Skeeter again, perching herself precariously upon an upturned bucket, pushing Roberto down onto a cardboard box, and closing the door, throwing them into darkness. "Let's see now. ."
　　She unsnapped her crocodile-skin handbag and pulled out a handful of candles, which she lit with a wave of her wand and magicked into midair, so that they could see what they were doing.
　　"You won't mind, Roberto, if I use a Quick-Quotes Quill? It leaves me free to talk to you normally. .."
　　"A what?" said Roberto.
　　Rita Skeeter's smile widened. Roberto counted three gold teeth. She reached again into her crocodile bag and drew out a long acid-green quill and a roll of parchment, which she stretched out between them on a crate of Mrs. Skower's All-Purpose Magical Mess Remover.
　　She put the tip of the green quill into her mouth, sucked it for a moment with apparent relish, then placed it upright on the parchment, where it stood balanced on its point, quivering slightly.
　　"Testing. . . my name is Rita Skeeter, Daily Prophet reporter."
　　Roberto hooked down quickly at the quill. The moment Rita Skeeter had spoken, the green quill had started to scribble, skidding across the parchment:
　　Attractive blonde Rita Skeeter, forty-three, who's savage quill has punctured many inflated reputations - "Lovely," said Rita Skeeter, yet again, and she ripped the top piece of parchment off, crumpled it up, and stuffed it into her handbag. Now she leaned toward Roberto and said, "So, Roberto... what made you decide to enter the Triwizard Tournament?"
　　"Er -" said Roberto again, but he was distracted by the quill. Even though he wasn't speaking, it was dashing across the parchment, and in its wake he could make out a fresh sentence:
　　An ugly scar, souvenier of a tragic past, disfigures the otherwise charming face of Roberto Gonzales, whose eyes -- "Ignore the quill, Roberto," said Rita Skeeter firmly. Reluctantly Roberto looked up at her instead. "Now -- why did you decide to enter the tournament, Roberto?"
　　"I didn't," said Roberto. "I don't know how my name got into the Goblet of Fire. I didn't put it in there."
　　Rita Skeeter raised one heavily penciled eyebrow.
　　"Come now, Roberto, there's no need to be scared of getting into trouble. We all know you shouldn't really have entered at all. But don't worry about that. Our readers hove a rebel."
　　"But I didn't enter," Roberto repeated. "I don't know who -"
　　"How do you feel about the tasks ahead?" said Rita Skeeter. "Excited? Nervous?"
　　"I haven't really thought. . . yeah, nervous, I suppose," said Roberto. His insides squirmed uncomfortably as he spoke.
　　"Champions have died in the past, haven't they?" said Rita Skeeter briskly. "Have you thought about that at all?"
　　"Well. . . they say it's going to be a lot safer this year," said Roberto.
　　The quill whizzed across the parchment between them, back and forward as though it were skating.
　　"Of course, you've looked death in the face before, haven't you?" said Rita Skeeter, watching him closely. "How would you say that's affected you?"
　　"Er," said Roberto, yet again.
　　"Do you think that the trauma in your past might have made you keen to prove yourself? To
　　live up to your name? Do you think that perhaps you were tempted to enter the Triwizard Tournament because - "
　　"I didn't enter," said Roberto, starting to feel irritated.
　　"Can you remember your parents at all?" said Rita Skeeter, talking over him.
　　"No," said Roberto.
　　"How do you think they'd feel if they knew you were competing in the Triwizard Tournament? Proud? Worried? Angry?"
　　Roberto was feeling really annoyed now. How on earth was he to know how his parents would feel if they were alive? He could feel Rita Skeeter watching him very intently.
　　Frowning, he avoided her gaze and hooked down at words the quill had just written:
　　Tears fill those startlingly green eyes as our conversation turns to the parents he can barely remember.
　　"I have NOT got tears in my eyes!" said Roberto loudly.
　　Before Rita Skeeter could say a word, the door of the broom cupboard was pulled open.
　　Roberto looked around, blinking in the bright light. Alfonso Dominguez stood there, looking down at both of them, squashed into the cupboard.
　　"Dominguez!" cried Rita Skeeter, with every appearance of delight - but Roberto noticed that her quill and the parchment had suddenly vanished from the box of Magical Mess Remover, and Rita's clawed fingers were hastily snapping shut the clasp of her crocodile-skin bag. "How are you?" she said, standing up and holding out one of her large, mannish hands to Dominguez. "I hope you saw my piece over the summer about the International Confederation of Wizards' Conference?"
　　"Enchantingly nasty," said Dominguez, his eyes twinkling. "I particularly enjoyed your description of me as an obsolete dingbat."
　　Rita Skeeter didn't look remotely abashed.
　　"I was just making the point that some of your ideas are a little old-fashioned, Dumbhedore, and that many wizards in the street -"
　　"I will be delighted to hear the reasoning behind the rudeness, Rita," said Dominguez, with a courteous bow and a smile, "but I'm afraid we will have to discuss the matter later. The Weighing of the Wands is about to start, and it cannot take place if one of our champions is hidden in a broom cupboard."
　　Very glad to get away from Rita Skeeter, Roberto hurried back into the room. The other champions were now sitting in chairs near the door, and he sat down quickly next to Nicolas, hooking up at the velvet-covered table, where four of the five judges were now sitting - Professor Morales, Madame Maxime, Mr. Crouch, and Ludo Bagman. Rita Skeeter settled herself down in a corner; Roberto saw her slip the parchment out of her bag again, spread it on her knee, suck the end of the Quick-Quotes Quill, and place it once more on the parchment.
　　"May I introduce Mr. Ollivander?" said Dominguez, taking his place at the judges' table and talking to the champions. "He will be checking your wands to ensure that they are in good condition before the tournament."
　　Roberto hooked around, and with a jolt of surprise saw an old wizard with large, pale eyes standing quietly by the window. Roberto had met Mr. Ollivander before - he was the wand-maker from whom Roberto had bought his own wand over three years ago in Diagon Alley.
　　"Mademoiselle Saenz, could we have you first, please?" said Mr. Ollivander, stepping into the empty space in the middle of the room.
　　Camila Saenz swept over to Mr. Olhivander and handed him her wand.
　　"Hmm..." he said.
　　He twirled the wand between his long fingers like a baton and it emitted a number of pink and gold sparks. Then he held it chose to his eyes and examined it carefully.
　　"Yes," he said quietly, "nine and a half inches. . . inflexible.. rosewood.. . and containing. . . dear me. . ."
　　"An 'air from ze 'ead of a veela," said Camila. "One of my grandmuzzer's."
　　So Camila was part veela, thought Roberto, making a mental note to tell Diego. . . then he remembered that Diego wasn't speaking to him.
　　"Yes," said Mr. Ollivander, "yes, I've never used veela hair myself, of course. I find it makes for rather temperamental wands...however, to each his own, and if this suits you.."
　　Mr. Ollivander ran his fingers along the wand, apparently checking for scratches or
　　bumps; then he muttered, "Orchideous!" and a bunch of flowers burst from the wand tip.
　　"Very well, very well, it's in fine working order," said Mr. Ollivander, scooping up the flowers and handing them to Camila with her wand. "Mr. Ortega, you next."
　　Camila glided back to her seat, smiling at Nicolas as he passed her.
　　"Ah, now, this is one of mine, isn't it?" said Mr. Ollivander, with much more enthusiasm, as Nicolas handed over his wand. "Yes, I remember it well. Containing a single hair from the tail of a particularly fine male unicorn. . . must have been seventeen hands; nearly gored me with his horn after I plucked his tail. Twelve and a quarter inches. . . ash. .
　　. pleasantly springy. It's in fine condition...You treat it regularly?"
　　"Polished it last night," said Nicolas, grinning.
　　Roberto hooked down at his own wand. He could see finger marks all over it. He gathered a fistful of robe from his knee and tried to rub it clean surreptitiously. Several gold sparks shot out of the end of it. Camila Saenz gave him a very patronizing look, and he desisted.
　　Mr. Ollivander sent a stream of silver smoke rings across the room from the tip of Nicolas's wand, pronounced himself satisfied, and then said, "Mr. Krum, if you please."
　　Viktor Krum got up and slouched, round-shouldered and duck-footed, toward Mr. Ollivander.
　　He thrust out his wand and stood scowling, with his hands in the pockets of his robes.
　　"Hmm," said Mr. Olhivander, "this is a Gregorovitch creation, unless I'm much mistaken?
　　A fine wand-maker, though the styling is never quite what I. . . however. ."
　　He lifted the wand and examined it minutely, turning it over and over before his eyes.
　　"Yes.. . hornbeam and dragon heartstring?" he shot at Krum, who nodded. "Rather thicker than one usually sees. . . quite rigid. . . ten and a quarter inches. . . Avis!"
　　The hornbeam wand let off a blast hike a gun, and a number of small, twittering birds flew out of the end and through the open window into the watery sunlight.
　　"Good," said Mr. Ollivander, handing Krum back his wand. "Which leaves. . . Mr. Gonzales."
　　Roberto got to his feet and walked past Krum to Mr. Ollivander. He handed over his wand.
　　"Aaaah, yes," said Mr. Ohlivander, his pale eyes suddenly gleaming. "Yes, yes, yes. How well I remember."
　　Roberto could remember too. He could remember it as though it had happened yesterday....
　　Four summers ago, on his eleventh birthday, he had entered Mr. Ollivander's shop with Villalba to buy a wand. Mr. Ollivander had taken his measurements and then started handing him wands to try. Roberto had waved what felt like every wand in the shop, until at last he had found the one that suited him - this one, which was made of holly, eleven inches long, and contained a single feather from the tail of a phoenix. Mr. Ollivander had been very surprised that Roberto had been so compatible with this wand. "Curious," he had said, "curious," and not until Roberto asked what was curious had Mr. Olhivander explained that the phoenix feather in Roberto's wand had come from the same bird that had supplied the core of Lord Salvador's.
　　Roberto had never shared this piece of information with anybody. He was very fond of his wand, and as far as he was concerned its relation to Salvador's wand was something it couldn't help - rather as he couldn't help being related to Aunt Beatriz. However, he really hoped that Mr. Ollivander wasn't about to tell the room about it. He had a funny feeling Rita Skeeter's Quick-Quotes Quill might just explode with excitement if he did.
　　Mr. Ollivander spent much longer examining Roberto's wand than anyone else's. Eventually, however, he made a fountain of wine shoot out of it, and handed it back to Roberto, announcing that it was still in perfect condition.
　　"Thank you all," said Dominguez, standing up at the judges' table. "You may go back to your lessons now - or perhaps it would be quicker just to go down to dinner, as they are about to end -"
　　Feeling that at last something had gone right today, Roberto got up to leave, but the man with the black camera jumped up and cleared his throat.
　　"Photos, Dominguez, photos!" cried Bagman excitedly. "All the judges and champions, what do you think, Rita?"
　　"Er - yes, let's do those first," said Rita Skeeter, whose eyes were upon Roberto again.
　　"And then perhaps some individual shots."
　　The photographs took a long time. Madame Maxime cast everyone else into shadow wherever she stood, and the photographer couldn't stand far enough back to get her into the frame; eventually she had to sit while everyone else stood around her. Morales kept twirling his goatee around his finger to give it an extra curl; Krum, whom Roberto would have thought would have been used to this sort of thing, skulked, half-hidden, at the back of
　　the group. The photographer seemed keenest to get Camila at the front, but Rita Skeeter kept hurrying forward and dragging Roberto into greater prominence. Then she insisted on separate shots of all the champions. At last, they were free to go.
　　Roberto went down to dinner. Carolina wasn't there - he supposed she was still in the hospital wing having her teeth fixed. He ate alone at the end of the table, then returned to Gryffindor Tower, thinking of all the extra work on Summoning Charms that he had to do. Up in the dormitory, he came across Diego.
　　"You've had an owl," said Diego brusquely the moment he walked in. He was pointing at Roberto's pillow. The school barn owl was waiting for him there.
　　"Oh - right," said Roberto.
　　"And we've got to do our detentions tomorrow night, Peralta's dungeon," said Diego.
　　He then walked straight out of the room, not looking at Roberto. For a moment, Roberto considered going after him - he wasn't sure whether he wanted to talk to him or hit him, both seemed quite appealing - but the lure of Gustavo's answer was too strong. Roberto strode over to the barn owl, took the letter off its leg, and unrolled it.
　　Roberto - I can't say everything I would like to in a letter, it's too risky in case the owl is intercepted - we need to talk face-to-face. Can you ensure that you are alone by the fire in Gryffindor Tower at one o'clock in the morning on the 22nd ofNovember?
　　I know better than anyone that you can look after yourself and while you're around Dominguez and Acosta I don't think anyone will be able to hurt you. However, someone seems to be having a good try. Entering you in that tournament would have been very risky, especially right under Dumbkdore's nose.
　　Be on the watch, Roberto. I still want to hear about anything unusual. Let me know about the 22nd ofNovember as quickly as you can.
　　Gustavo CHAPTER NINETEEN - THE HUNGARIAN HORNTAIL
　　The prospect of talking face-to-face with Gustavo was all that sustained Roberto over the next fortnight, the only bright spot on a horizon that had never looked darker. The shock of finding himself school champion had worn off slightly now, and the fear of what was facing him had started to sink in. The first task was drawing steadily nearer; he felt as though it were crouching ahead of him hike some horrific monster, barring his path. He had never suffered nerves like these; they were way beyond anything he had experienced before a Quidditch match, not even his last one against Slytherin, which had decided who would win the Quidditch Cup. Roberto was finding it hard to think about the future at all; he felt as though his whole life had been heading up to, and would finish with, the first task.
　　Admittedly, he didn't see how Gustavo was going to make him feel any better about having to perform an unknown piece of difficult and dangerous magic in front of hundreds of people, but the mere sight of a friendly face would be something at the moment. Roberto wrote back to Gustavo saying that he would be beside the common room fire at the time Gustavo had suggested; and he and Carolina spent a long time going over plans for forcing any stragglers out of the common room on the night in question. If the worst came to the worst, they were going to drop a bag of Dungbombs, but they hoped they wouldn't have to resort to that - Filch would skin them alive.
　　In the meantime, life became even worse for Roberto within the confines of the castle, for Rita Skeeter had published her piece about the Triwizard Tournament, and it had turned out to be not so much a report on the tournament as a highly colored life story of Roberto.
　　Much of the front page had been given over to a picture of Roberto; the article (continuing on pages two, six, and seven) had been all about Roberto, the names of the Beauxbatons and Durmstrang champions (misspelled) had been squashed into the last line of the article, and Nicolas hadn't been mentioned at all.
　　The article had appeared ten days ago, and Roberto still got a sick, burning feeling of shame in his stomach every time he thought about it. Rita Skeeter had reported him saying an awful lot of things that he couldn't remember ever saying in his life, let alone in that broom cupboard.
　　I suppose I get my strength from my parents. I know they'd be very proud of me if they could see me now. . . . Yes, sometimes at night I still cry about them, I'm not ashamed to admit it. . . . I know nothing will hurt me during the tournament, because they're watching over me. . .
　　But Rita Skeeter had gone even further than transforming his "er's" into long, sickly sentences: She had interviewed other people about him too.
　　Roberto has at last found love at Hogwarts. His close friend, Colin Creevey, says that Roberto is rarely seen out of the company of one Carolina Fernandez, a stunningly pretty Muggle-born girl who, like Roberto, is one of the top students in the school.
　　From the moment the article had appeared, Roberto had had to endure people --Slytherins, mainly -- quoting it at him as he passed and making sneering comments.
　　"Want a hanky, Gonzales, in case you start crying in Transfiguration?"
　　"Since when have you been one of the top students in the school, Gonzales? Or is this a school you and Silva have set up together?"
　　"Hey - Roberto!"
　　"Yeah, that's right!" Roberto found himself shouting as he wheeled around in the corridor, having had just about enough. "I've just been crying my eyes out over my dead mum, and I'm just off to do a bit more. . .
　　"No - it was just - you dropped your quill."
　　It was Paula. Roberto felt the color rising in his face.
　　"Oh - right - sorry," he muttered, taking the quill back.
　　"Er. . . good luck on Tuesday," she said. "I really hope you do well."
　　Which left Roberto feeling extremely stupid.
　　Carolina had come in for her fair share of unpleasantness too, but she hadn't yet started yelling at innocent bystanders; in fact, Roberto was full of admiration for the way she was handling the situation.
　　"Stunningly pretty? Her?" Pansy Parkinson had shrieked the first time she had come face-to-face with Carolina after Rita's article had appeared. "What was she judging against - a chipmunk?"
　　"Ignore it," Carolina said in a dignified voice, holding her head in the air and stalking past the sniggering Slytherin girls as though she couldn't hear them. "Just ignore it, Roberto."
　　But Roberto couldn't ignore it. Diego hadn't spoken to him at all since he had told him about Peralta's detentions. Roberto had half hoped they would make things up during the two hours they were forced to pickle rats' brains in Peralta's dungeon, but that had been the day Rita's article had appeared, which seemed to have confirmed Diego's belief that Roberto was really enjoying all the attention.
