　　Carolina was furious with the pair of them; she went from one to the other, trying to force them to talk to each other, but Roberto was adamant: He would talk to Diego again only if Diego admitted that Roberto hadn't put his name in the Goblet of Fire and apologized for calling him a liar.
　　"I didn't start this," Roberto said stubbornly. "It's his problem."
　　"You miss him!" Carolina said impatiently. "And I know he misses you -"
　　"Miss him?" said Roberto. "I don't miss him. . .
　　But this was a downright lie. Roberto liked Carolina very much, but she just wasn't the same as Diego. There was much hess laughter and a lot more hanging around in the library when Carolina was your best friend. Roberto still hadn't mastered Summoning Charms, he seemed to have developed something of a block about them, and Carolina insisted that learning the theory would help. They consequently spent a lot of time poring over books during their lunchtimes.
　　Viktor Krum was in the library an awful lot too, and Roberto wondered what he was up to.
　　Was he studying, or was he looking for things to help him through the first task?
　　Carolina often complained about Krum being there - not that he ever bothered them - but because groups of giggling girls often turned up to spy on him from behind bookshelves, and Carolina found the noise distracting.
　　"He's not even good-looking!" she muttered angrily, glaring at Krum's sharp profile.
　　"They only like him because he's famous! They wouldn't look twice at him if he couldn't do that WonkyFaint thing -"
　　"Wronski Feint," said Roberto, through gritted teeth. Quite apart from liking to get Quidditch terms correct, it caused him another pang to imagine Diego's expression if he could have heard Carolina talking about Wonky-Faints.
　　It is a strange thing, but when you are dreading something, and would give anything to slow down time, it has a disobliging habit of speeding up. The days until the first task seemed to slip by as though someone had fixed the clocks to work at double speed.
　　Roberto's feeling of barely controlled panic was with him wherever he went, as everpresent as the snide comments about the Daily Prophet article.
　　On the Saturday before the first task, all students in the third year and above were permitted to visit the village of Hogsmeade. Carolina told Roberto that it would do him good to get away from the castle for a bit, and Roberto didn't need much persuasion.
　　"What about Diego, though?" he said. "Don't you want to go with him?"
　　"Oh. . . well.. ." Carolina went slightly pink. "I thought we might meet up with him in the Three Broomsticks. . . ."
　　"No," said Roberto flatly.
　　"Oh Roberto, this is so stupid -"
　　"I'll come, but I'm not meeting Diego, and I'm wearing my Invisibility Cloak."
　　"Oh all right then. . ." Carolina snapped, "but I hate talking to you in that cloak, I never know if I'm looking at you or not."
　　So Roberto put on his Invisibility Cloak in the dormitory, went back downstairs, and together he and Carolina set off for Hogsmeade.
　　Roberto felt wonderfully free under the cloak; he watched other students walking past them as they entered the village, most of them sporting Support Nicolas Ortega! badges, but no horrible remarks came his way for a change, and nobody was quoting that stupid article.
　　"People keep looking at me now," said Carolina grumpily as they came out of Honeydukes Sweetshop later, eating large cream-filled chocolates. "They think I'm talking to myself."
　　"Don't move your lips so much then."
　　"Come on, please just take off your cloak for a bit, no one's going to bother you here."
　　"Oh yeah?" said Roberto. "Look behind you."
　　Rita Skeeter and her photographer friend had just emerged from the Three Broomsticks pub.
　　Talking in low voices, they passed right by Carolina without hooking at her. Roberto backed into the wall of Honeydukes to stop Rita Skeeter from hitting him with her crocodile-skin handbag. When they were gone, Roberto said, "She's staying in the village.
　　I bet she's coming to watch the first task."
　　As he said it, his stomach flooded with a wave of molten panic. He didn't mention this; he and Carolina hadn't discussed what was coming in the first task much; he had the feeling she didn't want to think about it.
　　"She's gone," said Carolina, looking right through Roberto toward the end of the street.
　　"Why don't we go and have a butterbeer in the Three Broomsticks, it's a bit cold, isn't it? You don't have to talk to Diego!" she added irritably, correctly interpreting his silence.
　　The Three Broomsticks was packed, mainly with Hogwarts students enjoying their free afternoon, but also with a variety of magical people Roberto rarely saw anywhere else.
　　Roberto supposed that as Hogsmeade was the only all-wizard village in Britain, it was a bit of a haven for creatures like hags, who were not as adept as wizards at disguising themselves.
　　It was very hard to move through crowds in the Invisibility Cloak, in case you accidentally trod on someone, which tended to lead to awkward questions. Roberto edged slowly toward a spare table in the corner while Carolina went to buy drinks. On his way through the pub, Roberto spotted Diego, who was sitting with Pablo, Luis, and Lee Jordan.
　　Resisting the urge to give Diego a good hard poke in the back of the head, he finally reached the table and sat down at it.
　　Carolina joined him a moment later and slipped him a butterbeer under his cloak.
　　"I look like such an idiot, sitting here on my own," she muttered. "Lucky I brought something to do."
　　And she pulled out a notebook in which she had been keeping a record of S.P.E.W. members.
　　Roberto saw his and Diego's names at the top of the very short list. It seemed a long time ago that they had sat making up those predictions together, and Carolina had turned up
　　and appointed them secretary and treasurer.
　　"You know, maybe I should try and get some of the villagers involved in S.P.E.W.,"
　　Carolina said thoughtfully, looking around the pub.
　　"Yeah, right," said Roberto. He took a swig of butterbeer under his cloak. "Carolina, when are you going to give up on this spew stuff?"
　　"When house-elves have decent wages and working conditions!" she hissed back. "You know, I'm starting to think it's time for more direct action. I wonder how you get into the school kitchens?"
　　"No idea, ask Pablo and Luis," said Roberto.
　　Carolina lapsed into thoughtful silence, while Roberto drank his butterbeer, watching the people in the pub. All of them looked cheerful and relaxed. Ernie Macmillan and Hannah Abbot were swapping Paulacolate Frog cards at a nearby table; both of them sporting Support Nicolas Ortega! badges on their cloaks. Right over by the door he saw Paula and a large group of her Ravenclaw friends. She wasn't wearing a Nicolas badge though. . . . This cheered up Roberto very slightly.
　　What wouldn't he have given to be one of these peophe, sitting around laughing and talking, with nothing to worry about but homework? He imagined how it would have felt to be here if his name hadn't come out of the Goblet of Fire. He wouldn't be wearing the Invisibility Cloak, for one thing. Diego would be sitting with him. The three of them would probably be happily imagining what deadly dangerous task the school champions would be facing on Tuesday. He'd have been really hooking forward to it, watching them do whatever it was...cheering on Nicolas with everyone else, safe in a seat at the back of the stands...
　　He wondered how the other champions were feeling. Every time he had seen Nicolas lately, he had been surrounded by admirers and looking nervous but excited. Roberto glimpsed Camila Saenz from time to time in the corridors; she looked exactly as she always did, haughty and unruffled. And Krum just sat in the library, poring over books.
　　Roberto thought of Gustavo, and the tight, tense knot in his chest seemed to ease slightly.
　　He would be speaking to him in just over twelve hours, for tonight was the night they were meeting at the common room fire - assuming nothing went wrong, as everything else had done lately...
　　"Look, it's Villalba!" said Carolina.
　　The back of Villalba's enormous shaggy head - he had mercifully abandoned his bunches -emerged over the crowd. Roberto wondered why he hadn't spotted him at once, as Villalba was so large, but standing up carefully, he saw that Villalba had been leaning low, talking to Professor Acosta. Villalba had his usual enormous tankard in front of him, but Acosta was drinking from his hip flask. Madam Rosmerta, the pretty landlady, didn't seem to think much of this; she was looking askance at Acosta as she collected glasses from tables around them. Perhaps she thought it was an insult to her mulled mead, but Roberto knew better. Acosta had told them all during their last Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson that he preferred to prepare his own food and drink at all times, as it was so easy for Dark wizards to poison an unattended cup.
　　As Roberto watched, he saw Villalba and Acosta get up to leave. He waved, then remembered that Villalba couldn't see him. Acosta, however, paused, his magical eye on the corner where Roberto was standing. He tapped Villalba in the small of the back (being unable to reach his shoulder), muttered something to him, and then the pair of them made their way back across the pub toward Roberto and Carolina's table.
　　"All right, Carolina?" said Villalba loudly.
　　"Hello," said Carolina, smiling back.
　　Acosta limped around the table and bent down; Roberto thought he was reading the S.P.E.W.
　　notebook, until he muttered, "Nice cloak, Gonzales."
　　Roberto stared at him in amazement. The large chunk missing from Acosta's nose was particularly obvious at a few inches' distance. Acosta grinned.
　　"Can your eye - I mean, can you - ?"
　　"Yeah, it can see through Invisibility Cloaks," Acosta said quietly. "And it's come in useful at times, I can tell you."
　　Villalba was beaming down at Roberto too. Roberto knew Villalba couldn't see him, but Acosta had obviously told Villalba he was there. Villalba now bent down on the pretext of reading the S.P.E.W. notebook as well, and said in a whisper so low that only Roberto could hear it, "Roberto, meet me tonight at midnight at me cabin. Wear that cloak."
　　Straightening up, Villalba said loudly, "Nice ter see yeh, Carolina," winked, and departed.
　　Acosta followed him.
　　"Why does Villalba want me to meet him at midnight?" Roberto said, very surprised.
　　"Does he?" said Carolina, looking startled. "I wonder what he's up to? I don't know whether you should go, Roberto. . . ." She looked nervously around and hissed, "It might make you late for Gustavo."
　　It was true that going down to Villalba's at midnight would mean cutting his meeting with Gustavo very fine indeed; Carolina suggested sending Hedwig down to Villalba's to tell him he couldn't go - always assuming she would consent to take the note, of course - Roberto, however, thought it better just to be quick at whatever Villalba wanted him for. He was very curious to know what this might be; Villalba had never asked Roberto to visit him so late at night.
　　At half past eleven that evening, Roberto, who had pretended to go up to bed early, pulled the Invisibility Cloak back over himself and crept back downstairs through the common room. Quite a few people were still in there. The Creevey brothers had managed to get hold of a stack of Support Nicolas Ortega! badges and were trying to bewitch them to make them say Support Roberto Gonzales! instead. So far, however, all they had managed to do was get the badges stuck on GONZALES STINKS. Roberto crept past them to the portrait hole and waited for a minute or so, keeping an eye on his watch. Then Carolina opened the Fat Lady for him from outside as they had planned. He slipped past her with a whispered "Thanks!" and set off through the castle.
　　The grounds were very dark. Roberto walked down the lawn toward the lights shining in Villalba's cabin. The inside of the enormous Beauxbatons carriage was also lit up; Roberto could hear Madame Maxime talking inside it as he knocked on Villalba's front door.
　　"You there, Roberto?" Villalba whispered, opening the door and looking around.
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, slipping inside the cabin and pulling the cloak down off his head.
　　"What's up?"
　　"Got summat ter show yeh," said Villalba.
　　There was an air of enormous excitement about Villalba. He was wearing a flower that resembled an oversized artichoke in his buttonhole. It looked as though he had abandoned the use of axle grease, but he had certainly attempted to comb his hair - Roberto could see the comb's broken teeth tangled in it.
　　"What're you showing me?" Roberto said warily, wondering if the skrewts had laid eggs, or Villalba had managed to buy another giant three-headed dog off a stranger in a pub.
　　"Come with me, keep quiet, an' keep yerself covered with that cloak," said Villalba. "We won' take Fang, he won' like it. . .
　　"Listen, Villalba, I can't stay long. . . . I've got to be back up at the castle by one o'clock -"
　　But Villalba wasn't listening; he was opening the cabin door and striding off into the night. Roberto hurried to follow and found, to his great surprise, that Villalba was leading him to the Beauxbatons carriage.
　　"Villalba, what - ?"
　　"Shhh!" said Villalba, and he knocked three times on the door bearing the crossed golden wands.
　　Madame Maxime opened it. She was wearing a silk shawl wrapped around her massive shoulders. She smiled when she saw Villalba.
　　"Ah, 'Agrid . . . it is time?"
　　"Bong-sewer," said Villalba, beaming at her, and holding out a hand to help her down the golden steps.
　　Madame Maxime closed the door behind her, Villalba offered her his arm, and they set off around the edge of the paddock containing Madame Maxime's giant winged horses, with Roberto, totally bewildered, running to keep up with them. Had Villalba wanted to show him Madame Maxime? He could see her any old time he wanted.. . she wasn't exactly hard to miss....
　　But it seemed that Madame Maxime was in for the same treat as Roberto, because after a while she said playfully, "Wair is it you are taking me, 'Agrid?"
　　"Yeh'll enjoy this," said Villalba gruffly, "worth seein', trust me. On'y - don' go tellin' anyone I showed yeh, right? Yeh're not s'posed ter know."
　　"Of course not," said Madame Maxime, fluttering her long black eyelashes.
　　And still they walked, Roberto getting more and more irritated as he jogged along in their wake, checking his watch every now and then. Villalba had some harebrained scheme in hand, which might make him miss Gustavo. If they didn't get there soon, he was going to turn
　　around, go straight back to the castle, and leave Villalba to enjoy his moonlit stroll with Madame Maxime.
　　But then - when they had walked so far around the perimeter of the forest that the castle and the lake were out of sight - Roberto heard something. Men were shouting up ahead. . .
　　then came a deafening, earsplitting roar. . .
　　Villalba led Madame Maxime around a clump of trees and came to a halt. Roberto hurried up alongside them - for a split second, he thought he was seeing bonfires, and men darting around them - and then his mouth fell open.
　　Dragons.
　　Four fully grown, enormous, vicious-looking dragons were rearing onto their hind legs inside an enclosure fenced with thick planks of wood, roaring and snorting - torrents of fire were shooting into the dark sky from their open, fanged mouths, fifty feet above the ground on their outstretched necks. There was a silvery-blue one with long, pointed horns, snapping and snarling at the wizards on the ground; a smooth-scaled green one, which was writhing and stamping with all its might; a red one with an odd fringe of fine gold spikes around its face, which was shooting mushroom-shaped fire clouds into the air; and a gigantic black one, more lizard-hike than the others, which was nearest to them.
　　At least thirty wizards, seven or eight to each dragon, were attempting to control them, pulling on the chains connected to heavy leather straps around their necks and legs.
　　Mesmerized, Roberto looked up, high above him, and saw the eyes of the black dragon, with vertical pupils like a cat's, bulging with either fear or rage, he couldn't tell which. .
　　. . It was making a horrible noise, a yowling, screeching scream.
　　"Keep back there, Villalba!" yelled a wizard near the fence, straining on the chain he was holding. "They can shoot fire at a range of twenty feet, you know! I've seen this Horntail do forty!"
　　"Is'n' it beautiful?" said Villalba softly.
　　"It's no good!" yelled another wizard. "Stunning Spells, on the count of three!"
　　Roberto saw each of the dragon keepers pull out his wand.
　　"Stupefy!" they shouted in unison, and the Stunning Spells shot into the darkness like fiery rockets, bursting in showers of stars on the dragons' scaly hides -Roberto watched the dragon nearest to them teeter dangerously on its back legs; its jaws stretched wide in a silent howl; its nostrils were suddenly devoid of flame, though still smoking - then, very slowly, it fell. Several tons of sinewy, scaly-black dragon hit the ground with a thud that Roberto could have sworn made the trees behind him quake.
　　The dragon keepers lowered their wands and walked forward to their fallen charges, each of which was the size of a small hill. They hurried to tighten the chains and fasten them securely to iron pegs, which they forced deep into the ground with their wands.
　　"Wan' a closer look?" Villalba asked Madame Maxime excitedly. The pair of them moved right up to the fence, and Roberto followed. The wizard who had warned Villalba not to come any closer turned, and Roberto realized who it was: Charlie Lopez.
　　"All right, Villalba?" he panted, coming over to talk. "They should be okay now - we put them out with a Sleeping Draft on the way here, thought it might be better for them to wake up in the dark and the quiet - but, like you saw, they weren't happy, not happy at all -"
　　"What breeds you got here, Charlie?" said Villalba, gazing at the closest dragon, the black one, with something chose to reverence. Its eyes were still just open. Roberto could see a strip of gleaming yellow beneath its wrinkled black eyelid.
　　"This is a Hungarian Horntail," said Charlie. "There's a Common Welsh Green over there, the smaller one -- a Swedish Short-Snout, that blue-gray -- and a Chinese Fireball, that's the red."
　　Charlie looked around; Madame Maxime was strolling away around the edge of the enclosure, gazing at the stunned dragons.
　　"I didn't know you were bringing her, Villalba," Charlie said, frowning. "The champions aren't supposed to know what's coming - she's bound to tell her student, isn't she?"
　　"Jus' thought she'd like ter see 'em," shrugged Villalba, still gazing, enraptured, at the dragons.
　　"Really romantic date, Villalba," said Charlie, shaking his head.
　　"Four. . ." said Villalba, "so it's one fer each o' the champions, is it? What've they gotta do - fight 'em?"
　　"Just get past them, I think," said Charlie. "We'll be on hand if it gets nasty, Extinguishing Spells at the ready. They wanted nesting mothers, I don't know why. . .
　　but I tell you this, I don't envy the one who gets the Horntail. Vicious thing. Its back end's as dangerous as its front, look."
　　Charlie pointed toward the Horntail's tail, and Roberto saw long, bronze-colored spikes protruding along it every few inches.
　　Five of Charlie's fellow keepers staggered up to the Horntail at that moment, carrying a clutch of huge granite-gray eggs between them in a blanket. They placed them carefully at the Horntail's side. Villalba let out a moan of longing.
　　"I've got them counted, Villalba," said Charlie sternly. Then he said, "How's Roberto?"
　　"Fine," said Villalba. He was still gazing at the eggs.
　　"Just hope he's still fine after he's faced this lot," said Charlie grimly, looking out over the dragons' enclosure. "I didn't dare tell Mum what he's got to do for the first task; she's already having kittens about him. . . ." Charlie imitated his mother's anxious voice. "How could they let him enter that tournament, he's much too young! I thought they were all safe, I thought there was going to be an age limit!' She was in floods after that Daily Prophet article about him. 'He still cries about his parents!
　　Oh bless him, I never knew!"
　　Roberto had had enough. Trusting to the fact that Villalba wouldn't miss him, with the attractions of four dragons and Madame Maxime to occupy him, he turned silently and began to walk away, back to the castle.
　　He didn't know whether he was glad he'd seen what was coming or not. Perhaps this way was better. The first shock was over now. Maybe if he'd seen the dragons for the first time on Tuesday, he would have passed out cold in front of the whole school. . . but maybe he would anyway. .. . He was going to be armed with his wand - which, just now, felt like nothing more than a narrow strip of wood -- against a fifty-foot-high, scaly, spike-ridden, fire-breathing dragon. And he had to get past it. With everyone watching.
　　How?
　　Roberto sped up, skirting the edge of the forest; he had just under fifteen minutes to get back to the fireside and talk to Gustavo, and he couldn't remember, ever, wanting to talk to someone more than he did right now -- when, without warning, he ran into something very solid.
　　Roberto fell backward, his glasses askew, clutching the cloak around him. A voice nearby said, "Ouch! Who's there?"
　　Roberto hastily checked that the cloak was covering him and hay very still, staring up at the dark outline of the wizard he had hit. He recognized the goatee. . . it was Morales.
　　"Who's there?" said Morales again, very suspiciously, looking around in the darkness.
　　Roberto remained still and silent. After a minute or so, Morales seemed to decide that he had hit some sort of animal; he was looking around at waist height, as though expecting to see a dog. Then he crept back under the cover of the trees and started to edge forward toward the place where the dragons were.
　　Very slowly and very carefully, Roberto got to his feet and set off again as fast as he could without making too much noise, hurrying through the darkness back toward Hogwarts.
　　He had no doubt whatsoever what Morales was up to. He had sneaked off his ship to try and find out what the first task was going to be. He might even have spotted Villalba and Madame Maxime heading off around the forest together - they were hardly difficult to spot at a distance. . . and now all Morales had to do was follow the sound of voices, and he, like Madame Maxime, would know what was in store for the champions.
　　By the looks of it, the only champion who would be facing the unknown on Tuesday was Nicolas.
　　Roberto reached the castle, slipped in through the front doors, and began to climb the marble stairs; he was very out of breath, but he didn't dare slow down. . . . He had less than five minutes to get up to the fire.
　　"Balderdash!" he gasped at the Fat Lady, who was snoozing in her frame in front of the portrait hole.
　　"If you say so," she muttered sleepily, without opening her eyes, and the picture swung forward to admit him. Roberto climbed inside. The common room was deserted, and, judging by the fact that it smelled quite normal, Carolina had not needed to set off any Dungbombs to ensure that he and Gustavo got privacy.
　　Roberto pulled off the Invisibility Cloak and threw himself into an armchair in front of the fire. The room was in semidarkness; the flames were the only source of light.
　　Nearby, on a table, the Support Nicolas Ortega! badges the Creeveys had been trying to
　　improve were glinting in the firelight. They now read GONZALES REALLY STINKS. Roberto looked back into the flames, and jumped.
　　Gustavo's head was sitting in the fire. If Roberto hadn't seen Mr. Ortega do exactly this back in the Lopezs' kitchen, it would have scared him out of his wits. Instead, his face breaking into the first smile he had worn for days, he scrambled out of his chair, crouched down by the hearth, and said, "Gustavo - how're you doing?"
　　Gustavo looked different from Roberto's memory of him. When they had said good-bye, Gustavo's face had been gaunt and sunken, surrounded by a quantity of long, black, matted hair - but the hair was short and clean now, Gustavo's face was fuller, and he looked younger, much more like the only photograph Roberto had of him, which had been taken at the Gonzaless' wedding.
　　"Never mind me, how are you?" said Gustavo seriously.
　　"I'm -" For a second, Roberto tried to say "fine" - but he couldn't do it. Before he could stop himself, he was talking more than he'd talked in days - about how no one believed he hadn't entered the tournament of his own free will, how Rita Skeeter had lied about him in the Daily Prophet, how he couldn't walk down a corridor without being sneered at - and about Diego, Diego not believing him, Diego's jealousy...
　　". . . and now Villalba's just shown me what's coming in the first task, and it's dragons, Gustavo, and I'm a goner," he finished desperately.
　　Gustavo looked at him, eyes full of concern, eyes that had not yet lost the look that Azkaban had given them - that deadened, haunted look He had let Roberto talk himself into silence without interruption, but now he said, "Dragons we can deal with, Roberto, but we'll get to that in a minute - I haven't got long here. . . I've broken into a wizarding house to use the fire, but they could be back at any time. There are things I need to warn you about."
　　"What?" said Roberto, feeling his spirits slip a further few notches.. . . Surely there could be nothing worse than dragons coming?
　　"Morales," said Gustavo. "Roberto, he was a Death Eater. You know what Death Eaters are, don't you?"
　　"Yes - he - what?"
　　"He was caught, he was in Azkaban with me, but he got released. I'd bet everything that's why Dominguez wanted an Auror at Hogwarts this year - to keep an eye on him.
　　Acosta caught Morales. Put him into Azkaban in the first place."
　　"Morales got released?" Roberto said slowly - his brain seemed to be struggling to absorb yet another piece of shocking information. "Why did they release him?"
　　"He did a deal with the Ministry of Magic," said Gustavo bitterly. "He said he'd seen the error of his ways, and then he named names. . . he put a load of other people into Azkaban in his place. . . . He's not very popular in there, I can tell you. And since he got out, from what I can tell, he's been teaching the Dark Arts to every student who passes through that school of his. So watch out for the Durmstrang champion as well."
　　"Okay," said Roberto slowly. "But. . . are you saying Morales put my name in the goblet?
　　Because if he did, he's a really good actor. He seemed furious about it. He wanted to stop me from competing."
　　"We know he's a good actor," said Gustavo, "because he convinced the Ministry of Magic to set him free, didn't he? Now, I've been keeping an eye on the Daily Prophet, Roberto.."
　　"- you and the rest of the world," said Roberto bitterly.
　　"- and reading between the lines of that Skeeter woman's article last month, Acosta was attacked the night before he started at Hogwarts. Yes, I know she says it was another false alarm," Gustavo said hastily, seeing Roberto about to speak, "but I don't think so, somehow. I think someone tried to stop him from getting to Hogwarts. I think someone knew their job would be a lot more difficult with him around. And no one's going to look into it too closely; Mad-Eye's heard intruders a bit too often. But that doesn't mean he can't still spot the real thing. Acosta was the best Auror the Ministry ever had."
　　"So. . . what are you saying?" said Roberto slowly. "Morales's trying to kill me? But - why?"
　　Gustavo hesitated.
　　"I've been nearing some very strange things," he said slowly. "The Death Eaters seem to be a bit more active than usual lately. They showed themselves at the Quidditch World Cup, didn't they? Someone set off the Dark Mark.. . and then - did you hear about that Ministry of Magic witch who's gone missing?"
　　"Bertha Jorkins?" said Roberto.
　　"Exactly. . . she disappeared in Albania, and that's definitely where Salvador was rumored to be last. . . and she would have known the Triwizard Tournament was coming up, wouldn't she?"
　　"Yeah, but. . . it's not very likely she'd have walked straight into Salvador, is it?"
　　said Roberto.
　　"Listen, I knew Bertha Jorkins," said Gustavo grimly. "She was at Hogwarts when I was, a few years above your dad and me. And she was an idiot. Very nosy, but no brains, none at all. It's not a good combination, Roberto. I'd say she'd be very easy to lure into a trap."
　　"So. . . so Salvador could have found out about the tournament?" said Roberto. "Is that what you mean? You think Morales might be here on his orders?"
　　"I don't know," said Gustavo slowly, "I just don't know...Morales doesn't strike me as the type who'd go back to Salvador unless he knew Salvador was powerful enough to protect him. But whoever put your name in that goblet did it for a reason, and I can't help thinking the tournament would be a very good way to attack you and make it hook like an accident."
　　"Looks hike a really good plan from where I'm standing," said Roberto grinning bleaky.
　　"They'll just have to stand back and let the dragons do their stuff."
　　"Right - these dragons," said Gustavo, speaking very quickly now. "There's a way, Roberto.
　　Don't be tempted to try a Stunning Spell - dragons are strong and too powerfully magical to be knocked out by a single Stunner, you need about half a dozen wizards at a time to overcome a dragon -"
　　"Yeah, I know, I just saw," said Roberto.
　　"But you can do it alone," said Gustavo. "There is away, and a simple spell's all you need. Just -"
　　But Roberto held up a hand to silence him, his heart suddenly pounding as though it would burst. He could hear footsteps coming down the spiral staircase behind him.
　　"Go!" he hissed at Gustavo. " Go! There's someone coming!"
　　Roberto scrambled to his feet, hiding the fire - if someone saw Gustavo's face within the walls of Hogwarts, they would raise an almighty uproar - the Ministry would get dragged in - he, Roberto, would be questioned about Gustavo's whereabouts - Roberto heard a tiny pop! in the fire behind him and knew Gustavo had gone. He watched the bottom of the spiral staircase. Who had decided to go for a stroll at one o'clock in the morning, and stopped Gustavo from telling him how to get past a dragon?
　　It was Diego. Dressed in his maroon paisley pajamas, Diego stopped dead facing Roberto across the room, and looked around.
　　"Who were you talking to?" he said.
　　"What's that got to do with you?" Roberto snarled. "What are you doing down here at this time of night?"
　　"I just wondered where you -" Diego broke off, shrugging. "Nothing. I'm going back to bed."
　　"Just thought you'd come nosing around, did you?" Roberto shouted. He knew that Diego had no idea what he'd walked in on, knew he hadn't done it on purpose, but he didn't care -at this moment he hated everything about Diego, right down to the several inches of bare ankle showing beneath his pajama trousers.
　　"Sorry about that," said Diego, his face reddening with anger. "Should've realized you didn't want to be disturbed. I'll let you get on with practicing for your next interview in peace."
　　Roberto seized one of the GONZALES REALLY STINKS badges off the table and chucked it, as hard as he could, across the room. It hit Diego on the forehead and bounced off.
　　"There you go," Roberto said. "Something for you to wear on Tuesday. You might even have a scar now, if yon're lucky.. . . That's what you want, isn't it?"
　　He strode across the room toward the stairs; he half expected Diego to stop him, he would even have liked Diego to throw a punch at him, but Diego just stood there in his too-small pajamas, and Roberto, having stormed upstairs, lay awake in bed fuming for a long time afterward and didn't hear him come up to bed.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY - THE FIRST TASK
　　Roberto got up on Sunday morning and dressed so inattentively that it was a while before he realized he was trying to pull his hat onto his foot instead of his sock.
　　When he'd finally got all his clothes on the right parts of his body, he hurried off to find Carolina, locating her at the Gryffindor table in the Great Hall, where she was eating breakfast with Martina. Feeling too queasy to eat, Roberto waited until Carolina had swallowed her last spoonful of porridge, then dragged her out onto the grounds. There, he told her all about the dragons, and about everything Gustavo had said, while they took another long walk around the lake.
　　Alarmed as she was by Gustavo's warnings about Morales, Carolina still thought that the dragons were the more pressing problem.
　　"Let's just try and keep you alive until Tuesday evening," she said desperately, "and then we can worry about Morales."
　　They walked three times around the lake, trying all the way to think of a simple spell that would subdue a dragon. Nothing whatsoever occurred to them, so they retired to the library instead. Here, Roberto pulled down every book he could find on dragons, and both of them set to work searching through the large pile.
　　"Talon-clipping by charms. .. treating scale-rot. . .' This is no good, this is for nutters like Villalba who want to keep them healthy. ..
　　"Dragons are extremely difficult to slay, owing to the ancient magic that imbues their thick hides, which none but the most powerful spells can penetrate. . .' But Gustavo said a simple one would do it.. .
　　"Let's try some simple spellbooks, then," said Roberto, throwing aside Men Who Love Dragons Too Much.
　　He returned to the table with a pile of spellbooks, set them down, and began to flick through each in turn, Carolina whispering nonstop at his elbow.
　　"Well, there are Switching Spells. . . but what's the point of Switching it? Unless you swapped its fangs for wine-gums or something that would make it less dangerous.. . . The trouble is, like that book said, not much is going to get through a dragon's hide. . . .
　　I'd say Transfigure it, but something that big, you really haven't got a hope, I doubt even Professor Romero. . . unless you're supposed to put the spell on yourself?
　　Maybe to give yourself extra powers? But they're not simple spells, I mean, we haven't done any of those in class, I only know about them because I've been doing O.W.L.
　　practice papers. . . ."
　　"Carolina," Roberto said, through gritted teeth, "will you shut up for a bit, please? I m trying to concentrate."
　　But all that happened, when Carolina fell silent, was that Roberto's brain filled with a sort of blank buzzing, which didn't seem to allow room for concentration. He stared hopelessly down the index of Basic Hexes for the Busy and Vexed. Instant scalping. . .
　　but dragons had no hair. . . pepper breath.. . that would probably increase a dragon's firepower. . . horn tongue. . . just what he needed, to give it an extra weapon...
　　"Oh no, he's back again, why can't he read on his stupid ship?" said Carolina irritably as Viktor Krum slouched in, cast a surly look over at the pair of them, and settled himself in a distant corner with a pile of books. "Come on, Roberto, we'll go back to the common room. . . his fan club'll be here in a moment, twittering away... ."
　　And sure enough, as they left the library, a gang of girls tiptoed past them, one of them wearing a Bulgaria scarf tied around her waist.
　　Roberto barely slept that night. When he awoke on Monday morning, he seriously considered for the first time ever just running away from Hogwarts. But as he looked around the Great Hall at breakfast time, and thought about what leaving the castle would mean, he knew he couldn't do it. It was the only place he had ever been happy. . . well, he supposed he must have been happy with his parents too, but he couldn't remember that.
　　Somehow, the knowledge that he would rather be here and facing a dragon than back on Privet Drive with Leonardo was good to know; it made him feel slightly calmer. He finished his bacon with difficulty (his throat wasn't working too well), and as he and Carolina got up, he saw Nicolas Ortega leaving the Hufflepuff table.
　　Nicolas still didn't know about the dragons. . . the only champion who didn't, if Roberto was right in thinking that Maxime and Morales would have told Camila and Krum....
　　"Carolina, I'll see you in the greenhouses," Roberto said, coming to his decision as he watched Nicolas leaving the Hall. "Go on, I'll catch you up."
　　"Roberto, you'll be late, the bell's about to ring -"
　　"I'll catch you up, okay?"
　　By the time Roberto reached the bottom of the marble staircase, Nicolas was at the top. He
　　was with a load of sixth-year friends. Roberto didn't want to talk to Nicolas in front of them; they were among those who had been quoting Rita Skeeter's article at him every time he went near them. He followed Nicolas at a distance and saw that he was heading toward the Charms corridor. This gave Roberto an idea. Pausing at a distance from them, he pulled out his wand, and took careful aim.
　　"Diffindo!"
　　Nicolas's bag split. Parchment, quills, and books spilled out of it onto the floor.
　　Several bottles of ink smashed.
　　"Don't bother," said Nicolas in an exasperated voice as his friends bent down to help him.
　　"Tell Flitwick I'm coming, go on. . .
　　This was exactly what Roberto had been hoping for. He slipped his wand back into his robes, waited until Nicolas's friends had disappeared into their classroom, and hurried up the corridor, which was now empty of everyone but himself and Nicolas.
　　"Hi," said Nicolas, picking up a copy of A Guide to Advanced Transfiguration that was now splattered with ink. "My bag just split. . . brand-new and all. . ."
　　"Nicolas," said Roberto, "the first task is dragons."
　　"What?" said Nicolas, looking up.
　　"Dragons," said Roberto, speaking quickly, in case Professor Flitwick came out to see where Nicolas had got to. "They've got four, one for each of us, and we've got to get past them."
　　Nicolas stared at him. Roberto saw some of the panic he'd been feeling since Saturday night flickering in Nicolas's gray eyes.
　　"Are you sure?" Nicolas said in a hushed voice.
　　"Dead sure," said Roberto. "I've seen them."
　　"But how did you find out? We're not supposed to know. . . ."
　　"Never mind," said Roberto quickly - he knew Villalba would be in trouble if he told the truth. "But I'm not the only one who knows. Camila and Krum will know by now - Maxime and Morales both saw the dragons too."
　　Nicolas straightened up, his arms full of inky quills, parchment, and books, his ripped bag dangling off one shoulder. He stared at Roberto, and there was a puzzled, almost suspicious look in his eyes.
　　"Why are you telling me?" he asked.
　　Roberto looked at him in disbelief. He was sure Nicolas wouldn't have asked that if he had seen the dragons himself. Roberto wouldn't have let his worst enemy face those monsters unprepared - well, perhaps Sosa or Peralta...
　　"It's just . . . fair, isn't it?" he said to Nicolas. "We all know now. . . we're on an even footing, aren't we?"
　　Nicolas was still hooking at him in a slightly suspicious way when Roberto heard a familiar clunking noise behind him. He turned around and saw Mad-Eye Acosta emerging from a nearby classroom.
　　"Come with me, Gonzales," he growled. "Ortega, off you go."
　　Roberto stared apprehensively at Acosta. Had he overheard them?
　　"Er - Professor, I'm supposed to be in Herbology -"
　　"Never mind that, Gonzales. In my office, please...
　　Roberto followed him, wondering what was going to happen to him now. What if Acosta wanted to know how he'd found out about the dragons? Would Acosta go to Dominguez and tell on Villalba, or just turn Roberto into a ferret? Well, it might be easier to get past a dragon if he were a ferret, Roberto thought dully, he'd be smaller, much less easy to see from a height of fifty feet..
　　He followed Acosta into his office. Acosta closed the door behind them and turned to look at Roberto, his magical eye fixed upon him as well as the normal one.
　　"That was a very decent thing you just did, Gonzales," Acosta said quietly.
　　Roberto didn't know what to say; this wasn't the reaction he had expected at all.
　　"Sit down," said Acosta, and Roberto sat, looking around.
　　He had visited this office under two of its previous occupants. In Professor Lockhart's day, the walls had been plastered with beaming, winking pictures of Professor Lockhart himself. When Cardozo had lived here, you were more likely to come across a specimen of some fascinating new Dark creature he had procured for them to study in class. Now, however, the office was full of a number of exceptionally odd objects that Roberto supposed Acosta had used in the days when he had been an Auror.
　　On his desk stood what looked hike a large, cracked, glass spinning top; Roberto recognized
　　it at once as a Sneakoscope, because he owned one himself, though it was much smaller than Acosta's. In the corner on a small table stood an object that looked something like an extra-squiggly, golden television aerial. It was humming slightly. What appeared to be a mirror hung opposite Roberto on the wall, but it was not reflecting the room. Shadowy figures were moving around inside it, none of them clearly in focus.
　　"Like my Dark Detectors, do you?" s aid Acosta, who was watching Roberto closely.
　　"What's that?" Roberto asked, pointing at the squiggly golden aerial.
　　"Secrecy Sensor. Vibrates when it detects concealment and lies.. . no use here, of course, too much interference - students in every direction lying about why they haven't done their homework Been humming ever since I got here. I had to disable my Sneakoscope because it wouldn't stop whistling. It's extra-sensitive, picks up stuff about a mile around. Of course, it could be picking up more than kid stuff," he added in a growl.
　　"And what's the mirror for?"
　　"Oh that's my Foe-Glass. See them out there, skulking around? I'm not really in trouble until I see the whites of their eyes. That's when I open my trunk."
　　He let out a short, harsh laugh, and pointed to the large trunk under the window. It had seven keyholes in a row. Roberto wondered what was in there, until Acosta's next question brought him sharply back to earth.
　　"So. . . found out about the dragons, have you?"
　　Roberto hesitated. He'd been afraid of this - but he hadn't told Nicolas, and he certainly wasn't going to tell Acosta, that Villalba had broken the rules.
　　"It's all right," said Acosta, sitting down and stretching out his wooden leg with a groan. "Cheating's a traditional part of the Triwizard Tournament and always has been."
　　"I didn't cheat," said Roberto sharply. "It was - a sort of accident that I found out."
　　Acosta grinned. "I wasn't accusing you, laddie. I've been telling Dominguez from the start, he can be as high-minded as he likes, but you can bet old Morales and Maxime won't be. They'll have told their champions everything they can. They want to win.
　　They want to beat Dominguez. They'd like to prove he's only human."
　　Acosta gave another harsh laugh, and his magical eye swiveled around so fast it made Roberto feel queasy to watch it.
　　"So. . . got any ideas how you're going to get past your dragon yet?" said Acosta.
　　"No," said Roberto.
　　"Well, I'm not going to tell you," said Acosta gruffly. "I don't show favoritism, me.
　　I'm just going to give you some good, general advice. And the first bit is - play to your strengths."
　　"I haven't got any," said Roberto, before he could stop himself. "Excuse me," growled Acosta, "you've got strengths if I say you've got them. Think now. What are you best at?"
　　Roberto tried to concentrate. What was he best at? Well, that was easy, really -- "Quidditch," he said dully, "and a fat lot of help -"
　　"That's right," said Acosta, staring at him very hard, his magical eye barely moving at all. "You're a damn good flier from what I've heard."
　　"Yeah, but.. ." Roberto stared at him. "I'm not allowed a broom, I've only got my wand..."
　　"My second piece of general advice," said Acosta loudly, interrupting him, "is to use a nice, simple spell that will enable you to get what you need."
　　Roberto looked at him blankly. What did he need?
　　"Come on, boy. . ." whispered Acosta. "Put them together... it's not that difficult..."
　　And it clicked. He was best at flying. He needed to pass the dragon in the air. For that, he needed his Firebolt. And for his Fire-bolt, he needed - "Carolina," Roberto whispered, when he had sped into greenhouse three minutes later, uttering a hurried apology to Professor Sprout as he passed her. "Carolina - I need you to help me."
　　"What d'you think I've been trying to do, Roberto?" she whispered back, her eyes round with anxiety over the top of the quivering Flutterby Bush she was pruning.
　　"Carolina, I need to learn how to do a Summoning Charm properly by tomorrow afternoon."
　　And so they practiced. They didn't have lunch, but headed for a free classroom, where Roberto tried with all his might to make various objects fly across the room toward him.
　　He was still having problems. The books and quills kept losing heart halfway across the room and dropping hike stones to the floor.
　　"Concentrate, Roberto, concentrate. . . ."
　　"What d'you think I'm trying to do?" said Roberto angrily. "A great big dragon keeps popping up in my head for some reason...Okay, try again. . . ."
　　He wanted to skip Divination to keep practicing, but Carolina refused point-blank to skive off Arithmancy, and there was no point in staying without her. He therefore had to endure over an hour of Professor Trelawney, who spent half the lesson telling everyone that the position of Mars with relation to Saturn at that moment meant that people born in July were in great danger of sudden, violent deaths.
　　"Well, that's good," said Roberto loudly, his temper getting the better of him, "just as long as it's not drawn-out. I don't want to suffer."
　　Diego looked for a moment as though he was going to laugh; he certainly caught Roberto's eye for the first time in days, but Roberto was still feeling too resentful toward Diego to care.
　　He spent the rest of the lesson trying to attract small objects toward him under the table with his wand. He managed to make a fly zoom straight into his hand, though he wasn't entirely sure that was his prowess at Summoning Charms - perhaps the fly was just stupid.
　　He forced down some dinner after Divination, then returned to the empty classroom with Carolina, using the Invisibility Cloak to avoid the teachers. They kept practicing until past midnight. They would have stayed longer, but Peeves turned up and, pretending to think that Roberto wanted things thrown at him, started chucking chairs across the room.
　　Roberto and Carolina left in a hurry before the noise attracted Filch, and went back to the Gryffindor common room, which was now mercifully empty.
　　At two o'clock in the morning, Roberto stood near the fireplace, surrounded by heaps of objects: books, quills, several upturned chairs, an old set of Gobstones, and Mauricio's toad, Trevor. Only in the last hour had Roberto really got the hang of the Summoning Charm.
　　"That's better, Roberto, that's loads better," Carolina said, looking exhausted but very pleased.
　　"Well, now we know what to do next time I can't manage a spell," Roberto said, throwing a rune dictionary back to Carolina, so he could try again, "threaten me with a dragon.
　　Right..." He raised his wand once more. "Accio Dictionary!"
　　The heavy book soared out of Carolina's hand, flew across the room, and Roberto caught it.
　　"Roberto, I really think you've got it!" said Carolina delightedly.
　　"Just as long as it works tomorrow," Roberto said. "The Firebolt's going to be much farther away than the stuff in here, it's going to be in the castle, and I'm going to be out there on the grounds. . . ."
　　"That doesn't matter," said Carolina firmly." Just as long as you're concentrating really, really hard on it, it'll come. Roberto, we'd better get some sleep.. . you're going to need it."
　　Roberto had been focusing so hard on learning the Summoning Charm that evening that some of his blind panic had heft him. It returned in full measure, however, on the following morning. The atmosphere in the school was one of great tension and excitement. Lessons were to stop at midday, giving all the students time to get down to the dragons' enclosure - though of course, they didn't yet know what they would find there.
　　Roberto felt oddly separate from everyone around him, whether they were wishing him good luck or hissing "We'll have a box of tissues ready, Gonzales" as he passed. It was a state of nervousness so advanced that he wondered whether he mightn't just lose his head when they tried to lead him out to his dragon, and start trying to curse everyone in sight.
　　Time was behaving in a more peculiar fashion than ever, rushing past in great dollops, so that one moment he seemed to be sitting down in his first lesson, History of Magic, and the next, walking into lunch.. . and then (where had the morning gone? the last of the dragon-free hours?), Professor Romero was hurrying over to him in the Great Hall.
　　Lots of people were watching.
　　"Gonzales, the champions have to come down onto the grounds now... . You have to get ready for your first task."
　　"Okay," said Roberto, standing up, his fork falling onto his plate with a clatter.
　　"Good luck, Roberto," Carolina whispered. "You'll be fine!"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto in a voice that was most unlike his own.
　　He heft the Great Hall with Professor Romero. She didn't seem herself either; in fact, she looked nearly as anxious as Carolina. As she walked him down the stone steps
　　and out into the cold November afternoon, she put her hand on his shoulder.
　　"Now, don't panic," she said, "just keep a cool head. . . . We've got wizards standing by to control the situation if it gets out of hand. . . . The main thing is just to do your best, and nobody will think any the worse of you. . . . Are you all right?"
　　"Yes," Roberto heard himself say. "Yes, I'm fine."
　　She was leading him toward the place where the dragons were, around the edge of the forest, but when they approached the clump of trees behind which the enclosure would be clearly visible, Roberto saw that a tent had been erected, its entrance facing them, screening the dragons from view.
　　"You're to go in here with the other champions," said Professor Romero, in a rather shaky sort of voice, "and wait for your turn, Gonzales. Mr. Bagman is in there. . . he'll be telling you the - the procedure. . . . Good luck."
　　"Thanks," said Roberto, in a flat, distant voice. She left him at the entrance of the tent. Roberto went inside.
　　Camila Saenz was sitting in a corner on a how wooden stool. She didn't look nearly as composed as usual, but rather pale and clammy. Viktor Krum looked even surlier than usual, which Roberto supposed was his way of showing nerves. Nicolas was pacing up and down. When Roberto entered, Nicolas gave him a small smile, which Roberto returned, feeling the muscles in his face working rather hard, as though they had forgotten how to do it.
　　"Roberto! Good-o!" said Bagman happily, looking around at him. "Come in, come in, make yourself at home!"
　　Bagman looked somehow like a slightly overblown cartoon figure, standing amid all the pale-faced champions. He was wearing his old Wasp robes again.
　　"Well, now we're all here - time to fill you in!" said Bagman brightly. "When the audience has assembled, I'm going to be offering each of you this bag" - he held up a small sack of purple silk and shook it at them - "from which you will each select a small model of the thing you are about to face! There are different - er - varieties, you see.
　　And I have to tell you something else too.. . ah, yes... your task is to collect the golden egg!"
　　Roberto glanced around. Nicolas had nodded once, to show that he understood Bagman's words, and then started pacing around the tent again; he looked slightly green. Camila Saenz and Krum hadn't reacted at all. Perhaps they thought they might be sick if they opened their mouths; that was certainly how Roberto felt. But they, at least, had volunteered for this. .
　　And in no time at all, hundreds upon hundreds of pairs of feet could be heard passing the tent, their owners talking excitedly, laughing, joking. . . . Roberto felt as separate from the crowd as though they were a different species. And then - it seemed like about a second later to Roberto - Bagman was opening the neck of the purple silk sack.
　　"Ladies first," he said, offering it to Camila Saenz.
　　She put a shaking hand inside the bag and drew out a tiny, perfect model of a dragon - a Welsh Green. It had the number two around its neck And Roberto knew, by the fact that Camila showed no sign of surprise, but rather a determined resignation, that he had been right: Madame Maxime had told her what was coming.
　　The same held true for Krum. He pulled out the scarlet Chinese Fireball. It had a number three around its neck. He didn't even blink, just sat back down and stared at the ground.
　　Nicolas put his hand into the bag, and out came the blueish-gray Swedish Short-Snout, the number one tied around its neck. Knowing what was left, Roberto put his hand into the silk bag and pulled out the Hungarian Horntail, and the number four. It stretched its wings as he looked down at it, and bared its minuscule fangs.
　　"Well, there you are!" said Bagman. "You have each pulled out the dragon you will face, and the numbers refer to the order in which you are to take on the dragons, do you see?
　　Now, I'm going to have to leave you in a moment, because I'm commentating. Mr. Ortega, you're first, just go out into the enclosure when you hear a whistle, all right? Now. .
　　. Roberto. . . could I have a quick word? Outside?"
　　"Er. . . yes," said Roberto blankly, and he got up and went out of the tent with Bagman, who walked him a short distance away, into the trees, and then turned to him with a fatherly expression on his face.
　　"Feeling all right, Roberto? Anything I can get you?"
　　"What?" said Roberto. "I - no, nothing."
　　"Got a plan?" said Bagman, lowering his voice conspiratorially. "Because I don't mind
　　sharing a few pointers, if you'd like them, you know. I mean," Bagman continued, lowering his voice still further, "you're the underdog here, Roberto. . . . Anything I can do to help. . ."
　　"No," said Roberto so quickly he knew he had sounded rude, "no - I - I know what I'm going to do, thanks."
　　"Nobody would know, Roberto," said Bagman, winking at him.
　　"No, I'm fine," said Roberto, wondering why he kept telling people this, and wondering whether he had ever been less fine. "I've got a plan worked out, I -"
　　A whistle had blown somewhere.
　　"Good lord, I've got to run!" said Bagman in alarm, and he hurried off.
　　Roberto walked back to the tent and saw Nicolas emerging from it, greener than ever. Roberto tried to wish him luck as he walked past, but all that came out of his mouth was a sort of hoarse grunt.
　　Roberto went back inside to Camila and Krum. Seconds hater, they heard the roar of the crowd, which meant Nicolas had entered the enclosure and was now face-to-face with the living counterpart of his model.
　　It was worse than Roberto could ever have imagined, sitting there and listening. The crowd screamed. . . yelled.. . gasped like a single many-headed entity, as Nicolas did whatever he was doing to get past the Swedish Short-Snout. Krum was still staring at the ground.
　　Camila had now taken to retracing Nicolas's steps, around and around the tent. And Bagman's commentary made everything much, much worse.. . . Horrible pictures formed in Roberto's mind as he heard: "Oooh, narrow miss there, very narrow". . . "He's taking risks, this one!". . . "Clever move - pity it didn't work!"
　　And then, after about fifteen minutes, Roberto heard the deafening roar that could mean only one thing: Nicolas had gotten past his dragon and captured the golden egg.
　　"Very good indeed!" Bagman was shouting. "And now the marks from the judges!"
　　But he didn't shout out the marks; Roberto supposed the judges were holding them up and showing them to the crowd.
　　"One down, three to go!" Bagman yelled as the whistle blew again. "Miss Saenz, if you please!"
　　Camila was trembling from head to foot; Roberto felt more warmly toward her than he had done so far as she heft the tent with her head held high and her hand clutching her wand. He and Krum were left alone, at opposite sides of the tent, avoiding each other's gaze.
　　The same process started again. . . ."Oh I'm not sure that was wise!" they could hear Bagman shouting gleefully. "Oh. . . nearly! Careful now. . . good lord, I thought she'd had it then!"
　　Ten minutes later, Roberto heard the crowd erupt into applause once more. . . . Camila must have been successful too. A pause, while Camila's marks were being shown. . . more clapping.. . then, for the third time, the whistle.
　　"And here comes Mr. Krum!" cried Bagman, and Krum slouched out, leaving Roberto quite alone.
　　He felt much more aware of his body than usual; very aware of the way his heart was pumping fast, and his fingers tingling with fear. . . yet at the same time, he seemed to be outside himself, seeing the walls of the tent, and hearing the crowd, as though from far away.
　　"Very daring!" Bagman was yelling, and Roberto heard the Chinese Fireball emit a horrible, roaring shriek, while the crowd drew its collective breath. "That's some nerve he's showing - and - yes, he's got the egg!"
　　Applause shattered the wintery air like breaking glass; Krum had finished - it would be Roberto's turn any moment.
　　He stood up, noticing dimly that his legs seemed to be made of marshmallow. He waited.
　　And then he heard the whistle blow. He walked out through the entrance of the tent, the panic rising into a crescendo inside him. And now he was walking past the trees, through a gap in the enclosure fence.
　　He saw everything in front of him as though it was a very highly colored dream. There were hundreds and hundreds of faces staring down at him from stands that had been magicked there since he'd last stood on this spot. And there was the Horntail, at the other end of the enclosure, crouched low over her clutch of eggs, her wings half-furled, her evil, yellow eyes upon him, a monstrous, scaly, black lizard, thrashing her spiked tail, heaving yard-long gouge marks in the hard ground. The crowd was making a great deal of noise, but whether friendly or not, Roberto didn't know or care. It was time to do
　　what he had to do. . . to focus his mind, entirely and absolutely, upon the thing that was his only chance.
　　He raised his wand.
　　"Accio Firebolt!" he shouted.
　　Roberto waited, every fiber of him hoping, praying. . . . If it hadn't worked. . . if it wasn't coming. . . He seemed to be looking at everything around him through some sort of shimmering, transparent barrier, like a heat haze, which made the enclosure and the hundreds of faces around him swim strangely....
　　And then he heard it, speeding through the air behind him; he turned and saw his Firebolt hurtling toward him around the edge of the woods, soaring into the enclosure, and stopping dead in midair beside him, waiting for him to mount. The crowd was making even more noise. . . . Bagman was shouting something. . . but Roberto's ears were not working properly anymore. . . listening wasn't important....
　　He swung his leg over the broom and kicked off from the ground. And a second later, something miraculous happened....
　　As he soared upward, as the wind rushed through his hair, as the crowd's faces became mere flesh-colored pinpnicks below, and the Horntail shrank to the size of a dog, he realized that he had heft not only the ground behind, but also his fear. . . . He was back where he belonged....
　　This was just another Quidditch match, that was all. . . just another Quidditch match, and that Horntail was just another ugly opposing team.
　　He looked down at the clutch of eggs and spotted the gold one, gleaming against its cement-colored fellows, residing safely between the dragon's front legs. "Okay," Roberto told himself, "diversionary tactics. . . let's go. . ."
　　He dived. The Horntail's head followed him; he knew what it was going to do and pulled out of the dive just in time; a jet of fire had been released exactly where he would have been had he not swerved away. . . but Roberto didn't care.. . that was no more than dodging a Bludger.
　　"Great Scott, he can fly!" yelled Bagman as the crowd shrieked and gasped. "Are you watching this, Mr. Krum?"
　　Roberto soared higher in a circle; the Horntail was still following his progress; its head revolving on its long neck - if he kept this up, it would be nicely dizzy - but better not push it too long, or it would be breathing fire again - Roberto plummeted just as the Horntail opened its mouth, but this time he was less lucky - he missed the flames, but the tail came whipping up to meet him instead, and as he swerved to the left, one of the long spikes grazed his shoulder, ripping his robes -- He could feel it stinging, he could hear screaming and groans from the crowd, but the cut didn't seem to be deep. . . . Now he zoomed around the back of the Horntail, and a possibility occurred to him....
　　The Horntail didn't seem to want to take off, she was too protective of her eggs. Though she writhed and twisted, furling and unfurling her wings and keeping those fearsome yellow eyes on Roberto, she was afraid to move too far from them. . . but he had to persuade her to do it, or he'd never get near them. . . . The trick was to do it carefully, gradually....
　　He began to fly, first this way, then the other, not near enough to make her breathe fire to stave him off, but still posing a sufficient threat to ensure she kept her eyes on him. Her head swayed this way and that, watching him out of those vertical pupils, her fangs bared...
　　He flew higher. The Horntail's head rose with him, her neck now stretched to its fullest extent, still swaying, hike a snake before its charmer. . .
　　Roberto rose a few more feet, and she let out a roar of exasperation. He was like a fly to her, a fly she was longing to swat; her tail thrashed again, but he was too high to reach now. . . . She shot fire into the air, which he dodged.. . . Her jaws opened wide....
　　"Come on," Roberto hissed, swerving tantalizingly above her, "come on, come and get me. . .
　　up you get now. ."
　　And then she reared, spreading her great, black, leathery wings at last, as wide as those of a small airplane - and Roberto dived. Before the dragon knew what he had done, or where he had disappeared to, he was speeding toward the ground as fast as he could go, toward the eggs now unprotected by her clawed front legs - he had taken his hands off his
　　Firebolt - he had seized the golden egg - And with a huge spurt of speed, he was off, he was soaring out over the stands, the heavy egg safely under his uninjured arm, and it was as though somebody had just turned the volume back up - for the first time, he became properly aware of the noise of the crowd, which was screaming and applauding as loudly as the Irish supporters at the World Cup - "Look at that!" Bagman was yelling. "Will you look at that! Our youngest champion is quickest to get his egg! Well, this is going to shorten the odds on Mr. Gonzales!"
　　Roberto saw the dragon keepers rushing forward to subdue the Horntail, and, over at the entrance to the enclosure, Professor McGonagalh, Professor Acosta, and Villalba hurrying to meet him, all of them waving him toward them, their smiles evident even from this distance. He flew back over the stands, the noise of the crowd pounding his eardrums, and came in smoothly to land, his heart lighter than it had been in weeks. . . . He had got through the first task, he had survived.
　　"That was excellent, Gonzales!" cried Professor Romero as he got off the Firebolt -which from her was extravagant praise. He noticed that her hand shook as she pointed at his shoulder. "You'll need to see Madam Pomfrey before the judges give out your score. .
　　. . Over there, she's had to mop up Ortega already. . . ."
　　"Yeh did it, Roberto!" said Villalba hoarsely. "Yeh did it! An' agains' the Horntail an' all, an' yeh know Charlie said that was the wors' - "
　　"Thanks, Villalba," said Roberto loudly, so that Villalba wouldn't blunder on and reveal that he had shown Roberto the dragons beforehand.
　　Professor Acosta looked very pleased too; his magical eye was dancing in its socket.
　　"Nice and easy does the trick, Gonzales," he growled.
　　"Right then, Gonzales, the first aid tent, please. . ." said Professor Romero.
　　Roberto walked out of the enclosure, still panting, and saw Madam Pomfrey standing at the mouth of a second tent, looking worried.
　　"Dragons!" she said, in a disgusted tone, pulling Roberto inside. The tent was divided into cubicles; he could make out Nicolas's shadow through the canvas, but Nicolas didn't seem to be badly injured; he was sitting up, at least. Madam Pomfrey examined Roberto's shoulder, talking furiously all the while. "Last year dementors, this year dragons, what are they going to bring into this school next? You're very lucky. . . this is quite shallow. . . it'll need cleaning before I heal it up, though... ."
　　She cleaned the cut with a dab of some purple liquid that smoked and stung, but then poked his shoulder with her wand, and he felt it heal instantly.
　　"Now, just sit quietly for a minute - sit! And then you can go and get your score."
　　She bustled out of the tent and he heard her go next door and say, "How does it feel now, Ortega?"
　　Roberto didn't want to sit still: He was too full of adrenaline. He got to his feet, wanting to see what was going on outside, but before he'd reached the mouth of the tent, two people had come darting inside - Carolina, followed closely by Diego.
　　"Roberto, you were brilliant!" Carolina said squeakily. There were fingernail marks on her face where she had been clutching it in fear. "You were amazing! You really were!"
　　But Roberto was looking at Diego, who was very white and staring at Roberto as though he were a ghost.
　　"Roberto," he said, very seriously, "whoever put your name in that goblet - I - I reckon they're trying to do you in!"
　　It was as though the last few weeks had never happened - as though Roberto were meeting Diego for the first time, right after he'd been made champion.
　　"Caught on, have you?" said Roberto coldly. "Took you long enough."
　　Carolina stood nervously between them, looking from one to the other. Diego opened his mouth uncertainly. Roberto knew Diego was about to apologize and suddenly he found he didn't need to hear it.
　　"It's okay," he said, before Diego could get the words out. "Forget it."
　　"No," said Diego, "I shouldn't've -"
　　"Forget it, "Roberto said.
　　Diego grinned nervously at him, and Roberto grinned back Carolina burst into tears.
　　"There's nothing to cry about!" Roberto told her, bewildered.
　　"You two are so stupid!" she shouted, stamping her foot on the ground, tears splashing down her front. Then, before either of them could stop her, she had given both of them a hug and dashed away, now positively howling.
　　"Barking mad," said Diego, shaking his head. "Roberto, c'mon, they'll be putting up your scores. . . ."
　　Picking up the golden egg and his Firebolt, feeling more elated than he would have believed possible an hour ago, Roberto ducked out of the tent, Diego by his side, talking fast.
　　"You were the best, you know, no competition. Nicolas did this weird thing where he Transfigured a rock on the ground. . . turned it into a dog. . . he was trying to make the dragon go for the dog instead of him. Well, it was a pretty cool bit of Transfiguration, and it sort of worked, because he did get the egg, but he got burned as well - the dragon changed its mind halfway through and decided it would rather have him than the Labrador; he only just got away. And that Camila girl tried this sort of charm, I think she was trying to put it into a trance - well, that kind of worked too, it went all sleepy, but then it snored, and this great jet of flame shot out, and her skirt caught fire - she put it out with a bit of water out of her wand. And Krum - you won't believe this, but he didn't even think of flying! He was probably the best after you, though.
　　Hit it with some sort of spell right in the eye. Only thing is, it went trampling around in agony and squashed half the real eggs - they took marks off for that, he wasn't supposed to do any damage to them."
　　Diego drew breath as he and Roberto reached the edge of the enclosure. Now that the Horntail had been taken away, Roberto could see where the five judges were sitting - right at the other end, in raised seats draped in gold.
　　"It's marks out of ten from each one," Diego said, and Roberto squinting up the field, saw the first judge - Madame Maxime - raise her wand in the air. What hooked like a long silver ribbon shot out of it, which twisted itself into a large figure eight.
　　"Not bad!" said Diego as the crowd applauded. "I suppose she took marks off for your shoulder. . .
　　Mr. Crouch came next. He shot a number nine into the air.
　　"Looking good!" Diego yelled, thumping Roberto on the back.
　　Next, Dominguez. He too put up a nine. The crowd was cheering harder than ever.
　　Ludo Bagman - ten.
　　"Ten?" said Roberto in disbelief. "But. . . I got hurt. . . . What's he playing at?"
　　"Roberto, don't complain!" Diego yelled excitedly.
　　And now Morales raised his wand. He paused for a moment, and then a number shot out of his wand too - four.
　　"What?" Diego bellowed furiously. "Four? You lousy, biased scum-bag, you gave Krum ten!"
　　But Roberto didn't care, he wouldn't have cared if Morales had given him zero; Diego's indignation on his behalf was worth about a hundred points to him. He didn't tell Diego this, of course, but his heart felt lighter than air as he turned to leave the enclosure.
　　And it wasn't just Diego. . . those weren't only Gryffindors cheering in the crowd. When it had come to it, when they had seen what he was facing, most of the school had been on his side as well as Nicolas's. . . . He didn't care about the Slytherins, he could stand whatever they threw at him now.
　　"You're tied in first place, Roberto! You and Krum!" said Charlie Lopez, hurrying to meet them as they set off back toward the school. "Listen, I've got to run, I've got to go and send Mum an owl, I swore I'd tell her what happened - but that was unbelievable!
　　Oh yeah - and they told me to tell you you've got to hang around for a few more minutes..
　　. . Bagman wants a word, back in the champions' tent."
　　Diego said he would wait, so Roberto reentered the tent, which somehow looked quite different now: friendly and welcoming. He thought back to how he'd felt while dodging the Horntail, and compared it to the long wait before he'd walked out to face it.... There was no comparison; the wait had been immeasurably worse.
　　Camila, Nicolas, and Krum all came in together. One side of Nicolas's face was covered in a thick orange paste, which was presumably mending his burn. He grinned at Roberto when he saw him.
　　"Good one, Roberto."
　　"And you," said Roberto, grinning back.
　　"Well done, all of you!" said Ludo Bagman, bouncing into the tent and looking as pleased as though he personally had just got past a dragon. "Now, just a quick few words. You've got a nice long break before the second task, which will take place at half past nine on the morning of February the twenty-fourth - but we're giving you something to think about in the meantime! If you look down at those golden eggs you're all holding, you will see
　　that they open. . . see the hinges there? You need to solve the clue inside the egg -because it will tell you what the second task is, and enable you to prepare for it! All clear? Sure? Well, off you go, then!"
　　Roberto left the tent, rejoined Diego, and they started to walk back around the edge of the forest, talking hard; Roberto wanted to hear what the other champions had done in more detail. Then, as they rounded the clump of trees behind which Roberto had first heard the dragons roar, a witch leapt out from behind them.
　　It was Rita Skeeter. She was wearing acid-green robes today; the Quick-Quotes Quill in her hand blended perfectly against them.
　　"Congratulations, Roberto!" she said, beaming at him. "I wonder if you could give me a quick word? How you felt facing that dragon? How you feel now, about the fairness of the scoring?"
　　"Yeah, you can have a word," said Roberto savagely. "Good-bye."
　　And he set off back to the castle with Diego.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE - THE HOUSE-ELF LIBERATION FDIEGOT
　　Roberto, Diego, and Carolina went up to the Owlery that evening to find Pigwidgeon, so that Roberto could send Gustavo a letter telling him that he had managed to get past his dragon unscathed. On the way, Roberto filled Diego in on everything Gustavo had told him about Morales. Though shocked at first to hear that Morales had been a Death Eater, by the time they entered the Owlery Diego was saying that they ought to have suspected it all along.
　　"Fits, doesn't it?" he said. "Remember what Sosa said on the train, about his dad being friends with Morales? Now we know where they knew each other.
　　They were probably running around in masks together at the World Cup.... I'll tell you one thing, though, Roberto, if it was Morales who put your name in the goblet, he's going to be feeling really stupid now, isn't he? Didn't work, did it? You only got a scratch!
　　Come here - I'll do it -"
　　Pigwidgeon was so overexcited at the idea of a delivery he was flying around and around Roberto's head, hooting incessantly. Diego snatched Pigwidgeon out of the air and held him still while Roberto attached the letter to his leg.
　　"There's no way any of the other tasks are going to be that dangerous, how could they be?" Diego went on as he carried Pigwidgeon to the window. "You know what? I reckon you could win this tournament, Roberto, I'm serious."
　　Roberto knew that Diego was only saying this to make up for his behavior of the last few weeks, but he appreciated it all the same. Carolina, however, leaned against the Owlery wall, folded her arms, and frowned at Diego.
　　"Roberto's got a long way to go before he finishes this tournament," she said seriously.
　　"If that was the first task, I hate to think what's coming next."
　　"Right little ray of sunshine, aren't you?" said Diego. "You and Professor Trelawney should get together sometime."
　　He threw Pigwidgeon out of the window. Pigwidgeon plummeted twelve feet before managing to pull himself back up again; the letter attached to his leg was much longer and heavier than usual - Roberto hadn't been able to resist giving Gustavo a blow-by-blow account of exactly how he had swerved, circled, and dodged the Horntail. They watched Pigwidgeon disappear into the darkness, and then Diego said, "Well, we'd better get downstairs for your surprise party, Roberto - Pablo and Luis should have nicked enough food from the kitchens by now."
　　Sure enough, when they entered the Gryffindor common room it exploded with cheers and yells again. There were mountains of cakes and flagons of pumpkin juice and butterbeer on every surface; Lee Jordan had let off some Filibuster's Fireworks, so that the air was thick with stars and sparks; and Dean Thomas, who was very good at drawing, had put up some impressive new banners, most of which depicted Roberto zooming around the Horntail's head on his Firebolt, though a couple showed Nicolas with his head on fire.
　　Roberto helped himself to food; he had almost forgotten what it was like to feel properly hungry, and sat down with Diego and Carolina. He couldn't believe how happy he felt; he had Diego back on his side, he'd gotten through the first task, and he wouldn't have to face the second one for three months.
　　"Blimey, this is heavy," said Lee Jordan, picking up the golden egg, which Roberto had left on a table, and weighing it in his hands. "Open it, Roberto, go on! Let's just see what's
　　inside it!"
　　"He's supposed to work out the clue on his own," Carolina said swiftly. "It's in the tournament rules. . . ."
　　"I was supposed to work out how to get past the dragon on my own too," Roberto muttered, so only Carolina could hear him, and she grinned rather guiltily.
　　"Yeah, go on, Roberto, open it!" several people echoed.
　　Lee passed Roberto the egg, and Roberto dug his fingernails into the groove that ran all the way around it and prised it open.
　　It was hollow and completely empty - but the moment Roberto opened it, the most horrible noise, a loud and screechy wailing, filled the room. The nearest thing to it Roberto had ever heard was the ghost orchestra at Nearly Headless Nick's deathday party, who had all been playing the musical saw.
　　"Shut it!" Pablo bellowed, his hands over his ears.
　　"What was that?" said Seamus Finnigan, staring at the egg as Roberto slammed it shut again. "Sounded like a banshee ... Maybe you've got to get past one of those next, Roberto!"
　　"It was someone being tortured!" said Mauricio, who had gone very white and spilled sausage rolls all over the floor. "You're going to have to fight the Cruciatus Curse!"
　　"Don't be a prat, Mauricio, that's illegal," said Luis. "They wouldn't use the Cruciatus Curse on the champions. I thought it sounded a bit like Miguel singing . ..
　　maybe you've got to attack him while he's in the shower. Roberto."
　　"Want a jam tart, Carolina?" said Pablo.
　　Carolina looked doubtfully at the plate he was offering her. Pablo grinned.
　　"It's all right," he said. "I haven't done anything to them. It's the custard creams you've got to watch -"
　　Mauricio, who had just bitten into a custard cream, choked and spat it out. Pablo laughed.
　　"Just my little joke, Mauricio.. . ."
　　Carolina took a jam tart. Then she said, "Did you get all this from the kitchens, Pablo?"
　　"Yep," said Pablo, grinning at her. He put on a high-pitched squeak and imitated a house-elf. "'Anything we can get you, sir, anything at all!' They're dead helpful...
　　get me a roast ox if I said I was peckish."
　　"How do you get in there?" Carolina said in an innocently casual sort of voice.
　　"Easy," said Pablo, "concealed door behind a painting of a bowl of fruit. Just tickle the pear, and it giggles and -" He stopped and looked suspiciously at her. "Why?"
　　"Nothing," said Carolina quickly.
　　"Going to try and lead the house-elves out on strike now, are you?" said Luis. "Going to give up all the leaflet stuff and try and stir them up into rebellion?"
　　Several people chortled. Carolina didn't answer.
　　"Don't you go upsetting them and telling them they've got to take clothes and salaries!"
　　said Pablo warningly. "You'll put them off their cooking!"
　　Just then, Mauricio caused a slight diversion by turning into a large canary.
　　"Oh - sorry, Mauricio!" Pablo shouted over all the laughter. "I forgot - it was the custard creams we hexed -"
　　Within a minute, however, Mauricio had molted, and once his feathers had fallen off, he reappeared looking entirely normal. He even joined in laughing.
