　　"Canary Creams!" Pablo shouted to the excitable crowd. "Luis and I invented them -seven Sickles each, a bargain!"
　　It was nearly one in the morning when Roberto finally went up to the dormitory with Diego, Mauricio, Seamus, and Dean. Before he pulled the curtains of his four-poster shut. Roberto set his tiny model of the Hungarian Horntail on the table next to his bed, where it yawned, curled up, and closed its eyes. Really, Roberto thought, as he pulled the hangings on his four-poster closed, Villalba had a point.. . they were all right, really, dragons. .
　　. .
　　The start of December brought wind and sleet to Hogwarts. Drafty though the castle always was in winter. Roberto was glad of its fires and thick walls every time he passed the Durmstrang ship on the lake, which was pitching in the high winds, its black sails billowing against the dark skies. He thought the Beauxbatons caravan was likely to be pretty chilly too. Villalba, he noticed, was keeping Madame Maxime's horses well provided with their preferred drink of single-malt whiskey; the fumes wafting from the trough in the
　　comer of their paddock was enough to make the entire Care of Magical Creatures class light-headed. This was unhelpful, as they were still tending the horrible skrewts and needed their wits about them.
　　"I'm not sure whether they hibernate or not," Villalba told the shivering class in the windy pumpkin patch next lesson. "Thought we'd jus' try an see if they fancied a kip . .
　　. we'll jus' settle 'em down in these boxes. . . ."
　　There were now only ten skrewts left; apparently their desire to kill one another had not been exercised out of them. Each of them was now approaching six feet in length. Their thick gray armor; their powerful, scuttling legs; their fire-blasting ends; their stings and their suckers, combined to make the skrewts the most repulsive things Roberto had ever seen. The class looked dispiritedly at the enormous boxes Villalba had brought out, all lined with pillows and fluffy blankets.
　　"We'll jus' lead 'em in here," Villalba said, "an' put the lids on, and we'll see what happens."
　　But the skrewts, it transpired, did not hibernate, and did not appreciate being forced into pillow-lined boxes and nailed in. Villalba was soon yelling, "Don panic, now, don' panic!" while the skrewts rampaged around the pumpkin patch, now strewn with the smoldering wreckage of the boxes. Most of the class - Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle in the lead - had fled into Villalba's cabin through the back door and barricaded themselves in; Roberto, Diego, and Carolina, however, were among those who remained outside trying to help Villalba. Together they managed to restrain and tie up nine of the skrewts, though at the cost of numerous burns and cuts; finally, only one skrewt was left.
　　"Don' frighten him, now!" Villalba shouted as Diego and Roberto used their wands to shoot jets of fiery sparks at the skrewt, which was advancing menacingly on them, its sting arched, quivering, over its back. "Jus' try an slip the rope 'round his sting, so he won hurt any o' the others!"
　　"Yeah, we wouldn't want that!" Diego shouted angrily as he and Roberto backed into the wall of Villalba's cabin, still holding the skrewt off with their sparks.
　　"Well, well, well. . . this does look like fun."
　　Rita Skeeter was leaning on Villalba's garden fence, looking in at the mayhem. She was wearing a thick magenta cloak with a furry purple collar today, and her crocodile-skin handbag was over her arm.
　　Villalba launched himself forward on top of the skrewt that was cornering Roberto and Diego and flattened it; a blast of fire shot out of its end, withering the pumpkin plants nearby.
　　"Who're you?" Villalba asked Rita Skeeter as he slipped a loop of rope around the skrewt's sting and tightened it.
　　"Rita Skeeter, Daily Prophet reporter," Rita replied, beaming at him. Her gold teeth glinted.
　　"Thought Dominguez said you weren' allowed inside the school anymore," said Villalba, frowning slightly as he got off the slightly squashed skrewt and started tugging it over to its fellows.
　　Rita acted as though she hadn't heard what Villalba had said.
　　"What are these fascinating creatures called?" she asked, beaming still more widely.
　　"Blast-Ended Skrewts," grunted Villalba.
　　"Really?" said Rita, apparently full of lively interest. "I've never heard of them before...where do they come from?"
　　Roberto noticed a dull red flush rising up out of Villalba's wild black beard, and his heart sank. Where had Villalba got the skrewts from? Carolina, who seemed to be thinking along these lines, said quickly, "They're very interesting, aren't they? Aren't they. Roberto?"
　　"What? Oh yeah . . . ouch . . . interesting," said Roberto as she stepped on his foot.
　　"Ah, you're here. Roberto!" said Rita Skeeter as she looked around. "So you like Care of Magical Creatures, do you? One of your favorite lessons?"
　　"Yes," said Roberto stoutly. Villalba beamed at him.
　　"Lovely," said Rita. "Really lovely. Been teaching long?" she added to Villalba.
　　Roberto noticed her eyes travel over Dean (who had a nasty cut across one cheek). Lavender (whose robes were badly singed), Seamus (who was nursing several burnt fingers), and then to the cabin windows, where most of the class stood, their noses pressed against the glass waiting to see if the coast was clear.
　　"This is o'ny me second year," said Villalba.
　　"Lovely... I don't suppose you'd like to give an interview, would you? Share some of your experience of magical creatures? The Prophet does a zoological column every
　　Wednesday, as I'm sure you know. We could feature these - er - Bang-Ended Scoots."
　　"Blast-Ended Skrewts," Villalba said eagerly. "Er - yeah, why not?"
　　Roberto had a very bad feeling about this, but there was no way of communicating it to Villalba without Rita Skeeter seeing, so he had to stand and watch in silence as Villalba and Rita Skeeter made arrangements to meet in the Three Broomsticks for a good long interview later that week. Then the bell rang up at the castle, signaling the end of the lesson.
　　"Well, good-bye, Roberto!" Rita Skeeter called merrily to him as he set off with Diego and Carolina. "Until Friday night, then, Villalba!"
　　"She'll twist everything he says," Roberto said under his breath.
　　"Just as long as he didn't import those skrewts illegally or anything," said Carolina desperately. They looked at one another - it was exactly the sort of thing Villalba might do.
　　"Villalbas been in loads of trouble before, and Dominguezs never sacked him," said Diego consolingly. "Worst that can happen is Villalba'll have to get rid of the skrewts. Sorry . . . did I say worst? I meant best."
　　Roberto and Carolina laughed, and, feeling slightly more cheerful, went off to lunch.
　　Roberto thoroughly enjoyed double Divination that afternoon; they were still doing star charts and predictions, but now that he and Diego were friends once more, the whole thing seemed very funny again. Professor Trelawney, who had been so pleased with the pair of them when they had been predicting their own horrific deaths, quickly became irritated as they sniggered through her explanation of the various ways in which Pluto could disrupt everyday life.
　　"I would think," she said, in a mystical whisper that did not conceal her obvious annoyance, "that some of us" - she stared very meaningfully at Roberto- "might be a little less frivolous had they seen what I have seen during my crystal gazing last night. As I sat here, absorbed in my needlework, the urge to consult the orb overpowered me. I arose, I settled myself before it, and I gazed into its crystalline depths . . . and what do you think I saw gazing back at me?"
　　"An ugly old bat in outsize specs?" Diego muttered under his breath.
　　Roberto fought hard to keep his face straight.
　　"Death, my dears."
　　Parvati and Lavender both put their hands over their mouths, looking horrified.
　　"Yes," said Professor Trelawney, nodding impressively, "it comes, ever closer, it circles overhead like a vulture, ever lower. . . ever lower over the castle. . . ."
　　She stared pointedly at Roberto, who yawned very widely and obviously.
　　"It'd be a bit more impressive if she hadn't done it about eighty times before," Roberto said as they finally regained the fresh air of the staircase beneath Professor Trelawney's room. "But if I'd dropped dead every time she's told me I'm going to, I'd be a medical miracle."
　　"You'd be a sort of extra-concentrated ghost," said Diego, chortling, as they passed the Bloody Baron going in the opposite direction, his wide eyes staring sinisterly. "At least we didn't get homework. I hope Carolina got loads off Professor Vector, I love not working when she is. . . ."
　　But Carolina wasn't at dinner, nor was she in the library when they went to look for her afterward. The only person in there was Viktor Krum. Diego hovered behind the bookshelves for a while, watching Krum, debating in whispers with Roberto whether he should ask for an autograph - but then Diego realized that six or seven girls were lurking in the next row of books, debating exactly the same thing, and he lost his enthusiasm for the idea.
　　"Wonder where she's got to?" Diego said as he and Roberto went back to Gryffindor Tower.
　　"Dunno . . . balderdash."
　　But the Fat Lady had barely begun to swing forward when the sound of racing feet behind them announced Carolina's arrival.
　　"Roberto!" she panted, skidding to a halt beside him (the Fat Lady stared down at her, eyebrows raised). "Roberto, you've got to come - you've got to come, the most amazing thing's happened- please -"
　　She seized Roberto's arm and started to try to drag him back along the corridor.
　　"What's the matter?" Roberto said.
　　"I'll show you when we get there - oh come on, quick -"
　　Roberto looked around at Diego; he looked back at Roberto, intrigued.
　　"Okay," Roberto said, starting off back down the corridor with Carolina, Diego hurrying to keep up.
　　"Oh don't mind me!" the Fat Lady called irritably after them. "Don't apologize for bothering me! I'll just hang here, wide open, until you get back, shall I?"
　　"Yeah, thanks!" Diego shouted over his shoulder.
　　"Carolina, where are we going?" Roberto asked, after she had led them down through six floors, and started down the marble staircase into the entrance hall.
　　"You'll see, you'll see in a minute!" said Carolina excitedly.
　　She turned left at the bottom of the staircase and hurried toward the door through which Nicolas Ortega had gone the night after the Goblet of Fire had regurgitated his and Roberto's names. Roberto had never been through here before. He and Diego followed Carolina down a flight of stone steps, but instead of ending up in a gloomy underground passage like the one that led to Peralta's dungeon, they found themselves in a broad stone corridor, brightly lit with torches, and decorated with cheerful paintings that were mainly of food.
　　"Oh hang on . . ." said Roberto slowly, halfway down the corridor. "Wait a minute, Carolina. . . ."
　　"What?" She turned around to look at him, anticipation all over her face.
　　"I know what this is about," said Roberto.
　　He nudged Diego and pointed to the painting just behind Carolina. It showed a gigantic silver fruit bowl.
　　"Carolina!" said Diego, cottoning on. "You're trying to rope us into that spew stuff again!"
　　"No, no, I'm not!" she said hastily. "And it's not spew, Diego -"
　　"Mejiaed the name, have you?" said Diego, frowning at her. "What are we now, then, the House-Elf Liberation Front? I'm not barging into that kitchen and trying to make them stop work, I'm not doing it -"
　　"I'm not asking you to!" Carolina said impatiently. "I came down here just now, to talk to them all, and I found - oh come on, Roberto, I want to show you!"
　　She seized his arm again, pulled him in front of the picture of the giant fruit bowl, stretched out her forefinger, and tickled the huge green pear. It began to squirm, chuckling, and suddenly turned into a large green door handle. Carolina seized it, pulled the door open, and pushed Roberto hard in the back, forcing him inside.
　　He had one brief glimpse of an enormous, high-ceilinged room, large as the Great Hall above it, with mounds of glittering brass pots and pans heaped around the stone walls, and a great brick fireplace at the other end, when something small hurtled toward him from the middle of the room, squealing, "Roberto Gonzales, sir! Roberto Gonzales!"
　　Next second all the wind had been knocked out of him as the squealing elf hit him hard in the midriff, hugging him so tightly he thought his ribs would break.
　　"D-Dobby?" Roberto gasped.
　　"It is Dobby, sir, it is!" squealed the voice from somewhere around his navel. "Dobby has been hoping and hoping to see Roberto Gonzales, sir, and Roberto Gonzales has come to see him, sir!"
　　Dobby let go and stepped back a few paces, beaming up at Roberto, his enormous, green, tennis-ball-shaped eyes brimming with tears of happiness. He looked almost exactly as Roberto remembered him; the pencil-shaped nose, the batlike ears, the long fingers and feet - all except the clothes, which were very different.
　　When Dobby had worked for the Sosas, he had always worn the same filthy old pillowcase.
　　Now, however, he was wearing the strangest assortment of garments Roberto had ever seen; he had done an even worse job of dressing himself than the wizards at the World Cup. He was wearing a tea cozy for a hat, on which he had pinned a number of bright badges; a tie patterned with horseshoes over a bare chest, a pair of what looked like children's soccer shorts, and odd socks. One of these, Roberto saw, was the black one Roberto had removed from his own foot and tricked Mr. Sosa into giving Dobby, thereby setting Dobby free. The other was covered in pink and orange stripes.
　　"Dobby, what're you doing here?" Roberto said in amazement. "Dobby has come to work at Hogwarts, sir!" Dobby squealed excitedly. "Professor Dominguez gave Dobby and Winky jobs, sir!
　　"Winky?" said Roberto. "She's here too?"
　　"Yes, sir, yes!" said Dobby, and he seized Roberto's hand and pulled him off into the kitchen between the four long wooden tables that stood there. Each of these tables, Roberto noticed as he passed them, was positioned exactly beneath the four House tables
　　above, in the Great Hall. At the moment, they were clear of food, dinner having finished, but he supposed that an hour ago they had been laden with dishes that were then sent up through the ceiling to their counterparts above.
　　At least a hundred little elves were standing around the kitchen, beaming, bowing, and curtsying as Dobby led Roberto past them. They were all wearing the same uniform: a tea towel stamped with the Hogwarts crest, and tied, as Winky's had been, like a toga.
　　Dobby stopped in front of the brick fireplace and pointed.
　　"Winky, sir!" he said.
　　Winky was sitting on a stool by the fire. Unlike Dobby, she had obviously not foraged for clothes. She was wearing a neat little skirt and blouse with a matching blue hat, which had holes in it for her large ears. However, while every one of Dobby's strange collection of garments was so clean and well cared for that it looked brand-new, Winky was plainly not taking care other clothes at all. There were soup stains all down her blouse and a burn in her skirt.
　　"Hello, Winky," said Roberto.
　　Winky's lip quivered. Then she burst into tears, which spilled out of her great brown eyes and splashed down her front, just as they had done at the Quidditch World Cup.
　　"Oh dear," said Carolina. She and Diego had followed Roberto and Dobby to the end of the kitchen. "Winky, don't cry, please don't..."
　　But Winky cried harder than ever. Dobby, on the other hand, beamed up at Roberto.
　　"Would Roberto Gonzales like a cup of tea?" he squeaked loudly, over Winky's sobs.
　　"Er - yeah, okay," said Roberto.
　　Instantly, about six house-elves came trotting up behind him, bearing a large silver tray laden with a teapot, cups for Roberto, Diego, and Carolina, a milk jug, and a large plate of biscuits.
　　"Good service!" Diego said, in an impressed voice. Carolina frowned at him, but the elves all looked delighted; they bowed very low and retreated.
　　"How long have you been here, Dobby?" Roberto asked as Dobby handed around the tea.
　　"Only a week. Roberto Gonzales, sir!" said Dobby happily. "Dobby came to see Professor Dominguez, sir. You see, sir, it is very difficult for a house-elf who has been dismissed to get a new position, sir, very difficult indeed -"
　　At this, Winky howled even harder, her squashed-tomato of a nose dribbling all down her front, though she made no effort to stem the flow.
　　"Dobby has traveled the country for two whole years, sir, trying to find work!" Dobby squeaked. "But Dobby hasn't found work, sir, because Dobby wants paying now!"
　　The house-elves all around the kitchen, who had been listening and watching with interest, all looked away at these words, as though Dobby had said something rude and embarrassing. Carolina, however, said, "Good for you, Dobby!"
　　"Thank you, miss!" said Dobby, grinning toothily at her. "But most wizards doesn't want a house-elf who wants paying, miss. 'That's not the point of a house-elf,' they says, and they slammed the door in Dobby's face! Dobby likes work, but he wants to wear clothes and he wants to be paid. Roberto Gonzales.... Dobby likes being free!"
　　The Hogwarts house-elves had now started edging away from Dobby, as though he were carrying something contagious. Winky, however, remained where she was, though there was a definite increase in the volume other crying.
　　"And then, Roberto Gonzales, Dobby goes to visit Winky, and finds out Winky has been freed too, sir!" said Dobby delightedly.
　　At this, Winky flung herself forward off her stool and lay face-down on the flagged stone floor, beating her tiny fists upon it and positively screaming with misery. Carolina hastily dropped down to her knees beside her and tried to comfort her, but nothing she said made the slightest difference. Dobby continued with his story, shouting shrilly over Winky's screeches.
　　"And then Dobby had the idea. Roberto Gonzales, sir! 'Why doesn't Dobby and Winky find work together?' Dobby says. 'Where is there enough work for two house-elves?' says Winky.
　　And Dobby thinks, and it comes to him, sir! Hogwarts! So Dobby and Winky came to see Professor Dominguez, sir, and Professor Dominguez took us on!"
　　Dobby beamed very brightly, and happy tears welled in his eyes again.
　　"And Professor Dominguez says he will pay Dobby, sir, if Dobby wants paying! And so Dobby is a free elf, sir, and Dobby gets a Galleon a week and one day off a month!"
　　"That's not very much!" Carolina shouted indignantly from the floor, over Winky's continued screaming and fist-beating.
　　"Professor Dominguez offered Dobby ten Galleons a week, and weekends off," said Dobby, suddenly giving a little shiver, as though the prospect of so much leisure and riches were frightening, "but Dobby beat him down, miss. . . . Dobby likes freedom, miss, but he isn't wanting too much, miss, he likes work better."
　　"And how much is Professor Dominguez paying you, Winky?" Carolina asked kindly.
　　If she had thought this would cheer up Winky, she was wildly mistaken. Winky did stop crying, but when she sat up she was glaring at Carolina through her massive brown eyes, her whole face sopping wet and suddenly furious.
　　"Winky is a disgraced elf, but Winky is not yet getting paid!" she squeaked. "Winky is not sunk so low as that! Winky is properly ashamed of being freed!"
　　"Ashamed?" said Carolina blankly. "But - Winky, come on! It's Mr. Crouch who should be ashamed, not you! You didn't do anything wrong, he was really horrible to you -"
　　But at these words, Winky clapped her hands over the holes in her hat, flattening her ears so that she couldn't hear a word, and screeched, "You is not insulting my master, miss! You is not insulting Mr. Crouch! Mr. Crouch is a good wizard, miss! Mr. Crouch is right to sack bad Winky!"
　　"Winky is having trouble adjusting, Roberto Gonzales," squeaked Dobby confidentially. "Winky forgets she is not bound to Mr. Crouch anymore; she is allowed to speak her mind now, but she won't do it."
　　"Can't house-elves speak their minds about their masters, then?" Roberto asked.
　　"Oh no, sir, no," said Dobby, looking suddenly serious. "'Tis part of the house-elf's enslavement, sir. We keeps their secrets and our silence, sir. We upholds the family's honor, and we never speaks ill of them - though Professor Dominguez told Dobby he does not insist upon this. Professor Dominguez said we is free to - to-"
　　Dobby looked suddenly nervous and beckoned Roberto closer. Roberto bent forward. Dobby whispered, "He said we is free to call him a - a barmy old codger if we likes, sir!"
　　Dobby gave a frightened sort of giggle.
　　"But Dobby is not wanting to, Roberto Gonzales," he said, talking normally again, and shaking his head so that his ears flapped. "Dobby likes Professor Dominguez very much, sir, and is proud to keep his secrets and our silence for him."
　　"But you can say what you like about the Sosas now?" Roberto asked him, grinning.
　　A slightly fearful look came into Dobby's immense eyes.
　　"Dobby - Dobby could," he said doubtfully. He squared his small shoulders. "Dobby could tell Roberto Gonzales that his old masters were - were - bad Dark wizards'."
　　Dobby stood for a moment, quivering all over, horror-struck by his own daring - then he rushed over to the nearest table and began banging his head on it very hard, squealing, "Bad Dobby! Bad Dobby!"
　　Roberto seized Dobby by the back of his tie and pulled him away from the table.
　　"Thank you. Roberto Gonzales, thank you," said Dobby breathlessly, rubbing his head.
　　"You just need a bit of practice," Roberto said.
　　"Practice!" squealed Winky furiously. "You is ought to be ashamed of yourself, Dobby, talking that way about your masters!"
　　"They isn't my masters anymore, Winky!" said Dobby defiantly. "Dobby doesn't care what they think anymore!"
　　"Oh you is a bad elf, Dobby!" moaned Winky, tears leaking down her face once more. "My poor Mr. Crouch, what is he doing without Winky? He is needing me, he is needing my help! I is looking after the Crouches all my life, and my mother is doing it before me, and my grandmother is doing it before her ... oh what is they saying if they knew Winky was freed? Oh the shame, the shame!" She buried her face in her skirt again and bawled.
　　"Winky," said Carolina firmly, "I'm quite sure Mr. Crouch is getting along perfectly well without you. We've seen him, you know -"
　　"You is seeing my master?" said Winky breathlessly, raising her tearstained face out of her skirt once more and goggling at Carolina. "You is seeing him here at Hogwarts?"
　　"Yes," said Carolina, "he and Mr. Bagman are judges in the Triwizard Tournament."
　　"Mr. Bagman comes too?" squeaked Winky, and to Roberto 's great surprise (and Diego's and Carolina's too, by the looks on their faces), she looked angry again. "Mr. Bagman is a bad wizard! A very bad wizard! My master isn't liking him, oh no, not at all!"
　　"Bagman - bad?" said Roberto.
　　"Oh yes," Winky said, nodding her head furiously, "My master is telling Winky some things! But Winky is not saying.. . Winky - Winky keeps her master's secrets. ..."
　　She dissolved yet again in tears; they could hear her sobbing into her skirt, "Poor
　　master, poor master, no Winky to help him no more!"
　　They couldn't get another sensible word out of Winky. They left her to her crying and finished their tea, while Dobby chatted happily about his life as a free elf and his plans for his wages.
　　"Dobby is going to buy a sweater next, Roberto Gonzales!" he said happily, pointing at his bare chest, "Tell you what, Dobby," said Diego, who seemed to have taken a great liking to the elf, "I'll give you the one my mum knits me this Christmas, I always get one from her. You don't mind maroon, do you?"
　　Dobby was delighted.
　　"We might have to shrink it a bit to fit you," Diego told him, "but it'll go well with your tea cozy."
　　As they prepared to take their leave, many of the surrounding elves pressed in upon them, offering snacks to take back upstairs. Carolina refused, with a pained look at the way the elves kept bowing and curtsying, but Roberto and Diego loaded their pockets with cream cakes and pies.
　　"Thanks a lot!" Roberto said to the elves, who had all clustered around the door to say good night. "See you, Dobby!"
　　"Roberto Gonzales . . . can Dobby come and see you sometimes, sir?" Dobby asked tentatively.
　　" 'Course you can," said Roberto, and Dobby beamed.
　　"You know what?" said Diego, once he, Carolina, and Roberto had left the kitchens behind and were climbing the steps into the entrance hall again. "All these years I've been really impressed with Pablo and Luis, nicking food from the kitchens - well, it's not exactly difficult, is it? They can't wait to give it away!"
　　"I think this is the best thing that could have happened to those elves, you know," said Carolina, leading the way back up the marble staircase. "Dobby coming to work here, I mean. The other elves will see how happy he is, being free, and slowly it'll dawn on them that they want that too!"
　　"Let's hope they don't look too closely at Winky," said Roberto.
　　"Oh she'll cheer up," said Carolina, though she sounded a bit doubtful. "Once the shock's worn off, and she's got used to Hogwarts, she'll see how much better off she is without that Crouch man."
　　"She seems to love him," said Diego thickly (he had just started on a cream cake).
　　"Doesn't think much of Bagman, though, does she?" said Roberto. "Wonder what Crouch says at home about him?"
　　"Probably says he's not a very good Head of Department," said Carolina, "and let's face it... he's got a point, hasn't he?"
　　"I'd still rather work for him than old Crouch," said Diego. "At least Bagman's got a sense of humor."
　　"Don't let Miguel hear you saying that," Carolina said, smiling slightly.
　　"Yeah, well, Miguel wouldn't want to work for anyone with a sense of humor, would he?"
　　said Diego, now starting on a chocolate eclair. "Miguel wouldn't recognize a joke if it danced naked in front of him wearing Dobby's tea cozy."
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO - THE UNEXPECTED TASK
　　Gonzales! Lopez! Will you pay attention?"
　　Professor Romero's irritated voice cracked like a whip through the Transfiguration class on Thursday, and Roberto and Diego both jumped and looked up.
　　It was the end of the lesson; they had finished their work; the guinea fowl they had been changing into guinea pigs had been shut away in a large cage on Professor Romero's desk (Mauricio's still had feathers); they had copied down their homework from the blackboard ("Describe, with examples, the ways in which Transforming Spells must be adapted when performing Cross-Species Switches"}. The bell was due to ring at any moment, and Roberto and Diego, who had been having a sword fight with a couple of Pablo and Luis's fake wands at the back of the class, looked up, Diego holding a tin parrot and Roberto, a rubber haddock.
　　"Now that Gonzales and Lopez have been kind enough to act their age," said Professor Romero, with an angry look at the pair of them as the head of Roberto's haddock drooped and fell silently to the floor - Diego's parrot's beak had severed it moments before - "I have something to say to you all.
　　"The Yule Ball is approaching - a traditional part of the Triwizard Tournament and an opportunity for us to socialize with our foreign guests. Now, the ball will be open only to fourth years and above - although you may invite a younger student if you wish -"
　　Lavender Brown let out a shrill giggle. Parvati Patil nudged her hard in the ribs, her face working furiously as she too fought not to giggle. They both looked around at Roberto, Professor Romero ignored them, which Roberto thought was distinctly unfair, as she had just told off him and Diego.
　　"Dress robes will be worn," Professor Romero continued, "and the ball will start at eight o'clock on Christmas Day, finishing at midnight in the Great Hall. Now then -"
　　Professor Romero stared deliberately around the class.
　　"The Yule Ball is of course a chance for us all to - er - let our hair down," she said, in a disapproving voice.
　　Lavender giggled harder than ever, with her hand pressed hard against her mouth to stifle the sound. Roberto could see what was funny this time: Professor Romero, with her hair in a tight bun, looked as though she had never let her hair down in any sense.
　　"But that does NOT mean," Professor Romero went on, "that we will be relaxing the standards of behavior we expect from Hogwarts students. I will be most seriously displeased if a Gryffindor student embarrasses the school in any way."
　　The bell rang, and there was the usual scuffle of activity as everyone packed their bags and swung them onto their shoulders.
　　Professor Romero called above the noise, "Gonzales - a word, if you please."
　　Assuming this had something to do with his headless rubber haddock, Roberto proceeded gloomily to the teacher's desk. Professor Romero waited until the rest of the class had gone, and then said, "Gonzales, the champions and their partners -"
　　"What partners?" said Roberto.
　　Profesor Romero looked suspiciously at him, as though she thought he was trying to be funny.
　　"Your partners for the Yule Ball, Gonzales," she said coldly. "Your dance partners."
　　Roberto's insides seemed to curl up and shrivel.
　　"Dance partners?" He felt himself going red. "I don't dance," he said quickly.
　　"Oh yes, you do," said Professor Romero irritably. "That's what I'm telling you.
　　Traditionally, the champions and their partners open the ball."
　　Roberto had a sudden mental image of himself in a top hat and tails, accompanied by a girl in the sort of frilly dress Aunt Beatriz always wore to Uncle Francisco's work parties.
　　"I'm not dancing," he said.
　　"It is traditional," said Professor Romero firmly. "You are a Hogwarts champion, and you will do what is expected of you as a representative of the school. So make sure you get yourself a partner, Gonzales."
　　"But-I don't-"
　　"You heard me, Gonzales," said Professor Romero in a very final sort of way.
　　A week ago. Roberto would have said finding a partner for a dance would be a cinch compared to taking on a Hungarian Horntail. But now that he had done the latter, and was facing the prospect of asking a girl to the ball, he thought he'd rather have another round with the dragon.
　　Roberto had never known so many people to put their names down to stay at Hogwarts for Christmas; he always did, of course, because the alternative was usually going back to Privet Drive, but he had always been very much in the minority before now. This year, however, everyone in the fourth year and above seemed to be staying, and they all seemed to Roberto to be obsessed with the coming ball - or at least all the girls were, and it was amazing how many girls Hogwarts suddenly seemed to hold; he had never quite noticed that before. Girls giggling and whispering in the corridors, girls shrieking with laughter as boys passed them, girls excitedly comparing notes on what they were going to wear on Christmas night... .
　　"Why do they have to move in packs?" Roberto asked Diego as a dozen or so girls walked past them, sniggering and staring at Roberto. "How're you supposed to get one on their own to ask them?"
　　"Lasso one?" Diego suggested. "Got any idea who you're going to try?"
　　Roberto didn't answer. He knew perfectly well whom he'd like to ask, but working up the nerve was something else. . . . Paula was a year older than he was; she was very pretty; she was a very good Quidditch player, and she was also very popular.
　　Diego seemed to know what was going on inside Roberto's head.
　　"Listen, you're not going to have any trouble. You're a champion. You've just beaten a Hungarian Horntail. I bet they'll be queuing up to go with you."
　　In tribute to their recently repaired friendship, Diego had kept the bitterness in his voice to a bare minimum. Moreover, to Roberto's amazement, he turned out to be quite right.
　　A curly-haired third-year Hufflepuff girl to whom Roberto had never spoken in his life asked him to go to the ball with her the very next day. Roberto was so taken aback he said no before he'd even stopped to consider the matter. The girl walked off looking rather hurt, and Roberto had to endure Dean's, Seamus's, and Diego's taunts about her all through History of Magic. The following day, two more girls asked him, a second year and (to his horror) a fifth year who looked as though she might knock him out if he refused.
　　"She was quite good-looking," said Diego fairly, after he'd stopped laughing.
　　"She was a foot taller than me," said Roberto, still unnerved. "Imagine what I'd look like trying to dance with her."
　　Carolina's words about Krum kept coming back to him. "They only like him because he's famous!" Roberto doubted very much if any of the girls who had asked to be his partner so far would have wanted to go to the ball with him if he hadn't been a school champion.
　　Then he wondered if this would bother him if Paula asked him.
　　On the whole. Roberto had to admit that even with the embarrassing prospect of opening the ball before him, life had definitely improved since he had got through the first task.
　　He wasn't attracting nearly as much unpleasantness in the corridors anymore, which he suspected had a lot to do with Nicolas - he had an idea Nicolas might have told the Hufflepuffs to leave Roberto alone, in gratitude for Roberto's tip-off about the dragons.
　　There seemed to be fewer Support Nicolas Ortega! badges around too. Javier Sosa, of course, was still quoting Rita Skeeter's article to him at every possible opportunity, but he was getting fewer and fewer laughs out of it - and just to heighten Roberto's feeling of well-being, no story about Villalba had appeared in the Daily Prophet.
　　"She didn' seem very int'rested in magical creatures, ter tell yeh the truth," Villalba said, when Roberto, Diego, and Carolina asked him how his interview with Rita Skeeter had gone during the last Care of Magical Creatures lesson of the term. To their very great relief, Villalba had given up on direct contact with the skrewts now, and they were merely sheltering behind his cabin today, sitting at a trestle table and preparing a fresh selection of food with which to tempt the skrewts.
　　"She jus' wanted me ter talk about you, Roberto," Villalba continued in a low voice. "Well, I told her we'd been friends since I went ter fetch yeh from the Carrizos. 'Never had to tell him off in four years?' she said. 'Never played you up in lessons, has he?' I told her no, an she didn' seem happy at all. Yeh'd think she wanted me to say yeh were horrible, Roberto."
　　" 'Course she did," said Roberto, throwing lumps of dragon liver into a large metal bowl and picking up his knife to cut some more. "She can't keep writing about what a tragic little hero I am, it'll get boring."
　　"She wants a new angle, Villalba," said Diego wisely as he shelled salamander eggs. "You were supposed to say Roberto's a mad delinquent!"
　　"But he's not!" said Villalba, looking genuinely shocked.
　　"She should've interviewed Peralta," said Roberto grimly. "He'd give her the goods on me any day. 'Gonzales has been crossing lines ever since he first arrived at this school. . . .'"
　　"Said that, did he?" said Villalba, while Diego and Carolina laughed. "Well, yeh might've bent a few rules. Roberto, bu' yeh're all righ' really, aren' you?"
　　"Cheers, Villalba," said Roberto, grinning.
　　"You coming to this ball thing on Christmas Day, Villalba?" said Diego.
　　"Though' I might look in on it, yeah," said Villalba gruffly. "Should be a good do, I reckon. You'll be openin the dancin', won yeh, Roberto? Who're you takin'?"
　　"No one, yet," said Roberto, feeling himself going red again. Villalba didn't pursue the subject.
　　The last week of term became increasingly boisterous as it progressed. Rumors about the Yule Ball were flying everywhere, though Roberto didn't believe half of them - for instance, that Dominguez had bought eight hundred barrels of mulled mead from Madam Rosmerta. It seemed to be fact, however, that he had booked the Weird Sisters. Exactly who or what the Weird Sisters were Roberto didn't know, never having had access to a wizard's wireless, but he deduced from the wild excitement of those who had grown up
　　listening to the WWN (Wizarding Wireless Network) that they were a very famous musical group.
　　Some of the teachers, like little Professor Flitwick, gave up trying to teach them much when their minds were so clearly elsewhere; he allowed them to play games in his lesson on Wednesday, and spent most of it talking to Roberto about the perfect Summoning Charm Roberto had used during the first task of the Triwizard Tournament. Other teachers were not so generous. Nothing would ever deflect Professor Binns, for example, from plowing on through his notes on goblin rebellions - as Binns hadn't let his own death stand in the way of continuing to teach, they supposed a small thing like Christmas wasn't going to put him off. It was amazing how he could make even bloody and vicious goblin riots sound as boring as Miguels cauldron-bottom report. Professors Romero and Acosta kept them working until the very last second of their classes too, and Peralta, of course, would no sooner let them play games in class than adopt Roberto. Staring nastily around at them all, he informed them that he would be testing them on poison antidotes during the last lesson of the term.
　　"Evil, he is," Diego said bitterly that night in the Gryffindor common room. "Springing a test on us on the last day. Ruining the last bit of term with a whole load of studying."
　　"Mmm . . . you're not exactly straining yourself, though, are you?" said Carolina, looking at him over the top of her Potions notes. Diego was busy building a card castle out of his Exploding Snap pack - a much more interesting pastime than with Muggle cards, because of the chance that the whole thing would blow up at any second.
　　"It's Christmas, Carolina," said Roberto lazily; he was rereading Flying with the Cannons for the tenth time in an armchair near the fire.
　　Carolina looked severely over at him too. "I'd have thought you'd be doing something constructive, Roberto, even if you don't want to learn your antidotes!"
　　"Like what?" Roberto said as he watched Joey Jenkins of the Cannons belt a Bludger toward a Ballycastle Bats Chaser.
　　"That egg!" Carolina hissed.
　　"Come on, Carolina, I've got till February the twenty-fourth," Roberto said.
　　He had put the golden egg upstairs in his trunk and hadn't opened it since the celebration party after the first task. There were still two and a half months to go until he needed to know what all the screechy wailing meant, after all.
　　"But it might take weeks to work it out!" said Carolina. "You're going to look a real idiot if everyone else knows what the next task is and you don't!"
　　"Leave him alone, Carolina, he's earned a bit of a break," said Diego, and he placed the last two cards on top of the castle and the whole lot blew up, singeing his eyebrows.
　　"Nice look, Diego ... go well with your dress robes, that will."
　　It was Pablo and Luis. They sat down at the table with Roberto, Diego, and Carolina as Diego felt how much damage had been done.
　　"Diego, can we borrow Pigwidgeon?" Luis asked.
　　"No, he's off delivering a letter," said Diego. "Why?"
　　"Because Luis wants to invite him to the ball," said Pablo sarcastically.
　　"Because we want to send a letter, you stupid great prat," said Luis.
　　"Who d'you two keep writing to, eh?" said Diego.
　　"Nose out, Diego, or I'll burn that for you too," said Pablo, waving his wand threateningly.
　　"So . . . you lot got dates for the ball yet?"
　　"Nope," said Diego.
　　"Well, you'd better hurry up, mate, or all the good ones will be gone," said Pablo.
　　"Who're you going with, then?" said Diego.
　　"Angelina," said Pablo promptly, without a trace of embarrassment.
　　"What?" said Diego, taken aback. "You've already asked her?"
　　"Good point," said Pablo. He turned his head and called across the common room, "Oi!
　　Angelina!"
　　Angelina, who had been chatting with Alicia Spinnet near the fire, looked over at him.
　　"What?" she called back.
　　"Want to come to the ball with me?"
　　Angelina gave Pablo an appraising sort of look.
　　"All right, then," she said, and she turned back to Alicia and carried on chatting with a bit of a grin on her face.
　　"There you go," said Pablo to Roberto and Diego, "piece of cake."
　　He got to his feet, yawning, and said, "We'd better use a school owl then, Luis, come
　　on. .. ."
　　They left. Diego stopped feeling his eyebrows and looked across the smoldering wreck of his card castle at Roberto.
　　"We should get a move on, you know . . . ask someone. He's right. We don't want to end up with a pair of trolls."
　　Carolina let out a sputter of indignation.
　　"A pair of... what, excuse me?"
　　"Well - you know," said Diego, shrugging. "I'd rather go alone than with - with Eloise Midgen, say."
　　"Her acne's loads better lately - and she's really nice!"
　　"Her nose is off-center," said Diego.
　　"Oh I see," Carolina said, bristling. "So basically, you're going to take the best-looking girl who'll have you, even if she's completely horrible?"
　　"Er - yeah, that sounds about right," said Diego.
　　"I'm going to bed," Carolina snapped, and she swept off toward the girls' staircase without another word.
　　The Hogwarts staff, demonstrating a continued desire to impress the visitors from Beauxbatons and Durmstrang, seemed determined to show the castle at its best this Christmas. When the decorations went up. Roberto noticed that they were the most stunning he had yet seen inside the school. Everlasting icicles had been attached to the banisters of the marble staircase; the usual twelve Christmas trees in the Great Hall were bedecked with everything from luminous holly berries to real, hooting, golden owls, and the suits of armor had all been bewitched to sing carols whenever anyone passed them.
　　It was quite something to hear "0 Come, All Ye Faithful" sung by an empty helmet that only knew half the words. Several times, Filch the caretaker had to extract Peeves from inside the armor, where he had taken to hiding, filling in the gaps in the songs with lyrics of his own invention, all of which were very rude.
　　And still. Roberto hadn't asked Paula to the ball. He and Diego were getting very nervous now, though as Roberto pointed out, Diego would look much less stupid than he would without a partner; Roberto was supposed to be starting the dancing with the other champions.
　　"I suppose there's always Moaning Myrtle," he said gloomily, referring to the ghost who haunted the girls' toilets on the second floor.
　　"Roberto - we've just got to grit our teeth and do it," said Diego on Friday morning, in a tone that suggested they were planning the storming of an impregnable fortress. "When we get back to the common room tonight, we'll both have partners - agreed?"
　　"Er . . . okay," said Roberto.
　　But every time he glimpsed Paula that day - during break, and then lunchtime, and once on the way to History of Magic - she was surrounded by friends. Didn't she ever go anywhere alone? Could he perhaps ambush her as she was going into a bathroom? But no - she even seemed to go there with an escort of four or five girls. Yet if he didn't do it soon, she was bound to have been asked by somebody else.
　　He found it hard to concentrate on Peralta's Potions test, and consequently forgot to add the key ingredient - a bezoar - meaning that he received bottom marks. He didn't care, though; he was too busy screwing up his courage for what he was about to do. When the bell rang, he grabbed his bag, and hurried to the dungeon door.
　　"I'll meet you at dinner," he said to Diego and Carolina, and he dashed off upstairs.
　　He'd just have to ask Paula for a private word, that was all. ... He hurried off through the packed corridors looking for her, and (rather sooner than he had expected) he found her, emerging from a Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson.
　　"Er - Paula? Could I have a word with you?"
　　Giggling should be made illegal. Roberto thought furiously, as all the girls around Paula started doing it. She didn't, though. She said, "Okay," and followed him out of earshot other classmates.
　　Roberto turned to look at her and his stomach gave a weird lurch as though he had missed a step going downstairs.
　　"Er," he said.
　　He couldn't ask her. He couldn't. But he had to. Paula stood there looking puzzled, watching him. The words came out before Roberto had quite got his tongue around them.
　　"Wangoballwime?"
　　"Sorry?" said Paula.
　　"D'you - d'you want to go to the ball with me?" said Roberto. Why did he have to go red now? Why?
　　"Oh!" s aid Paula, and she went red too. "Oh Roberto, I'm really sorry," and she truly looked it. "I've already said I'll go with someone else."
　　"Oh," said Roberto.
　　It was odd; a moment before his insides had been writhing like snakes, but suddenly he didn't seem to have any insides at all.
　　"Oh okay," he said, "no problem."
　　"I'm really sorry," she said again.
　　"That's okay," said Roberto.
　　They stood there looking at each other, and then Paula said, "Well-"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto.
　　"Well, 'bye," said Paula, still very red. She walked away.
　　Roberto called after her, before he could stop himself.
　　"Who're you going with?"
　　"Oh - Nicolas," she said. "Nicolas Ortega."
　　"Oh right," said Roberto.
　　His insides had come back again. It felt as though they had been filled with lead in their absence.
　　Completely forgetting about dinner, he walked slowly back up to Gryffindor Tower, Paula's voice echoing in his ears with every step he took. "Nicolas - Nicolas Ortega." He had been starting to quite like Nicolas - prepared to overlook the fact that he had once beaten him at Quidditch, and was handsome, and popular, and nearly everyone's favorite champion. Now he suddenly realized that Nicolas was in fact a useless pretty boy who didn't have enough brains to fill an eggcup.
　　"Fairy lights," he said dully to the Fat Lady - the password had been changed the previous day.
　　"Yes, indeed, dear!" she trilled, straightening her new tinsel hair band as she swung forward to admit him.
　　Entering the common room, Roberto looked around, and to his surprise he saw Diego sitting ashen-faced in a distant corner. Martina was sitting with him, talking to him in what seemed to be a low, soothing voice.
　　"What's up, Diego?" said Roberto, joining them.
　　Diego looked up at Roberto, a sort of blind horror in his face.
　　"Why did I do it?" he said wildly. "I don't know what made me do it!
　　"What?" said Roberto.
　　"He - er - just asked Camila Saenz to go to the ball with him," said Martina. She looked as though she was fighting back a smile, but she kept patting Diego's arm sympathetically.
　　"You what?' said Roberto.
　　"I don't know what made me do it!" Diego gasped again. "What was I playing at? There were people - all around - I've gone mad - everyone watching! I was just walking past her in the entrance hall - she was standing there talking to Ortega - and it sort of came over me - and I asked her!"
　　Diego moaned and put his face in his hands. He kept talking, though the words were barely distinguishable.
　　"She looked at me like I was a sea slug or something. Didn't even answer. And then - I dunno - I just sort of came to my senses and ran for it."
　　"She's part veela," said Roberto. "You were right - her grandmother was one. It wasn't your fault, I bet you just walked past when she was turning on the old charm for Ortega and got a blast of it - but she was wasting her time. He's going with Paula Mejia."
　　Diego looked up.
　　"I asked her to go with me just now," Roberto said dully, "and she told me."
　　Martina had suddenly stopped smiling.
　　"This is mad," said Diego. "We're the only ones left who haven't got anyone - well, except Mauricio. Hey - guess who he asked? Carolina!"
　　"What?" said Roberto, completely distracted by this startling news.
　　"Yeah, I know!" said Diego, some of the color coming back into his face as he started to laugh. "He told me after Potions! Said she's always been really nice, helping him out with work and stuff- but she told him she was already going with someone. Ha! As if!
　　She just didn't want to go with Mauricio ... I mean, who would?"
　　"Don't!" said Martina, annoyed. "Don't laugh -"
　　Just then Carolina climbed in through the portrait hole.
　　"Why weren't you two at dinner?" she said, coming over to join them.
　　"Because - oh shut up laughing, you two - because they've both just been turned down by girls they asked to the ball!" said Martina.
　　That shut Roberto and Diego up.
　　"Thanks a bunch, Martina," said Diego sourly.
　　"All the good-looking ones taken, Diego?" said Carolina loftily. "Eloise Midgen starting to look quite pretty now, is she? Well, I'm sure you'll find someone somewhere who'll have you."
　　But Diego was staring at Carolina as though suddenly seeing her in a whole new light.
　　"Carolina, Mauricio's right - you are a girl. . . ."
　　"Oh well spotted," she said acidly.
　　"Well - you can come with one of us!"
　　"No, I can't," snapped Carolina.
　　"Oh come on," he said impatiently, "we need partners, we're going to look really stupid if we haven't got any, everyone else has . . ."
　　"I can't come with you," said Carolina, now blushing, "because I'm already going with someone."
　　"No, you're not!" said Diego. "You just said that to get rid of Mauricio!"
　　"Oh did I?" said Carolina, and her eyes flashed dangerously. "Just because it's taken you three years to notice, Diego, doesn't mean no one else has spotted I'm a girl!"
　　Diego stared at her. Then he grinned again.
　　"Okay, okay, we know you're a girl," he said. "That do? Will you come now?"
　　"I've already told you!" Carolina said very angrily. "I'm going with someone else!"
　　And she stormed off toward the girls' dormitories again.
　　"She's lying," said Diego flatly, watching her go.
　　"She's not," said Martina quietly.
　　"Who is it then?" said Diego sharply.
　　"I'm not telling you, it's her business," said Martina.
　　"Right," said Diego, who looked extremely put out, "this is getting stupid. Martina, you can go with Roberto, and I'll just -"
　　"I can't," said Martina, and she went scarlet too. "I'm going with - with Mauricio. He asked me when Carolina said no, and I thought. . . well. . . I'm not going to be able to go otherwise, I'm not in fourth year." She looked extremely miserable. "I think I'll go and have dinner," she said, and she got up and walked off to the portrait hole, her head bowed.
　　Diego goggled at Roberto.
　　"What's got into them?" he demanded.
　　But Roberto had just seen Parvati and Lavender come in through the portrait hole. The time had come for drastic action.
　　"Wait here," he said to Diego, and he stood up, walked straight up to Parvati, and said, "Parvati? Will you go to the ball with me?"
　　Parvati went into a fit of giggles. Roberto waited for them to subside, his fingers crossed in the pocket of his robes.
　　"Yes, all right then," she said finally, blushing furiously.
　　"Thanks," said Roberto, in relief. "Lavender - will you go with Diego?"
　　"She's going with Seamus," said Parvati, and the pair of them giggled harder than ever.
　　Roberto sighed.
　　"Can't you think of anyone who'd go with Diego?" he said, lowering his voice so that Diego wouldn't hear.
　　"What about Carolina Fernandez?" said Parvati.
　　"She's going with someone else."
　　Parvati looked astonished.
　　"Ooooh - who?" she said keenly.
　　Roberto shrugged. "No idea," he said. "So what about Diego?"
　　"Well. . ." said Parvati slowly, "I suppose my sister might. . . Padma, you know ... in Ravenclaw. I'll ask her if you like."
　　"Yeah, that would be great," said Roberto. "Let me know, will you?"
　　And he went back over to Diego, feeling that this ball was a lot more trouble than it was worth, and hoping very much that Padma Patil's nose was dead center.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE - THE YULE BALL
　　Despite the very heavy load of homework that the fourth years had been given for the holidays. Roberto was in no mood to work when term ended, and spent the week leading up to Christmas enjoying himself as fully as possible along with everyone else. Gryffindor Tower was hardly less crowded now than during term-time; it seemed to have shrunk slightly too, as its inhabitants were being so much rowdier than usual. Pablo and Luis had had a great success with their Canary Creams, and for the first couple of days of the holidays, people kept bursting into feather all over the place. Before long, however, all the Gryffindors had learned to treat food anybody else offered them with extreme caution, in case it had a Canary Cream concealed in the center, and Luis confided to Roberto that he and Pablo were now working on developing something else. Roberto made a mental note never to accept so much as a crisp from Pablo and Luis in future. He still hadn't forgotten Leonardo and the Ton-Tongue Toffee.
　　Snow was falling thickly upon the castle and its grounds now. The pale blue Beauxbatons carriage looked like a large, chilly, frosted pumpkin next to the iced gingerbread house that was Villalba's cabin, while the Durmstrang ship's portholes were glazed with ice, the rigging white with frost. The house-elves down in the kitchen were outdoing themselves with a series of rich, warming stews and savory puddings, and only Camila Saenz seemed to be able to find anything to complain about.
　　"It is too 'eavy, all zis 'Ogwarts food," they heard her saying grumpily as they left the Great Hall behind her one evening (Diego skulking behind Roberto, keen not to be spotted by Camila). "I will not fit into my dress robes!"
　　"Oooh there's a tragedy," Carolina snapped as Camila went out into the entrance hall. "She really thinks a lot of herself, that one, doesn't she?"
　　"Carolina - who are you going to the ball with?" said Diego.
　　He kept springing this question on her, hoping to startle her into a response by asking it when she least expected it. However, Carolina merely frowned and said, "I'm not telling you, you'll just make fun of me."
　　"You're joking, Lopez!" said Sosa, behind them. "You're not telling me someone's asked that to the ball? Not the long-molared Mudblood?"
　　; Roberto and Diego both whipped around, but Carolina said loudly, waving to somebody over Sosas shoulder, "Hello, Professor Acosta!"
　　Sosa went pale and jumped backward, looking wildly around for Acosta, but he was still up at the staff table, finishing his stew.
　　"Twitchy little ferret, aren't you, Sosa?" said Carolina scathingly, and she, Roberto, and Diego went up the marble staircase laughing heartily.
　　"Carolina," said Diego, looking sideways at her, suddenly frowning, "your teeth ..."
　　"What about them?" she said.
　　"Well, they're different. . . I've just noticed. . . ."
　　"Of course they are - did you expect me to keep those fangs Sosa gave me?"
　　"No, I mean, they're different to how they were before he put that hex on you. . . .
　　They're all... straight and - and normal-sized."
　　Carolina suddenly smiled very mischievously, and Roberto noticed it too: It was a very different smile from the one he remembered.
　　"Well. . . when I went up to Madam Pomfrey to get them shrunk, she held up a mirror and told me to stop her when they were back to how they normally were," she said. "And I just. . . let her carry on a bit." She smiled even more widely. "Mum and Dad won't be too pleased. I've been trying to persuade them to let me shrink them for ages, but they wanted me to carry on with my braces. You know, they're dentists, they just don't think teeth and magic should - look! Pigwidgeons back!"
　　Diego's tiny owl was twittering madly on the top of the icicle-laden banisters, a scroll of parchment tied to his leg. People passing him were pointing and laughing, and a group of third-year girls paused and said, "Oh look at the weeny owl! Isn't he cute?"
　　Stupid little feathery git!" Diego hissed, hurrying up the stairs and snatching up Pigwidgeon. "You bring letters to the addressee! You don't hang around showing off!"
　　Pigwidgeon hooted happily, his head protruding over Diego's fist. The third-year girls all looked very shocked.
　　"Clear off!" Diego snapped at them, waving the fist holding Pigwidgeon, who hooted more
　　happily than ever as he soared through the air. "Here - take it, Roberto," Diego added in an undertone as the third-year girls scuttled away looking scandalized. He pulled Gustavo's reply off Pigwidgeons leg. Roberto pocketed it, and they hurried back to Gryffindor Tower to read it.
　　Everyone in the common room was much too busy in letting off more holiday steam to observe what anyone else was up to. Diego, Roberto, and Carolina sat apart from everyone else by a dark window that was gradually filling up with snow, and Roberto read out:
　　Dear Roberto, Congratulations on getting past the Horntail. Whoever put your name in that goblet shouldn't be feeling too happy right now! I was going to suggest a Conjunctivitus Curse, as a dragon's eyes are its weakest point - "That's what Krum did!" Carolina whispered -but your way was better, I'm impressed.
　　Don't get complacent, though. Roberto. You've only done one task; whoever put you in for the tournament's got plenty more opportunity if they're trying to hurt you. Keep your eyes open -particularly when the person we discussed is around and concentrate on keeping yourself out of trouble.
　　Keep in touch, I still want to hear about anything unusual.
　　Gustavo "He sounds exactly like Acosta," said Roberto quietly, tucking the letter away again inside his robes. "'Constant vigilance!' You'd think I walk around with my eyes shut, banging off the walls. ..."
　　"But he's right, Roberto," said Carolina, "you have still got two tasks to do. You really ought to have a look at that egg, you know, and start working out what it means. . . ."
　　"Carolina, he's got ages!" snapped Diego. "Want a game of chess, Roberto?"
　　"Yeah, okay," said Roberto. Then, spotting the look on Carolina's face, he said, "Come on, how'm I supposed to concentrate with all this noise going on? I won't even be able to hear the egg over this lot."
　　"Oh I suppose not," she sighed, and she sat down to watch their chess match, which culminated in an exciting checkmate of Diego's, involving a couple of recklessly brave pawns and a very violent bishop.
　　Roberto awoke very suddenly on Christmas Day. Wondering what had caused his abrupt return to consciousness, he opened his eyes, and saw something with very large, round, green eyes staring back at him in the darkness, so close they were almost nose to nose.
　　"Dobby!" Roberto yelled, scrambling away from the elf so fast he almost fell out of bed.
　　"Don't do that!"
　　"Dobby is sorry, sir!" squeaked Dobby anxiously, jumping backward with his long fingers over his mouth. "Dobby is only wanting to wish Roberto Gonzales 'Merry Christmas' and bring him a present, Sir! Roberto Gonzales did say Dobby could come and see him sometimes, sir!"
　　It's okay," said Roberto, still breathing rather faster than usual, while his heart rate returned to normal. "Just - just prod me or something in future, all right, don't bend over me like that. .."
　　Roberto pulled back the curtains around his four-poster, took his glasses from his bedside table, and put them on. His yell had awoken Diego, Seamus, Dean, and Mauricio. All of them were peering through the gaps in their own hangings, heavy-eyed and tousle-haired.
　　"Someone attacking you, Roberto?" Seamus asked sleepily.
　　"No, it's just Dobby," Roberto muttered. "Go back to sleep."
　　"Nah . . . presents!" said Seamus, spotting the large pile at the foot of his bed. Diego, Dean, and Mauricio decided that now they were awake they might as well get down to some present-opening too. Roberto turned back to Dobby, who was now standing nervously next to Robertos bed, still looking worried that he had upset Roberto. There was a Christmas bauble tied to the loop on top of his tea cozy.
　　"Can Dobby give Roberto Gonzales his present?" he squeaked tentatively.
　　"'Course you can," said Roberto. "Er. . . I've got something for you too."
　　It was a lie; he hadn't bought anything for Dobby at all, but he quickly opened his trunk and pulled out a particularly knobbly rolled-up pair of socks. They were his oldest and foulest, mustard yellow, and had once belonged to Uncle Francisco. The reason they were extra-knobbly was that Roberto had been using them to cushion his Sneakoscope for over a year now. He pulled out the Sneako-scope and handed the socks to Dobby, saying, "Sorry, I forgot to wrap them..."
　　But Dobby was utterly delighted.
　　"Socks are Dobby's favorite, favorite clothes, sir!" he said, ripping off his odd ones and pulling on Uncle Francisco's. "I has seven now, sir. . . . But sir ..." he said, his eyes widening, having pulled both socks up to their highest extent, so that they reached to the bottom of his shorts, "they has made a mistake in the shop, Roberto Gonzales, they is giving you two the same!"
　　"Ah, no, Roberto, how come you didn't spot that?" said Diego, grinning over from his own bed, which was now strewn with wrapping paper. "Tell you what, Dobby - here you go - take these two, and you can mix them up properly. And here's your sweater."
　　He threw Dobby a pair of violet socks he had just unwrapped, and the hand-knitted sweater Mrs. Lopez had sent, Dobby looked quite overwhelmed.
　　"Sir is very kind!" he squeaked, his eyes brimming with tears again, bowing deeply to Diego. "Dobby knew sir must be a great wizard, for he is Roberto Gonzales's greatest friend, but Dobby did not know that he was also as generous of spirit, as noble, as selfless -"
　　"They're only socks," said Diego, who had gone slightly pink around the ears, though he looked rather pleased all the same. "Wow, Roberto -" He had just opened Roberto's present, a Chudley Cannon hat. "Cool!" He jammed it onto his head, where it clashed horribly with his hair.
　　Dobby now handed Roberto a small package, which turned out to be - socks.
　　"Dobby is making them himself, sir!" the elf said happily. "He is buying the wool out of his wages, sir!"
　　The left sock was bright red and had a pattern of broomsticks upon it; the right sock was green with a pattern of Snitches.
　　"They're . . . they're really . . . well, thanks, Dobby," said Roberto, and he pulled them on, causing Dobby's eyes to leak with happiness again.
　　"Dobby must go now, sir, we is already making Christmas dinner in the kitchens!" said Dobby, and he hurried out of the dormitory, waving good-bye to Diego and the others as he passed.
　　Roberto's other presents were much more satisfactory than Dobby's odd socks - with the obvious exception of the Carrizos', which consisted of a single tissue, an all-time low -Roberto supposed they too were remember ing the Ton-Tongue Toffee. Carolina had given Roberto a book called Quidditch Teams of Britain and Ireland; Diego, a bulging bag of Dungbombs; Gustavo, a handy penknife with attachments to unlock any lock and undo any knot; and Villalba, a vast box of sweets including all Robertos favorites: Bertie Bott's Every Flavor Beans, Paulacolate Frogs, Drooble's Best Blowing Gum, and Fizzing Whizbees.
　　There was also, of course, Mrs. Lopez's usual package, including a new sweater (green, with a picture of a dragon on it - Roberto supposed Charlie had told her all about the Horntail), and a large quantity of homemade mince pies.
　　Roberto and Diego met up with Carolina in the common room, and they went down to breakfast together. They spent most of the morning in Gryffindor Tower, where everyone was enjoying their presents, then returned to the Great Hall for a magnificent lunch, which included at least a hundred turkeys and Christmas puddings, and large piles of Cribbage's Wizarding Crackers.
　　They went out onto the grounds in the afternoon; the snow was untouched except for the deep channels made by the Durmstrang and Beauxbatons students on their way up to the castle. Carolina chose to watch Roberto and the Lopezs' snowball fight rather than join in, and at five o'clock said she was going back upstairs to get ready for the ball.
　　"What, you need three hours?" said Diego, looking at her incredulously and paying for his lapse in concentration when a large snowball, thrown by Luis, hit him hard on the side of the head. "Who're you going with?" he yelled after Carolina, but she just waved and disappeared up the stone steps into the castle.
　　There was no Christmas tea today, as the ball included a feast, so at seven o'clock, when it had become hard to aim properly, the others abandoned their snowball fight and trooped back to the common room. The Fat Lady was sitting in her frame with her friend Violet from downstairs, both of them extremely tipsy, empty boxes of chocolate liqueurs littering the bottom other picture.
　　"Lairy fights, that's the one!" she giggled when they gave the password, and she swung forward to let them inside.
　　Roberto, Diego, Seamus, Dean, and Mauricio changed into their dress robes up in their dormitory, all of them looking very self-conscious, but none as much as Diego, who surveyed himself in the long mirror in the corner with an appalled look on his face. There was
　　just no getting around the fact that his robes looked more like a dress than anything else. In a desperate attempt to make them look more manly, he used a Severing Charm on the ruff and cuffs. It worked fairly well; at least he was now lace-free, although he hadn't done a very neat job, and the edges still looked depressingly frayed as the boys set off downstairs.
　　"I still can't work out how you two got the best-looking girls in the year," muttered Dean.
　　"Animal magnetism," said Diego gloomily, pulling stray threads out of his cuffs.
　　The common room looked strange, full of people wearing different colors instead of the usual mass of black. Parvati was waiting for Roberto at the foot of the stairs. She looked very pretty indeed, in robes of shocking pink, with her long dark plait braided with gold, and gold bracelets glimmering at her wrists. Roberto was relieved to see that she wasn't giggling.
　　"You - er - look nice," he said awkwardly.
　　"Thanks," she said. "Padma's going to meet you in the entrance hall," she added to Diego.
　　"Right," said Diego, looking around. "Where's Carolina?"
　　Parvati shrugged. "Shall we go down then, Roberto?"
　　"Okay," said Roberto, wishing he could just stay in the common room. Pablo winked at Roberto as he passed him on the way out of the portrait hole.
　　The entrance hall was packed with students too, all milling around waiting for eight o'clock, when the doors to the Great Hall would be thrown open. Those people who were meeting partners from different Houses were edging through the crowd trying to find one another. Parvati found her sister, Padma, and led her over to Roberto and Diego.
　　"Hi," said Padma, who was looking just as pretty as Parvati in robes of bright turquoise.
　　She didn't look too enthusiastic about having Diego as a partner, though; her dark eyes lingered on the frayed neck and sleeves of his dress robes as she looked him up and down.
　　"Hi," said Diego, not looking at her, but staring around at the crowd. "Oh no ..."
　　He bent his knees slightly to hide behind Roberto, because Camila Saenz was passing, looking stunning in robes of silver-gray satin, and accompanied by the Ravenclaw Quidditch captain, Roger Davies. When they had disappeared, Diego stood straight again and stared over the heads of the crowd.
　　"Where is Carolina?" he said again.
　　A group of Slytherins came up the steps from their dungeon common room. Sosa was in front; he was wearing dress robes of black velvet with a high collar, which in Roberto's opinion made him look like a vicar. Pansy Parkinson in very frilly robes of pale pink was clutching Sosa's arm. Crabbe and Goyle were both wearing green; they resembled moss-colored boulders, and neither of them, Roberto was pleased to see, had managed to find a partner.
　　The oak front doors opened, and everyone turned to look as the Durmstrang students entered with Professor Morales. Krum was at the front of the party, accompanied by a pretty girl in blue robes Roberto didn't know. Over their heads he saw that an area of lawn right in front of the castle had been transformed into a sort of grotto full of fairy lights - meaning hundreds of actual living fairies were sitting in the rosebushes that had been conjured there, and fluttering over the statues of what seemed to be Father Christmas and his reindeer.
　　Then Professor Romero's voice called, "Champions over here, please!"
　　Parvati readjusted her bangles, beaming; she and Roberto said, "See you in a minute" to Diego and Padma and walked forward, the chattering crowd parting to let them through. Professor Romero, who was wearing dress robes of red tartan and had arranged a rather ugly wreath of thistles around the brim other hat, told them to wait on one side of the doors while everyone else went inside; they were to enter the Great Hall in procession when the rest of the students had sat down. Camila Saenz and Roger Davies stationed themselves nearest the doors; Davies looked so stunned by his good fortune in having Camila for a partner that he could hardly take his eyes off her. Nicolas and Paula were close to Roberto too; he looked away from them so he wouldn't have to talk to them. His eyes fell instead on the girl next to Krum. His jaw dropped.
　　It was Carolina.
　　But she didn't look like Carolina at all. She had done something with her hair; it was no longer bushy but sleek and shiny, and twisted up into an elegant knot at the back of her head. She was wearing robes made of a floaty, periwinkle-blue material, and she was holding herself differently, somehow - or maybe it was merely the absence of the twenty
　　or so books she usually had slung over her back. She was also smiling - rather nervously, it was true - but the reduction in the size of her front teeth was more noticeable than ever; Roberto couldn't understand how he hadn't spotted it before.
　　"Hi, Roberto!" she said. "Hi, Parvati!"
　　Parvati was gazing at Carolina in unflattering disbelief. She wasn't the only one either; when the doors to the Great Hall opened, Krum's fan club from the library stalked past, throwing Carolina looks of deepest loathing. Pansy Parkinson gaped at her as she walked by with Sosa, and even he didn't seem to be able to find an insult to throw at her. Diego, however, walked right past Carolina without looking at her.
　　Once everyone else was settled in the Hall, Professor Romero told the champions and their partners to get in line in pairs and to follow her. They did so, and everyone in the Great Hall applauded as they entered and started walking up toward a large round table at the top of the Hall, where the judges were sitting.
　　The walls of the Hall had all been covered in sparkling silver frost, with hundreds of garlands of mistletoe and ivy crossing the starry black ceiling. The House tables had vanished; instead, there were about a hundred smaller, lantern-lit ones, each seating about a dozen people.
　　Roberto concentrated on not tripping over his feet. Parvati seemed to be enjoying herself; she was beaming around at everybody, steering Roberto so forcefully that he felt as though he were a show dog she was putting through its paces. He caught sight of Diego and Padma as he neared the top table. Diego was watching Carolina pass with narrowed eyes. Padma was looking sulky.
　　Dominguez smiled happily as the champions approached the top table, but Morales wore an expression remarkably like Diego's as he watched Krum and Carolina draw nearer. Ludo Bagman, tonight in robes of bright purple with large yellow stars, was clapping as enthusiastically as any of the students; and Madame Maxime, who had changed her usual uniform of black satin for a flowing gown of lavender silk, was applauding them politely.
　　But Mr. Crouch, Roberto suddenly realized, was not there. The fifth seat at the table was occupied by Miguel Lopez.
　　When the champions and their partners reached the table, Miguel drew out the empty chair beside him, staring pointedly at Roberto. Roberto took the hint and sat down next to Miguel, who was wearing brand-new, navy-blue dress robes and an expression of such smugness that Roberto thought it ought to be fined.
　　"I've been promoted," Miguel said before Roberto could even ask, and from his tone, he might have been announcing his election as supreme ruler of the universe. "I'm now Mr.
　　Crouch's personal assistant, and I'm here representing him."
　　"Why didn't he come?" Roberto asked. He wasn't looking forward to being lectured on cauldron bottoms all through dinner.
　　"I'm afraid to say Mr. Crouch isn't well, not well at all. Hasn't been right since the World Cup. Hardly surprising - overwork. He's not as young as he was - though still quite brilliant, of course, the mind remains as great as it ever was. But the World Cup was a fiasco for the whole Ministry, and then, Mr. Crouch suffered a huge personal shock with the misbehavior of that house-elf of his, Blinky, or whatever she was called. Naturally, he dismissed her immediately afterward, but - well, as I say, he's getting on, he needs looking after, and I think he's found a definite drop in his home comforts since she left. And then we had the tournament to arrange, and the aftermath of the Cup to deal with - that revolting Skeeter woman buzzing around - no, poor man, he's having a well earned, quiet Christmas. I'm just glad he knew he had someone he could rely upon to take his place."
　　Roberto wanted very much to ask whether Mr. Crouch had stopped calling Miguel "Weatherby"
　　yet, but resisted the temptation.
　　There was no food as yet on the glittering golden plates, but small menus were lying in front of each of them. Roberto picked his up uncertainly and looked around - there were no waiters. Dominguez, however, looked carefully down at his own menu, then said very clearly to his plate, "Pork chops!"
　　And pork chops appeared. Getting the idea, the rest of the table placed their orders with their plates too. Roberto glanced up at Carolina to see how she felt about this new and more complicated method of dining - surely it meant plenty of extra work for the house-elves? - but for once, Carolina didn't seem to be thinking about S.P.E.W. She was deep in talk with Viktor Krum and hardly seemed to notice what she was eating.
　　It now occurred to Roberto that he had never actually heard Krum speak before, but he was
　　certainly talking now, and very enthusiastically at that.
　　"Veil, ve have a castle also, not as big as this, nor as comfortable, I am thinking," he was telling Carolina. "Ve have just four floors, and the fires are lit only for magical purposes. But ve have grounds larger even than these - though in vinter, ve have very little daylight, so ve are not enjoying them. But in summer ve are flying every day, over the lakes and the mountains -"
　　"Now, now, Viktor!" said Morales with a laugh that didn't reach his cold eyes, "don't go giving away anything else, now, or your charming friend will know exactly where to find us!"
　　Dominguez smiled, his eyes twinkling. "Ramon, all this secrecy ., . one would almost think you didn't want visitors."
　　"Well, Dominguez," said Morales, displaying his yellowing teeth to their fullest extent, "we are all protective of our private domains, are we not? Do we not jealously guard the halls of learning that have been entrusted to us? Are we not right to be proud that we alone know our school's secrets, and right to protect them?"
　　"Oh I would never dream of assuming I know all Hogwarts' secrets, Ramon," said Dominguez amicably. "Only this morning, for instance, I took a wrong turning on the way to the bathroom and found myself in a beautifully proportioned room I have never seen before, containing a really rather magnificent collection of chamber pots. When I went back to investigate more closely, I discovered that the room had vanished. But I must keep an eye out for it. Possibly it is only accessible at five-thirty in the morning. Or it may only appear at the quarter moon - or when the seeker has an exceptionally full bladder."
　　Roberto snorted into his plate of goulash. Miguel frowned, but Roberto could have sworn Dominguez had given him a very small wink.
　　Meanwhile Camila Saenz was criticizing the Hogwarts decorations to Roger Davies.
　　"Zis is nothing," she said dismissively, looking around at the sparkling walls of the Great Hall. "At ze Palace of Beauxbatons, we 'ave ice sculptures all around ze dining chamber at Chreestmas. Zey do not melt, of course . . . zey are like 'uge statues of diamond, glittering around ze place. And ze food is seemply superb. And we 'ave choirs of wood nymphs, 'oo serenade us as we eat. We 'ave none of zis ugly armor in ze 'alls, and eef a poltergeist ever entaired into Beauxbatons, 'e would be expelled like zat."
　　She slapped her hand onto the table impatiently.
　　Roger Davies was watching her talk with a very dazed look on his face, and he kept missing his mouth with his fork. Roberto had the impression that Davies was too busy staring at Camila to take in a word she was saying.
　　"Absolutely right," he said quickly, slapping his own hand down on the table in imitation of Camila. "Like that. Yeah."
　　Roberto looked around the Hall. Villalba was sitting at one of the other staff tables; he was back in his horrible hairy brown suit and gazing up at the top table. Roberto saw him give a small wave, and looking around, saw Madame Maxime return it, her opals glittering in the candlelight.
　　Carolina was now teaching Krum to say her name properly; he kept calling her "Hermy-own."
　　"Her-my-oh-nee," she said slowly and clearly.
　　"Herm-own-ninny."
　　"Close enough," she said, catching Roberto's eye and grinning.
　　When all the food had been consumed, Dominguez stood up and asked the students to do the same. Then, with a wave of his wand, all the tables zoomed back along the walls leaving the floor clear, and then he conjured a raised platform into existence along the right wall. A set of drums, several guitars, a lute, a cello, and some bagpipes were set upon it.
　　The "Weird Sisters now trooped up onto the stage to wildly enthusiastic applause; they were all extremely hairy and dressed in black robes that had been artfully ripped and torn. They picked up their instruments, and Roberto, who had been so interested in watching them that he had almost forgotten what was coming, suddenly realized that the lanterns on all the other tables had gone out, and that the other champions and their partners were standing up.
　　"Come on!" Parvati hissed. "We're supposed to dance!"
　　Roberto tripped over his dress robes as he stood up. The Weird Sisters struck up a slow, mournful tune; Roberto walked onto the brightly lit dance floor, carefully avoiding catching anyone's eye (he could see Seamus and Dean waving at him and sniggering), and next moment, Parvati had seized his hands, placed one around her waist, and was holding
　　the other tightly in hers.
