　　It wasn't as bad as it could have been. Roberto thought, revolving slowly on the spot (Parvati was steering). He kept his eyes fixed over the heads of the watching people, and very soon many of them too had come onto the dance floor, so that the champions were no longer the center of attention. Mauricio and Martina were dancing nearby - he could see Martina wincing frequently as Mauricio trod on her feet - and Dominguez was waltzing with Madame Maxime. He was so dwarfed by her that the top of his pointed hat barely tickled her chin; however, she moved very gracefully for a woman so large. Mad-Eye Acosta was doing an extremely ungainly two-step with Professor Sinistra, who was nervously avoiding his wooden leg.
　　"Nice socks. Gonzales," Acosta growled as he passed, his magical eye staring through Roberto's robes.
　　"Oh - yeah, Dobby the house-elf knitted them for me," said Roberto, grinning.
　　"He is so creepy!" Parvati whispered as Acosta clunked away. "I don't think that eye should be allowed."
　　Roberto heard the final, quavering note from the bagpipe with relief. The Weird Sisters stopped playing, applause filled the hall once more, and Roberto let go of Parvati at once.
　　"Let's sit down, shall we?"
　　"Oh - but - this is a really good one!" Parvati said as the Weird Sisters struck up a new song, which was much faster.
　　"No, I don't like it," Roberto lied, and he led her away from the dance floor, past Pablo and Angelina, who were dancing so exhuberantly that people around them were backing away in fear of injury, and over to the table where Diego and Padma were sitting.
　　"How's it going?" Roberto asked Diego, sitting down and opening a bottle of butterbeer.
　　Diego didn't answer. He was glaring at Carolina and Krum, who were dancing nearby. Padma was sitting with her arms and legs crossed, one foot jiggling in time to the music.
　　Every now and then she threw a disgruntled look at Diego, who was completely ignoring her.
　　Parvati sat down on Roberto's other side, crossed her arms and legs too, and within minutes was asked to dance by a boy from Beauxbatons.
　　"You don't mind, do you, Roberto?" Parvati said.
　　"What?" said Roberto, who was now watching Paula and Nicolas.
　　"Oh never mind," snapped Parvati, and she went off with the boy from Beauxbatons. When the song ended, she did not return.
　　Carolina came over and sat down in Parvati's empty chair. She was a bit pink in the face from dancing.
　　"Hi," said Roberto. Diego didn't say anything.
　　"It's hot, isn't it?" said Carolina, fanning herself with her hand. "Viktors just gone to get some drinks."
　　Diego gave her a withering look. "Viktor?" he said. "Hasn't he asked you to call him Vicky yet?"
　　Carolina looked at him in surprise. "What's up with you?" she said.
　　"If you don't know," said Diego scathingly, "I'm not going to tell you."
　　Carolina stared at him, then at Roberto, who shrugged.
　　"Diego, what - ?"
　　"He's from Durmstrang!" spat Diego. "He's competing against Roberto! Against Hogwarts! You -you're -" Diego was obviously casting around for words strong enough to describe Carolina's crime, "fraternizing with the enemy, that's what you're doing!"
　　Carolina's mouth fell open.
　　"Don't be so stupid!" she said after a moment. "The enemy! Honestly - who was the one who was all excited when they saw him arrive? Who was the one who wanted his autograph?
　　Who's got a model of him up in their dormitory?"
　　Diego chose to ignore this. "I s'pose he asked you to come with him while you were both in the library?"
　　"Yes, he did," said Carolina, the pink patches on her cheeks glowing more brightly. "So what?"
　　"What happened - trying to get him to join spew, were you?"
　　"No, I wasn't! If you really want to know, he - he said he'd been coming up to the library every day to try and talk to me, but he hadn't been able to pluck up the courage!"
　　Carolina said this very quickly, and blushed so deeply that she was the same color as Parvati's robes.
　　"Yeah, well - that's his story," said Diego nastily.
　　"And what's that supposed to mean?"
　　"Obvious, isn't it? He's Morales's student, isn't he? He knows who you hang around with. . . . He's just trying to get closer to Roberto - get inside information on him - or get near enough to jinx him -"
　　Carolina looked as though Diego had slapped her. When she spoke, her voice quivered.
　　"For your information, he hasn't asked me one single thing about Roberto, not one -"
　　Diego changed tack at the speed of light.
　　"Then he's hoping you'll help him find out what his egg means! I suppose you've been putting your heads together during those cozy little library sessions -"
　　"I'd never help him work out that egg!" said Carolina, looking outraged. "Never. How could you say something like that - I want Roberto to win the tournament. Roberto knows that, don't you, Roberto?"
　　"You've got a funny way of showing it," sneered Diego.
　　"This whole tournament's supposed to be about getting to know foreign wizards and making friends with them!" said Carolina hotly.
　　"No it isn't!" shouted Diego. "It's about winning!"
　　People were starting to stare at them.
　　"Diego," said Roberto quietly, "I haven't got a problem with Carolina coming with Krum -"
　　But Diego ignored Roberto too.
　　"Why don't you go and find Vicky, he'll be wondering where you are," said Diego.
　　"Don't call him Vicky!"
　　Carolina jumped to her feet and stormed off across the dance floor, disappearing into the crowd. Diego watched her go with a mixture of anger and satisfaction on his face.
　　"Are you going to ask me to dance at all?" Padma asked him.
　　"No," said Diego, still glaring after Carolina.
　　"Fine," snapped Padma, and she got up and went to join Parvati and the Beauxbatons boy, who conjured up one of his friends to join them so fast that Roberto could have sworn he had zoomed him there by a Summoning Charm.
　　"Vare is Herm-own-ninny?" said a voice.
　　Krum had just arrived at their table clutching two butterbeers.
　　"No idea," said Diego mulishly, looking up at him. "Lost her, have you?"
　　Krum was looking surly again.
　　"Veil, if you see her, tell her I haff drinks," he said, and he slouched off.
　　"Made friends with Viktor Krum, have you, Diego?"
　　Miguel had bustled over, rubbing his hands together and looking extremely pompous.
　　"Excellent! That's the whole point, you know - international magical cooperation!"
　　To Roberto's displeasure, Miguel now took Padma's vacated seat. The top table was now empty; Professor Dominguez was dancing with Professor Sprout, Ludo Bagman with Professor Romero; Madame Maxime and Villalba were cutting a wide path around the dance floor as they waltzed through the students, and Morales was nowhere to be seen. When the next song ended, everybody applauded once more, and Roberto saw Ludo Bagman kiss Professor Romero's hand and make his way back through the crowds, at which point Pablo and Luis accosted him.
　　"What do they think they're doing, annoying senior Ministry members?" Miguel hissed, watching Pablo and Luis suspiciously. "No respect..."
　　Ludo Bagman shook off Pablo and Luis fairly quickly, however, and, spotting Roberto, waved and came over to their table.
　　"I hope my brothers weren't bothering you, Mr. Bagman?" said Miguel at once.
　　"What? Oh not at all, not at all!" said Bagman. "No, they were just telling me a bit more about those fake wands of theirs. Wondering if I could advise them on the marketing. I've promised to put them in touch with a couple of contacts of mine at Zonko's Joke Shop. ..."
　　Miguel didn't look happy about this at all, and Roberto was prepared to bet he would be rushing to tell Mrs. Lopez about this the moment he got home. Apparently Pablo and Luis's plans had grown even more ambitious lately, if they were hoping to sell to the public. Bagman opened his mouth to ask Roberto something, but Miguel diverted him.
　　"How do you feel the tournament's going, Mr. Bagman? Our department's quite satisfied -the hitch with the Goblet of Fire" - he glanced at Roberto - "was a little unfortunate, of course, but it seems to have gone very smoothly since, don't you think?"
　　"Oh yes," Bagman said cheerfully, "it's all been enormous fun. How's old Barty doing?
　　Shame he couldn't come."
　　"Oh I'm sure Mr. Crouch will be up and about in no time," said Miguel importantly, "but in the meantime, I'm more than willing to take up the slack. Of course, it's not all attending balls" - he laughed airily - "oh no, I've had to deal with all sorts of things that have cropped up in his absence - you heard Ali Bashir was caught smuggling a consignment of flying carpets into the country? And then we've been trying to persuade the Transylvanians to sign the International Ban on Dueling. I've got a meeting with their Head of Magical Cooperation in the new year -"
　　"Let's go for a walk," Diego muttered to Roberto, "get away from Miguel. ..."
　　Pretending they wanted more drinks. Roberto and Diego left the table, edged around the dance floor, and slipped out into the entrance hall. The front doors stood open, and the fluttering fairy lights in the rose garden winked and twinkled as they went down the front steps, where they found themselves surrounded by bushes; winding, ornamental paths; and large stone statues. Roberto could hear splashing water, which sounded like a fountain. Here and there, people were sitting on carved benches. He and Diego set off along one of the winding paths through the rosebushes, but they had gone only a short way when they heard an unpleasantly familiar voice.
　　"... don't see what there is to fuss about, Ramon."
　　"Carlos, you cannot pretend this isn't happening!" Moraless voice sounded anxious and hushed, as though keen not to be overheard. "It's been getting clearer and clearer for months. I am becoming seriously concerned, I can't deny it _"
　　"Then flee," said Peraltas voice curtly. "Flee - I will make your excuses. I, however, am remaining at Hogwarts."
　　Peralta and Morales came around the corner. Peralta had his wand out and was blasting rosebushes apart, his expression most ill-natured. Squeals issued from many of the bushes, and dark shapes emerged from them.
　　"Ten points from Ravenclaw, Fawcett!" Peralta snarled as a girl ran past him. "And ten points from Hufflepuff too, Stebbins!" as a boy went rushing after her. "And what are you two doing?" he added, catching sight of Roberto and Diego on the path ahead. Morales, Roberto saw, looked slightly discomposed to see them standing there. His hand went nervously to his goatee, and he began winding it around his finger.
　　"We re walking," Diego told Peralta shortly. "Not against the law, is it?"
　　"Keep walking, then!" Peralta snarled, and he brushed past them, his long black cloak billowing out behind him. Morales hurried away after Peralta. Roberto and Diego continued down the path.
　　"What's got Morales all worried?" Diego muttered.
　　"And since when have he and Peralta been on first-name terms?"said Roberto slowly.
　　They had reached a large stone reindeer now, over which they could see the sparkling jets of a tall fountain. The shadowy outlines of two enormous people were visible on a stone bench, watching the water in the moonlight. And then Roberto heard Villalba speak.
　　"Momen' I saw yeh, I knew," he was saying, in an oddly husky voice.
　　Roberto and Diego froze. This didn't sound like the sort of scene they ought to walk in on, somehow. . . . Roberto looked around, back up the path, and saw Camila Saenz and Roger Davies standing half-concealed in a rosebush nearby. He tapped Diego on the shoulder and jerked his head toward them, meaning that they could easily sneak off that way without being noticed (Camila and Davies looked very busy to Roberto), but Diego, eyes widening in horror at the sight of Camila, shook his head vigorously, and pulled Roberto deeper into the shadows behind the reindeer.
　　"What did you know, 'Agrid?" said Madame Maxime, a purr in her low voice.
　　Roberto definitely didn't want to listen to this; he knew Villalba would hate to be overheard in a situation like this (he certainly would have) - if it had been possible he would have put his fingers in his ears and hummed loudly, but that wasn't really an option.
　　Instead he tried to interest himself in a beetle crawling along the stone reindeer's back, but the beetle just wasn't interesting enough to block out Villalba's next words.
　　"I jus' knew . . . knew you were like me. . . . Was it yer mother or yer father?"
　　"I - I don't know what you mean, 'Agrid. ..."
　　"It was my mother," said Villalba quietly. "She was one o' the las' ones in Britain.
　　'Course, I can' remember her too well. . . she left, see. When I was abou' three. She wasn' really the maternal sort. Well. . . it's not in their natures, is it? Dunno what happened to her . . . might be dead fer all I know. ..."
　　Madame Maxime didn't say anything. And Roberto, in spite of himself, took his eyes off the
　　beetle and looked over the top of the reindeer's antlers, listening. ... He had never heard Villalba talk about his childhood before.
　　"Me dad was broken-hearted when she wen'. Tiny little bloke, my dad was. By the time I was six I could lift him up an' put him on top o' the dresser if he annoyed me. Used ter make him laugh. . . ." Villalba's deep voice broke. Madame Maxime was listening, motionless, apparently staring at the silvery fountain. "Dad raised me . . . but he died, o' course, jus' after I started school. Sorta had ter make me own way after that.
　　Dominguez was a real help, mind. Very kind ter me, he was. . . ."
　　Villalba pulled out a large spotted silk handkerchief and blew his nose heavily.
　　"So ... anyway . . . enough abou' me. What about you? Which side you got it on?"
　　But Madame Maxime had suddenly got to her feet.
　　"It is chilly," she said - but whatever the weather was doing, it was nowhere near as cold as her voice. "I think I will go in now."
　　"Eh?" said Villalba blankly. "No, don go! I've - I've never met another one before!"
　　"Anuzzer what, precisely?" said Madame Maxime, her tone icy.
　　Roberto could have told Villalba it was best not to answer; he stood there in the shadows gritting his teeth, hoping against hope he wouldn't - but it was no good. "Another half-giant, o' course!" said Villalba.
　　"'Ow dare you!" shrieked Madame Maxime. Her voice exploded through the peaceful night air like a foghorn; behind him. Roberto heard Camila and Roger fall out of their rosebush.
　　"I 'ave nevair been more insulted in my life! 'Alf-giant? Moi? I 'ave - I 'ave big bones!"
　　She stormed away; great multicolored swarms of fairies rose into the air as she passed, angrily pushing aside bushes. Villalba was still sitting on the bench, staring after her.
　　It was much too dark to make out his expression. Then, after about a minute, he stood up and strode away, not back to the castle, but off out into the dark grounds in the direction of his cabin.
　　"C'mon," Roberto said, very quietly to Diego. "Let's go. . . ."
　　But Diego didn't move.
　　"What's up?" said Roberto, looking at him.
　　Diego looked around at Roberto, his expression very serious indeed.
　　"Did you know?" he whispered. "About Villalba being half-giant?"
　　"No," Roberto said, shrugging. "So what?"
　　He knew immediately, from the look Diego was giving him, that he was once again revealing his ignorance of the wizarding world. Brought up by the Carrizos, there were many things that wizards took for granted that were revelations to Roberto, but these surprises had become fewer with each successive year. Now, however, he could tell that most wizards would not have said "So what?" upon finding out that one of their friends had a giantess for a mother.
　　"I'll explain inside," said Diego quietly, "c'mon. . .."
　　Camila and Roger Davies had disappeared, probably into a more private clump of bushes.
　　Roberto and Diego returned to the Great Hall. Parvati and Padma were now sitting at a distant table with a whole crowd of Beauxbatons boys, and Carolina was once more dancing with Krum. Roberto and Diego sat down at a table far removed from the dance floor.
　　"So?" Roberto prompted Diego. "What's the problem with giants?"
　　"Well, they're . . . they're . . ." Diego struggled for words. ". . . not very nice," he finished lamely.
　　"Who cares?" Roberto said. "There's nothing wrong with Villalba!"
　　"I know there isn't, but. . . blimey, no wonder he keeps it quiet," Diego said, shaking his head. "I always thought he'd got in the way of a bad Engorgement Charm when he was a kid or something. Didn't like to mention it. ..."
　　"But what's it matter if his mother was a giantess?" said Roberto.
　　"Well... no one who knows him will care, 'cos they'll know he's not dangerous," said Diego slowly. "But. . . Roberto, they're just vicious, giants. It's like Villalba said, it's in their natures, they're like trolls . . . they just like killing, everyone knows that.
　　There aren't any left in Britain now, though."
　　"What happened to them?"
　　"Well, they were dying out anyway, and then loads got themselves killed by Aurors.
　　There're supposed to be giants abroad, though. . . . They hide out in mountains mostly. .
　　. ."
　　"I don't know who Maxime thinks she's kidding," Roberto said, watching Madame Maxime
　　sitting alone at the judges' table, looking very somber. "If Villalba's half-giant, she definitely is. Big bones . .. the only thing that's got bigger bones than her is a dinosaur."
　　Roberto and Diego spent the rest of the ball discussing giants in their corner, neither of them having any inclination to dance. Roberto tried not to watch Paula and Nicolas too much; it gave him a strong desire to kick something.
　　When the Weird Sisters finished playing at midnight, everyone gave them a last, loud round of applause and started to wend their way into the entrance hall. Many people were expressing the wish that the ball could have gone on longer, but Roberto was perfectly happy to be going to bed; as far as he was concerned, the evening hadn't been much fun.
　　Out in the entrance hall, Roberto and Diego saw Carolina saying good night to Krum before he went back to the Durmstrang ship. She gave Diego a very cold look and swept past him up the marble staircase without speaking. Roberto and Diego followed her, but halfway up the staircase Roberto heard someone calling him.
　　"Hey-Roberto!"
　　It was Nicolas Ortega. Roberto could see Paula waiting for him in the entrance hall below.
　　"Yeah?" said Roberto coldly as Nicolas ran up the stairs toward him.
　　Nicolas looked as though he didn't want to say whatever it was in front of Diego, who shrugged, looking bad-tempered, and continued to climb the stairs.
　　"Listen ..." Nicolas lowered his voice as Diego disappeared. "I owe you one for telling me about the dragons. You know that golden egg? Does yours wail when you open it?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto.
　　"Well... take a bath, okay?"
　　"What?"
　　"Take a bath, and - er - take the egg with you, and - er - just mull things over in the hot water. It'll help you think. . . . Trust me."
　　Roberto stared at him.
　　"Tell you what," Nicolas said, "use the prefects' bathroom. Fourth door to the left of that statue of Boris the Bewildered on the fifth floor. Password's 'pine fresh.' Gotta go ... want to say good night -"
　　He grinned at Roberto again and hurried back down the stairs to Paula.
　　Roberto walked back to Gryffindor Tower alone. That had been extremely strange advice.
　　Why would a bath help him to work out what the wailing egg meant? Was Nicolas pulling his leg? Was he trying to make Roberto look like a fool, so Paula would like him even more by comparison?
　　The Fat Lady and her friend Vi were snoozing in the picture over the portrait hole. Roberto had to yell "Fairy lights!" before he woke them up, and when he did, they were extremely irritated. He climbed into the common room and found Diego and Carolina having a blazing row. Standing ten feet apart, they were bellowing at each other, each scarlet in the face.
　　"Well, if you don't like it, you know what the solution is, don't you?" yelled Carolina; her hair was coming down out of its elegant bun now, and her face was screwed up in anger.
　　"Oh yeah?" Diego yelled back. "What's that?"
　　"Next time there's a ball, ask me before someone else does, and not as a last resort!"
　　Diego mouthed soundlessly like a goldfish out of water as Carolina turned on her heel and stormed up the girls' staircase to bed. Diego turned to look at Roberto.
　　"Well," he sputtered, looking thunderstruck, "well - that just proves - completely missed the point -"
　　Roberto didn't say anything. He liked being back on speaking terms with Diego too much to speak his mind right now - but he somehow thought that Carolina had gotten the point much better than Diego had.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR - RITA SKEETER'S SCOOP
　　Everybody got up late on Boxing Day. The Gryffindor common room was much quieter than it had been lately, many yawns punctuating the lazy conversations. Carolina's hair was bushy again; she confessed to Roberto that she had used liberal amounts of Sleekeazy's Hair Potion on it for the ball, "but it's way too much bother to do every day," she said matter-of-factly, scratching a purring Crookshanks behind the ears.
　　Diego and Carolina seemed to have reached an unspoken agreement not to discuss their
　　argument. They were being quite friendly to each other, though oddly formal. Diego and Roberto wasted no time in telling Carolina about the conversation they had overheard between Madame Maxime and Villalba, but Carolina didn't seem to find the news that Villalba was a half-giant nearly as shocking as Diego did.
　　"Well, I thought he must be," she said, shrugging. "I knew he couldn't be pure giant because they're about twenty feet tall. But honestly, all this hysteria about giants.
　　They can't all be horrible. . . . It's the same sort of prejudice that people have toward werewolves. . . . It's just bigotry, isn't it?"
　　Diego looked as though he would have liked to reply scathingly, but perhaps he didn't want another row, because he contented himself with shaking his head disbelievingly while Carolina wasn't looking.
　　It was time now to think of the homework they had neglected during the first week of the holidays. Everybody seemed to be feeling rather flat now that Christmas was over -everybody except Roberto, that is, who was starting (once again) to feel slightly nervous.
　　The trouble was that February the twenty-fourth looked a lot closer from this side of Christmas, and he still hadn't done anything about working out the clue inside the golden egg. He therefore started taking the egg out of his trunk every time he went up to the dormitory, opening it, and listening intently, hoping that this time it would make some sense. He strained to think what the sound reminded him of, apart from thirty musical saws, but he had never heard anything else like it. He closed the egg, shook it vigorously, and opened it again to see if the sound had changed, but it hadn't. He tried asking the egg questions, shouting over all the wailing, but nothing happened. He even threw the egg across the room - though he hadn't really expected that to help.
　　Roberto had not forgotten the hint that Nicolas had given him, but his less-than-friendly feelings toward Nicolas just now meant that he was keen not to take his help if he could avoid it. In any case, it seemed to him that if Nicolas had really wanted to give Roberto a hand, he would have been a lot more explicit. He, Roberto, had told Nicolas exactly what was coming in the first task - and Nicolas's idea of a fair exchange had been to tell Roberto to take a bath. Well, he didn't need that sort of rubbishy help - not from someone who kept walking down corridors hand in hand with Paula, anyway. And so the first day of the new term arrived, and Roberto set off to lessons, weighed down with books, parchment, and quills as usual, but also with the lurking worry of the egg heavy in his stomach, as though he were carrying that around with him too.
　　Snow was still thick upon the grounds, and the greenhouse windows were covered in condensation so thick that they couldn't see out of them in Herbology. Nobody was looking forward to Care of Magical Creatures much in this weather, though as Diego said, the skrewts would probably warm them up nicely, either by chasing them, or blasting off so forcefully that Villalba's cabin would catch fire.
　　When they arrived at Villalba 's cabin, however, they found an elderly witch with closely cropped gray hair and a very prominent chin standing before his front door.
　　"Hurry up, now, the bell rang five minutes ago," she barked at them as they struggled toward her through the snow.
　　"Who're you?" said Diego, staring at her. "Wheres Villalba?"
　　"My name is Professor Grubbly-Plank," she said briskly. "I am your temporary Care of Magical Creatures teacher."
　　"Where's Villalba?" Roberto repeated loudly.
　　"He is indisposed," said Professor Grubbly-Plank shortly.
　　Soft and unpleasant laughter reached Robertos ears. He turned; Javier Sosa and the rest of the Slytherins were joining the class. All of them looked gleeful, and none of them looked surprised to see Professor Grubbly-Plank.
　　"This way, please," said Professor Grubbly-Plank, and she strode off around the paddock where the Beauxbatons horses were shivering. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina followed her, looking back over their shoulders at Villalba's cabin. All the curtains were closed. Was Villalba in there, alone and ill?
　　"What's wrong with Villalba?" Roberto said, hurrying to catch up with Professor Grubbly-Plank.
　　"Never you mind," she said as though she thought he was being nosy.
　　"I do mind, though," said Roberto hotly. "What's up with him?"
　　Professor Grubbly-Plank acted as though she couldn't hear him. She led them past the paddock where the huge Beauxbatons horses were standing, huddled against the cold, and toward a tree on the edge of the forest, where a large and beautiful unicorn was
　　tethered.
　　Many of the girls "ooooohed!" at the sight of the unicorn.
　　"Oh it's so beautiful!" whispered Lavender Brown. "How did she get it? They're supposed to be really hard to catch!"
　　The unicorn was so brightly white it made the snow all around look gray. It was pawing the ground nervously with its golden hooves and throwing back its horned head.
　　"Boys keep back!" barked Professor Grubbly-Plank, throwing out an arm and catching Roberto hard in the chest. "They prefer the woman's touch, unicorns. Girls to the front, and approach with care, come on, easy does it. ..."
　　She and the girls walked slowly forward toward the unicorn, leaving the boys standing near the paddock fence, watching. The moment Professor Grubbly-Plank was out of earshot.
　　Roberto turned to Diego.
　　"What d'you reckons wrong with him? You don't think a skrewt - ?"
　　"Oh he hasn't been attacked, Gonzales, if that's what you're thinking," said Sosa softly.
　　"No, he's just too ashamed to show his big, ugly face."
　　"What d'you mean?" said Roberto sharply.
　　Sosa put his hand inside the pocket of his robes and pulled out a folded page of newsprint.
　　"There you go," he said. "Hate to break it to you. Gonzales. ..."
　　He smirked as Roberto snatched the page, unfolded it, and read it, with Diego, Seamus, Dean, and Mauricio looking over his shoulder. It was an article topped with a picture of Villalba looking extremely shifty.
　　DOMINGUEZ'S GIANT MISTAKE Alfonso Dominguez, eccentric Headmaster of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, has never been afraid to make controversial staff appointments, writes Rita Skeeter, Special Correspondent. In September of this year, he hired Alastor "Mad-Eye" Acosta, the notoriously jinx-happy ex-Auror, to teach Defense Against the Dark Arts, a decision that caused many raised eyebrows at the Ministry of Magic, given Acosta's well-known habit of attacking anybody who makes a sudden movement in his presence. Mad-Eye Acosta, however, looks responsible and kindly when set beside the part-human Dominguez employs to teach Care of Magical Creatures.
　　Matias Villalba, who admits to being expelled from Hogwarts in his third year, has enjoyed the position of gamekeeper at the school ever since, a job secured for him by Dominguez.
　　Last year, however, Villalba used his mysterious influence over the headmaster to secure the additional post of Care of Magical Creatures teacher, over the heads of many better-qualified candidates.
　　An alarmingly large and ferocious-looking man, Villalba has been using his newfound authority to terrify the students in his care with a succession of horrific creatures.
　　While Dominguez turns a blind eye, Villalba has maimed several pupils during a series of lessons that many admit to being "very frightening."
　　'I was attacked by a hippogriff, and my friend Vincent Crabbe got a bad bite off a flobberworm," says Javier Sosa, a fourth-year student. "We all hate Villalba, but we're just too scared to say anything."
　　Villalba has no intention of ceasing his campaign of intimidation, however. In conversation with a Daily Prophet reporter last month, he admitted breeding creatures he has dubbed "Blast-Ended Skrewts," highly dangerous crosses between manti-cores and fire-crabs. The creation of new breeds of magical creature is, of course, an activity usually closely observed by the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures. Villalba, however, considers himself to be above such petty restrictions.
　　"I was just having some fun," he says, before hastily changing the subject.
　　As if this were not enough, the Daily Prophet has now unearthed evidence that Villalba is not - as he has always pretended - a pure-blood wizard. He is not, in fact, even pure human. His mother, we can exclusively reveal, is none other than the giantess Fridwulfa, whose whereabouts are currently unknown.
　　Bloodthirsty and brutal, the giants brought themselves to the point of extinction by warring amongst themselves during the last century. The handful that remained joined the ranks of He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named, and were responsible for some of the worst mass Muggle killings of his reign of terror.
　　While many of the giants who served He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named were killed by Aurors
　　working against the Dark Side, Fridwulfa was not among them. It is possible she escaped to one of the giant communities still existing in foreign mountain ranges. If his antics during Care of Magical Creatures lessons are any guide, however, Frid-wulfa's son appears to have inherited her brutal nature.
　　In a bizarre twist, Villalba is reputed to have developed a close friendship with the boy who brought around You-Know-Who's fall from power - thereby driving Villalba's own mother, like the rest of You-Know-Who's supporters, into hiding. Perhaps Roberto Gonzales is unaware of the unpleasant truth about his large friend - but Alfonso Dominguez surely has a duty to ensure that Roberto Gonzales, along with his fellow students, is warned about the dangers of associating with part-giants.
　　Roberto finished reading and looked up at Diego, whose mouth was hanging open.
　　"How did she find out?" he whispered.
　　But that wasn't what was bothering Roberto.
　　"What d'you mean, 'we all hate Villalba'?" Roberto spat at Sosa. "What's this rubbish about him" - he pointed at Crabbe - "getting a bad bite off a flobberworm? They haven't even got teeth!"
　　Crabbe was sniggering, apparently very pleased with himself.
　　"Well, I think this should put an end to the oaf's teaching career," said Sosa, his eyes glinting. "Half-giant. . . and there was me thinking he'd just swallowed a bottle of Skele-Gro when he was young. ... None of the mummies and daddies are going to like this at all. ... They'll be worried he'll eat their kids, ha, ha. ..."
　　"You-"
　　"Are you paying attention over there?"
　　Professor Grubbly-Planks voice carried over to the boys; the girls were all clustered around the unicorn now, stroking it. Roberto was so angry that the Daily Prophet article shook in his hands as he turned to stare unseeingly at the unicorn, whose many magical properties Professor Grubbly-Plank was now enumerating in a loud voice, so that the boys could hear too.
　　"I hope she stays, that woman!" said Parvati Patil when the lesson had ended and they were all heading back to the castle for lunch. "That's more what I thought Care of Magical Creatures would be like . . . proper creatures like unicorns, not monsters. . .
　　."
　　"What about Villalba?" Roberto said angrily as they went up the steps.
　　"What about him?" said Parvati in a hard voice. "He can still be gamekeeper, can't he?"
　　Parvati had been very cool toward Roberto since the ball. He supposed that he ought to have paid her a bit more attention, but she seemed to have had a good time all the same.
　　She was certainly telling anybody who would listen that she had made arrangements to meet the boy from Beauxbatons in Hogsmeade on the next weekend trip.
　　"That was a really good lesson," said Carolina as they entered the Great Hall. "I didn't know half the things Professor Grubbly-Plank told us about uni -"
　　"Look at this!" Roberto snarled, and he shoved the Daily Prophet article under Carolina's nose.
　　Carolina's mouth fell open as she read. Her reaction was exactly the same as Diego's.
　　"How did that horrible Skeeter woman find out? You don't think Villalba told her?"
　　"No," said Roberto, leading the way over to the Gryffindor table and throwing himself into a chair, furious. "He never even told us, did he? I reckon she was so mad he wouldn't give her loads of horrible stuff about me, she went ferreting around to get him back."
　　"Maybe she heard him telling Madame Maxime at the ball," said Carolina quietly.
　　"We'd have seen her in the garden!" said Diego. "Anyway, she's not supposed to come into school anymore, Villalba said Dominguez banned her. . . ."
　　"Maybe she's got an Invisibility Cloak," said Roberto, ladling chicken casserole onto his plate and splashing it everywhere in his anger. "Sort of thing she'd do, isn't it, hide in bushes listening to people."
　　"Like you and Diego did, you mean," said Carolina.
　　"We weren't trying to hear him!" said Diego indignantly. "We didn't have any choice! The stupid prat, talking about his giantess mother where anyone could have heard him!"
　　"We've got to go and see him," said Roberto. "This evening, after Divination. Tell him we want him back . . . you do want him back?" he shot at Carolina.
　　"I - well, I'm not going to pretend it didn't make a nice change, having a proper Care of Magical Creatures lesson for once - but I do want Villalba back, of course I do!" Carolina
　　added hastily, quailing under Roberto's furious stare.
　　So that evening after dinner, the three of them left the castle once more and went down through the frozen grounds to Villalba's cabin. They knocked, and Fang's booming barks answered.
　　"Villalba, it's us!" Roberto shouted, pounding on the door. "Open up!"
　　Villalba didn't answer. They could hear Fang scratching at the door, whining, but it didn't open. They hammered on it for ten more minutes; Diego even went and banged on one of the windows, but there was no response.
　　"What's he avoiding us for?" Carolina said when they had finally given up and were walking back to the school. "He surely doesn't think we'd care about him being half-giant?"
　　But it seemed that Villalba did care. They didn't see a sign of him all week. He didn't appear at the staff table at mealtimes, they didn't see him going about his gamekeeper duties on the grounds, and Professor Grubbly-Plank continued to take the Care of Magical Creatures classes. Sosa was gloating at every possible opportunity.
　　"Missing your half-breed pal?" he kept whispering to Roberto whenever there was a teacher around, so that he was safe from Roberto's retaliation. "Missing the elephant-man?"
　　There was a Hogsmeade visit halfway through January. Carolina was very surprised that Roberto was going to go.
　　"I just thought you'd want to take advantage of the common room being quiet," she said.
　　"Really get to work on that egg."
　　"Oh I - I reckon I've got a pretty good idea what it's about now," Roberto lied.
　　"Have you really?" said Carolina, looking impressed. "Well done!"
　　Robertos insides gave a guilty squirm, but he ignored them. He still had five weeks to work out that egg clue, after all, and that was ages. . . whereas if he went into Hogsmeade, he might run into Villalba, and get a chance to persuade him to come back.
　　He, Diego, and Carolina left the castle together on Saturday and set off through the cold, wet grounds toward the gates. As they passed the Durmstrang ship moored in the lake, they saw Viktor Krum emerge onto the deck, dressed in nothing but swimming trunks. He was very skinny indeed, but apparently a lot tougher than he looked, because he climbed up onto the side of the ship, stretched out his arms, and dived, right into the lake.
　　"He's mad!" said Roberto, staring at Krums dark head as it bobbed out into the middle of the lake. "It must be freezing, it's January!"
　　"It's a lot colder where he comes from," said Carolina. "I suppose it feels quite warm to him."
　　"Yeah, but there's still the giant squid," said Diego. He didn't sound anxious - if anything, he sounded hopeful. Carolina noticed his tone of voice and frowned.
　　"He's really nice, you know," she said. "He's not at all like you'd think, coming from Durmstrang. He likes it much better here, he told me."
　　Diego said nothing. He hadn't mentioned Viktor Krum since the ball, but Roberto had found a miniature arm under his bed on Boxing Day, which had looked very much as though it had been snapped off a small model figure wearing Bulgarian Quidditch robes.
　　Roberto kept his eyes skinned for a sign of Villalba all the way down the slushy High Street, and suggested a visit to the Three Broomsticks once he had ascertained that Villalba was not in any of the shops.
　　The pub was as crowded as ever, but one quick look around at all the tables told Roberto that Villalba wasn't there. Heart sinking, he went up to the bar with Diego and Carolina, ordered three butterbeers from Madam Rosmerta, and thought gloomily that he might just as well have stayed behind and listened to the egg wailing after all.
　　"Doesn't he ever go into the office?" Carolina whispered suddenly. "Look!"
　　She pointed into the mirror behind the bar, and Roberto saw Ludo Bagman reflected there, sitting in a shadowy corner with a bunch of goblins. Bagman was talking very fast in a low voice to the goblins, all of whom had their arms crossed and were looking rather menacing.
　　It was indeed odd. Roberto thought, that Bagman was here at the Three Broomsticks on a weekend when there was no Triwizard event, and therefore no judging to be done. He watched Bagman in the mirror. He was looking strained again, quite as strained as he had that night in the forest before the Dark Mark had appeared. But just then Bagman glanced over at the bar, saw Roberto, and stood up.
　　"In a moment, in a moment!" Roberto heard him say brusquely to the goblins, and Bagman hurried through the pub toward Roberto, his boyish grin back in place.
　　"Roberto!" he said. "How are you? Been hoping to run into you! Everything going all right?"
　　"Fine, thanks," said Roberto.
　　"Wonder if I could have a quick, private word, Roberto?" said Bagman eagerly. "You couldn't give us a moment, you two, could you?"
　　"Er - okay," said Diego, and he and Carolina went off to find a table.
　　Bagman led Roberto along the bar to the end furthest from Madam Rosmerta.
　　"Well, I just thought I'd congratulate you again on your splendid performance against that Horntail, Roberto," said Bagman. "Really superb."
　　"Thanks," said Roberto, but he knew this couldn't be all that Bagman wanted to say, because he could have congratulated Roberto in front of Diego and Carolina. Bagman didn't seem in any particular rush to spill the beans, though. Roberto saw him glance into the mirror over the bar at the goblins, who were all watching him and Roberto in silence through their dark, slanting eyes.
　　"Absolute nightmare," said Bagman to Roberto in an undertone, noticing Roberto watching the goblins too. "Their English isn't too good . . . it's like being back with all the Bulgarians at the Quidditch World Cup . . . but at least they used sign language another human could recognize. This lot keep gabbling in Gobblede-gook . . . and I only know one word of Gobbledegook. Bladvak. It means 'pickax.' I don't like to use it in case they think I'm threatening them."
　　He gave a short, booming laugh.
　　"What do they want?" Roberto said, noticing how the goblins were still watching Bagman very closely.
　　"Er - well. . ." said Bagman, looking suddenly nervous. "They ... er ... they're looking for Barty Crouch."
　　"Why are they looking for him here?" said Roberto. "He's at the Ministry in London, isn't he?"
　　"Er ... as a matter of fact, I've no idea where he is," said Bagman. "He's sort of...
　　stopped coming to work. Been absent for a couple of weeks now. Young Miguel, his assistant, says he's ill. Apparently he's just been sending instructions in by owl. But would you mind not mentioning that to anyone. Roberto? Because Rita Skeeter's still poking around everywhere she can, and I'm willing to bet she'd work up Bartys illness into something sinister. Probably say he's gone missing like Bertha Jorkins."
　　"Have you heard anything about Bertha Jorkins?" Roberto asked.
　　"No," said Bagman, looking strained again. "I've got people looking, of course ..."
　　(About time, thought Roberto) "and it's all very strange. She definitely arrived in Albania, because she met her second cousin there. And then she left the cousin's house to go south and see an aunt. . . and she seems to have vanished without trace en route.
　　Blowed if I can see where she's got to ... she doesn't seem the type to elope, for instance . . . but still. . . . What are we doing, talking about goblins and Bertha Jorkins? I really wanted to ask you" - he lowered his voice - "how are you getting on with your golden egg?"
　　"Er . . . not bad," Roberto said untruthfully.
　　Bagman seemed to know he wasn't being honest.
　　"Listen, Roberto," he said (still in a very low voice), "I feel very bad about all this . .
　　. you were thrown into this tournament, you didn't volunteer for it... and if. . ." (his voice was so quiet now, Roberto had to lean closer to listen) "if I can help at all... a prod in the right direction . . . I've taken a liking to you . . . the way you got past that dragon! . . . well, just say the word."
　　Roberto stared up into Bagman's round, rosy face and his wide, baby-blue eyes.
　　"We're supposed to work out the clues alone, aren't we?" he said, careful to keep his voice casual and not sound as though he was accusing the head of the Department of Magical Games and Sports of breaking the rules.
　　"Well. . . well, yes," said Bagman impatiently, "but - come on. Roberto - we all want a Hogwarts victory, don't we?"
　　"Have you offered Nicolas help?" Roberto said.
　　The smallest of frowns creased Bagman's smooth face. "No, I haven't," he said. "I -well, like I say, I've taken a liking to you. Just thought I'd offer ..."
　　"Well, thanks," said Roberto, "but I think I'm nearly there with the egg . . . couple more days should crack it."
　　He wasn't entirely sure why he was refusing Bagman's help, except that Bagman was almost a stranger to him, and accepting his assistance would feel somehow much more like
　　cheating than asking advice from Diego, Carolina, or Gustavo.
　　Bagman looked almost affronted, but couldn't say much more as Pablo and Luis turned up at that point.
　　"Hello, Mr. Bagman," said Pablo brightly. "Can we buy you a drink?"
　　"Er . . . no," said Bagman, with a last disappointed glance at Roberto, "no, thank you, boys ..."
　　Pablo and Luis looked quite as disappointed as Bagman, who was surveying Roberto as though he had let him down badly.
　　"Well, I must dash," he said. "Nice seeing you all. Good luck, Roberto."
　　He hurried out of the pub. The goblins all slid off their chairs and exited after him.
　　Roberto went to rejoin Diego and Carolina.
　　"What did he want?" Diego said, the moment Roberto had sat down.
　　"He offered to help me with the golden egg," said Roberto.
　　"He shouldn't be doing that!" said Carolina, looking very shocked. "He's one of the judges! And anyway, you've already worked it out - haven't you?"
　　"Er . . . nearly," said Roberto.
　　"Well, I don't think Dominguez would like it if he knew Bagman was trying to persuade you to cheat!" said Carolina, still looking deeply disapproving. "I hope he's trying to help Nicolas as much!"
　　"He's not, I asked," said Roberto.
　　"Who cares if Ortegas getting help?" said Diego. Roberto privately agreed.
　　"Those goblins didn't look very friendly," said Carolina, sipping her butterbeer. "What were they doing here?"
　　"Looking for Crouch, according to Bagman," said Roberto. "He's still ill. Hasn't been into work."
　　"Maybe Miguels poisoning him," said Diego. "Probably thinks if Crouch snuffs it he'll be made head of the Department of International Magical Cooperation."
　　Carolina gave Diego a don't-joke-about-things-like-that look, and said, "Funny, goblins looking for Mr. Crouch. . . . They'd normally deal with the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures."
　　"Crouch can speak loads of different languages, though," said Roberto. "Maybe they need an interpreter."
　　"Worrying about poor 'ickle goblins, now, are you?" Diego asked Carolina. "Thinking of starting up S.P.U.G. or something? Society for the Protection of Ugly Goblins?"
　　"Ha, ha, ha," said Carolina sarcastically. "Goblins don't need protection. Haven't you been listening to what Professor Binns has been telling us about goblin rebellions?"
　　"No," said Roberto and Diego together.
　　"Well, the/re quite capable of dealing with wizards," said Carolina, taking another sip of butterbeer. "They're very clever. They're not like house-elves, who never stick up for themselves."
　　"Uh-oh," said Diego, staring at the door.
　　Rita Skeeter had just entered. She was wearing banana-yellow robes today; her long nails were painted shocking pink, and she was accompanied by her paunchy photographer. She bought drinks, and she and the photographer made their way through the crowds to a table nearby. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina glaring at her as she approached. She was talking fast and looking very satisfied about something.
　　"... didn't seem very keen to talk to us, did he, Bozo? Now, why would that be, do you think? And what's he doing with a pack of goblins in tow anyway? Showing them the sights . .. what nonsense ... he was always a bad liar. Reckon something's up? Think we should do a bit of digging? 'Disgraced Ex-Head of Magical Games and Sports, Ludo Bagman . . .' Snappy start to a sentence, Bozo - we just need to find a story to fit it -"
　　"Trying to ruin someone else's life?" said Roberto loudly.
　　A few people looked around. Rita Skeeter's eyes widened behind her jeweled spectacles as she saw who had spoken.
　　"Roberto!" she said, beaming. "How lovely! Why don't you come and join- ?"
　　"I wouldn't come near you with a ten-foot broomstick," said Roberto furiously. "What did you do that to Villalba for, eh?"
　　Rita Skeeter raised her heavily penciled eyebrows.
　　"Our readers have a right to the truth, Roberto. I am merely doing my-"
　　"Who cares if he's half-giant?" Roberto shouted. "There's nothing wrong with him!"
　　The whole pub had gone very quiet. Madam Rosmerta was staring over from behind the bar,
　　apparently oblivious to the fact that the flagon she was filling with mead was overflowing.
　　Rita Skeeters smile flickered very slightly, but she hitched it back almost at once; she snapped open her crocodile-skin handbag, pulled out her Quick-Quotes Quill, and said, "How about giving me an interview about the Villalba you know. Roberto? The man behind the muscles? Your unlikely friendship and the reasons behind it. Would you call him a father substitute?"
　　Carolina stood up very abruptly, her butterbeer clutched in her hand as though it were a grenade.
　　"You horrible woman," she said, through gritted teeth, "you don't care, do you, anything for a story, and anyone will do, wont they? Even Ludo Bagman -"
　　"Sit down, you silly little girl, and don't talk about things you don't understand," said Rita Skeeter coldly, her eyes hardening as they fell on Carolina. "I know things about Ludo Bagman that would make your hair curl... not that it needs it -" she added, eyeing Carolina's bushy hair.
　　"Let's go," said Carolina, "c'mon. Roberto - Diego . .."
　　They left; many people were staring at them as they went. Roberto glanced back as they reached the door. Rita Skeeter's Quick-Quotes Quill was out; it was zooming backward and forward over a piece of parchment on the table.
　　"She'll be after you next, Carolina," said Diego in a low and worried voice as they walked quickly back up the street.
　　"Let her try!" said Carolina defiantly; she was shaking with rage. "I'll show her! Silly little girl, am I? Oh, I'll get her back for this. First Roberto, then Villalba ..."
　　"You don't want to go upsetting Rita Skeeter," said Diego nervously. "I'm serious, Carolina, she'll dig up something on you -"
　　"My parents don't read the Daily Prophet. She can't scare me into hiding!" said Carolina, now striding along so fast that it was all Roberto and Diego could do to keep up with her. The last time Roberto had seen Carolina in a rage like this, she had hit Javier Sosa around the face. "And Villalba isn't hiding anymore! He should never have let that excuse for a human being upset him! Come on!"
　　Breaking into a run, she led them all the way back up the road, through the gates flanked by winged boars, and up through the grounds to Villalba's cabin.
　　The curtains were still drawn, and they could hear Fang barking as they approached.
　　"Villalba!" Carolina shouted, pounding on his front door. "Villalba, that's enough! We know you're in there! Nobody cares if your mum was a giantess, Villalba! You can't let that foul Skeeter woman do this to you! Villalba, get out here, you're just being -"
　　The door opened. Carolina said, "About t-!" and then stopped, very suddenly, because she had found herself face-to-face, not with Villalba, but with Alfonso Dominguez.
　　"Good afternoon," he said pleasantly, smiling down at them.
　　"We-er-we wanted to see Villalba," said Carolina in a rather small voice.
　　"Yes, I surmised as much," said Dominguez, his eyes twinkling. "Why don't you come in?"
　　"Oh . . . um ... okay," said Carolina.
　　She, Diego, and Roberto went into the cabin; Fang launched himself upon Roberto the moment he entered, barking madly and trying to lick his ears. Roberto fended off Fang and looked around.
　　Villalba was sitting at his table, where there were two large mugs of tea. He looked a real mess. His face was blotchy, his eyes swollen, and he had gone to the other extreme where his hair was concerned; far from trying to make it behave, it now looked like a wig of tangled wire.
　　"Hi, Villalba," said Roberto.
　　Villalba looked up.
　　"'Lo," he said in a very hoarse voice.
　　"More tea, I think," said Dominguez, closing the door behind Roberto, Diego, and Carolina, drawing out his wand, and twiddling it; a revolving tea tray appeared in midair along with a plate of cakes. Dominguez magicked the tray onto the table, and everybody sat down. There was a slight pause, and then Dominguez said, "Did you by any chance hear what Miss Fernandez was shouting, Villalba?"
　　Carolina went slightly pink, but Dominguez smiled at her and continued, "Carolina, Roberto, and Diego still seem to want to know you, judging by the way they were attempting to break down the door."
　　"Of course we still want to know you!" Roberto said, staring at Villalba. "You don't think
　　anything that Skeeter cow - sorry, Professor," he added quickly, looking at Dominguez.
　　"I have gone temporarily deaf and haven't any idea what you said. Roberto," said Dominguez, twiddling his thumbs and staring at the ceiling.
　　"Er-right," said Roberto sheepishly. "I just meant-Villalba, how could you think we'd care what that-woman-wrote about you?"
　　Two fat tears leaked out of Villalba's beetle-black eyes and fell slowly into his tangled beard.
　　"Living proof of what I've been telling you, Villalba," said Dominguez, still looking carefully up at the ceiling. "I have shown you the letters from the countless parents who remember you from their own days here, telling me in no uncertain terms that if I sacked you, they would have something to say about it -"
　　"Not all of 'em," said Villalba hoarsely. "Not all of 'em wan me ter stay."
　　"Really, Villalba, if you are holding out for universal popularity, I'm afraid you will be in this cabin for a very long time," said Dominguez, now peering sternly over his half-moon spectacles. "Not a week has passed since I became headmaster of this school when I haven't had at least one owl complaining about the way I run it. But what should I do? Barricade myself in my study and refuse to talk to anybody?"
　　"Yeh - yeh're not half-giant!" said Villalba croakily.
　　"Villalba, look what I've got for relatives!" Roberto said furiously. "Look at the Carrizos!"
　　"An excellent point," said Professor Dominguez. "My own brother, Aberforth, was prosecuted for practicing inappropriate charms on a goat. It was all over the papers, but did Aberforth hide? No, he did not! He held his head high and went about his business as usual! Of course, I'm not entirely sure he can read, so that may not have been bravery. . .."
　　"Come back and teach, Villalba," said Carolina quietly, "please come back, we really miss you."
　　Villalba gulped. More tears leaked out down his cheeks and into his tangled beard.
　　Dominguez stood up. "I refuse to accept your resignation, Villalba, and I expect you back at work on Monday," he said. "You will join me for breakfast at eight-thirty in the Great Hall. No excuses. Good afternoon to you all."
　　Dominguez left the cabin, pausing only to scratch Fangs ears. When the door had shut behind him, Villalba began to sob into his dustbin-lid-sized hands. Carolina kept patting his arm, and at last, Villalba looked up, his eyes very red indeed, and said, "Great man, Dominguez . . . great man . .."
　　"Yeah, he is," said Diego. "Can I have one of these cakes, Villalba?"
　　"Help yerself," said Villalba, wiping his eyes on the back of his hand. "Ar, he's righ', o' course - yeh're all righ' . . .I bin stupid . .. my ol' dad woulda bin ashamed o' the way I've bin behavin'...." More tears leaked out, but he wiped them away more forcefully, and said, "Never shown you a picture of my old dad, have I? Here..."
　　Villalba got up, went over to his dresser, opened a drawer, and pulled out a picture of a short wizard with Villalba's crinkled black eyes, beaming as he sat on top of Villalba's shoulder. Villalba was a good seven or eight feet tall, judging by the apple tree beside him, but his face was beardless, young, round, and smooth - he looked hardly older than eleven.
　　"Tha was taken jus' after I got inter Hogwarts," Villalba croaked. "Dad was dead chuffed ... thought I migh' not be a wizard, see, 'cos me mum ... well, anyway. 'Course, I never was great shakes at magic, really... but at least he never saw me expelled. Died, see, in me second year. . . ."
　　"Dominguez was the one who stuck up for me after Dad went. Got me the gamekeeper job .
　　. . trusts people, he does. Gives 'em second chances ... tha's what sets him apar' from other heads, see. He'll accept anyone at Hogwarts, s'long as they've got the talent.
　　Knows people can turn out okay even if their families weren' ... well... all tha' respectable. But some don understand that. There's some who'd always hold it against yeh . . . there's some who'd even pretend they just had big bones rather than stand up an' say - I am what I am, an' I'm not ashamed. 'Never be ashamed,' my ol' dad used ter say, 'there's some who'll hold it against you, but they're not worth botherin' with.' An' he was right. I've bin an idiot. I'm not botherin' with her no more, I promise yeh that. Big bones . . . I'll give her big bones."
　　Roberto, Diego, and Carolina looked at one another nervously; Roberto would rather have taken fifty Blast-Ended Skrewts for a walk than admit to Villalba that he had overheard him
　　talking to Madame Maxime, but Villalba was still talking, apparently unaware that he had said anything odd.
　　"Yeh know wha, Roberto?" he said, looking up from the photograph of his father, his eyes very bright, "when I firs' met you, you reminded me o' me a bit. Mum an' Dad gone, an' you was feelin' like yeh wouldn' fit in at Hogwarts, remember? Not sure yeh were really up to it... an' now look at yeh, Roberto! School champion!"
　　He looked at Roberto for a moment and then said, very seriously, "Yeh know what I'd love.
　　Roberto? I'd love yeh ter win, I really would. It'd show 'em all... yeh don' have ter be pureblood ter do it. Yeh don have ter be ashamed of what yeh are. It'd show 'em Dominguez's the one who's got it righ', lettin' anyone in as long as they can do magic.
　　How you doin' with that egg, Roberto?"
　　"Great," said Roberto. "Really great."
　　Villalba's miserable face broke into a wide, watery smile.
　　"Tha's my boy. . . you show 'em, Roberto, you show 'em. Beat 'em all."
　　Lying to Villalba wasn't quite like lying to anyone else. Roberto went back to the castle later that afternoon with Diego and Carolina, unable to banish the image of the happy expression on Villalba's whiskery face as he had imagined Roberto winning the tournament.
　　The incomprehensible egg weighed more heavily than ever on Robertos conscience that evening, and by the time he had got into bed, he had made up his mind - it was time to shelve his pride and see if Nicolas's hint was worth anything.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE - THE EGG AND THE EYE
　　Roberto had no idea how long a bath he would need to work out the secret of the golden egg, he decided to do it at night, when he would be able to take as much time as he wanted.
　　Reluctant though he was to accept more favors from Nicolas, he also decided to use the prefects' bathroom; far fewer people were allowed in there, so it was much less likely that he would be disturbed.
　　Roberto planned his excursion carefully, because he had been caught out of bed and out-of-bounds by Filch the caretaker in the middle of the night once before, and had no desire to repeat the experience. The Invisibility Cloak would, of course, be essential, and as an added precaution, Roberto thought he would take the Marauders Map, which, next to the cloak, was the most useful aid to rule-breaking Roberto owned. The map showed the whole of Hogwarts, including its many shortcuts and secret passageways and, most important of all, it revealed the people inside the castle as minuscule, labeled dots, moving around the corridors, so that Roberto would be forewarned if somebody was approaching the bathroom.
　　On Thursday night, Roberto sneaked up to bed, put on the cloak, crept back downstairs, and, just as he had done on the night when Villalba had shown him the dragons, waited for the portrait hole to open. This time it was Diego who waited outside to give the Fat Lady the password ("banana fritters"), "Good luck," Diego muttered, climbing into the room as Roberto crept out past him.
　　It was awkward moving under the cloak tonight, because Roberto had the heavy egg under one arm and the map held in front of his nose with the other. However, the moonlit corridors were empty and silent, and by checking the map at strategic intervals, Roberto was able to ensure that he wouldn't run into anyone he wanted to avoid. When he reached the statue of Boris the Bewildered, a lost-looking wizard with his gloves on the wrong hands, he located the right door, leaned close to it, and muttered the password, "Pine fresh," just as Nicolas had told him.
　　The door creaked open. Roberto slipped inside, bolted the door behind him, and pulled off the Invisibility Cloak, looking around.
　　His immediate reaction was that it would be worth becoming a prefect just to be able to use this bathroom. It was softly lit by a splendid candle-filled chandelier, and everything was made of white marble, including what looked like an empty, rectangular swimming pool sunk into the middle of the floor. About a hundred golden taps stood all around the pools edges, each with a differently colored Jewel set into its handle. There was also a diving board. Long white linen curtains hung at the windows; a large pile of fluffy white towels sat in a corner, and there was a single golden-framed painting on the wall. It featured a blonde mermaid who was fast asleep on a rock, her long hair over her face. It fluttered every time she snored.
　　Roberto moved forward, looking around, his footsteps echoing off the walls. Magnificent
　　though the bathroom was - and quite keen though he was to try out a few of those taps -now he was here he couldn't quite suppress the feeling that Nicolas might have been having him on. How on earth was this supposed to help solve the mystery of the egg?
　　Nevertheless, he put one of the Huffy towels, the cloak, the map, and the egg at the side of the swimming-pool-sized bath, then knelt down and turned on a few of the taps.
　　He could tell at once that they carried different sorts of bubble bath mixed with the water, though it wasn't bubble bath as Roberto had ever experienced it. One tap gushed pink and blue bubbles the size of footballs; another poured ice-white foam so thick that Roberto thought it would have supported his weight if he'd cared to test it; a third sent heavily perfumed purple clouds hovering over the surface of the water. Roberto amused himself for awhile turning the taps on and off, particularly enjoying the effect of one whose jet bounced off the surface of the water in large arcs. Then, when the deep pool was full of hot water, foam, and bubbles, which took a very short time considering its size, Roberto turned off all the taps, pulled off his pajamas, slippers, and dressing gown, and slid into the water.
　　It was so deep that his feet barely touched the bottom, and he actually did a couple of lengths before swimming back to the side and treading water, staring at the egg. Highly enjoyable though it was to swim in hot and foamy water with clouds of different-colored steam wafting all around him, no stroke of brilliance came to him, no sudden burst of understanding.
　　Roberto stretched out his arms, lifted the egg in his wet hands, and opened it. The wailing, screeching sound filled the bathroom, echoing and reverberating off the marble walls, but it sounded just as incomprehensible as ever, if not more so with all the echoes. He snapped it shut again, worried that the sound would attract Filch, wondering whether that hadn't been Nicolas's plan - and then, making him jump so badly that he dropped the egg, which clattered away across the bathroom floor, someone spoke.
　　"I'd try putting it in the water, if I were you."
　　Roberto had swallowed a considerable amount of bubbles in shock. He stood up, sputtering, and saw the ghost of a very glum-looking girl sitting cross-legged on top of one of the taps. It was Moaning Myrtle, who was usually to be heard sobbing in the S-bend of a toilet three floors below.
　　"Myrtle!" Roberto said in outrage, "I'm - I'm not wearing anything!"
　　The foam was so dense that this hardly mattered, but he had a nasty feeling that Myrtle had been spying on him from out of one of the taps ever since he had arrived.
　　"I closed my eyes when you got in," she said, blinking at him through her thick spectacles. "You haven't been to see me for ages."
　　"Yeah . . . well. . ." said Roberto, bending his knees slightly, just to make absolutely sure Myrtle couldn't see anything but his head, "I'm not supposed to come into your bathroom, am I? It's a girls' one."
　　"You didn't used to care," said Myrtle miserably. "You used to be in there all the time."
　　This was true, though only because Roberto, Diego, and Carolina had found Myrtle's out-of-order toilets a convenient place to brew Polyjuice Potion in secret - a forbidden potion that had turned him and Diego into living replicas of Crabbe and Goyle for an hour, so that they could sneak into the Slytherin common room.
　　"I got told off for going in there." said Roberto, which was half-true; Miguel had once caught him coming out of Myrtles bathroom. "I thought I'd better not come back after that."
　　"Oh ... I see ..." said Myrtle, picking at a spot on her chin in a morose sort of way.
　　"Well... anyway... I'd try the egg in the water. That's what Nicolas Ortega did."
　　"Have you been spying on him too?" said Roberto indignantly. "What d'you do, sneak up here in the evenings to watch the prefects take baths?"
　　"Sometimes," said Myrtle, rather slyly, "but I've never come out to speak to anyone before."
　　"I'm honored," said Roberto darkly. "You keep your eyes shut!"
　　He made sure Myrtle had her glasses well covered before hoisting himself out of the bath, wrapping the towel firmly around his waist, and going to retrieve the egg. Once he was back in the water, Myrtle peered through her fingers and said, "Go on, then . .. open it under the water!"
　　Roberto lowered the egg beneath the foamy surface and opened it... and this time, it did not wail. A gurgling song was coming out of it, a song whose words he couldnt distinguish through the water.
　　"You need to put your head under too," said Myrtle, who seemed to be thoroughly enjoying bossing him around. "Go on!"
　　Roberto took a great breath and slid under the surface - and now, sitting on the marble bottom of the bubble-filled bath, he heard a chorus of eerie voices singing to him from the open egg in his hands:
　　"Come seek us where our voices sound, We cannot sing above the ground, And while you re searching, ponder this:
　　Wove taken what you'll sorely miss, An hour long you'll have to look, And to recover what we took, But past an hour- the prospect's black, Too late, it's gone, it wont come back"
　　Roberto let himself float back upward and broke the bubbly surface, shaking his hair out of his eyes.
　　"Hear it?" said Myrtle.
　　"Yeah ... 'Come seek us where our voices sound .. .' and if I need persuading ... hang on, I need to listen again...."
　　He sank back beneath the water. It took three more underwater renditions of the egg's song before Roberto had it memorized; then he trod water for a while, thinking hard, while Myrtle sat and watched him.
　　"I've got to go and look for people who can't use their voices above the ground. . . ."
　　he said slowly. "Er . . . who could that be?"
　　"Slow, aren't you?"
　　He had never seen Moaning Myrtle so cheerful, apart from the day when a dose of PolyJuice Potion had given Carolina the hairy face and tail of a cat. Roberto stared around the bathroom, thinking ... if the voices could only be heard underwater, then it made sense for them to belong to underwater creatures. He ran this theory past Myrtle, who smirked at him.
　　"Well, thats what Ortega thought," she said. "He lay there talking to himself for ages about it. Ages and ages . . . nearly all the bubbles had gone. ..."
　　"Underwater ..." Roberto said slowly. "Myrtle . . . what lives in the lake, apart from the giant squid?"
　　"Oh all sorts," she said. "I sometimes go down there . . . sometimes don't have any choice, if someone flushes my toilet when I'm not expecting it...."
　　Trying not to think about Moaning Myrtle zooming down a pipe to the lake with the contents of a toilet. Roberto said, "Well, does anything in there have a human voice?
　　Hang on -"
　　Roberto's eyes had fallen on the picture of the snoozing mermaid on the wall.
　　"Myrtle, there aren't merpeople in there, are there?"
　　"Oooh, very good," she said, her thick glasses twinkling, "it took Ortega much longer than that! And that was with her awake too" - Myrtle jerked her head toward the mermaid with an expression of great dislike on her glum face - "giggling and showing off and flashing her fins.. .."
　　"Thats it, isn't it?" said Roberto excitedly. "The second tasks to go and find the merpeople in the lake and ... and ..."
　　But he suddenly realized what he was saying, and he felt the excitement drain out of him as though someone had just pulled a plug in his stomach. He wasn't a very good swimmer; he'd never had much practice. Leonardo had had lessons in his youth, but Aunt Beatriz and Uncle Francisco, no doubt hoping that Roberto would drown one day, hadn't bothered to give him any. A couple of lengths of this bath were all very well, but that lake was very large, and very deep . . . and merpeople would surely live right at the bottom. . . .
　　"Myrtle," Roberto said slowly, "how am I supposed to breathe?"
　　At this, Myrtle's eyes filled with sudden tears again.
　　"Tactless!" she muttered, groping in her robes for a handkerchief.
　　"What's tactless?" said Roberto, bewildered.
　　"Talking about breathing in front of me!" she said shrilly, and her voice echoed loudly around the bathroom. "When I can't. . . when I haven't. . . not for ages ..."
　　She buried her face in her handkerchief and sniffed loudly. Roberto remembered how touchy
　　Myrtle had always been about being dead, but none of the other ghosts he knew made such a fuss about it.
　　"Sorry," he said impatiently. "I didn't mean - I just forgot. . ."
　　"Oh yes, very easy to forget Myrtle's dead," said Myrtle, gulping, looking at him out of swollen eyes. "Nobody missed me even when I was alive. Took them hours and hours to find my body - I know, I was sitting there waiting for them. Olive Hornby came into the bathroom - Are you in here again, sulking, Myrtle?' she said, 'because Professor Dippet asked me to look for you -' And then she saw my body . . . ooooh, she didn't forget it until her dying day, I made sure of that... followed her around and reminded her, I did.
　　I remember at her brother's wedding -"
　　But Roberto wasn't listening; he was thinking about the merpeople's song again. "We've taken what you II sorely miss." That sounded as though they were going to steal something of his, something he had to get back. What were they going to take?
　　"--and then, of course, she went to the Ministry of Magic to stop me stalking her, so I had to come back here and live in my toilet."
　　"Good," said Roberto vaguely. "Well, I'm a lot further on than I was. . . . Shut your eyes again, will you? I'm getting out."
　　He retrieved the egg from the bottom of the bath, climbed out, dried himself, and pulled on his pajamas and dressing gown again.
　　"Will you come and visit me in my bathroom again sometime?" Moaning Myrtle asked mournfully as Roberto picked up the Invisibility Cloak.
　　"Er . . . I'll try," Roberto said, though privately thinking the only way he'd be visiting Myrtle's bathroom again was if every other toilet in the castle got blocked. "See you.
　　Myrtle... thanks for your help."
　　"Bye, 'bye," she said gloomily, and as Roberto put on the Invisibllity Cloak he saw her zoom back up the tap.
　　Out in the dark corridor, Roberto examined the Marauders Map to check that the coast was still clear. Yes, the dots belonging to Filch and his cat, Mrs. Norris, were safely in their office . .. nothing else seemed to be moving apart from Peeves, though he was bouncing around the trophy room on the floor above. ... Roberto had taken his first step back toward Gryffindor Tower when something else on the map caught his eye . . .
　　something distinctly odd.
　　Peeves was not the only thing that was moving. A single dot was flitting around a room in the bottom left-hand corner - Peraltas office. But the dot wasn't labeled "Carlos Peralta" ... it was Bartemius Crouch.
　　Roberto stared at the dot. Mr. Crouch was supposed to be too ill to go to work or to come to the Yule Ball - so what was he doing, sneaking into Hogwarts at one o'clock in the morning? Roberto watched closely as the dot moved around and around the room, pausing here and there. ...
　　Roberto hesitated, thinking . . . and then his curiosity got the better of him. He turned and set off in the opposite direction toward the nearest staircase. He was going to see what Crouch was up to.
　　Roberto walked down the stairs as quietly as possible, though the faces in some of the portraits still turned curiously at the squeak of a floorboard, the rustle of his pajamas. He crept along the corridor below, pushed aside a tapestry about halfway along, and proceeded down a narrower staircase, a shortcut that would take him down two floors.
　　He kept glancing down at the map, wondering ... It just didn't seem in character, somehow, for correct, law-abiding Mr. Crouch to be sneaking around somebody else's office this late at night....
　　And then, halfway down the staircase, not thinking about what he was doing, not concentrating on anything but the peculiar behavior of Mr. Crouch, Robertos leg suddenly sank right through the trick step Mauricio always forgot to jump. He gave an ungainly wobble, and the golden egg, still damp from the bath, slipped from under his arm. He lurched forward to try and catch it, but too late; the egg fell down the long staircase with a bang as loud as a bass drum on every step - the Invisibility Cloak slipped - Roberto snatched at it, and the Marauder s Map fluttered out of his hand and slid down six stairs, where, sunk in the step to above his knee, he couldn't reach it.
　　The golden egg fell through the tapestry at the bottom of the staircase, burst open, and began wailing loudly in the corridor below. Roberto pulled out his wand and struggled to touch the Marauder s Map, to wipe it blank, but it was too far away to reach -Pulling the cloak back over himself Roberto straightened up, listening hard with his eyes
　　screwed up with fear. . . and, almost immediately -"
　　PEEVES!"
　　It was the unmistakable hunting cry of Filch the caretaker. Roberto could hear his rapid, shuffling footsteps coming nearer and nearer, his wheezy voice raised in fury.
　　"What's this racket? Wake up the whole castle, will you? I'll have you, Peeves, I'll have you, you'll... and what is this?"
　　Filch's footsteps halted; there was a clink of metal on metal and the wailing stopped -Filch had picked up the egg and closed it. Roberto stood very still, one leg still Jammed tightly in the magical step, listening. Any moment now, Filch was going to pull aside the tapestry, expecting to see Peeves . . . and there would be no Peeves ... but if he came up the stairs, he would spot the Marauder's Map . . . and Invisibility Cloak or not, the map would show "Roberto Gonzales" standing exactly where he was.
　　"Egg?" Filch said quietly at the foot of the stairs. "My sweet!" - Mrs. Norris was obviously with him - "This is a Triwizard clue! This belongs to a school champion!"
　　Roberto felt sick; his heart was hammering very fast -"
　　PEEVES!" Filch roared gleefully. "You've been stealing!"
　　He ripped back the tapestry below, and Roberto saw his horrible, pouchy face and bulging, pale eyes staring up the dark and (to Filch) deserted staircase.
　　"Hiding, are you?" he said softly. "I'm coming to get you, Peeves. . . . You've gone and stolen a Triwizard clue, Peeves... . Dominguez'll have you out of here for this, you filthy, pilfering poltergeist. ..."
　　Filch started to climb the stairs, his scrawny, dust-colored cat at his heels. Mrs.
　　Morris's lamp-like eyes, so very like her masters, were fixed directly upon Roberto. He had had occasion before now to wonder whether the Invisibility Cloak worked on cats. . .
　　. Sick with apprehension, he watched Filch drawing nearer and nearer in his old flannel dressing gown - he tried desperately to pull his trapped leg free, but it merely sank a few more inches - any second now, Filch was going to spot the map or walk right into him -"
　　Filch? Whats going on?"
　　Filch stopped a few steps below Roberto and turned. At the foot of the stairs stood the only person who could make Roberto's situation worse: Peralta. He was wearing a long gray nightshirt and he looked livid.
　　"Its Peeves, Professor," Filch whispered malevolently. "He threw this egg down the stairs."
　　Peralta climbed up the stairs quickly and stopped beside Filch. Roberto gritted his teeth, convinced his loudly thumping heart would give him away at any second. . . .
　　"Peeves?" said Peralta softly, staring at the egg in Filch's hands. "But Peeves couldn't get into my office. . . ."
　　"This egg was in your office. Professor?"
　　"Of course not," Peralta snapped. "I heard banging and wailing -"
　　"Yes, Professor, that was the egg -"
　　"- I was coming to investigate -"
　　"- Peeves threw it. Professor -"
　　"- and when I passed my office, I saw that the torches were lit and a cupboard door was ajar! Somebody has been searching it!"
　　But Peeves couldn't -"
　　"I know he couldn't, Filch!" Peralta snapped again. "I seal my office with a spell none but a wizard could break!" Peralta looked up the stairs, straight through Roberto, and then down into the corridor below. "I want you to come and help me search for the intruder, Filch."
　　"I - yes, Professor - but -"
　　Filch looked yearningly up the stairs, right through Roberto, who could see that he was very reluctant to forgo the chance of cornering Peeves. Go, Roberto pleaded with him silently, go with Peralta . . . go. . . Mrs. Norris was peering around Filch's legs....
　　Roberto had the distinct impression that she could smell him.. . . Why had he filled that bath with so much perfumed foam?
　　"The thing is, Professor," said Filch plaintively, "the headmaster will have to listen to me this time. Peeves has been stealing from a student, it might be my chance to get him thrown out of the castle once and for all -"
　　"Filch, I don't give a damn about that wretched poltergeist; it's my office that's -"
　　Clunk. Clunk. Clunk.
　　Peralta stopped talking very abruptly. He and Filch both looked down at the foot of the stairs. Roberto saw Mad-Eye Acosta limp into sight through the narrow gap between their heads. Acosta was wearing his old traveling cloak over his nightshirt and leaning on his staff as usual.
　　"Pajama party, is it?" he growled up the stairs.
　　"Professor Peralta and I heard noises, Professor," said Filch at once. "Peeves the Poltergeist, throwing things around as usual - and then Professor Peralta discovered that someone had broken into his off -"
　　"Shut up!" Peralta hissed to Filch.
　　Acosta took a step closer to the foot of the stairs. Roberto saw Acostas magical eye travel over Peralta, and then, unmistakably, onto himself.
　　Robertos heart gave a horrible jolt. Acosta could see through Invisibility Cloaks... he alone could see the full strangeness of the scene:
　　Peralta in his nightshirt, Filch clutching the egg, and he, Roberto, trapped in the stairs behind them. Acosta's lopsided gash of a mouth opened in surprise. For a few seconds, he and Roberto stared straight into each other's eyes. Then Acosta closed his mouth and turned his blue eye upon Peralta again.
　　"Did I hear that correctly, Peralta?" he asked slowly. "Someone broke into your office?"
　　"It is unimportant," said Peralta coldly. "On the contrary," growled Acosta, "it is very important. Who'd want to break into your office?"
