　　"A student, I daresay," said Peralta. Roberto could see a vein flickering horribly on Peralta's greasy temple. "It has happened before. Potion ingredients have gone missing from my private store cupboard ... students attempting illicit mixtures, no doubt...."
　　"Reckon they were after potion ingredients, eh?" said Acosta. "Not hiding anything else in your office, are you?"
　　Roberto saw the edge of Peraltas sallow face turn a nasty brick color, the vein in his temple pulsing more rapidly.
　　"You know I'm hiding nothing, Acosta," he said in a soft and dangerous voice, "as you've searched my office pretty thoroughly yourself."
　　Acostas face twisted into a smile. "Auror's privilege, Peralta. Dominguez told me to keep an eye -"
　　"Dominguez happens to trust me," said Peralta through clenched teeth. "I refuse to believe that he gave you orders to search my office!"
　　"Course Dominguez trusts you," growled Acosta. "Hes a trusting man, isn't he? Believes in second chances. But me - I say there are spots that don't come off, Peralta. Spots that never come off, d'you know what I mean?"
　　Peralta suddenly did something very strange. He seized his left forearm convulsively with his right hand, as though something on it had hurt him.
　　Acosta laughed. "Get back to bed, Peralta."
　　"You don't have the authority to send me anywhere!" Peralta hissed, letting go of his arm as though angry with himself. "I have as much right to prowl this school after dark as you do!"
　　"Prowl away," said Acosta, but his voice was full of menace. "I look forward to meeting you in a dark corridor some time.... You've dropped something, by the way. ..."
　　With a stab of horror. Roberto saw Acosta point at the Marauders Map, still lying on the staircase six steps below him. As Peralta and Filch both turned to look at it, Roberto threw caution to the winds; he raised his arms under the cloak and waved furiously at Acosta to attract his attention, mouthing "It's mine! Mine!"
　　Peralta had reached out for it, a horrible expression of dawning comprehension on his face -"
　　Accio Parchment!"
　　The map flew up into the air, slipped through Peraltas outstretched fingers, and soared down the stairs into Acostas hand.
　　"My mistake," Acosta said calmly. "It's mine - must've dropped it earlier -"
　　But Peralta's black eyes were darting from the egg in Filch's arms to the map in Acostas hand, and Roberto could tell he was putting two and two together, as only Peralta could. . .
　　.
　　"Gonzales," he said quietly.
　　"What's that?" said Acosta calmly, folding up the map and pocketing it.
　　"Gonzales!" Peralta snarled, and he actually turned his head and stared right at the place where Roberto was, as though he could suddenly see him. "That egg is Gonzaless egg. That
　　piece of parchment belongs to Gonzales. I have seen it before, I recognize it! Gonzales is here! Gonzales, in his Invisibility Cloak!"
　　Peralta stretched out his hands like a blind man and began to move up the stairs; Roberto could have sworn his over-large nostrils were dilating, trying to sniff Roberto out -trapped.
　　Roberto leaned backward, trying to avoid Peraltas fingertips, but any moment now-"
　　There's nothing there, Peralta!" barked Acosta, "but I'll be happy to tell the headmaster how quickly your mind jumped to Roberto Gonzales!"
　　"Meaning what?" Peralta turned again to look at Acosta, his hands still outstretched, inches from Roberto's chest.
　　"Meaning that Dominguez's very interested to know who's got it in for that boy!" said Acosta, limping nearer still to the foot of the stairs. "And so am I, Peralta . . . very interested...." The torchlight flickered across his mangled face, so that the scars, and the chunk missing from his nose, looked deeper and darker than ever.
　　Peralta was looking down at Acosta, and Roberto couldn't see the expression on his face. For a moment, nobody moved or said anything. Then Peralta slowly lowered his hands.
　　"I merely thought," said Peralta, in a voice of forced calm, "that if Gonzales was wandering around after hours again ... it's an unfortunate habit of his ... he should be stopped.
　　For - for his own safety."
　　"Ah, I see," said Acosta softly. "Got Gonzales's best interests at heart, have you?"
　　There was a pause. Peralta and Acosta were still staring at each other, Mrs. Norris gave a loud meow, still peering around Filch's legs, looking for the source of Roberto's bubble-bath smell.
　　"I think I will go back to bed," Peralta said curtly.
　　"Best idea you've had all night," said Acosta. "Now, Filch, if you'll just give me that egg-"
　　"No!" said Filch, clutching the egg as though it were his firstborn son. "Professor Acosta, this is evidence of Peeves' treachery!"
　　"It's the property of the champion he stole it from," said Acosta. Hand it over, now."
　　Peralta swept downstairs and passed Acosta without another word. Filch made a chirruping noise to Mrs. Norris, who stared blankly at Roberto for a few more seconds before turning and following her master. Still breathing very fast. Roberto heard Peralta walking away down the corridor; Filch handed Acosta the egg and disappeared from view too, muttering to Mrs. Norris. "Never mind. my sweet.. . we'll see Dominguez in the morning ... tell him what Peeves was up to...."
　　A door slammed. Roberto was left staring down at Acosta, who placed his staff on the bottommost stair and started to climb laboriously toward him, a dull clunk on every other step.
　　"Close shave. Gonzales," he muttered.
　　"Yeah ... I - er ... thanks," said Roberto weakly.
　　"What is this thing?" said Acosta, drawing the Marauder's Map out of his pocket and unfolding it.
　　"Map of Hogwarts," said Roberto, hoping Acosta was going to pull him out of the staircase soon; his leg was really hurting him.
　　"Merlins beard," Acosta whispered, staring at the map, his magical eye going haywire.
　　"This . .. this is some map. Gonzales!"
　　"Yeah, its . . . quite useful," Roberto said. His eyes were starting to water from the pain. "Er - Professor Acosta, d'you think you could help me - ?"
　　"What? Oh! Yes . . . yes, of course . .."
　　Acosta took hold of Robertos arms and pulled; Robertos leg came free of the trick step, and he climbed onto the one above it. Acosta was still gazing at the map.
　　"Gonzales ..." he said slowly, "you didn't happen, by any chance, to see who broke into Peraltas office, did you? On this map, I mean?"
　　"Er . . . yeah, I did . . ." Roberto admitted. "It was Mr. Crouch."
　　Acostas magical eye whizzed over the entire surface of the map. He looked suddenly alarmed.
　　"Crouch?" he said. "You're - you're sure. Gonzales?"
　　"Positive," said Roberto.
　　"Well, he's not here anymore," said Acosta, his eye still whizzing over the map. "Crouch . .. that's very - very interesting... ."
　　He said nothing for almost a minute, still staring at the map. Roberto could tell that
　　this news meant something to Acosta and very much wanted to know what it was. He wondered whether he dared ask. Acosta scared him slightly. . . yet Acosta had just helped him avoid an awful lot of trouble. . . .
　　"Er ... Professor Acosta . . . why d'you reckon Mr. Crouch wanted to look around Peraltas office?"
　　Acostas magical eye left the map and fixed, quivering, upon Roberto. It was a penetrating glare, and Roberto had the impression that Acosta was sizing him up, wondering whether to answer or not, or how much to tell him.
　　"Put it this way. Gonzales," Acosta muttered finally, "they say old Mad-Eye's obsessed with catching Dark wizards . . . but I'm nothing - nothing - compared to Barty Crouch."
　　He continued to stare at the map. Roberto was burning to know more.
　　"Professor Acosta?" he said again. "D'you think... could this have anything to do with .
　　. . maybe Mr. Crouch thinks there's something going on. ..."
　　"Like what?" said Acosta sharply.
　　Roberto wondered how much he dare say. He didn't want Acosta to guess that he had a source of information outside Hogwarts; that might lead to tricky questions about Gustavo.
　　"I don't know," Roberto muttered, "odd stuffs been happening lately, hasn't it? It's been in the Daily Prophet... the Dark Mark at the World Cup, and the Death Eaters and everything...."
　　Both of Acosta's mismatched eyes widened.
　　"You're a sharp boy. Gonzales," he said. His magical eye roved back to the Marauder's Map.
　　"Crouch could be thinking along those lines," he said slowly. "Very possible. . . there have been some funny rumors flying around lately - helped along by Rita Skeeter, of course. It's making a lot of people nervous, I reckon." A grim smile twisted his lopsided mouth. "Oh if there's one thing I hate," he muttered, more to himself than to Roberto, and his magical eye was fixed on the left-hand corner of the map, "its a Death Eater who walked free. ..."
　　Roberto stared at him. Could Acosta possibly mean what Roberto thought he meant?
　　"And now I want to ask you a question. Gonzales," said Acosta in a more businesslike tone.
　　Robertos heart sank; he had thought this was coming. Acosta was going to ask where he had got this map, which was a very dubious magical object - and the story of how it had fallen into his hands incriminated not only him, but his own father, Pablo and Luis Lopez, and Professor Cardozo, their last Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher. Acosta waved the map in front of Roberto, who braced himself-"
　　Can I borrow this?"
　　"Oh!" said Roberto.
　　He was very fond of his map, but on the other hand, he was extremely relieved that Acosta wasn't asking where he'd got it, and there was no doubt that he owed Acosta a favor.
　　"Yeah, okay."
　　"Good boy," growled Acosta. "I can make good use of this . .. this might be exactly what I've been looking for. . . . Right, bed, Gonzales, come on, now. ..."
　　They climbed to the top of the stairs together, Acosta still examining the map as though it was a treasure the like of which he had never seen before. They walked in silence to the door of Acosta's office, where he stopped and looked up at Roberto.
　　"You ever thought of a career as an Auror, Gonzales?"
　　"No," said Roberto, taken aback.
　　"You want to consider it," said Acosta, nodding and looking at Roberto thoughtfully. "Yes, indeed ... and incidentally ... I'm guessing you werent Just taking that egg for a walk tonight?"
　　"Er - no," said Roberto, grinning. "I've been working out the clue."
　　Acosta winked at him, his magical eye going haywire again. "Nothing like a nighttime stroll to give you ideas, Gonzales. . .. See you in the morning...."
　　He went back into his office, staring down at the Marauders Map again, and closed the door behind him.
　　Roberto walked slowly back to Gryffindor Tower, lost in thought about Peralta, and Crouch, and what it all meant.... Why was Crouch pretending to be ill, if he could manage to get to Hogwarts when he wanted to? What did he think Peralta was concealing in his office?
　　And Acosta thought he. Roberto, ought to be an Auror! Interesting idea.. . but somehow.
　　Roberto thought, as he got quietly into his four-poster ten minutes later, the egg and the cloak now safely back in his trunk, he thought he'd like to check how scarred the rest of them were before he chose it as a career.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-SIX - THE SECOND TASK
　　You said you'd already worked out that egg clue!" said Carolina indignantly.
　　"Keep your voice down!" said Roberto crossly. "I just need to - sort of fine-tune it, all right?"
　　He, Diego, and Carolina were sitting at the very back of the Charms class with a table to themselves. They were supposed to be practicing the opposite of the Summoning Charm today - the Banishing Charm. Owing to the potential for nasty accidents when objects kept flying across the room. Professor Flitwick had given each student a stack of cushions on which to practice, the theory being that these wouldn't hurt anyone if they went off target. It was a good theory, but it wasn't working very well. Mauricio's aim was so poor that he kept accidentally sending much heavier things flying across the room - Professor Flitwick, for instance.
　　"Just forget the egg for a minute, all right?" Roberto hissed as Professor Flitwick went whizzing resignedly past them, landing on top of a large cabinet. "I'm trying to tell you about Peralta and Acosta. ..."
　　This class was an ideal cover for a private conversation, as everyone was having far too much fun to pay them any attention. Roberto had been recounting his adventures of the previous night in whispered installments for the last half hour.
　　"Peralta said Acostas searched his office as well?" Diego whispered, his eyes alight with interest as he Banished a cushion with a sweep of his wand (it soared into the air and knocked Parvati's hat off). "What. . . d'you reckon Acosta's here to keep an eye on Peralta as well as Morales?"
　　"Well, I dunno if that's what Dominguez asked him to do, but he's definitely doing it,"
　　said Roberto, waving his wand without paying much attention, so that his cushion did an odd sort of belly flop off the desk. "Acosta said Dominguez only lets Peralta stay here because he's giving him a second chance or something. ..."
　　"What?" said Diego, his eyes widening, his next cushion spinning high into the air, ricocheting off the chandelier, and dropping heavily onto Flitwick's desk. "Roberto...
　　maybe Acosta thinks Peralta put your name in the Goblet of Fire!"
　　"Oh Diego," said Carolina, shaking her head sceptically, "we thought Peralta was trying to kill Roberto before, and it turned out he was saving Roberto's life, remember?"
　　She Banished a cushion and it flew across the room and landed in the box they were all supposed to be aiming at. Roberto looked at Carolina, thinking... it was true that Peralta had saved his life once, but the odd thing was, Peralta definitely loathed him, just as he'd loathed Roberto s father when they had been at school together. Peralta loved taking points from Roberto, and had certainly never missed an opportunity to give him punishments, or even to suggest that he should be suspended from the school.
　　"I don't care what Acosta says," Carolina went on. "Dominguez's not stupid. He was right to trust Villalba and Professor Cardozo, even though loads of people wouldn't have given them jobs, so why shouldn't he be right about Peralta, even if Peralta is a bit -"
　　"- evil," said Diego promptly. "Come on, Carolina, why are all these Dark wizard catchers searching his office, then?"
　　"Why has Mr. Crouch been pretending to be ill?" said Carolina, ignoring Diego. "Its a bit funny, isn't it, that he cant manage to come to the Yule Ball, but he can get up here in the middle of the night when he wants to?"
　　"You just don't like Crouch because of that elf, Winky," said Diego, sending a cushion soaring into the window.
　　"You just want to think Peraltas up to something," said Carolina, sending her cushion zooming neatly into the box.
　　"I just want to know what Peralta did with his first chance, if he's on his second one,"
　　said Roberto grimly, and his cushion, to his very great surprise, flew straight across the room and landed neatly on top of Carolina's.
　　Obedient to Gustavo's wish of hearing about anything odd at Hogwarts, Roberto sent him a letter by brown owl that night, explaining all about Mr. Crouch breaking into Peralta s office, and Acosta and Peralta's conversation. Then Roberto turned his attention in earnest to the most urgent problem facing him: how to survive underwater for an hour on the twenty-fourth of February.
　　Diego quite liked the idea of using the Summoning Charm again - Roberto had explained about
　　Aqua-Lungs, and Diego couldn't see why Roberto shouldn't Summon one from the nearest Muggle town. Carolina squashed this plan by pointing out that, in the unlikely event that Roberto managed to learn how to operate an Aqua-Lung within the set limit of an hour, he was sure to be disqualified for breaking the International Code of Wizarding Secrecy - it was too much to hope that no Muggles would spot an Aqua-Lung zooming across the countryside to Hogwarts.
　　"Of course, the ideal solution would be for you to Transfigure yourself into a submarine or something," Carolina said. "If only we'd done human Transfiguration already! But I don't think we start that until sixth year, and it can go badly wrong if you don't know what you're doing...."
　　"Yeah, I don't fancy walking around with a periscope sticking out of my head," said Roberto. "I s'pose I could always attack someone in front of Acosta; he might do it for me...."
　　"I don't think he'd let you choose what you wanted to be turned into, though," said Carolina seriously. "No, I think your best chance is some sort of charm."
　　So Roberto, thinking that he would soon have had enough of the library to last him a lifetime, buried himself once more among the dusty volumes, looking for any spell that might enable a human to survive without oxygen. However, though he, Diego, and Carolina searched through their lunchtimes, evenings, and whole weekends - though Roberto asked Professor Romero for a note of permission to use the Restricted Section, and even asked the irritable, vulture-like librarian. Madam Pince, for help - they found nothing whatsoever that would enable Roberto to spend an hour underwater and live to tell the tale.
　　Familiar flutterings of panic were starting to disturb Roberto now, and he was finding it difficult to concentrate in class again. The lake, which Roberto had always taken for granted as just another feature of the grounds, drew his eyes whenever he was near a classroom window, a great, iron-gray mass of chilly water, whose dark and icy depths were starting to seem as distant as the moon.
　　Just as it had before he faced the Horntail, time was slipping away as though somebody had bewitched the clocks to go extra-fast. There was a week to go before February the twenty-fourth (there was still time) . . . there were five days to go (he was bound to find something soon) .. . three days to go (please let me find something... please). . .
　　With two days left. Roberto started to go off food again. The only good thing about breakfast on Monday was the return of the brown owl he had sent to Gustavo. He pulled off the parchment, unrolled it, and saw the shortest letter Gustavo had ever written to him.
　　Send date of next Hogsmeade weekend by return owl.
　　Roberto turned the parchment over and looked at the back, hoping to see something else, but it was blank.
　　"Weekend after next," whispered Carolina, who had read the note over Robertos shoulder.
　　"Here - take my quill and send this owl back straight away."
　　Roberto scribbled the dates down on the back of Gustavo's letter, tied it onto the brown owl's leg, and watched it take flight again. What had he expected? Advice on how to survive underwater? He had been so intent on telling Gustavo all about Peralta and Acosta he had completely forgotten to mention the eggs clue.
　　"What's he want to know about the next Hogsmeade weekend for?" said Diego.
　　"Dunno," said Roberto dully. The momentary happiness that had flared inside him at the sight of the owl had died. "Come on ...Care of Magical Creatures."
　　Whether Villalba was trying to make up for the Blast-Ended Skrewts, or because there were now only two skrewts left, or because he was trying to prove he could do anything that Professor Grubbly-Plank could. Roberto didnt know, but Villalba had been continuing her lessons on unicorns ever since he'd returned to work. It turned out that Villalba knew quite as much about unicorns as he did about monsters, though it was clear that he found their lack of poisonous fangs disappointing.
　　Today he had managed to capture two unicorn foals. Unlike full-grown unicorns, they were pure gold. Parvati and Lavender went into transports of delight at the sight of them, and even Pansy Parkinson had to work hard to conceal how much she liked them.
　　"Easier ter spot than the adults," Villalba told the class. "They turn silver when they're abou' two years old, an' they grow horns at aroun four. Don' go pure white till they're full grown, 'round about seven. They're a bit more trustin when they're babies .. . don mind boys so much.... C'mon, move in a bit, yeh can pat 'em if yeh want. . . give 'em a
　　few o' these sugar lumps. . . .
　　"You okay. Roberto?" Villalba muttered, moving aside slightly, while most of the others swarmed around the baby unicorns.
　　"Yeah," said Roberto. "Jus' nervous, eh?" said Villalba.
　　"Bit," said Roberto.
　　"Roberto," said Villalba, clapping a massive hand on his shoulder, so that Roberto's knees buckled under its weight, "I'd've bin worried before I saw yeh take on tha Horntail, but I know now yeh can do anythin' yeh set yer mind ter. I'm not worried at all. Yeh're goin ter be fine. Got yer clue worked out, haven' yeh?"
　　Roberto nodded, but even as he did so, an insane urge to confess that he didn't have any idea how to survive at the bottom of the lake for an hour came over him. He looked up at Villalba - perhaps he had to go into the lake sometimes, to deal with the creatures in it?
　　He looked after everything else on the grounds, after all-"
　　Yeh're goin' ter win," Villalba growled, patting Robertos shoulder again, so that Roberto actually felt himself sink a couple of inches into the soft ground. "I know it. I can feel it. Yeh're goin' ter win, Roberto n Roberto just couldn't bring himself to wipe the happy, confident smile off Villalba's face.
　　Pretending he was interested in the young unicorns, he forced a smile in return, and moved forward to pat them with the others.
　　By the evening before the second task. Roberto felt as though he were trapped in a nightmare. He was fully aware that even if, by some miracle, he managed to find a suitable spell, he'd have a real job mastering it overnight. How could he have let this happen? Why hadn't he got to work on the egg's clue sooner? Why had he ever let his mind wander in class - what if a teacher had once mentioned how to breathe underwater?
　　He sat with Carolina and Diego in the library as the sun set outside, tearing feverishly through page after page of spells, hidden from one another by the massive piles of books on the desk in front of each of them. Roberto s heart gave a huge leap every time he saw the word "water" on a page, but more often than not it was merely "Take two pints of water, half a pound of shredded mandrake leaves, and a newt..."
　　"I don't reckon it can be done," said Diegos voice flatly from the other side of the table.
　　"There's nothing. Nothing. Closest was that thing to dry up puddles and ponds, that Drought Charm, but that was nowhere near powerful enough to drain the lake."
　　"There must be something," Carolina muttered, moving a candle closer to her. Her eyes were so tired she was poring over the tiny print of Olde and Forgotten Bewitchments and Charmes with her nose about an inch from the page. "They'd never have set a task that was undoable."
　　"They have," said Diego. "Roberto, just go down to the lake tomorrow, right, stick your head in, yell at the merpeople to give back whatever they've nicked, and see if they chuck it out. Best you can do, mate."
　　"There's a way of doing it!" Carolina said crossly. "There Just has to be!"
　　She seemed to be taking the library's lack of useful information on the subject as a personal insult; it had never failed her before.
　　"I know what I should have done," said Roberto, resting, face-down, on Saucy Tricks for Tricky Sorts. "I should've learned to be an Animagus like Gustavo."
　　An Animagus was a wizard who could transform into an animal.
　　"Yeah, you could've turned into a goldfish any time you wanted!" said Diego.
　　"Or a frog," yawned Roberto. He was exhausted. "It takes years to become an Animagus, and then you have to register yourself and everything," said Carolina vaguely, now squinting down the index of Weird Wizarding Dilemmas and Their Solutions. "Professor Romero told us, remember... you've got to register yourself with the Improper Use of Magic Office ...what animal you become, and your markings, so you can't abuse it..."
　　"Carolina, I was joking," said Roberto wearily. "I know I haven't got a chance of turning into a frog by tomorrow morning...."
　　"Oh this is no use," Carolina said, snapping shut Weird Wizarding Dilemmas. "Who on earth wants to make their nose hair grow into ringlets?"
　　"I wouldn't mind," said Pablo Lopezs voice. "Be a talking point, wouldn't it?"
　　Roberto, Diego, and Carolina looked up. Pablo and Luis had just emerged from behind some bookshelves.
　　"What're you two doing here?" Diego asked.
　　"Looking for you," said Luis. "Romero wants you, Diego. And you, Carolina."
　　"Why?" said Carolina, looking surprised.
　　"Dunno ... she was looking a bit grim, though," said Pablo.
　　"We're supposed to take you down to her office," said Luis.
　　Diego and Carolina stared at Roberto, who felt his stomach drop. Was Professor Romero about to tell Diego and Carolina off? Perhaps she'd noticed how much they were helping him, when he ought to be working out how to do the task alone?
　　"We'll meet you back in the common room," Carolina told Roberto as she got up to go with Diego - both of them looked very anxious. "Bring as many of these books as you can, okay?"
　　"Right," said Roberto uneasily.
　　By eight o'clock. Madam Pince had extinguished all the lamps and came to chivvy Roberto out of the library. Staggering under the weight of as many books as he could carry, Roberto returned to the Gryffindor common room, pulled a table into a corner, and continued to search. There was nothing in Madcap Magic for Wacky Warlocks. . . nothing in A Guide to Medieval Sorcery . . . not one mention of underwater exploits in An Anthology of Eighteenth-Century Charms, or in Dreadful Denizens of the Deep, or Powers You Never Knew You Had and What to Do with Them Now Youve Wised Up.
　　Crookshanks crawled into Robertos lap and curled up, purring deeply. The common room emptied slowly around Roberto. People kept wishing him luck for the next morning in cheery, confident voices like Villalba s, all of them apparently convinced that he was about to pull off another stunning performance like the one he had managed in the first task. Roberto couldn't answer them, he just nodded, feeling as though there were a golfball stuck in his throat. By ten to midnight, he was alone in the room with Crookshanks. He had searched all the remaining books, and Diego and Carolina had not come back.
　　It's over, he told himself. You can't do it. You'll just have to go down to the lake in the morning and tell the judges....
　　He imagined himself explaining that he couldn't do the task. He pictured Bagman's look of round-eyed surprise, Moraless satisfied, yellow-toothed smile. He could almost hear Camila Saenz saying "I knew it. . . 'e is too young, 'e is only a little boy." He saw Sosa flashing his GONZALES STINKS badge at the front of the crowd, saw Villalba s crestfallen, disbelieving face. . . .
　　Forgetting that Crookshanks was on his lap. Roberto stood up very suddenly; Crookshanks hissed angrily as he landed on the floor, gave Roberto a disgusted look, and stalked away with his bottlebrush tail in the air, but Roberto was already hurrying up the spiral staircase to his dormitory. ... He would grab the Invisibility Cloak and go back to the library, he'd stay there all night if he had to. ...
　　"Lumos," Roberto whispered fifteen minutes later as he opened the library door.
　　Wand tip alight, he crept along the bookshelves, pulling down more books - books of hexes and charms, books on merpeople and water monsters, books on famous witches and wizards, on magical inventions, on anything at all that might include one passing reference to underwater survival. He carried them over to a table, then set to work, searching them by the narrow beam of his wand, occasionally checking his watch. . . .
　　One in the morning. . . two in the morning . . . the only way he could keep going was to tell himself, over and over again, next book. . . in the next one. . . the next one. . .
　　The mermaid in the painting in the prefects' bathroom was laughing. Roberto was bobbing like a cork in bubbly water next to her rock, while she held his Firebolt over his head.
　　"Come and get it!" she giggled maliciously. "Come on, jump!"
　　"I can't," Roberto panted, snatching at the Firebolt, and struggling not to sink. "Give it to me!"
　　But she just poked him painfully in the side with the end of the broomstick, laughing at him.
　　"That hurts - get off- ouch -"
　　"Roberto Gonzales must wake up, sir!"
　　"Stop poking me -"
　　"Dobby must poke Roberto Gonzales, sir, he must wake up!"
　　Roberto opened his eyes. He was still in the library; the Invisibility Cloak had slipped off his head as he'd slept, and the side of his face was stuck to the pages of Where There's a Wand, There's a Way. He sat up, straightening his glasses, blinking in the bright daylight.
　　"Roberto Gonzales needs to hurry!" squeaked Dobby. "The second task starts in ten minutes,
　　and Roberto Gonzales -"
　　"Ten minutes?" Roberto croaked. "Ten - ten minutes?"
　　He looked down at his watch. Dobby was right. It was twenty past nine. A large, dead weight seemed to fall through Roberto's chest into his stomach.
　　"Hurry, Roberto Gonzales!" squeaked Dobby, plucking at Roberto's sleeve. "You is supposed to be down by the lake with the other champions, sir!"
　　"It's too late, Dobby," Roberto said hopelessly. "I'm not doing the task, I don't know how-"
　　"Roberto Gonzales will do the task!" squeaked the elf. "Dobby knew Roberto had not found the right book, so Dobby did it for him!"
　　"What?" said Roberto. "But you don't know what the second task is -"
　　"Dobby knows, sir! Roberto Gonzales has to go into the lake and find his Wheezy -"
　　"Find my what?"
　　"- and take his Wheezy back from the merpeople!"
　　"What's a Wheezy?"
　　"Your Wheezy, sir, your Wheezy-Wheezy who is giving Dobby his sweater!"
　　Dobby plucked at the shrunken maroon sweater he was now wearing over his shorts.
　　"What?" Roberto gasped. "They've got. . . they've got Diego?"
　　"The thing Roberto Gonzales will miss most, sir!" squeaked Dobby. "'But past an hour-'"
　　"- 'the prospect's black,'" Roberto recited, staring, horror-struck, at the elf. " 'Too late, it's gone, it won't come back.' Dobby - what've I got to do?"
　　"You has to eat this, sir!" s queaked the elf, and he put his hand in the pocket of his shorts and drew out a ball of what looked like slimy, grayish-green rat tails. "Right before you go into the lake, sir - gillyweed!"
　　"What's it do?" said Roberto, staring at the gillyweed.
　　"It will make Roberto Gonzales breathe underwater, sir!"
　　"Dobby," said Roberto frantically, "listen - are you sure about this?"
　　He couldn't quite forget that the last time Dobby had tried to "help" him, he had ended up with no bones in his right arm.
　　"Dobby is quite sure, sir!" said the elf earnestly. "Dobby hears things, sir, he is a house-elf, he goes all over the castle as he lights the fires and mops the floors. Dobby heard Professor Romero and Professor Acosta in the staffroom, talking about the next task. . . . Dobby cannot let Roberto Gonzales lose his Wheezy!"
　　Robertos doubts vanished. Jumping to his feet he pulled off the Invisibility Cloak, stuffed it into his bag, grabbed the gillyweed, and put it into his pocket, then tore out of the library with Dobby at his heels.
　　"Dobby is supposed to be in the kitchens, sir!" Dobby squealed as they burst into the corridor. "Dobby will be missed - good luck, Roberto Gonzales, sir, good luck!"
　　"See you later, Dobby!" Roberto shouted, and he sprinted along the corridor and down the stairs, three at a time.
　　The entrance hall contained a few last-minute stragglers, all leaving the Great Hall after breakfast and heading through the double oak doors to watch the second task. They stared as Roberto flashed past, sending Colin and Dennis Creevey flying as he leapt down the stone steps and out onto the bright, chilly grounds.
　　As he pounded down the lawn he saw that the seats that had encircled the dragons' enclosure in November were now ranged along the opposite bank, rising in stands that were packed to the bursting point and reflected in the lake below. The excited babble of the crowd echoed strangely across the water as Roberto ran flat-out around the other side of the lake toward the judges, who were sitting at another gold-draped table at the water's edge. Nicolas, Camila, and Krum were beside the judges' table, watching Roberto sprint toward them.
　　"I'm . .. here ..." Roberto panted, skidding to a halt in the mud and accidentally splattering Camilas robes.
　　"Where have you been?" said a bossy, disapproving voice. "The task's about to start!"
　　Roberto looked around. Miguel Lopez was sitting at the judges' table - Mr. Crouch had failed to turn up again.
　　"Now, now, Miguel!" said Ludo Bagman, who was looking intensely relieved to see Roberto.
　　"Let him catch his breath!"
　　Dominguez smiled at Roberto, but Morales and Madame Maxime didn't look at all pleased to see him. ... It was obvious from the looks on their faces that they had thought he wasn't going to turn up.
　　Roberto bent over, hands on his knees, gasping for breath; he had a stitch in his side that felt as though he had a knife between his ribs, but there was no time to get rid of it; Ludo Bagman was now moving among the champions, spacing them along the bank at intervals of ten feet. Roberto was on the very end of the line, next to Krum, who was wearing swimming trunks and was holding his wand ready.
　　"All right. Roberto?" Bagman whispered as he moved Roberto a few feet farther away from Krum. "Know what you're going to do?"
　　"Yeah," Roberto panted, massaging his ribs.
　　Bagman gave Roberto's shoulder a quick squeeze and returned to the judges' table; he pointed his wand at his throat as he had done at the World Cup, said, "Sonorus!" and his voice boomed out across the dark water toward the stands.
　　"Well, all our champions are ready for the second task, which will start on my whistle.
　　They have precisely an hour to recover what has been taken from them. On the count of three, then. One . . . two . . . three!"
　　The whistle echoed shrilly in the cold, still air; the stands erupted with cheers and applause; without looking to see what the other champions were doing, Roberto pulled off his shoes and socks, pulled the handful of gillyweed out of his pocket, stuffed it into his mouth, and waded out into the lake.
　　It was so cold he felt the skin on his legs searing as though this were fire, not icy water. His sodden robes weighed him down as he walked in deeper; now the water was over his knees, and his rapidly numbing feet were slipping over silt and flat, slimy stones.
　　He was chewing the gillyweed as hard and fast as he could; it felt unpleasantly slimy and rubbery, like octopus tentacles. Waist-deep in the freezing water he stopped, swallowed, and waited for something to happen.
　　He could hear laughter in the crowd and knew he must look stupid, walking into the lake without showing any sign of magical power. The part of him that was still dry was covered in goose pimples; half immersed in the icy water, a cruel breeze lifting his hair, Roberto started to shiver violently. He avoided looking at the stands; the laughter was becoming louder, and there were catcalls and jeering from the Slytherins. ...
　　Then, quite suddenly, Roberto felt as though an invisible pillow had been pressed over his mouth and nose. He tried to draw breath, but it made his head spin; his lungs were empty, and he suddenly felt a piercing pain on either side of his neck -Roberto clapped his hands around his throat and felt two large slits just below his ears, flapping in the cold air. . . . He had gills. Without pausing to think, he did the only thing that made sense - he flung himself forward into the water.
　　The first gulp of icy lake water felt like the breath of life. His head had stopped spinning; he took another great gulp of water and felt it pass smoothly through his gills, sending oxygen back to his brain. He stretched out his hands in front of him and stared at them. They looked green and ghostly under the water, and they had become webbed. He twisted around and looked at his bare feet - they had become elongated and the toes were webbed too:
　　It looked as though he had sprouted flippers.
　　The water didn't feel icy anymore either ... on the contrary, he felt pleasantly cool and very light. . . . Roberto struck out once more, marveling at how far and fast his flipper-like feet propelled him through the vater, and noticing how clearly he could see, and how he no longer seemed to need to blink. He had soon swum so far into the lake that he could no longer see the bottom. He flipped over and dived into its depths.
　　Silence pressed upon his ears as he soared over a strange, dark, foggy landscape. He could only see ten feet around him, so that as he sped throuugh the water new scenes seemed to loom suddenly out of the incoming darkness: forests of rippling, tangled black weed, wide plains of mud littered with dull, glimmering stones. He swam deeper and deeper, out toward the middle of the lake, his eyes wide, staring through the eerily gray-lit water around him to the shadow beyond, where the water became opaque.
　　Small fish flickered past him like silver darts. Once or twice he thought he saw something larger moving ahead of him, but when he got nearer, he discovered it to be nothing but a large, blackened log, or a dense clump of weed. There was no sign of any of the other champions, merpeople, Diego - nor, thankfully, the giant squid.
　　Light green weed stretched ahead of him as far as he could see, two feet deep, like a meadow of very overgrown grass. Roberto was staring unblinkingly ahead of him, trying to discern shapes through the gloom . . . and then, without warning, something grabbed hold of his ankle.
　　Roberto twisted his body around and saw a grindylow, a small, horned water demon, poking out of the weed, its long fingers clutched tightly around Roberto's leg, its pointed fangs bared - Roberto stuck his webbed hand quickly inside his robes and fumbled for his wand.
　　By the time he had grasped it, two more grindylows had risen out of the weed, had seized handfuls of Roberto's robes, and were attempting to drag him down.
　　"Relashio!" Roberto shouted, except that no sound came out. ... A large bubble issued from his mouth, and his wand, instead of sending sparks at the grindylows, pelted them with what seemed to be a jet of boiling water, for where it struck them, angry red patches appeared on their green skin. Roberto pulled his ankle out of the grindylows grip and swam, as fast as he could, occasionally sending more jets of hot water over his shoulder at random; every now and then he felt one of the grindylows snatch at his foot again, and he kicked out, hard; finally, he felt his foot connect with a horned skull, and looking back, saw the dazed grindylow floating away, cross-eyed, while its fellows shook their fists at Roberto and sank back into the weed.
　　Roberto slowed down a little, slipped his wand back inside his robes, and looked around, listening again. He turned full circle in the water, the silence pressing harder than ever against his eardrums. He knew he must be even deeper in the lake now, but nothing was moving but the rippling weed.
　　"How are you getting on?"
　　Roberto thought he was having a heart attack. He whipped around and saw Moaning Myrtle floating hazily in front of him, gazing at him through her thick, pearly glasses.
　　"Myrtle!" Roberto tried to shout - but once again, nothing came out of his mouth but a very large bubble. Moaning Myrtle actually giggled.
　　"You want to try over there!" she said, pointing. "I won't come with you. ... I don't like them much, they always chase me when I get too close. ..."
　　Roberto gave her the thumbs-up to show his thanks and set off once more, careful to swim a bit higher over the weed to avoid any more grindylows that might be lurking there.
　　He swam on for what felt like at least twenty minutes. He was passing over vast expanses of black mud now, which swirled murkily as he disturbed the water. Then, at long last, he heard a snatch of haunting mersong.
　　"An hour long you'll have to look, And to recover what we took..."
　　Roberto swam faster and soon saw a large rock emerge out of the muddy water ahead. It had paintings of merpeople on it; they were carrying spears and chasing what looked like the giant squid. Roberto swam on past the rock, following the mersong.
　　". . . your time's half gone, so tarry not Lest what you seek stays here to rot. ..."
　　A cluster of crude stone dwellings stained with algae loomed suddenly out of the gloom on all sides. Here and there at the dark windows, Roberto saw faces . . . faces that bore no resemblance at all to the painting of the mermaid in the prefects' bathroom. . . .
　　The merpeople had grayish skin and long, wild, dark green hair. Their eyes were yellow, as were their broken teeth, and they wore thick ropes of pebbles around their necks. They leered at Roberto as he swam past; one or two of them emerged from their caves to watch him better, their powerful, silver fish tails beating the water, spears clutched in their hands.
　　Roberto sped on, staring around, and soon the dwellings became more numerous; there were gardens of weed around some of them, and he even saw a pet grindylow tied to a stake outside one door. Merpeople were emerging on all sides now, watching him eagerly, pointing at his webbed hands and gills, talking behind their hands to one another. Roberto sped around a corner and a very strange sight met his eyes.
　　A whole crowd of merpeople was floating in front of the houses that lined what looked like a mer-version of a village square. A choir of merpeople was singing in the middle, calling the champions toward them, and behind them rose a crude sort of statue; a gigantic merperson hewn from a boulder. Four people were bound tightly to the tail of the stone merperson.
　　Diego was tied between Carolina and Paula Mejia. There was also a girl who looked no older than eight, whose clouds of silvery hair made Roberto feel sure that she was Camila
　　Saenz's sister. All four of them appeared to be in a very deep sleep. Their heads were lolling onto their shoulders, and fine streams of bubbles kept issuing from their mouths.
　　Roberto sped toward the hostages, half expecting the merpeople to lower their spears and charge at him, but they did nothing. The ropes of weed tying the hostages to the statue were thick, slimy, and very strong. For a fleeting second he thought of the knife Gustavo had bought him for Christmas - locked in his trunk in the castle a quarter of a mile away, no use to him whatsoever.
　　He looked around. Many of the merpeople surrounding them were carrying spears. He swam swiftly toward a seven-foot-tall merman with a long green beard and a choker of shark fangs and tried to mime a request to borrow the spear. The merman laughed and shook his head.
　　"We do not help," he said in a harsh, croaky voice.
　　"Come ON!" Roberto said fiercely (but only bubbles issued from his mouth), and he tried to pull the spear away from the merman, but the merman yanked it back, still shaking his head and laughing.
　　Roberto swirled around, staring about. Something sharp . . . anything . . .
　　There were rocks littering the lake bottom. He dived and snatched up a particularly jagged one and returned to the statue. He began to hack at the ropes binding Diego, and after several minutes' hard work, they broke apart. Diego floated, unconscious, a few inches above the lake bottom, drifting a little in the ebb of the water.
　　Roberto looked around. There was no sign of any of the other champions. What were they playing at? Why didn't they hurry up? He turned back to Carolina, raised the jagged rock, and began to hack at her bindings too -At once, several pairs of strong gray hands seized him. Half a dozen mermen were pulling him away from Carolina, shaking their green-haired heads, and laughing.
　　"You take your own hostage," one of them said to him. "Leave the others ..."
　　"No way!" said Roberto furiously - but only two large bubbles came out.
　　Your task is to retrieve your own friend . . . leave the others ..." She's my friend too!" Roberto yelled, gesturing toward Carolina, an enormous silver bubble emerging soundlessly from his lips. "And I don't want them to die either!"
　　Paula's head was on Carolinas shoulder; the small silver-haired girl was ghostly green and pale. Roberto struggled to fight off the mermen, but they laughed harder than ever, holding him back. Roberto looked wildly around. Where were the other champions? Would he have time to take Diego to the surface and come back down for Carolina and the others?
　　Would he be able to find them again? He looked down at his watch to see how much time was left - it had stopped working.
　　But then the merpeople around him pointed excitedly over his head. Roberto looked up and saw Nicolas swimming toward them. There was an enormous bubble around his head, which made his features look oddly wide and stretched.
　　"Got lost!" he mouthed, looking panic-stricken. "Camila and Krum're coming now!"
　　Feeling enormously relieved, Roberto watched Nicolas pull a knife out of his pocket and cut Paula free. He pulled her upward and out of sight.
　　Roberto looked around, waiting. Where were Camila and Krum? Time was getting short, and according to the song, the hostages would be lost after an hour. . . .
　　The merpeople started screeching animatedly. Those holding Roberto loosened their grip, staring behind them. Roberto turned and saw something monstrous cutting through the water toward them: a human body in swimming trunks with the head of a shark. ... It was Krum.
　　He appeared to have transfigured himself- but badly.
　　The shark-man swam straight to Carolina and began snapping and biting at her ropes; the trouble was that Krum's new teeth were positioned very awkwardly for biting anything smaller than a dolphin, and Roberto was quite sure that if Krum wasn't careful, he was going to rip Carolina in half. Darting forward. Roberto hit Krum hard on the shoulder and held up the jagged stone. Krum seized it and began to cut Carolina free. Within seconds, he had done it; he grabbed Carolina around the waist, and without a backward glance, began to rise rapidly with her toward the surface.
　　Now what? Roberto thought desperately. If he could be sure that Camila was coming. . . .
　　But still no sign. There was nothing to be done except. . .
　　He snatched up the stone, which Krum had dropped, but the mermen now closed in around Diego and the little girl, shaking their heads at him. Roberto pulled out his wand.
　　"Get out of the way!"
　　Only bubbles flew out of his mouth, but he had the distinct impression that the mermen had understood him, because they suddenly stopped laughing. Their yellowish eyes were fixed upon Roberto's wand, and they looked scared. There might be a lot more of them than there were of him, but Roberto could tell, by the looks on their faces, that they knew no more magic than the giant squid did.
　　"You've got until three!" Roberto shouted; a great stream of bubbles burst from him, but he held up three fingers to make sure they got the message. "One . . ." (he put down a finger) "two . . ." (he put down a second one) -They scattered. Roberto darted forward and began to hack at the ropes binding the small girl to the statue, and at last she was free. He seized the little girl around the waist, grabbed the neck of Diegos robes, and kicked off from the bottom.
　　It was very slow work. He could no longer use his webbed hands to propel himself forward; he worked his flippers furiously, but Diego and Camila's sister were like potato-filled sacks dragging him back down. ... He fixed his eyes skyward, though he knew he must still be very deep, the water above him was so dark, . . .
　　Merpeople were rising with him. He could see them swirling around him with ease, watching him struggle through the water. .. . Would they pull him back down to the depths when the time was up? Did they perhaps eat humans? Roberto's legs were seizing up with the effort to keep swimming; his shoulders were aching horribly with the effort of dragging Diego and the girl...
　　He was drawing breath with extreme difficulty. He could feel pain on the sides of his neck again ... he was becoming very aware of how wet the water was in his mouth .. . yet the darkness was definitely thinning now... he could see daylight above him.. ..
　　He kicked hard with his flippers and discovered that they were nothing more than feet...water was flooding through his mouth into his lungs ... he was starting to feel dizzy, but he knew light and air were only ten feet above him ... he had to get there ...
　　he had to ...
　　Roberto kicked his legs so hard and fast it felt as though his muscles were screaming in protest; his very brain felt waterlogged, he couldn't breathe, he needed oxygen, he had to keep going, he could not stop -And then he felt his head break the surface of the lake; wonderful, cold, clear air was making his wet face sting; he gulped it down, feeling as though he had never breathed properly before, and, panting, pulled Diego and the little girl up with him. All around him, wild, green-haired heads were emerging out of the water with him, but they were smiling at him.
　　The crowd in the stands was making a great deal of noise; shouting and screaming, they all seemed to be on their feet; Roberto had the impression they thought that Diego and the little girl might be dead, but they were wrong . . . both of them had opened their eyes; the girl looked scared and confused, but Diego merely expelled a great spout of water, blinked in the bright light, turned to Roberto, and said, "Wet, this, isn't it?" Then he spotted Camila's sister. "What did you bring her for?"
　　"Camila didn't turn up, I couldn't leave her," Roberto panted.
　　"Roberto, you prat," said Diego, "you didn't take that song thing seriously, did you?
　　Dominguez wouldn't have let any of us drown!"
　　"The song said -"
　　"It was only to make sure you got back inside the time limit!" said Diego. "I hope you didn't waste time down there acting the hero!"
　　Roberto felt both stupid and annoyed. It was all very well for Diego; he'd been asleep, he hadn't felt how eerie it was down in the lake, surrounded by spear-carrying merpeople who'd looked more than capable of murder.
　　"C'mon," Roberto said shortly, "help me with her, I don't think she can swim very well."
　　They pulled Camila's sister through the water, back toward the bank where the judges stood watching, twenty merpeople accompanying them like a guard of honor, singing their horrible screechy songs.
　　Roberto could see Madam Pomfrey fussing over Carolina, Krum, Nicolas, and Paula, all of whom were wrapped in thick blankets.
　　Dominguez and Ludo Bagman stood beaming at Roberto and Diego from the bank as they swam nearer, but Miguel, who looked very white and somehow much younger than usual, came splashing out to meet them. Meanwhile Madame Maxime was trying to restrain Camila Saenz, who was quite hysterical, fighting tooth and nail to return to the water.
　　"Gabrielle! Gabrielle! Is she alive? Is she 'urt?"
　　"She's fine!" Roberto tried to tell her, but he was so exhausted he could hardly talk, let alone shout.
　　Miguel seized Diego and was dragging him back to the bank ("Gerroff, Miguel, I'm all right!"); Dominguez and Bagman were pulling Roberto upright; Camila had broken free of Madame Maxime and was hugging her sister.
　　"It was ze grindylows . . . zey attacked me ... oh Gabrielle, I thought... I thought.. ."
　　"Come here, you," said Madam Pomfrey. She seized Roberto and pulled him over to Carolina and the others, wrapped him so tightly in a blanket that he felt as though he were in a straitjacket, and forced a measure of very hot potion down his throat. Steam gushed out of his ears.
　　"Roberto, well done!" Carolina cried. "You did it, you found out how all by yourself!"
　　"Well -" said Roberto. He would have told her about Dobby, but he had just noticed Morales watching him. He was the only judge who had not left the table; the only judge not showing signs of pleasure and relief that Roberto, Diego, and Camila's sister had got back safely. "Yeah, that's right," said Roberto, raising his voice slightly so that Morales could hear him.
　　"You haff a water beetle in your hair, Herm-own-ninny," said Krum. Roberto had the impression that Krum was drawing her attention back onto himself; perhaps to remind her that he had just rescued her from the lake, but Carolina brushed away the beetle impatiently and said, "You're well outside the time limit, though, Roberto. . . . Did it take you ages to find us?"
　　"No ... I found you okay...."
　　Roberto's feeling of stupidity was growing. Now he was out of the water, it seemed perfectly clear that Dominguezs safety precautions wouldn't have permitted the death of a hostage just because their champion hadn't turned up. Why hadn't he just grabbed Diego and gone? He would have been first back.... Nicolas and Krum hadn't wasted time worrying about anyone else; they hadn't taken the mersong seriously. ...
　　Dominguez was crouching at the water's edge, deep in conversation with what seemed to be the chief merperson, a particularly wild and ferocious-looking female. He was making the same sort of screechy noises that the merpeople made when they were above water; clearly, Dominguez could speak Mermish. Finally he straightened up, turned to his fellow judges, and said, "A conference before we give the marks, I think."
　　The judges went into a huddle. Madam Pomfrey had gone to rescue Diego from Miguel's clutches; she led him over to Roberto and the others, gave him a blanket and some Pepperup Potion, then went to fetch Camila and her sister. Camila had many cuts on her face and arms and her robes were torn, but she didn't seem to care, nor would she allow Madam Pomfrey to clean them.
　　"Look after Gabrielle," she told her, and then she turned to Roberto. "You saved 'er," she said breathlessly. "Even though she was not your 'ostage."
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, who was now heartily wishing he'd left all three girls tied to the statue.
　　Camila bent down, kissed Roberto twice on each cheek (he felt his face burn and wouldn't have been surprised if steam was coming out of his ears again), then said to Diego, "And you too-you 'elped -"
　　"Yeah," said Diego, looking extremely hopeful, "yeah, a bit -"
　　Camila swooped down on him too and kissed him. Carolina looked simply furious, but just then, Ludo Bagman's magically magnified voice boomed out beside them, making them all jump, and causing the crowd in the stands to go very quiet.
　　"Ladies and gentlemen, we have reached our decision. Merchieftainess Murcus has told us exactly what happened at the bottom of the lake, and we have therefore decided to award marks out of fifty for each of the champions, as follows. . . .
　　"Camila Saenz, though she demonstrated excellent use of the Bubble-Head Charm, was attacked by grindylows as she approached her goal, and failed to retrieve her hostage.
　　We award her twenty-five points."
　　Applause from the stands.
　　"I deserved zero," said Camila throatily, shaking her magnificent head.
　　"Nicolas Ortega, who also used the Bubble-Head Charm, was first to return with his hostage, though he returned one minute outside the time limit of an hour." Enormous cheers from the Hufflepuffs in the crowd; Roberto saw Paula give Nicolas a glowing look. "We therefore award him forty-seven points."
　　Robertos heart sank. If Nicolas had been outside the time limit, he most certainly had been.
　　"Viktor Krum used an incomplete form of Transfiguration, which was nevertheless effective, and was second to return with his hostage. We award him forty points."
　　Morales clapped particularly hard, looking very superior.
　　"Roberto Gonzales used gillyweed to great effect," Bagman continued. "He returned last, and well outside the time limit of an hour. However, the Merchieftainess informs us that Mr.
　　Gonzales was first to reach the hostages, and that the delay in his return was due to his determination to return all hostages to safety, not merely his own."
　　Diego and Carolina both gave Roberto half-exasperated, half-commiserating looks.
　　"Most of the judges," and here, Bagman gave Morales a very nasty look, "feel that this shows moral fiber and merits full marks. However . . . Mr. Gonzales's score is forty-five points."
　　Roberto's stomach leapt - he was now tying for first place with Nicolas. Diego and Carolina, caught by surprise, stared at Roberto, then laughed and started applauding hard with the rest of the crowd.
　　"There you go. Roberto!" Diego shouted over the noise. "You weren't being thick after all -you were showing moral fiber!"
　　Camila was clapping very hard too, but Krum didn't look happy at all. He attempted to engage Carolina in conversation again, but she was too busy cheering Roberto to listen.
　　"The third and final task will take place at dusk on the twenty-fourth of June,"
　　continued Bagman. "The champions will be notified of what is coming precisely one month beforehand. Thank you all for your support of the champions."
　　It was over. Roberto thought dazedly, as Madam Pomfrey began herding the champions and hostages back to the castle to get into dry clothes ... it was over, he had got through ... he didn't have to worry about anything now until June the twenty-fourth. . ..
　　Next time he was in Hogsmeade, Roberto decided as he walked back up the stone steps into the castle, he was going to buy Dobby a pair of socks for every day of the year.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-SEVEN - PADFOOT RETURNS
　　One of the best things about the aftermath of the second task was that everybody was very keen to hear details of what had happened down in the lake, which meant that Diego was getting to share Roberto's limelight for once. Roberto noticed that Diego's version of events changed subtly with every retelling. At first, he gave what seemed to be the truth; it tallied with Carolina's story, anyway - Dominguez had put all the hostages into a bewitched sleep in Professor Romero's office, first assuring them that they would be quite safe, and would awake when they were back above the water. One week later, however, Diego was telling a thrilling tale of kidnap in which he struggled single-handedly against fifty heavily armed merpeople who had to beat him into submission before tying him up.
　　"But I had my wand hidden up my sleeve," he assured Padma Patil, who seemed to be a lot keener on Diego now that he was getting so much attention and was making a point of talking to him every time they passed in the corridors. "I could've taken those mer-idiots any time I wanted."
　　"What were you going to do, snore at them?" said Carolina waspishly. People had been teasing her so much about being the thing that Viktor Krum would most miss that she was in a rather tetchy mood.
　　Diego's ears went red, and thereafter, he reverted to the bewitched sleep version of events.
　　As they entered March the weather became drier, but cruel winds skinned their hands and faces every time they went out onto the grounds. There were delays in the post because the owls kept being blown off course. The brown owl that Roberto had sent to Gustavo with the dates of the Hogsmeade weekend turned up at breakfast on Friday morning with half its feathers sticking up the wrong way; Roberto had no sooner torn off Gustavo's reply than it took flight, clearly afraid it was going to be sent outside again.
　　Gustavo's letter was almost as short as the previous one.
　　Be at stile at end of road out of Hogsmeade (past Dervish and Banges) at two o'clock on Saturday afternoon. Bring as much food as you can.
　　"He hasn't come back to Hogsmeade?" said Diego incredulously.
　　"It looks like it, doesn't it?" said Carolina.
　　"I can't believe him," said Roberto tensely, "if he's caught. . ."
　　"Made it so far, though, hasn't he?" said Diego. "And it's not like the place is swarming with dementors anymore."
　　Roberto folded up the letter, thinking. If he was honest with himself, he really wanted to see Gustavo again. He therefore approached the final lesson of the afternoon - double Potions - feeling considerably more cheerful than he usually did when descending the steps to the dungeons.
　　Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle were standing in a huddle outside the classroom door with Pansy Parkinson's gang of Slytherin girls. All of them were looking at something Roberto couldn't see and sniggering heartily. Pansys pug-like face peered excitedly around Goyle's broad back as Roberto, Diego, and Carolina approached.
　　"There they are, there they are!" she giggled, and the knot of Slytherins broke apart.
　　Roberto saw that Pansy had a magazine in her hands - Witch Weekly. The moving picture on the front showed a curly-haired witch who was smiling toothily and pointing at a large sponge cake with her wand.
　　"You might find something to interest you in there, Fernandez!" Pansy said loudly, and she threw the magazine at Carolina, who caught it, looking startled. At that moment, the dungeon door opened, and Peralta beckoned them all inside.
　　Carolina, Roberto, and Diego headed for a table at the back of the dungeon as usual. Once Peralta had turned his back on them to write up the ingredients of todays potion on the blackboard, Carolina hastily rifled through the magazine under the desk. At last, in the center pages, Carolina found what they were looking for. Roberto and Diego leaned in closer.
　　A color photograph of Roberto headed a short piece entitled:
　　Roberto Gonzales's Secret Heartache A boy like no other, perhaps - yet a boy suffering all the usual pangs of adolescence, writes Rita Skeeter. Deprived of love since the tragic demise of his parents, fourteen-year-old Roberto Gonzales thought he had found solace in his steady girlfriend at Hogwarts, Muggle-born Carolina Fernandez. Little did he know that he would shortly be suffering yet another emotional blow in a life already littered with personal loss.
　　Miss Fernandez, a plain but ambitious girl, seems to have a taste for famous wizards that Roberto alone cannot satisfy. Since the arrival at Hogwarts of Viktor Krum, Bulgarian Seeker and hero of the last World Quidditch Cup, Miss Fernandez has been toying with both boys' affections. Krum, who is openly smitten with the devious Miss Fernandez, has already invited her to visit him in Bulgaria over the summer holidays, and insists that he has "never felt this way about any other girl."
　　However, it might not be Miss Fernandez's doubtful natural charms that have captured these unfortunate boys' interest.
　　"She's really ugly," says Pansy Parkinson, a pretty and vivacious fourth-year student, "but she'd be well up to making a Love Potion, she's quite brainy. I think that's how she's doing it."
　　Love Potions are, of course, banned at Hogwarts, and no doubt Alfonso Dominguez will want to investigate these claims. In the meantime, Roberto Gonzaless well-wishers must hope that, next time, he bestows his heart on a worthier candidate.
　　"I told you!" Diego hissed at Carolina as she stared down at the article. "I told you not to annoy Rita Skeeter! She's made you out to be some sort of- of scarlet woman!"
　　Carolina stopped looking astonished and snorted with laughter. "Scarlet woman?" she repeated, shaking with suppressed giggles as she looked around at Diego.
　　"It's what my mum calls them," Diego muttered, his ears going red.
　　"If that's the best Rita can do, she's losing her touch," said Carolina, still giggling, as she threw Witch Weekly onto the empty chair beside her. "What a pile of old rubbish."
　　She looked over at the Slytherins, who were all watching her and Roberto closely across the room to see if they had been upset by the article. Carolina gave them a sarcastic smile and a wave, and she, Roberto, and Diego started unpacking the ingredients they would need for their Wit-Sharpening Potion.
　　"There's something funny, though," said Carolina ten minutes later, holding her pestle suspended over a bowl of scarab beetles. "How could Rita Skeeter have known . . . ?"
　　"Known what?" said Diego quickly. "You haven't been mixing up Love Potions, have you?"
　　"Don't be stupid," Carolina snapped, starting to pound up her beetles again. "No, it's just. . . how did she know Viktor asked me to visit him over the summer?"
　　Carolina blushed scarlet as she said this and determinedly avoided Diego's eyes.
　　"What?" said Diego, dropping his pestle with a loud clunk.
　　"He asked me right after he'd pulled me out of the lake,"
　　Carolina muttered. "After he'd got rid of his shark's head. Madam Pomfrey gave us both blankets and then he sort of pulled me away from the judges so they wouldn't hear, and he said, if I wasn't doing anything over the summer, would I like to -"
　　"And what did you say?" said Diego, who had picked up his pestle and was grinding it on the desk, a good six inches from his bowl, because he was looking at Carolina.
　　"And he did say he'd never felt the same way about anyone else," Carolina went on, going so red now that Roberto could almost feel the heat coming from her, "but how could Rita Skeeter have heard him? She wasn't there ... or was she? Maybe she has got an Invisibility Cloak; maybe she sneaked onto the grounds to watch the second task. ..."
　　"And what did you say?" Diego repeated, pounding his pestle down so hard that it dented the desk.
　　"Well, I was too busy seeing whether you and Roberto were okay to-"
　　"Fascinating though your social life undoubtedly is. Miss Fernandez," said an icy voice right behind them, and all three of them jumped, "I must ask you not to discuss it in my class. Ten points from Gryffindor."
　　Peralta had glided over to their desk while they were talking. The whole class was now looking around at them; Sosa took the opportunity to flash GONZALES STINKS across the dungeon at Roberto.
　　"Ah . . . reading magazines under the table as well?" Peralta added, snatching up the copy of Witch Weekly. "A further ten points from Gryffindor ... oh but of course ..." Peraltas black eyes glittered as they fell on Rita Skeeter's article. "Gonzales has to keep up with his press cuttings. . . ."
　　The dungeon rang with the Slytherins' laughter, and an unpleasant smile curled Peralta's thin mouth. To Roberto's fury, he began to read the article aloud.
　　"'Roberto Gonzales's Secret Heartache. . . dear, dear. Gonzales, what's ailing you now? 'A boy like no other, perhaps. . .'"
　　Roberto could feel his face burning. Peralta was pausing at the end of every sentence to allow the Slytherins a hearty laugh. The article sounded ten times worse when read by Peralta. Even Carolina was blushing scarlet now.
　　"'. . . Roberto Gonzales's well-wishers must hope that, next time, he bestows his heart upon a worthier candidate.' How very touching," sneered Peralta, rolling up the magazine to continued gales of laughter from the Slytherins. "Well, I think I had better separate the three of you, so you can keep your minds on your potions rather than on your tangled love lives. Lopez, you stay here. Miss Fernandez, over there, beside Miss Parkinson.
　　Gonzales - that table in front of my desk. Move. Now."
　　Furious, Roberto threw his ingredients and his bag into his cauldron and dragged it up to the front of the dungeon to the empty table. Peralta followed, sat down at his desk and watched Roberto unload his cauldron. Determined not to look at Peralta, Roberto resumed the mashing of his scarab beetles, imagining each one to have Peralta's face.
　　"All this press attention seems to have inflated your already over-large head. Gonzales,"
　　said Peralta quietly, once the rest of the class had settled down again.
　　Roberto didn't answer. He knew Peralta was trying to provoke him; he had done this before.
　　No doubt he was hoping for an excuse to take a round fifty points from Gryffindor before the end of the class.
　　"You might be laboring under the delusion that the entire wizarding world is impressed with you," Peralta went on, so quietly that no one else could hear him (Roberto continued to pound his scarab beetles, even though he had already reduced them to a very fine powder), "but I don't care how many times your picture appears in the papers. To me. Gonzales, you are nothing but a nasty little boy who considers rules to be beneath him."
　　Roberto tipped the powdered beetles into his cauldron and started cutting up his ginger roots. His hands were shaking slightly out of anger, but he kept his eyes down, as though he couldn't hear what Peralta was saying to him.
　　"So I give you fair warning, Gonzales," Peralta continued in a sorter and more dangerous
　　voice, "pint-sized celebrity or not - if I catch you breaking into my office one more time -"
　　"I haven't been anywhere near your office!" said Roberto angrily, forgetting his feigned deafness.
　　"Don't lie to me," Peralta hissed, his fathomless black eyes boring into Robertos. "Boomslang skin. Gillyweed. Both come from my private stores, and I know who stole them."
　　Roberto stared back at Peralta, determined not to blink or to look guilty. In truth, he hadn't stolen either of these things from Peralta. Carolina had taken the boomslang skin back in their second year - they had needed it for the Polyjuice Potion - and while Peralta had suspected Roberto at the time, he had never been able to prove it. Dobby, of course, had stolen the gillyweed.
　　"I don't know what you're talking about," Roberto lied coldly.
　　"You were out of bed on the night my office was broken into!" Peralta hissed. "I know it.
　　Gonzales! Now, Mad-Eye Acosta might have joined your fan club, but I will not tolerate your behavior! One more nighttime stroll into my office, Gonzales, and you will pay!"
　　"Right," said Roberto coolly, turning back to his ginger roots. "I'll bear that in mind if I ever get the urge to go in there."
　　Peralta's eyes flashed. He plunged a hand into the inside of his black robes. For one wild moment. Roberto thought Peralta was about to pull out his wand and curse him - then he saw that Peralta had drawn out a small crystal bottle of a completely clear potion. Roberto stared at it.
　　"Do you know what this is. Gonzales?" Peralta said, his eyes glittering dangerously again.
　　"No," said Roberto, with complete honesty this time.
　　"It is Veritaserum - a Truth Potion so powerful that three drops would have you spilling your innermost secrets for this entire class to hear," said Peralta viciously. "Now, the use of this potion is controlled by very strict Ministry guidelines. But unless you watch your step, you might just find that my hand slips" - he shook the crystal bottle slightly - "right over your evening pumpkin juice. And then. Gonzales . . . then we'll find out whether you've been in my office or not."
　　Roberto said nothing. He turned back to his ginger roots once more, picked up his knife, and started slicing them again. He didn't like the sound of that Truth Potion at all, nor would he put it past Peralta to slip him some. He repressed a shudder at the thought of what might come spilling out of his mouth if Peralta did it... quite apart from landing a whole lot of people in trouble - Carolina and Dobby for a start - there were all the other things he was concealing . . . like the fact that he was in contact with Gustavo . .
　　. and - his insides squirmed at the thought - how he felt about Paula. ... He tipped his ginger roots into the cauldron too, and wondered whether he ought to take a leaf out of Acosta s book and start drinking only from a private hip flask.
　　There was a knock on the dungeon door.
　　"Enter," said Peralta in his usual voice.
　　The class looked around as the door opened. Professor Morales came in. Everyone watched him as he walked up toward Peralta's desk. He was twisting his finger around his goatee and looking agitated.
　　"We need to talk," said Morales abruptly when he had reached Peralta. He seemed so determined that nobody should hear what he was saying that he was barely opening his lips; it was as though he were a rather poor ventriloquist. Roberto kept his eyes on his ginger roots, listening hard.
　　"I'll talk to you after my lesson, Morales," Peralta muttered, but Morales interrupted him.
　　"I want to talk now, while you can't slip off, Carlos. You've been avoiding me."
　　"After the lesson," Peralta snapped.
　　Under the pretext of holding up a measuring cup to see if he'd poured out enough armadillo bile, Roberto sneaked a sidelong glance at the pair of them. Morales looked extremely worried, and Peralta looked angry.
　　Morales hovered behind Peralta's desk for the rest of the double period. He seemed intent on preventing Peralta from slipping away at the end of class. Keen to hear what Morales wanted to say, Roberto deliberately knocked over his bottle of armadillo bile with two minutes to go to the bell, which gave him an excuse to duck down behind his cauldron and mop up while the rest of the class moved noisily toward the door.
　　"What's so urgent?" he heard Peralta hiss at Morales.
　　"This," said Morales, and Roberto, peering around the edge of his cauldron, saw Morales
　　pull up the left-hand sleeve of his robe and show Peralta something on his inner forearm.
　　"Well?" said Morales, still making every effort not to move his lips. "Do you see?
　　It's never been this clear, never since - "
　　"Put it away!" snarled Peralta, his black eyes sweeping the classroom.
　　"But you must have noticed -" Morales began in an agitated voice.
　　"We can talk later, Morales!" spat Peralta. "Gonzales! What are you doing?"
　　"Clearing up my armadillo bile, Professor," said Roberto innocently, straightening up and showing Peralta the sodden rag he was holding.
　　Morales turned on his heel and strode out of the dungeon. He looked both worried and angry. Not wanting to remain alone with an exceptionally angry Peralta, Roberto threw his books and ingredients back into his bag and left at top speed to tell Diego and Carolina what he had just witnessed.
　　They left the castle at noon the next day to find a weak silver sun shining down upon the grounds. The weather was milder than it had been all year, and by the time they arrived in Hogsmeade, all three of them had taken off their cloaks and thrown them over their shoulders. The food Gustavo had told them to bring was in Roberto's bag; they had sneaked a dozen chicken legs, a loaf of bread, and a flask of pumpkin juice from the lunch table.
　　They went into Gladrags Wizardwear to buy a present for Dobby, where they had fun selecting the most lurid socks they could find, including a pair patterned with flashing gold and silver stars, and another that screamed loudly when they became too smelly.
　　Then, at half past one, they made their way up the High Street, past Dervish and Banges, and out toward the edge of the village.
　　Roberto had never been in this direction before. The winding lane was leading them out into the wild countryside around Hogsmeade. The cottages were fewer here, and their gardens larger; they were walking toward the foot of the mountain in whose shadow Hogsmeade lay. Then they turned a corner and saw a stile at the end of the lane. Waiting for them, its front paws on the topmost bar, was a very large, shaggy black dog, which was carrying some newspapers in its mouth and looking very familiar. . . .
　　"Hello, Gustavo," said Roberto when they had reached him.
　　The black dog sniffed Roberto's bag eagerly, wagged its tail once, then turned and began to trot away from them across the scrubby patch of ground that rose to meet the rocky foot of the mountain. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina climbed over the stile and followed.
　　Gustavo led them to the very foot of the mountain, where the ground was covered with boulders and rocks. It was easy for him, with his four paws, but Roberto, Diego, and Carolina were soon out of breath. They followed Gustavo higher, up onto the mountain itself. For nearly half an hour they climbed a steep, winding, and stony path, following Gustavo's wagging tail, sweating in the sun, the shoulder straps of Roberto's bag cutting into his shoulders.
　　Then, at last, Gustavo slipped out of sight, and when they reached the place where he had vanished, they saw a narrow fissure in the rock. They squeezed into it and found themselves in a cool, dimly lit cave. Tethered at the end of it, one end of his rope around a large rock, was Buckbeak the hippogriff. Half gray horse, half giant eagle, Buckbeak's fierce orange eye flashed at the sight of them. All three of them bowed low to him, and after regarding them imperiously for a moment, Buckbeak bent his scaly front knees and allowed Carolina to rush forward and stroke his feathery neck. Roberto, however, was looking at the black dog, which had just turned into his godfather.
　　Gustavo was wearing ragged gray robes; the same ones he had been wearing when he had left Azkaban. His black hair was longer than it had been when he had appeared in the fire, and it was untidy and matted once more. He looked very thin.
　　"Chicken!" he said hoarsely after removing the old Daily Prophets from his mouth and throwing them down onto the cave floor.
　　Roberto pulled open his bag and handed over the bundle of chicken legs and bread.
　　"Thanks," said Gustavo, opening it, grabbing a drumstick, sitting down on the cave floor, and tearing off a large chunk with his teeth. "I've been living off rats mostly. Can't steal too much food from Hogsmeade; I'd draw attention to myself."
　　He grinned up at Roberto, but Roberto returned the grin only reluctantly.
　　"What're you doing here, Gustavo?" he said.
　　"Fulfilling my duty as godfather," said Gustavo, gnawing on the chicken bone in a very doglike way. "Don't worry about it, I'm pretending to be a lovable stray."
　　He was still grinning, but seeing the anxiety in Robertos face, said more seriously, "I
　　want to be on the spot. Your last letter . . . well, let's just say things are getting fishier. I've been stealing the paper every time someone throws one out, and by the looks of things, I'm not the only one who's getting worried."
　　He nodded at the yellowing Daily Prophets on the cave floor, and Diego picked them up and unfolded them. Roberto, however, continued to stare at Gustavo.
　　"What if they catch you? What if you're seen?"
　　"You three and Dominguez are the only ones around here who know I'm an Animagus," said Gustavo, shrugging, and continuing to devour the chicken leg.
　　Diego nudged Roberto and passed him the Daily Prophets. There were two: The first bore the headline Mystery Illness ofBartemius Crouch, the second, Ministry Witch Still Missing-Minister of Magic Now Personally Involved.
　　Roberto scanned the story about Crouch. Phrases jumped out at him: hasn't been seen in public since November. . . house appears deserted. . . St. Mungo's Hospital for Magical Maladies and Injuries decline comment. . . Ministry refuses to confirm rumors of critical illness. . . .
　　"They're making it sound like he's dying," said Roberto slowly. "But he can't be that ill if he managed to get up here. . . ."
　　"My brothers Crouch's personal assistant," Diego informed Gustavo. "He says Crouch is suffering from overwork."
　　"Mind you, he did look ill, last time I saw him up close," said Roberto slowly, still reading the story. "The night my name came out of the goblet. ..."
