　　"Getting his comeuppance for sacking Winky, isn't he?" said Carolina, an edge to her voice. She was stroking Buckbeak, who was crunching up Gustavo's chicken bones. "I bet he wishes he hadn't done it now - bet he feels the difference now she's not there to look after him."
　　"Carolina's obsessed with house-elfs," Diego muttered to Gustavo, casting Carolina a dark look. Gustavo, however, looked interested.
　　"Crouch sacked his house-elf?"
　　"Yeah, at the Quidditch World Cup," said Roberto, and he launched into the story of the Dark Mark's appearance, and Winky being found with Robertos wand clutched in her hand, and Mr. Crouch's fury. When Roberto had finished, Gustavo was on his feet again and had started pacing up and down the cave.
　　"Let me get this straight," he said after a while, brandishing a fresh chicken leg. "You first saw the elfin the Top Box. She was saving Crouch a seat, right?"
　　"Right," said Roberto, Diego, and Carolina together.
　　"But Crouch didn't turn up for the match?"
　　"No," said Roberto. "I think he said he'd been too busy."
　　Gustavo paced all around the cave in silence. Then he said, "Roberto, did you check your pockets for your wand after you'd left the Top Box?"
　　"Erm . . ." Roberto thought hard. "No," he said finally. "I didn't need to use it before we got in the forest. And then I put my hand in my pocket, and all that was in there were my Omnioculars." He stared at Gustavo. "Are you saying whoever conjured the Mark stole my wand in the Top Box?"
　　"It's possible," said Gustavo.
　　"Winky didn't steal that wand!" Carolina insisted.
　　"The elf wasn't the only one in that box," said Gustavo, his brow furrowed as he continued to pace. "Who else was sitting behind you?"
　　"Loads of people," said Roberto. "Some Bulgarian ministers .. . Cornelius Fudge ... the Sosas ..."
　　"The Sosas!" said Diego suddenly, so loudly that his voice echoed all around the cave, and Buckbeak tossed his head nervously. "I bet it was Mariano Sosa!"
　　"Anyone else?" said Gustavo.
　　"No one," said Roberto.
　　"Yes, there was, there was Ludo Bagman," Carolina reminded him.
　　"Oh yeah . . ."
　　"I don't know anything about Bagman except that he used to be Beater for the Wimbourne Wasps," said Gustavo, still pacing. "What's he like?"
　　"He's okay," said Roberto. "He keeps offering to help me with the Triwizard Tournament."
　　"Does he, now?" said Gustavo, frowning more deeply. "I wonder why he'd do that?"
　　"Says he's taken a liking to me," said Roberto.
　　"Hmm," said Gustavo, looking thoughtful.
　　"We saw him in the forest just before the Dark Mark appeared," Carolina told Gustavo.
　　"Remember?" she said to Roberto and Diego.
　　"Yeah, but he didn't stay in the forest, did he?" said Diego. "The moment we told him about the riot, he went off to the campsite."
　　"How d'you know?" Carolina shot back. "How d'you know where he Disapparated to?"
　　"Come off it," said Diego incredulously. "Are you saying you reckon Ludo Bagman conjured the Dark Mark?"
　　"It's more likely he did it than Winky," said Carolina stubbornly.
　　"Told you," said Diego, looking meaningfully at Gustavo, "told you she's obsessed with house -"
　　But Gustavo held up a hand to silence Diego.
　　"When the Dark Mark had been conjured, and the elf had been discovered holding Roberto's wand, what did Crouch do?"
　　"Went to look in the bushes," said Roberto, "but there wasn't anyone else there."
　　"Of course," Gustavo muttered, pacing up and down, "of course, he'd want to pin it on anyone but his own elf... and then he sacked her?"
　　"Yes," said Carolina in a heated voice, "he sacked her, just because she hadn't stayed in her tent and let herself get trampled -"
　　"Carolina, will you give it a rest with the elf!" said Diego.
　　Gustavo shook his head and said, "She's got the measure of Crouch better than you have, Diego. If you want to know what a mans like, take a good look at how he treats his inferiors, not his equals."
　　He ran a hand over his unshaven face, evidently thinking hard.
　　"All these absences of Barty Crouch's ... he goes to the trouble of making sure his house-elf saves him a seat at the Quidditch World Cup, but doesn't bother to turn up and watch. He works very hard to reinstate the Triwizard Tournament, and then stops coming to that too. . . . It's not like Crouch. If he's ever taken a day off work because of illness before this, I'll eat Buckbeak."
　　"D'you know Crouch, then?" said Roberto.
　　Gustavo's face darkened. He suddenly looked as menacing as he had the night when Roberto first met him, the night when Roberto still believed Gustavo to be a murderer.
　　"Oh I know Crouch all right," he said quietly. "He was the one who gave the order for me to be sent to Azkaban - without a trial."
　　"What?" said Diego and Carolina together.
　　"You're kidding!" said Roberto.
　　"No, I'm not," said Gustavo, taking another great bite of chicken. "Crouch used to be Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement, didn't you know?"
　　Roberto, Diego, and Carolina shook their heads.
　　"He was tipped for the next Minister of Magic," said Gustavo. "He's a great wizard, Barty Crouch, powerfully magical - and power-hungry. Oh never a Salvador supporter," he said, reading the look on Robertos face. "No, Barty Crouch was always very outspoken against the Dark Side. But then a lot of people who were against the Dark Side . . . well, you wouldn't understand . . . you're too young. ..."
　　"That's what my dad said at the World Cup," said Diego, with a trace of irritation in his voice. "Try us, why don't you?"
　　A grin flashed across Gustavo's thin face.
　　"All right, I'll try you. . . ." He walked once up the cave, back again, and then said, "Imagine that Salvador's powerful now. You don't know who his supporters are, you don't know who's working for him and who isn't; you know he can control people so that they do terrible things without being able to stop themselves. You're scared for yourself, and your family, and your friends. Every week, news comes of more deaths, more disappearances, more torturing . . . the Ministry of Magic's in disarray, they don't know what to do, they're trying to keep everything hidden from the Muggles, but meanwhile, Muggles are dying too. Terror everywhere . . . panic . . . confusion . . . that's how it used to be.
　　"Well, times like that bring out the best in some people and the worst in others.
　　Crouch's principles might've been good in the beginning - I wouldn't know. He rose quickly through the Ministry, and he started ordering very harsh measures against Salvadors supporters. The Aurors were given new powers - powers to kill rather than capture, for instance. And I wasn't the only one who was handed straight to the dementors without trial. Crouch fought violence with violence, and authorized the use of
　　the Unforgivable Curses against suspects. I would say he became as ruthless and cruel as many on the Dark Side. He had his supporters, mind you - plenty of people thought he was going about things the right way, and there were a lot of witches and wizards clamoring for him to take over as Minister of Magic. When Salvador disappeared, it looked like only a matter of time until Crouch got the top job. But then something rather unfortunate happened. ..." Gustavo smiled grimly. "Crouch's own son was caught with a group of Death Eaters who'd managed to talk their way out of Azkaban. Apparently they were trying to find Salvador and return him to power."
　　"Crouch's son was caught?" gasped Carolina.
　　"Yep," said Gustavo, throwing his chicken bone to Buckbeak, flinging himself back down on the ground beside the loaf of bread, and tearing it in half. "Nasty little shock for old Barty, I'd imagine. Should have spent a bit more time at home with his family, shouldn't he? Ought to have left the office early once in a while . . . gotten to know his own son."
　　He began to wolf down large pieces of bread.
　　"Was his son a Death Eater?" said Roberto.
　　"No idea," said Gustavo, still stuffing down bread. "I was in Azkaban myself when he was brought in. This is mostly stuff I've found out since I got out. The boy was definitely caught in the company of people I'd bet my life were Death Eaters - but he might have been in the wrong place at the wrong time, just like the house-elf."
　　"Did Crouch try and get his son off?" Carolina whispered.
　　Gustavo let out a laugh that was much more like a bark.
　　"Crouch let his son off? I thought you had the measure of him, Carolina! Anything that threatened to tarnish his reputation had to go; he had dedicated his whole life to becoming Minister of Magic. You saw him dismiss a devoted house-elf because she associated him with the Dark Mark again - doesn't that tell you what he's like? Crouch's fatherly affection stretched just far enough to give his son a trial, and by all accounts, it wasn't much more than an excuse for Crouch to show how much he hated the boy . . . then he sent him straight to Azkaban."
　　"He gave his own son to the dementors?" asked Roberto quietly.
　　"That's right," said Gustavo, and he didn't look remotely amused now. "I saw the dementors bringing him in, watched them through the bars in my cell door. He can't have been more than nineteen. They took him into a cell near mine. He was screaming for his mother by nightfall. He went quiet after a few days, though . . .they all went quiet in the end. . . except when they shrieked in their sleep. ..."
　　For a moment, the deadened look in Gustavo's eyes became more pronounced than ever, as though shutters had closed behind them.
　　"So he's still in Azkaban?" Roberto said.
　　"No," said Gustavo dully. "No, he's not in there anymore. He died about a year after they brought him in."
　　"He died?"
　　"He wasn't the only one," said Gustavo bitterly. "Most go mad in there, and plenty stop eating in the end. They lose the will to live. You could always tell when a death was coming, because the dementors could sense it, they got excited. That boy looked pretty sickly when he arrived. Crouch being an important Ministry member, he and his wife were allowed a deathbed visit. That was the last time I saw Barty Crouch, half carrying his wife past my cell. She died herself, apparently, shortly afterward. Grief. Wasted away just like the boy. Crouch never came for his sons body. The dementors buried him outside the fortress; I watched them do it."
　　Gustavo threw aside the bread he had just lifted to his mouth and instead picked up the flask of pumpkin juice and drained it.
　　"So old Crouch lost it all, just when he thought he had it made," he continued, wiping his mouth with the back of his hand. "One moment, a hero, poised to become Minister of Magic...next, his son dead, his wife dead, the family name dishonored, and, so I've heard since I escaped, a big drop in popularity. Once the boy had died, people started feeling a bit more sympathetic toward the son and started asking how a nice young lad from a good family had gone so badly astray. The conclusion was that his father never cared much for him. So Cornelius Fudge got the top job, and Crouch was shunted sideways into the Department of International Magical Cooperation."
　　There was a long silence. Roberto was thinking of the way Crouch's eyes had bulged as he'd looked down at his disobedient house-elf back in the wood at the Quidditch World Cup.
　　This, then, must have been why Crouch had overreacted to Winky being found beneath the Dark Mark. It had brought back memories of his son, and the old scandal, and his fall from grace at the Ministry.
　　"Acosta says Crouch is obsessed with catching Dark wizards," Roberto told Gustavo.
　　"Yeah, I've heard it's become a bit of a mania with him," said Gustavo, nodding. "If you ask me, he still thinks he can bring back the old popularity by catching one more Death Eater."
　　"And he sneaked up here to search Peralta's office!" s aid Diego triumphantly, looking at Carolina.
　　"Yes, and that doesn't make sense at all," said Gustavo.
　　"Yeah, it does!" said Diego excitedly, but Gustavo shook his head.
　　"Listen, if Crouch wants to investigate Peralta, why hasn't he been coming to judge the tournament? It would be an ideal excuse to make regular visits to Hogwarts and keep an eye on him."
　　"So you think Peralta could be up to something, then?" asked Roberto, but Carolina broke in.
　　"Look, I don't care what you say, Dominguez trusts Peralta -"
　　"Oh give it a rest, Carolina," said Diego impatiently. "I know Dominguezs brilliant and everything, but that doesn't mean a really clever Dark wizard couldn't fool him -"
　　"Why did Peralta save Roberto's life in the first year, then? Why didn't he just let him die?"
　　"I dunno - maybe he thought Dominguez would kick him out-"
　　"What d'you think, Gustavo?" Roberto said loudly, and Diego and Carolina stopped bickering to listen.
　　"I think they've both got a point," said Gustavo, looking thoughtfully at Diego and Carolina. "Ever since I found out Peralta was teaching here, I've wondered why Dominguez hired him. Peralta's always been fascinated by the Dark Arts, he was famous for it at school. Slimy, oily, greasy-haired kid, he was," Gustavo added, and Roberto and Diego grinned at each other. "Peralta knew more curses when he arrived at school than half the kids in seventh year, and he was part of a gang of Slytherins who nearly all turned out to be Death Eaters."
　　Gustavo held up his fingers and began ticking off names.
　　"Rosier and Wilkes - they were both killed by Aurors the year before Salvador fell. The Gimenezs - they're a married couple - they're in Azkaban. Avery - from what I've heard he wormed his way out of trouble by saying he'd been acting under the Imperius Curse -he's still at large. But as far as I know, Peralta was never even accused of being a Death Eater - not that that means much. Plenty of them were never caught. And Peralta s certainly clever and cunning enough to keep himself out of trouble."
　　"Peralta knows Morales pretty well, but he wants to keep that quiet," said Diego.
　　"Yeah, you should've seen Peralta's face when Morales turned up in Potions yesterday!"
　　said Roberto quickly. "Morales wanted to talk to Peralta, he says Peralta's been avoiding him. Morales looked really worried. He showed Peralta something on his arm, but I couldn't see what it was."
　　He showed Peralta something on his arm?" said Gustavo, looking frankly bewildered. He ran his fingers distractedly through his filthy hair, then shrugged again. "Well, I've no idea what that's about. . . but if Morales s genuinely worried, and he's going to Peralta for answers ..."
　　Gustavo stared at the cave wall, then made a grimace of frustration.
　　"There's still the fact that Dominguez trusts Peralta, and I know Dominguez trusts where a lot of other people wouldn't, but I just can't see him letting Peralta teach at Hogwarts if he'd ever worked for Salvador."
　　"Why are Acosta and Crouch so keen to get into Peraltas office then?" said Diego stubbornly.
　　"Well," said Gustavo slowly, "I wouldn't put it past Mad-Eye to have searched every single teacher's office when he got to Hogwarts. He takes his Defense Against the Dark Arts seriously, Acosta. I'm not sure he trusts anyone at all, and after the things he's seen, it's not surprising. I'll say this for Acosta, though, he never killed if he could help it. Always brought people in alive where possible. He was tough, but he never descended to the level of the Death Eaters. Crouch, though . . . he's a different matter ... is he really ill? If he is, why did he make the effort to drag himself up to Peralta's office?
　　And if he's not. . . what's he up to? What was he doing at the World Cup that was so important he didn't turn up in the Top Box? What's he been doing while he should have been judging the tournament?"
　　Gustavo lapsed into silence, still staring at the cave wall. Buckbeak was ferreting around on the rocky floor, looking for bones he might have overlooked. Finally, Gustavo looked up at Diego.
　　"You say your brother s Crouch's personal assistant? Any chance you could ask him if he's seen Crouch lately?"
　　"I can try," said Diego doubtfully. "Better not make it sound like I reckon Crouch is up to anything dodgy, though. Miguel loves Crouch."
　　"And you might try and find out whether they've got any leads on Bertha Jorkins while you're at it," said Gustavo, gesturing to the second copy of the Daily Prophet.
　　"Bagman told me they hadn't," said Roberto.
　　"Yes, he's quoted in the article in there," said Gustavo, nodding at the paper.
　　"Blustering on about how bad Bertha's memory is. Well, maybe she's changed since I knew her, but the Bertha I knew wasn't forgetful at all - quite the reverse. She was a bit dim, but she had an excellent memory for gossip. It used to get her into a lot of trouble; she never knew when to keep her mouth shut. I can see her being a bit of a liability at the Ministry of Magic . . . maybe that's why Bagman didn't bother to look for her for so long. ..."
　　Gustavo heaved an enormous sigh and rubbed his shadowed eyes.
　　"What's the time?"
　　Roberto checked his watch, then remembered it hadn't been working since it had spent over an hour in the lake.
　　"It's half past three," said Carolina.
　　"You'd better get back to school," Gustavo said, getting to his feet. "Now listen . . ."
　　He looked particularly hard at Roberto. "I don't want you lot sneaking out of school to see me, all right? Just send notes to me here. I still want to hear about anything odd.
　　But you're not to go leaving Hogwarts without permission; it would be an ideal opportunity for someone to attack you."
　　"No one's tried to attack me so far, except a dragon and a couple of grindylows," Roberto said, but Gustavo scowled at him.
　　"I don't care . . . I'll breathe freely again when this tournament's over, and that's not until June. And don't forget, if you're talking about me among yourselves, call me Snuffles, okay?"
　　He handed Roberto the empty napkin and flask and went to pat Buckbeak good-bye. "I'll walk to the edge of the village with you," said Gustavo, "see if I can scrounge another paper."
　　He transformed into the great black dog before they left the cave, and they walked back down the mountainside with him, across the boulder-strewn ground, and back to the stile.
　　Here he allowed each of them to pat him on the head, before turning and setting off at a run around the outskirts of the village. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina made their way back into Hogsmeade and up toward Hogwarts.
　　"Wonder if Miguel knows all that stuff about Crouch?" Diego said as they walked up the drive to the castle. "But maybe he doesn't care . . . It'd probably just make him admire Crouch even more. Yeah, Miguel loves rules. He'd just say Crouch was refusing to break them for his own son."
　　"Miguel would never throw any of his family to the dementors," said Carolina severely.
　　"I don't know," said Diego. "If he thought we were standing in the way of his career .. .
　　Miguel's really ambitious, you know. ..."
　　They walked up the stone steps into the entrance hall, where the delicious smells of dinner wafted toward them from the Great Hall.
　　"Poor old Snuffles," said Diego, breathing deeply. "He must really like you. Roberto. . . .
　　Imagine having to live off rats."
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-EIGHT - THE MADNESS OF MR CROUCH
　　Roberto, Diego, and Carolina went up to the Owlery after breakfast on Sunday to send a letter to Miguel, asking, as Gustavo had suggested, whether he had seen Mr. Crouch lately. They used Hedwig, because it had been so long since she'd had a job. When they had watched her fly out of sight through the Owlery window, they proceeded down to the kitchen to give Dobby his new socks.
　　The house-elves gave them a very cheery welcome, bowing and curtsying and bustling around making tea again. Dobby was ecstatic about his present.
　　"Roberto Gonzales is too good to Dobby!" he squeaked, wiping large tears out of his enormous eyes.
　　"You saved my life with that gillyweed, Dobby, you really did," said Roberto.
　　"No chance of more of those eclairs, is there?" said Diego, who was looking around at the beaming and bowing house-elves.
　　"You've just had breakfast!" said Carolina irritably, but a great silver platter of eclairs was already zooming toward them, supported by four elves.
　　"We should get some stuff to send up to Snuffles," Roberto muttered.
　　"Good idea," said Diego. "Give Pig something to do. You couldn't give us a bit of extra food, could you?" he said to the surrounding elves, and they bowed delightedly and hurried off to get some more.
　　"Dobby, where's Winky?" said Carolina, who was looking around.
　　"Winky is over there by the fire, miss," said Dobby quietly, his ears drooping slightly.
　　"Oh dear," said Carolina as she spotted Winky.
　　Roberto looked over at the fireplace too. Winky was sitting on the same stool as last time, but she had allowed herself to become so filthy that she was not immediately distinguishable from the smoke-blackened brick behind her. Her clothes were ragged and unwashed. She was clutching a bottle of butterbeer and swaying slightly on her stool, staring into the fire. As they watched her, she gave an enormous hiccup.
　　"Winky is getting through six bottles a day now," Dobby whispered to Roberto.
　　"Well, it's not strong, that stuff," Roberto said.
　　But Dobby shook his head. "'Tis strong for a house-elf, sir," he said.
　　Winky hiccuped again. The elves who had brought the eclairs gave her disapproving looks as they returned to work.
　　"Winky is pining, Roberto Gonzales," Dobby whispered sadly. "Winky wants to go home. Winky still thinks Mr. Crouch is her master, sir, and nothing Dobby says will persuade her that Professor Dominguez is her master now."
　　"Hey, Winky," said Roberto, struck by a sudden inspiration, walking over to her, and bending down, "you don't know what Mr. Crouch might be up to, do you? Because he's stopped turning up to judge the Triwizard Tournament."
　　Winky's eyes flickered. Her enormous pupils focused on Roberto. She swayed slightly again and then said, "M - Master is stopped - hic - coming?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, "we haven't seen him since the first task. The Daily Prophet's saying he's ill."
　　Winky swayed some more, staring blurrily at Roberto.
　　"Master- hic- ill?"
　　Her bottom lip began to tremble.
　　"But we're not sure if that's true," said Carolina quickly.
　　"Master is needing his - hie - Winky!" whimpered the elf. "Master cannot - hic - manage - hic - all by himself. . . ."
　　"Other people manage to do their own housework, you know, Winky," Carolina said severely.
　　"Winky - hic - is not only - hic - doing housework for Mr. Crouch!" Winky squeaked indignantly, swaying worse than ever and slopping butterbeer down her already heavily stained blouse. "Master is - hic - trusting Winky with - hic - the most important - hic - the most secret..."
　　"What?" said Roberto.
　　But Winky shook her head very hard, spilling more butterbeer down herself.
　　"Winky keeps - hic - her master's secrets," she said mutinously, swaying very heavily now, frowning up at Roberto with her eyes crossed. "You is - hic - nosing, you is."
　　"Winky must not talk like that to Roberto Gonzales!" said Dobby angrily. "Roberto Gonzales is brave and noble and Roberto Gonzales is not nosy!"
　　"He is nosing - hic - into my master's - hic - private and secret - hic - Winky is a good house-elf- hic - Winky keeps her silence - hic - people trying to - hic - pry and poke -hic -"
　　Winky's eyelids drooped and suddenly, without warning, she slid off her stool into the hearth, snoring loudly. The empty bottle of butterbeer rolled away across the stone-flagged floor. Half a dozen house-elves came hurrying forward, looking disgusted.
　　One of them picked up the bottle; the others covered Winky with a large checked tablecloth and tucked the ends in neatly, hiding her from view.
　　"We is sorry you had to see that, sirs and miss!" squeaked a nearby elf, shaking his head and looking very ashamed. "We is hoping you will not judge us all by Winky, sirs and miss!"
　　"She's unhappy!" said Carolina, exasperated. "Why don't you try and cheer her up instead
　　of covering her up?"
　　"Begging your pardon, miss," said the house-elf, bowing deeply again, "but house-elves has no right to be unhappy when there is work to be done and masters to be served."
　　"Oh for heavens sake!" Carolina cried. "Listen to me, all of you! You've got just as much right as wizards to be unhappy! You've got the right to wages and holidays and proper clothes, you don't have to do everything you're told - look at Dobby!"
　　"Miss will please keep Dobby out of this," Dobby mumbled, looking scared. The cheery smiles had vanished from the faces of the house-elves around the kitchen. They were suddenly looking at Carolina as though she were mad and dangerous.
　　"We has your extra food!" squeaked an elf at Roberto's elbow, and he shoved a large ham, a dozen cakes, and some fruit into Roberto's arms. "Good-bye!"
　　The house-elves crowded around Roberto, Diego, and Carolina and began shunting them out of the kitchen, many little hands pushing in the smalls of their backs.
　　"Thank you for the socks, Roberto Gonzales!" Dobby called miserably from the hearth, where he was standing next to the lumpy tablecloth that was Winky.
　　"You couldn't keep your mouth shut, could you, Carolina?" said Diego angrily as the kitchen door slammed shut behind them. "They won't want us visiting them now! We could've tried to get more stuff out of Winky about Crouch!"
　　"Oh as if you care about that!" scoffed Carolina. "You only like coming down here for the food!"
　　It was an irritable sort of day after that. Roberto got so tired of Diego and Carolina sniping at each other over their homework in the common room that he took Gustavo's food up to the Owlery that evening on his own.
　　Pigwidgeon was much too small to carry an entire ham up to the mountain by himself, so Roberto enlisted the help of two school screech owls as well. When they had set off into the dusk, looking extremely odd carrying the large package between them. Roberto leaned on the windowsill, looking out at the grounds, at the dark, rustling treetops of the Forbidden Forest, and the rippling sails of the Durmstrang ship. An eagle owl flew through the coil of smoke rising from Villalbas chimney; it soared toward the castle, around the Owlery, and out of sight. Looking down, Roberto saw Villalba digging energetically in front of his cabin. Roberto wondered what he was doing; it looked as though he were making a new vegetable patch. As he watched, Madame Maxime emerged from the Beauxbatons carriage and walked over to Villalba. She appeared to be trying to engage him in conversation. Villalba leaned upon his spade, but did not seem keen to prolong their talk, because Madame Maxime returned to the carriage shortly afterward.
　　Unwilling to go back to Gryffindor Tower and listen to Diego and Carolina snarling at each other, Roberto watched Villalba digging until the darkness swallowed him and the owls around Roberto began to awake, swooshing past him into the night.
　　By breakfast the next day Diego's and Carolina's bad moods had burnt out, and to Robertos relief, Diego's dark predictions that the house-elves would send substandard food up to the Gryffindor table because Carolina had insulted them proved false; the bacon, eggs, and kippers were quite as good as usual.
　　When the post owls arrived, Carolina looked up eagerly; she seemed to be expecting something.
　　"Miguel won't've had time to answer yet," said Diego. "We only sent Hedwig yesterday."
　　"No, it's not that," said Carolina. "I've taken out a subscription to the Daily Prophet.
　　I'm getting sick of finding everything out from the Slytherins."
　　"Good thinking!" said Roberto, also looking up at the owls. "Hey, Carolina, I think you're in luck -"
　　A gray owl was soaring down toward Carolina.
　　"It hasn't got a newspaper, though," she said, looking disappointed. "It's -"
　　But to her bewilderment, the gray owl landed in front of her plate, closely followed by four barn owls, a brown owl, and a tawny.
　　"How many subscriptions did you take out?" said Roberto, seizing Carolina's goblet before it was knocked over by the cluster of owls, all of whom were jostling close to her, trying to deliver their own letter first.
　　"What on earth - ?" Carolina said, taking the letter from the gray owl, opening it, and starting to read. "Oh really!" she sputtered, going rather red.
　　"What's up?" said Diego.
　　"It,'s - oh how ridiculous -"
　　She thrust the letter at Roberto, who saw that it was not handwritten, but composed from pasted letters that seemed to have been cut out of the Daily Prophet.
　　YOU ARE A WICKED GIRL. ROBERTO GONZALES DESERVES BETTER. GO BACK WHERE YOU CAME FROM MUGGLE.
　　"They're all like it!" said Carolina desperately, opening one letter after another.
　　"'Roberto Gonzales can do much better than the likes of you. . . .' 'You deserve to be boiled in frog spawn. . . .' Ouch!"
　　She had opened the last envelope, and yellowish-green liquid smelling strongly of petrol gushed over her hands, which began to erupt in large yellow boils.
　　"Undiluted bubotuber pus!" said Diego, picking up the envelope gingerly and sniffing it.
　　"Ow!" said Carolina, tears starting in her eyes as she tried to rub the pus off her hands with a napkin, but her fingers were now so thickly covered in painful sores that it looked as though she were wearing a pair of thick, knobbly gloves.
　　"You'd better get up to the hospital wing," said Roberto as the owls around Carolina took flight. "We'll tell Professor Sprout where you've gone. . . ."
　　"I warned her!" said Diego as Carolina hurried out of the Great Hall, cradling her hands.
　　"I warned her not to annoy Rita Skeeter! Look at this one ..." He read out one of the letters Carolina had left behind: "I read In Witch Weekly about how you are playing Roberto Gonzales false and that boy has had enough hardship and I will be sending you a curse by next post as soon as I can find a big enough envelope.' Blimey, she'd better watch out for herself."
　　Carolina didn't turn up for Herbology. As Roberto and Diego left the greenhouse for their Care of Magical Creatures class, they saw Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle descending the stone steps of the castle. Pansy Parkinson was whispering and giggling behind them with her gang of Slytherin girls. Catching sight of Roberto, Pansy called, "Gonzales, have you split up with your girlfriend? Why was she so upset at breakfast?"
　　Roberto ignored her; he didn't want to give her the satisfaction of knowing how much trouble the Witch Weekly article had caused.
　　Villalba, who had told them last lesson that they had finished with unicorns, was waiting for them outside his cabin with a fresh supply of open crates at his feet. Robertos heart sank at the sight of the crates - surely not another skrewt hatching? - but when he got near enough to see inside, he found himself looking at a number of flurry black creatures with long snouts. Their front paws were curiously flat, like spades, and they were blinking up at the class, looking politely puzzled at all the attention.
　　"These're nifflers," said Villalba, when the class had gathered around. "Yeh find 'em down mines mostly. They like sparkly stuff. . . . There yeh go, look."
　　One of the nifflers had suddenly leapt up and attempted to bite Pansy Parkinson's watch off her wrist. She shrieked and jumped backward.
　　"Useful little treasure detectors," said Villalba happily. "Thought we'd have some fun with 'em today. See over there?" He pointed at the large patch of freshly turned earth Roberto had watched him digging from the Owlery window. "I've buried some gold coins.
　　I've got a prize fer whoever picks the niffler that digs up most. Jus' take off all yer valuables, an' choose a niffler, an get ready ter set 'em loose."
　　Roberto took off his watch, which he was only wearing out of habit, as it didn't work anymore, and stuffed it into his pocket. Then he picked up a niffler. It put its long snout in Roberto's ear and sniffed enthusiastically. It was really quite cuddly.
　　"Hang on," said Villalba, looking down into the crate, "there's a spare niffler here . . .
　　who's missin? Where's Carolina?"
　　"She had to go to the hospital wing," said Diego.
　　"We'll explain later," Roberto muttered; Pansy Parkinson was listening.
　　It was easily the most fun they had ever had in Care of Magical Creatures. The nifflers dived in and out of the patch of earth as though it were water, each scurrying back to the student who had released it and spitting gold into their hands. Diego's was particularly efficient; it had soon filled his lap with coins.
　　"Can you buy these as pets, Villalba?" he asked excitedly as his niffler dived back into the soil, splattering his robes.
　　"Yer mum wouldn' be happy, Diego," said Villalba, grinning. "They wreck houses, nifflers. I reckon they've nearly got the lot, now," he added, pacing around the patch of earth while the nifflers continued to dive. "I on'y buried a hundred coins. Oh there y'are,
　　Carolina!"
　　Carolina was walking toward them across the lawn. Her hands were very heavily bandaged and she looked miserable. Pansy Parkinson was watching her beadily.
　　"Well, let's check how yeh've done!" said Villalba. "Count yer coins! An' there's no point tryin' ter steal any, Goyle," he added, his beetle-black eyes narrowed. "It's leprechaun gold. Vanishes after a few hours."
　　Goyle emptied his pockets, looking extremely sulky. It turned out that Diego's niffler had been most successful, so Villalba gave him an enormous slab of Honeydukes chocolate for a prize. The bell rang across the grounds for lunch; the rest of the class set off back to the castle, but Roberto, Diego, and Carolina stayed behind to help Villalba put the nifflers back in their boxes. Roberto noticed Madame Maxime watching them out other carriage window.
　　"What yeh done ter your hands, Carolina?" said Villalba, looking concerned.
　　Carolina told him about the hate mail she had received that morning, and the envelope full of bubotuber pus.
　　"Aaah, don worry," said Villalba gendy, looking down at her. "I got some o' those letters an all, after Rita Skeeter wrote abou me mum. 'Yeh're a monster an yeh should be put down.' 'Yer mother killed innocent people an if you had any decency you d jump in a lake.'"
　　"No!" said Carolina, looking shocked.
　　"Yeah," said Villalba, heaving the niffler crates over by his cabin wall. "They're jus' nutters, Carolina. Don' open 'em if yeh get any more. Chuck 'em straigh' in the fire."
　　"You missed a really good lesson," Roberto told Carolina as they headed back toward the castle. "They're good, nifflers, aren't they, Diego?"
　　Diego, however, was frowning at the chocolate Villalba had given him. He looked thoroughly put out about something.
　　"What's the matter?" said Roberto. "Wrong flavor?"
　　"No," said Diego shortly. "Why didn't you tell me about the gold?"
　　"What gold?" said Roberto.
　　"The gold I gave you at the Quidditch World Cup," said Diego. "The leprechaun gold I gave you for my Omnioculars. In the Top Box. Why didn't you tell me it disappeared?"
　　Roberto had to think for a moment before he realized what Diego was talking about.
　　"Oh . . ." he said, the memory coming back to him at last. "I dunno ... I never noticed it had gone. I was more worried about my wand, wasn't I?"
　　They climbed the steps into the entrance hall and went into the Great Hall for lunch.
　　"Must be nice," Diego said abruptly, when they had sat down and started serving themselves roast beef and Yorkshire puddings. "To have so much money you don't notice if a pocketful of Galleons goes missing."
　　"Listen, I had other stuff on my mind that night!" s aid Roberto impatiently. "We all did, remember?"
　　"I didn't know leprechaun gold vanishes," Diego muttered. "I thought I was paying you back. You shouldn't've given me that Chudley Cannon hat for Christmas."
　　"Forget it, all right?" said Roberto.
　　Diego speared a roast potato on the end of his fork, glaring at it. Then he said, "I hate being poor."
　　Roberto and Carolina looked at each other. Neither of them really knew what to say.
　　"It's rubbish," said Diego, still glaring down at his potato. "I don't blame Pablo and Luis for trying to make some extra money. Wish I could. Wish I had a niffler."
　　"Well, we know what to get you next Christmas," said Carolina brightly. Then, when Diego continued to look gloomy, she said, "Come on, Diego, it could be worse. At least your fingers aren't full of pus." Carolina was having a lot of difficulty managing her knife and fork, her fingers were so stiff and swollen. "I hate that Skeeter woman!" she burst out savagely. "I'll get her back for this if it's the last thing I do!"
　　Hate mail continued to arrive for Carolina over the following week, and although she followed Villalba's advice and stopped opening it, several of her ill-wishers sent Howlers, which exploded at the Gryffindor table and shrieked insults at her for the whole Hall to hear. Even those people who didn't read Witch Weekly knew all about the supposed Roberto-Krum-Carolina triangle now. Roberto was getting sick of telling people that Carolina wasn't his girlfriend.
　　"It'll die down, though," he told Carolina, "if we just ignore it. ... People got bored with that stuff she wrote about me last time
　　"I want to know how she's listening into private conversations when she's supposed to be banned from the grounds!" said Carolina angrily.
　　Carolina hung back in their next Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson to ask Professor Acosta something. The rest of the class was very eager to leave; Acosta had given them such a rigorous test of hex-deflection that many of them were nursing small injuries.
　　Roberto had such a bad case of Twitchy Ears, he had to hold his hands clamped over them as he walked away from the class.
　　"Well, Rita's definitely not using an Invisibility Cloak!" Carolina panted five minutes later, catching up with Roberto and Diego in the entrance hall and pulling Robertos hand away from one of his wiggling ears so that he could hear her. "Acosta says he didn't see her anywhere near the judges' table at the second task, or anywhere near the lake!"
　　"Carolina, is there any point in telling you to drop this?" said Diego.
　　"No!" said Carolina stubbornly. "I want to know how she heard me talking to Viktor! And how she found out about Villalbas mum!"
　　"Maybe she had you bugged," said Roberto.
　　"Bugged?" said Diego blankly. "What. . . put fleas on her or something?"
　　Roberto started explaining about hidden microphones and recording equipment. Diego was fascinated, but Carolina interrupted them.
　　"Aren't you two ever going to read Hogwarts, A History^"
　　"What's the point?" said Diego. "You know it by heart, we can just ask you."
　　"All those substitutes for magic Muggles use - electricity, computers, and radar, and all those things - they all go haywire around Hogwarts, there's too much magic in the air.
　　No, Rita's using magic to eavesdrop, she must be. ... If I could just find out what it is ... ooh, if it's illegal, I'll have her ..."
　　"Haven't we got enough to worry about?" Diego asked her. "Do we have to start a vendetta against Rita Skeeter as well?"
　　"I'm not asking you to help!" Carolina snapped. "I'll do it on my own!"
　　She marched back up the marble staircase without a backward glance. Roberto was quite sure she was going to the library.
　　"What's the betting she comes back with a box of / Hate Rita Skeeter badges?" said Diego.
　　Carolina, however, did not ask Roberto and Diego to help her pursue vengeance against Rita Skeeter, for which they were both grateful, because their workload was mounting ever higher in the days before the Easter holidays. Roberto frankly marveled at the fact that Carolina could research magical methods of eavesdropping as well as everything else they had to do. He was working flat-out just to get through all their homework, though he made a point of sending regular food packages up to the cave in the mountain for Gustavo; after last summer, Roberto had not forgotten what it felt like to be continually hungry.
　　He enclosed notes to Gustavo, telling him that nothing out of the ordinary had happened, and that they were still waiting for an answer from Miguel.
　　Hedwig didn't return until the end of the Easter holidays. Miguel's letter was enclosed in a package of Easter eggs that Mrs. Lopez had sent. Both Robertos and Diego's were the size of dragon eggs and full of homemade toffee. Carolinas, however, was smaller than a chicken egg. Her face fell when she saw it.
　　"Your mum doesn't read Witch Weekly, by any chance, does she, Diego?" she asked quietly.
　　"Yeah," said Diego, whose mouth was full of toffee. "Gets it for the recipes."
　　Carolina looked sadly at her tiny egg.
　　"Don't you want to see what Miguel's written?" Roberto asked her hastily.
　　Miguels letter was short and irritated.
　　As I am constantly telling the Daily Prophet, Mr. Crouch is taking a well-deserved break.
　　He is sending in regular owls with instructions. No, I haven't actually seen him, but I think I can be trusted to know my own superior's handwriting. I have quite enough to do at the moment without trying to quash these ridiculous rumors. Please don't bother me again unless it's something important. Happy Easter.
　　The start of the summer term would normally have meant that Roberto was training hard for the last Quidditch match of the season. This year, however, it was the third and final task in the Triwizard Tournament for which he needed to prepare, but he still didn't know what he would have to do. Finally, in the last week of May, Professor Romero held him back in Transfiguration.
　　"You are to go down to the Quidditch field tonight at nine o'clock. Gonzales," she told
　　him. "Mr. Bagman will be there to tell the champions about the third task."
　　So at half past eight that night. Roberto left Diego and Carolina in Gryffindor Tower and went downstairs. As he crossed the entrance hall, Nicolas came up from the Hufflepuff common room.
　　"What d'you reckon it's going to be?" he asked Roberto as they went together down the stone steps, out into the cloudy night. "Camila keeps going on about underground tunnels; she reckons we've got to find treasure."
　　"That wouldn't be too bad," said Roberto, thinking that he would simply ask Villalba for a niffler to do the job for him.
　　They walked down the dark lawn to the Quidditch stadium, turned through a gap in the stands, and walked out onto the field.
　　"What've they done to it?" Nicolas said indignantly, stopping dead.
　　The Quidditch field was no longer smooth and flat. It looked as though somebody had been building long, low walls all over it that twisted and crisscrossed in every direction.
　　"They're hedges!" said Roberto, bending to examine the nearest one.
　　"Hello there!" called a cheery voice.
　　Ludo Bagman was standing in the middle of the field with Krum and Camila. Roberto and Nicolas made their way toward them, climbing over the hedges. Camila beamed at Roberto as he came nearer. Her attitude toward him had changed completely since he had saved her sister from the lake.
　　"Well, what d'you think?" said Bagman happily as Roberto and Nicolas climbed over the last hedge. "Growing nicely, aren't they? Give them a month and Villalba'll have them twenty feet high. Don't worry," he added, grinning, spotting the less-than-happy expressions on Robertos and Nicolas's faces, "you'll have your Quidditch field back to normal once the task is over! Now, I imagine you can guess what we're making here?"
　　No one spoke for a moment. Then -"
　　Maze," grunted Krum.
　　"That's right!" said Bagman. "A maze. The third task's really very straightforward.
　　The Triwizard Cup will be placed in the center of the maze. The first champion to touch it will receive full marks."
　　"We seemply 'ave to get through the maze?" said Camila.
　　"There will be obstacles," said Bagman happily, bouncing on the balls of his feet.
　　"Villalba is providing a number of creatures . . . then there will be spells that must be broken ... all that sort of thing, you know. Now, the champions who are leading on points will get a head start into the maze." Bagman grinned at Roberto and Nicolas. "Then Mr. Krum will enter . . . then Miss Saenz. But you'll all be in with a fighting chance, depending how well you get past the obstacles. Should be fun, eh?"
　　Roberto, who knew only too well the kind of creatures that Villalba was likely to provide for an event like this, thought it was unlikely to be any fun at all. However, he nodded politely like the other champions.
　　"Very well. . . if you haven't got any questions, we'll go back up to the castle, shall we, it's a bit chilly. ..."
　　Bagman hurried alongside Roberto as they began to wend their way out of the growing maze.
　　Roberto had the feeling that Bagman was going to start offering to help him again, but just then, Krum tapped Roberto on the shoulder.
　　"Could I haff a vord?"
　　"Yeah, all right," said Roberto, slightly surprised.
　　"Vill you valk vith me?"
　　"Okay," said Roberto curiously.
　　Bagman looked slightly perturbed.
　　"I'll wait for you. Roberto, shall I?"
　　"No, it's okay, Mr. Bagman," said Roberto, suppressing a smile, "I think I can find the castle on my own, thanks."
　　Roberto and Krum left the stadium together, but Krum did not set a course for the Durmstrang ship. Instead, he walked toward the forest.
　　"What're we going this way for?" said Roberto as they passed Villalba s cabin and the illuminated Beauxbatons carriage.
　　"Don't vont to be overheard," said Krum shortly.
　　When at last they had reached a quiet stretch of ground a short way from the Beauxbatons horses' paddock, Krum stopped in the shade of the trees and turned to face Roberto.
　　"I vant to know," he said, glowering, "vot there is between you and Hermy-own-ninny."
　　Roberto, who from Krum's secretive manner had expected something much more serious than this, stared up at Krum in amazement.
　　"Nothing," he said. But Krum glowered at him, and Roberto, somehow struck anew by how tall Krum was, elaborated. "We're friends. She's not my girlfriend and she never has been.
　　It's just that Skeeter woman making things up."
　　"Hermy-own-ninny talks about you very often," said Krum, looking suspiciously at Roberto.
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, "because were friends."
　　He couldn't quite believe he was having this conversation with Viktor Krum, the famous International Quidditch player. It was as though the eighteen-year-old Krum thought he.
　　Roberto, was an equal - a real rival -"
　　You haff never . . . you haff not..."
　　"No," said Roberto very firmly.
　　Krum looked slightly happier. He stared at Roberto for a few seconds, then said, "You fly very veil. I vos votching at the first task."
　　"Thanks," said Roberto, grinning broadly and suddenly feeling much taller himself. "I saw you at the Quidditch World Cup. The Wronski Feint, you really -"
　　But something moved behind Krum in the trees, and Roberto, who had some experience of the sort of thing that lurked in the forest, instinctively grabbed Krum's arm and pulled him around.
　　"Vot is it?"
　　Roberto shook his head, staring at the place where he'd seen movement. He slipped his hand inside his robes, reaching for his wand.
　　Suddenly a man staggered out from behind a tall oak. For a moment, Roberto didn't recognize him . . . then he realized it was Mr. Crouch.
　　He looked as though he had been traveling for days. The knees of his robes were ripped and bloody, his face scratched; he was unshaven and gray with exhaustion. His neat hair and mustache were both in need of a wash and a trim. His strange appearance, however, was nothing to the way he was behaving. Muttering and gesticulating, Mr. Crouch appeared to be talking to someone that he alone could see. He reminded Roberto vividly of an old tramp he had seen once when out shopping with the Carrizos. That man too had been conversing wildly with thin air; Aunt Beatriz had seized Leonardo's hand and pulled him across the road to avoid him; Uncle Francisco had then treated the family to a long rant about what he would like to do with beggars and vagrants.
　　"Vosn't he a judge?" said Krum, staring at Mr. Crouch. "Isn't he vith your Ministry?"
　　Roberto nodded, hesitated for a moment, then walked slowly toward Mr. Crouch, who did not look at him, but continued to talk to a nearby tree.
　　"... and when you've done that, Weatherby, send an owl to Dominguez confirming the number of Durmstrang students who will be attending the tournament, Morales has just sent word there will be twelve. . . ."
　　"Mr. Crouch?" said Roberto cautiously.
　　"... and then send another owl to Madame Maxime, because she might want to up the number of students she's bringing, now Morales's made it a round dozen ... do that, Weatherby, will you? Will you? Will..."
　　Mr. Crouch's eyes were bulging. He stood staring at the tree, muttering soundlessly at it. Then he staggered sideways and fell to his knees.
　　"Mr. Crouch?" Roberto said loudly. "Are you all right?"
　　Crouch's eyes were rolling in his head. Roberto looked around at Krum, who had followed him into the trees, and was looking down at Crouch in alarm.
　　"Vot is wrong with him?"
　　"No idea," Roberto muttered. "Listen, you'd better go and get someone -"
　　"Dominguez!" gasped Mr. Crouch. He reached out and seized a handful of Robertos robes, dragging him closer, though his eyes were staring over Roberto's head. "I need... see ...
　　Dominguez. ..."
　　"Okay," said Roberto, "if you get up, Mr. Crouch, we can go up to the-"
　　"I've done . . . stupid . . . thing . . ." Mr. Crouch breathed. He looked utterly mad.
　　His eyes were rolling and bulging, and a trickle of spittle was sliding down his chin.
　　Every word he spoke seemed to cost him a terrible effort. "Must. . . tell. . .
　　Dominguez . . ."
　　"Get up, Mr. Crouch," said Roberto loudly and clearly. "Get up, I'll take you to Dominguez!"
　　Mr, Crouch's eyes rolled forward onto Roberto.
　　"Who ... you?" he whispered.
　　"I'm a student at the school," said Roberto, looking around at Krum for some help, but Krum was hanging back, looking extremely nervous.
　　"You're not... his?" whispered Crouch, his mouth sagging.
　　"No," said Roberto, without the faintest idea what Crouch was talking about.
　　"Dominguez's?"
　　"That's right," said Roberto.
　　Crouch was pulling him closer; Roberto tried to loosen Crouch's grip on his robes, but it was too powerful.
　　"Warn ... Dominguez ..."
　　"I'll get Dominguez if you let go of me," said Roberto. "Just let go, Mr. Crouch, and I'll get him.. . ."
　　"Thank you, Weatherby, and when you have done that, I would like a cup of tea. My wife and son will be arriving shortly, we are attending a concert tonight with Mr. and Mrs.
　　Fudge."
　　Crouch was now talking fluently to a tree again, and seemed completely unaware that Roberto was there, which surprised Roberto so much he didn't notice that Crouch had released him.
　　"Yes, my son has recently gained twelve O.W.L.S, most satisfactory, yes, thank you, yes, very proud indeed. Now, if you could bring me that memo from the Andorran Minister of Magic, I think I will have time to draft a response. ..."
　　"You stay here with him!" Roberto said to Krum. "I'll get Dominguez, I'll be quicker, I know where his office is -"
　　"He is mad," said Krum doubtfully, staring down at Crouch, who was still gabbling to the tree, apparently convinced it was Miguel.
　　"Just stay with him," said Roberto, starting to get up, but his movement seemed to trigger another abrupt change in Mr. Crouch, who seized him hard around the knees and pulled Roberto back to the ground.
　　"Don't. . . leave .. . me!" he whispered, his eyes bulging again. "I... escaped .. .
　　must warn . . . must tell... see Dominguez . . . my fault... all my fault. . . Bertha .
　　. . dead ... all my fault. .. my son ... my fault... tell Dominguez ... Roberto Gonzales ...
　　the Dark Lord . . . stronger . . . Roberto Gonzales ..."
　　"I'll get Dominguez if you let me go, Mr. Crouch!" said Roberto. He looked furiously around at Krum. "Help me, will you?"
　　Looking extremely apprehensive, Krum moved forward and squatted down next to Mr. Crouch.
　　"Just keep him here," said Roberto, pulling himself free of Mr. Crouch. "I'll be back with Dominguez."
　　"Hurry, von't you?" Krum called after him as Roberto sprinted away from the forest and up through the dark grounds. They were deserted; Bagman, Nicolas, and Camila had disappeared.
　　Roberto tore up the stone steps, through the oak front doors, and off up the marble staircase, toward the second floor.
　　Five minutes later he was hurtling toward a stone gargoyle standing halfway along an empty corridor.
　　"Sher - sherbet lemon!" he panted at it.
　　This was the password to the hidden staircase to Dominguez's office - or at least, it had been two years ago. The password had evidently changed, however, for the stone gargoyle did not spring to life and jump aside, but stood frozen, glaring at Roberto malevolently.
　　"Move!" Roberto shouted at it. "C'mon!"
　　But nothing at Hogwarts had ever moved just because he shouted at it; he knew it was no good. He looked up and down the dark corridor. Perhaps Dominguez was in the staffroom?
　　He started running as fast as he could toward the staircase -"
　　GONZALES!"
　　Roberto skidded to a halt and looked around. Peralta had just emerged from the hidden staircase behind the stone gargoyle. The wall was sliding shut behind him even as he beckoned Roberto back toward him.
　　"What are you doing here, Gonzales?"
　　"I need to see Professor Dominguez!" said Roberto, running back up the corridor and skidding to a standstill in front of Peralta instead. "It's Mr. Crouch . . . he's just turned up ... he's in the forest... he's asking -"
　　"What is this rubbish?" said Peralta, his black eyes glittering. "What are you talking about?"
　　"Mr. Crouch!" Roberto shouted. "From the Ministry! He's ill or something - he's in the forest, he wants to see Dominguez! Just give me the password up to -"
　　"The headmaster is busy. Gonzales," said Peralta, his thin mouth curling into an unpleasant smile.
　　"I've got to tell Dominguez!" Roberto yelled.
　　"Didn't you hear me. Gonzales?"
　　Roberto could tell Peralta was thoroughly enjoying himself, denying Roberto the thing he wanted when he was so panicky.
　　"Look," said Roberto angrily, "Crouch isn't right - he's - he's out of his mind - he says he wants to warn -"
　　The stone wall behind Peralta slid open. Dominguez was standing there, wearing long green robes and a mildly curious expression. "Is there a problem?" he said, looking between Roberto and Peralta.
　　"Professor!" Roberto said, sidestepping Peralta before Peralta could speak, "Mr. Crouch is here - he's down in the forest, he wants to speak to you!"
　　Roberto expected Dominguez to ask questions, but to his relief, Dominguez did nothing of the sort.
　　"Lead the way," he said promptly, and he swept off along the corridor behind Roberto, leaving Peralta standing next to the gargoyle and looking twice as ugly.
　　"What did Mr. Crouch say. Roberto?" said Dominguez as they walked swiftly down the marble staircase.
　　"Said he wants to warn you . . . said he's done something terrible ... he mentioned his son . . . and Bertha Jorkins .. . and - and Salvador. . . something about Salvador getting stronger. ..."
　　"Indeed," said Dominguez, and he quickened his pace as they hurried out into the pitch-darkness.
　　"He's not acting normally," Roberto said, hurrying along beside Dominguez. "He doesn't seem to know where he is. He keeps talking like he thinks Miguel Lopez's there, and then he changes, and says he needs to see you. ... I left him with Viktor Krum."
　　"You did?" said Dominguez sharply, and he began to take longer strides still, so that Roberto was running to keep up. "Do you know if anybody else saw Mr. Crouch?"
　　"No," said Roberto. "Krum and I were talking, Mr. Bagman had just finished telling us about the third task, we stayed behind, and then we saw Mr. Crouch coming out of the forest -"
　　"Where are they?" said Dominguez as the Beauxbatons carriage emerged from the darkness.
　　"Over here," said Roberto, moving in front of Dominguez, leading the way through the trees. He couldn't hear Crouch's voice anymore, but he knew where he was going; it hadn't been much past the Beauxbatons carriage . . . somewhere around here. . . .
　　"Viktor?" Roberto shouted.
　　No one answered.
　　"They were here," Roberto said to Dominguez. "They were definitely somewhere around here.
　　..."
　　"Lumos," Dominguez said, lighting his wand and holding it up.
　　Its narrow beam traveled from black trunk to black trunk, illuminating the ground. And then it fell upon a pair of feet.
　　Roberto and Dominguez hurried forward. Krum was sprawled on the forest floor. He seemed to be unconscious. There was no sign at all of Mr. Crouch. Dominguez bent over Krum and gently lifted one of his eyelids.
　　"Stunned," he said softly. His half-moon glasses glittered in the wandlight as he peered around at the surrounding trees.
　　"Should I go and get someone?" said Roberto. "Madam Pomfrey?"
　　"No," said Dominguez swiftly. "Stay here."
　　He raised his wand into the air and pointed it in the direction of Villalba's cabin. Roberto saw something silvery dart out of it and streak away through the trees like a ghostly bird. Then Dominguez bent over Krum again, pointed his wand at him, and muttered, "Ennervate."
　　Krum opened his eyes. He looked dazed. When he saw Dominguez, he tried to sit up, but Dominguez put a hand on his shoulder and made him lie still.
　　"He attacked me!" Krum muttered, putting a hand up to his head. "The old madman attacked me! I vos looking around to see vare Gonzales had gone and he attacked from behind!"
　　"Lie still for a moment," Dominguez said.
　　The sound of thunderous footfalls reached them, and Villalba came panting into sight with Fang at his heels. He was carrying his crossbow.
　　"Professor Dominguez!" he said, his eyes widening. "Roberto - what the - ?"
　　"Villalba, I need you to fetch Professor Morales," said Dominguez. "His student has been attacked. When you've done that, kindly alert Professor Acosta -"
　　"No need, Dominguez," said a wheezy growl. "I'm here."
　　Acosta was limping toward them, leaning on his staff, his wand lit.
　　"Damn leg," he said furiously. "Would've been here quicker . . . what's happened? Peralta said something about Crouch -"
　　"Crouch?" said Villalba blankly.
　　"Morales, please, Villalba!" said Dominguez sharply.
　　"Oh yeah . .'. right y'are, Professor. . ." said Villalba, and he turned and disappeared into the dark trees, Fang trotting after him.
　　"I don't know where Barty Crouch is," Dominguez told Acosta, "but it is essential that we find him."
　　"I'm onto it," growled Acosta, and he pulled out his wand and limped off into the forest.
　　Neither Dominguez nor Roberto spoke again until they heard the unmistakable sounds of Villalba and Fang returning. Morales was hurrying along behind them. He was wearing his sleek silver furs, and he looked pale and agitated.
　　"What is this?" he cried when he saw Krum on the ground and Dominguez and Roberto beside him. "What's going on?"
　　"I vos attacked!" said Krum, sitting up now and rubbing his head. "Mr. Crouch or votever his name -"
　　"Crouch attacked you? Crouch attacked you? The Triwizard judge?"
　　"Ramon," Dominguez began, but Morales had drawn himself up, clutching his furs around him, looking livid.
　　"Treachery!" he bellowed, pointing at Dominguez. "It is a plot! You and your Ministry of Magic have lured me here under false pretenses, Dominguez! This is not an equal competition! First you sneak Gonzales into the tournament, though he is underage! Now one of your Ministry friends attempts to put my champion out of action! I smell double-dealing and corruption in this whole affair, and you, Dominguez, you, with your talk of closer international wizarding links, of rebuilding old ties, of forgetting old differences - here's what I think of you!"
　　Morales spat onto the ground at Dominguez's feet. In one swift movement, Villalba seized the front of Morales's furs, lifted him into the air, and slammed him against a nearby tree.
　　"Apologize!" Villalba snarled as Morales gasped for breath, Villalba's massive fist at his throat, his feet dangling in midair.
　　"Villalba, no!" Dominguez shouted, his eyes flashing.
　　Villalba removed the hand pinning Morales to the tree, and Morales slid all the way down the trunk and slumped in a huddle at its roots; a few twigs and leaves showered down upon his head.
　　"Kindly escort Roberto back up to the castle, Villalba," said Dominguez sharply.
　　Breathing heavily, Villalba gave Morales a glowering look.
　　"Maybe I'd better stay here. Headmaster. . . ."
　　"You will take Roberto back to school, Villalba," Dominguez repeated firmly. "Take him right up to Gryffindor Tower. And Roberto - I want you to stay there. Anything you might want to do - any owls you might want to send - they can wait until morning, do you understand me?"
　　"Er - yes," said Roberto, staring at him. How had Dominguez known that, at that very moment, he had been thinking about sending Pigwidgeon straight to Gustavo, to tell him what had happened?
　　"I'll leave Fang with yeh. Headmaster," Villalba said, staring menacingly at Morales, who was still sprawled at the foot of the tree, tangled in furs and tree roots. "Stay, Fang.
　　C'mon, Roberto."
　　They marched in silence past the Beauxbatons carriage and up toward the castle.
　　"How dare he," Villalba growled as they strode past the lake. "How dare he accuse Dominguez. Like Dominguez'd do anythin' like that. Like Dominguez wanted you in the tournament in the firs' place. Worried! I dunno when I seen Dominguez more worried than he's bin lately. An' you!" Villalba suddenly said angrily to Roberto, who looked up at
　　him, taken aback. "What were yeh doin', wanderin' off with ruddy Krum? He's from Durmstrang, Roberto! Coulda jinxed yeh right there, couldn he? Hasn' Acosta taught yeh nothin'? 'Magine lettin him lure yeh off on yer own -"
　　"Krum's all right!" said Roberto as they climbed the steps into the entrance hall. "He wasn't trying to jinx me, he just wanted to talk about Carolina -"
　　"I'll be havin' a few words with her, an' all," said Villalba grimly, stomping up the stairs. "The less you lot 'ave ter do with these foreigners, the happier yeh'll be. Yeh can trust any of 'em."
　　"You were getting on all right with Madame Maxime," Roberto said, annoyed.
　　"Don' you talk ter me abou' her!" said Villalba, and he looked quite frightening for a moment. "I've got her number now! Tryin' ter get back in me good books, tryin' ter get me ter tell her what's comin in the third task. Ha! You can' trust any of'em!"
　　Villalba was in such a bad mood, Roberto was quite glad to say good-bye to him in front of the Fat Lady. He clambered through the portrait hole into the common room and hurried straight for the corner where Diego and Carolina were sitting, to tell them what had happened.
　　CHAPTER TWENTY-NINE - THE DREAM
　　It comes down to this," said Carolina, rubbing her forehead. "Either Mr. Crouch attacked Viktor, or somebody else attacked both of them when Viktor wasn't looking."
　　"It must've been Crouch," said Diego at once. "That's why he was gone when Roberto and Dominguez got there. He'd done a runner."
　　"I don't think so," said Roberto, shaking his head. "He seemed really weak - I don't reckon he was up to Disapparating or anything."
　　"You cant Disapparate on the Hogwarts grounds, haven't I told you enough times?" said Carolina.
　　"Okay. . . hows this for a theory," said Diego excitedly. "Krum attacked Crouch - no, wait for it - and then Stunned himself!"
　　"And Mr. Crouch evaporated, did he?" said Carolina coldly.
　　"Oh yeah . . ."
　　It was daybreak. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina had crept out of their dormitories very early and hurried up to the Owlery together to send a note to Gustavo. Now they were standing looking out at the misty grounds. All three of them were puffy-eyed and pale because they had been talking late into the night about Mr. Crouch.
　　"Just go through it again, Roberto," said Carolina. "What did Mr. Crouch actually say?"
　　"I've told you, he wasn't making much sense," said Roberto. "He said he wanted to warn Dominguez about something. He definitely mentioned Bertha Jorkins, and he seemed to think she was dead. He kept saying stuff was his fault. . . . He mentioned his son."
　　"Well, that was his fault," said Carolina testily.
　　"He was out of his mind," said Roberto. "Half the time he seemed to think his wife and son were still alive, and he kept talking to Miguel about work and giving him instructions."
　　"And . . . remind me what he said about You-Know-Who?" said Diego tentatively.
　　"I've told you," Roberto repeated dully. "He said he's getting stronger."
　　There was a pause. Then Diego said in a falsely confident voice, "But he was out of his mind, like you said, so half of it was probably just raving. ..."
　　"He was sanest when he was trying to talk about Salvador," said Roberto, and Diego winced at the sound of the name. "He was having real trouble stringing two words together, but that was when he seemed to know where he was, and know what he wanted to do. He just kept saying he had to see Dominguez."
　　Roberto turned away from the window and stared up into the rafters. The many perches were half-empty; every now and then, another owl would swoop in through one of the windows, returning from its night's hunting with a mouse in its beak.
　　"If Peralta hadn't held me up," Roberto said bitterly, "we might've got there in time. 'The headmaster is busy. Gonzales . . . what's this rubbish, Gonzales?' Why couldn't he have just got out of the way?"
　　"Maybe he didn't want you to get there!" said Diego quickly. "Maybe - hang on - how fast d'you reckon he could've gotten down to the forest? D'you reckon he could've beaten you and Dominguez there?"
　　"Not unless he can turn himself into a bat or something," said Roberto.
　　"Wouldn't put it past him," Diego muttered.
　　"We need to see Professor Acosta," said Carolina. "We need to find out whether he found Mr. Crouch,"
　　"If he had the Marauder's Map on him, it would've been easy," said Roberto.
　　"Unless Crouch was already outside the grounds," said Diego, "because it only shows up to the boundaries, doesn't -"
　　"Shh!" said Carolina suddenly.
　　Somebody was climbing the steps up to the Owlery. Roberto could hear two voices arguing, coming closer and closer.
　　"- that's blackmail, that is, we could get into a lot of trouble for that-"
　　"- we've tried being polite; it's time to play dirty, like him. He wouldn't like the Ministry of Magic knowing what he did -"
　　"I'm telling you, if you put that in writing, it's blackmail!"
　　"Yeah, and you won't be complaining if we get a nice fat payoff, will you?"
　　The Owlery door banged open. Pablo and Luis came over the threshold, then froze at the sight of Roberto, Diego, and Carolina.
　　"What're you doing here?" Diego and Pablo said at the same time.
　　"Sending a letter," said Roberto and Luis in unison.
　　"What, at this time?" said Carolina and Pablo.
　　Pablo grinned.
　　"Fine - we won't ask you what you're doing, if you don't ask us," he said.
　　He was holding a sealed envelope in his hands. Roberto glanced at it, but Pablo, whether accidentally or on purpose, shifted his hand so that the name on it was covered.
　　"Well, don't let us hold you up," Pablo said, making a mock bow and pointing at the door.
　　Diego didn't move. "Who're you blackmailing?" he said.
　　The grin vanished from Pablo's face. Roberto saw Luis half glance at Pablo, before smiling at Diego.
　　"Don't be stupid, I was only joking," he said easily.
　　"Didn't sound like that," said Diego.
　　Pablo and Luis looked at each other. Then Pablo said abruptly, "I've told you before, Diego, keep your nose out if you like it the shape it is. Can't see why you would, but -"
　　"It's my business if you're blackmailing someone," said Diego. "Luis's right, you could end up in serious trouble for that."
　　"Told you, I was joking," said Luis. He walked over to Pablo, pulled the letter out of his hands, and began attaching it to the leg of the nearest barn owl. "You're starting to sound a bit like our dear older brother, you are, Diego. Carry on like this and you'll be made a prefect."
　　"No, I won't!" said Diego hotly.
　　Luis carried the barn owl over to the window and it took off. Luis turned around and grinned at Diego.
　　"Well, stop telling people what to do then. See you later."
　　He and Pablo left the Owlery. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina stared at one another.
　　"You don't think they know something about all this, do you?" Carolina whispered. "About Crouch and everything?"
　　"No," said Roberto. "If it was something that serious, they'd tell someone. They'd tell Dominguez."
　　Diego, however, was looking uncomfortable.
　　"What's the matter?" Carolina asked him.
　　"Well. . ." said Diego slowly, "I dunno if they would. They're . . . they're obsessed with making money lately, I noticed it when I was hanging around with them - when - you know -"
　　"We weren't talking." Roberto finished the sentence for him. "Yeah, but blackmail..."
　　"It's this joke shop idea they've got," said Diego. "I thought they were only saying it to annoy Mum, but they really mean it, they want to start one. They've only got a year left at Hogwarts, they keep going on about how it's time to think about their future, and Dad can't help them, and they need gold to get started."
　　Carolina was looking uncomfortable now.
　　"Yes, but. . . they wouldn't do anything against the law to get gold."
　　"Wouldn't they?" said Diego, looking skeptical. "I dunno . . . they don't exactly mind breaking rules, do they?"
　　"Yes, but this is the law" said Carolina, looking scared. "This isn't some silly school rule. . . . They'll get a lot more than detention for blackmail! Diego. . . maybe you'd
　　better tell Miguel. . . ."
　　"Are you mad?" said Diego. "Tell Miguel? He'd probably do a Crouch and turn them in." He stared at the window through which Pablo and Luis's owl had departed, then said, "Come on, let's get some breakfast."
　　"D'you think it's too early to go and see Professor Acosta?" Carolina said as they went down the spiral staircase.
　　"Yes," said Roberto. "He'd probably blast us through the door if we wake him at the crack of dawn; he'll think we're trying to attack him while he's asleep. Let's give it till break."
　　History of Magic had rarely gone so slowly. Roberto kept checking Diego's watch, having finally discarded his own, but Diego's was moving so slowly he could have sworn it had stopped working too. All three of them were so tired they could happily have put their heads down on the desks and slept; even Carolina wasn't taking her usual notes, but was sitting with her head on her hand, gazing at Professor Binns with her eyes out of focus.
　　When the bell finally rang, they hurried out into the corridors toward the Dark Arts classroom and found Professor Acosta leaving it. He looked as tired as they felt. The eyelid of his normal eye was drooping, giving his face an even more lopsided appearance than usual.
　　"Professor Acosta?" Roberto called as they made their way toward him through the crowd.
　　"Hello, Gonzales," growled Acosta. His magical eye followed a couple of passing first years, who sped up, looking nervous; it rolled into the back of Acosta's head and watched them around the corner before he spoke again.
　　"Come in here."
　　He stood back to let them into his empty classroom, limped in after them, and closed the door.
　　"Did you find him?" Roberto asked without preamble. "Mr. Crouch?"
　　"No," said Acosta. He moved over to his desk, sat down, stretched out his wooden leg with a slight groan, and pulled out his hip flask.
　　"Did you use the map?" Roberto said.
　　"Of course," said Acosta, taking a swig from his flask. "Took a leaf out of your book, Gonzales. Summoned it from my office into the forest. He wasn't anywhere on there."
　　"So he did Disapparate?" said Diego.
　　"You can't Disapparate on the grounds, Diego!" said Carolina. "There are other ways he could have disappeared, aren't there, Professor?"
　　Acosta's magical eye quivered as it rested on Carolina. "You're another one who might think about a career as an Auror," he told her. "Mind works the right way. Fernandez."
　　Carolina flushed pink with pleasure.
　　"Well, he wasn't invisible," said Roberto. "The map shows invisible people. He must've left the grounds, then."
　　"But under his own steam?" said Carolina eagerly, "or because someone made him?"
　　"Yeah, someone could've - could've pulled him onto a broom and flown off with him, couldn't they?" said Diego quickly, looking hopefully at Acosta as if he too wanted to be told he had the makings of an Auror.
　　"We can't rule out kidnap," growled Acosta.
　　"So," said Diego, "d'you reckon he's somewhere in Hogsmeade?"
　　"Could be anywhere," said Acosta, shaking his head. "Only thing we know for sure is that he's not here."
　　He yawned widely, so that his scars stretched, and his lopsided mouth revealed a number of missing teeth. Then he said, "Now, Dominguez's told me you three fancy yourselves as investigators, but there's nothing you can do for Crouch. The Ministry'll be looking for him now, Dominguez's notified them. Gonzales, you just keep your mind on the third task."
　　"What?" said Roberto. "Oh yeah . . ."
　　He hadn't given the maze a single thought since he'd left it with Krum the previous night.
　　"Should be right up your street, this one," said Acosta, looking up at Roberto and scratching his scarred and stubbly chin. "From what Dominguez's said, you've managed to get through stuff like this plenty of times. Broke your way through a series of obstacles guarding the Sorcerers Stone in your first year, didn't you?"
　　"We helped," Diego said quickly. "Me and Carolina helped."
　　Acosta grinned.
　　"Well, help him practice for this one, and I'll be very surprised if he doesn't win,"
　　said Acosta. "In the meantime .. . constant vigilance, Gonzales. Constant vigilance." He took another long draw from his hip flask, and his magical eye swiveled onto the window.
　　The topmost sail of the Durmstrang ship was visible through it.
　　"You two," counseled Acosta, his normal eye on Diego and Carolina, "you stick close to Gonzales, all right? I'm keeping an eye on things, but all the same . . . you can never have too many eyes out."
　　Gustavo sent their owl back the very next morning. It fluttered down beside Roberto at the same moment that a tawny owl landed in front of Carolina, clutching a copy of the Daily Prophet in its beak. She took the newspaper, scanned the first few pages, said, "Ha!
　　She hasn't got wind of Crouch!" then joined Diego and Roberto in reading what Gustavo had to say on the mysterious events of the night before last.
　　Roberto - what do you think you are playing at, walking off into the forest with Viktor Krum? I want you to swear, by return owl, that you are not going to go walking with anyone else at night. There is somebody highly dangerous at Hogwarts. It is clear to me that they wanted to stop Crouch from seeing Dominguez and you were probably feet away from them in the dark. You could have been killed.
　　Your name didn't get into the Goblet of Fire by accident. If someone's trying to attack you, they're on their last chance. Stay close to Diego and Carolina, do not leave Gryffindor Tower after hours, and arm yourself for the third task. Practice Stunning and Disarming. A few hexes wouldn't go amiss either. There's nothing you can do about Crouch. Keep your head down and look after yourself. I'm waiting for your letter giving me your word you won't stray out-of-bounds again.
　　Gustavo "Who's he, to lecture me about being out-of-bounds?" said Roberto in mild indignation as he folded up Gustavo's letter and put it inside his robes. "After all the stuff he did at school!"
　　"He's worried about you!" said Carolina sharply. "Just like Acosta and Villalba! So listen to them!"
　　"No one's tried to attack me all year," said Roberto. "No one's done anything to me at all-"
　　"Except put your name in the Goblet of Fire," said Carolina. "And they must've done that for a reason. Roberto. Snuffles is right. Maybe they've been biding their time. Maybe this is the task they're going to get you."
　　"Look," said Roberto impatiently, "let's say Gustavo is right, and someone Stunned Krum to kidnap Crouch. Well, they would've been in the trees near us, wouldn't they? But they waited till I was out of the way until they acted, didn't they? So it doesn't look like I'm their target, does it?"
　　"They couldn't have made it look like an accident if they'd murdered you in the forest!"
　　said Carolina. "But if you die during a task-"
　　"They didn't care about attacking Krum, did they?" said Roberto. "Why didn't they just polish me off at the same time? They could've made it look like Krum and I had a duel or something."
　　"Roberto, I don't understand it either," said Carolina desperately. "I just know there are a lot of odd things going on, and I don't like it. ... Acosta's right - Gustavo is right -you've got to get in training for the third task, straight away. And you make sure you write back to Gustavo and promise him you're not going to go sneaking off alone again."
　　The Hogwarts grounds never looked more inviting than when Roberto had to stay indoors. For the next few days he spent all of his free time either in the library with Carolina and Diego, looking up hexes, or else in empty classrooms, which they sneaked into to practice.
　　Roberto was concentrating on the Stunning Spell, which he had never used before. The trouble was that practicing it involved certain sacrifices on Diego's and Carolina's part.
　　"Can't we kidnap Mrs. Norris?" Diego suggested on Monday lunchtime as he lay flat on his back in the middle of their Charms classroom, having just been Stunned and reawoken by Roberto for the fifth time in a row. "Let's Stun her for a bit. Or you could use Dobby, Roberto, I bet he'd do anything to help you. I'm not complaining or anything" - he got gingerly to his feet, rubbing his backside - "but I'm aching all over. ..."
　　"Well, you keep missing the cushions, don't you!" said Carolina impatiently, rearranging
　　the pile of cushions they had used for the Banishing Spell, which Flitwick had left in a cabinet. "Just try and fall backward!"
　　"Once you're Stunned, you can't aim too well, Carolina! "said Diego angrily. "Why don't you take a turn?"
　　"Well, I think Roberto's got it now, anyway," said Carolina hastily. "And we don't have to worry about Disarming, because he's been able to do that for ages. ... I think we ought to start on some of these hexes this evening."
　　She looked down the list they had made in the library.
　　"I like the look of this one," she said, "this Impediment Curse. Should slow down anything that's trying to attack you. Roberto. We'll start with that one."
　　The bell rang. They hastily shoved the cushions back into Flitwicks cupboard and slipped out of the classroom.
　　"See you at dinner!" said Carolina, and she set off for Arithmancy, while Roberto and Diego headed toward North Tower, and Divination. Broad strips of dazzling gold sunlight tell across the corridor from the high windows. The sky outside was so brightly blue it looked as though it had been enameled.
