It wasn't very effective, but it burned a small hole in the hedge through which Roberto forced his leg, kicking at the thick brambles and branches until they broke and made an opening; he struggled through it, tearing his robes, and looking to his right, saw Nicolas jerking and twitching on the ground, Krum standing over him.
　　Roberto pulled himself up and pointed his wand at Krum just as Krum looked up. Krum turned and began to run.
　　"Stupefy!" Roberto yelled.
　　The spell hit Krum in the back; he stopped dead in his tracks, fell forward, and lay motionless, facedown in the grass. Roberto-dashed over to Nicolas, who had stopped twitching and was lying there panting, his hands over his face.
　　"Are you all right?" Roberto said roughly, grabbing Nicolas's arm.
　　"Yeah," panted Nicolas. "Yeah ... I don't believe it... he crept up behind me. ... I heard him, I turned around, and he had his wand on me. . . ."
　　Nicolas got up. He was still shaking. He and Roberto looked down at Krum.
　　"I can't believe this ... I thought he was all right," Roberto said, staring at Krum.
　　"So did I," said Nicolas.
　　"Did you hear Camila scream earlier?" said Roberto.
　　"Yeah," said Nicolas. "You don't think Krum got her too?"
　　"I don't know," said Roberto slowly.
　　"Should we leave him here?" Nicolas muttered.
　　"No," said Roberto. "I reckon we should send up red sparks. Someone'll come and collect him . . . otherwise he'll probably be eaten by a skrewt."
　　"He'd deserve it," Nicolas muttered, but all the same, he raised his wand and shot a
　　shower of red sparks into the air, which hovered high above Krum, marking the spot where he lay.
　　Roberto and Nicolas stood there in the darkness for a moment, looking around them. Then Nicolas said, "Well... I s'pose we'd better go on. . . ."
　　"What?" said Roberto. "Oh . . . yeah . . . right. . ."
　　It was an odd moment. He and Nicolas had been briefly united against Krum - now the fact that they were opponents came back to Roberto. The two of them proceeded up the dark path without speaking, then Roberto turned left, and Nicolas right. Nicolas's footsteps soon died away.
　　Roberto moved on, continuing to use the Four-Point Spell, making sure he was moving in the right direction. It was between him and Nicolas now. His desire to reach the cup first was now burning stronger than ever, but he could hardly believe what he'd just seen Krum do. The use of an Unforgivable Curse on a fellow human being meant a life term in Azkaban, that was what Acosta had told them. Krum surely couldn't have wanted the Triwizard Cup that badly....Roberto sped up.
　　Every so often he hit more dead ends, but the increasing darkness made him feel sure he was getting near the heart of the maze. Then, as he strode down a long, straight path, he saw movement once again, and his beam of wandlight hit an extraordinary creature, one which he had only seen in picture form, in his Monster Book of Monsters.
　　It was a sphinx. It had the body of an over-large lion: great clawed paws and a long yellowish tail ending in a brown tuft. Its head, however, was that of a woman. She turned her long, almond-shaped eyes upon Roberto as he approached. He raised his wand, hesitating. She was not crouching as if to spring, but pacing from side to side of the path, blocking his progress. Then she spoke, in a deep, hoarse voice.
　　"You are very near your goal. The quickest way is past me."
　　"So ... so will you move, please?" said Roberto, knowing what the answer was going to be.
　　"No," she said, continuing to pace. "Not unless you can answer my riddle. Answer on your first guess - I let you pass. Answer wrongly - I attack. Remain silent - I will let you walk away from me unscathed."
　　Roberto's stomach slipped several notches. It was Carolina who was good at this sort of thing, not him. He weighed his chances. If the riddle was too hard, he could keep silent, get away from the sphinx unharmed, and try and find an alternative route to the center.
　　"Okay," he said. "Can I hear the riddle?"
　　The sphinx sat down upon her hind legs, in the very middle of the path, and recited:
　　"First think of the person who lives in disguise, Who deals in secrets and tells naught but lies.
　　Next, tell me what's always the last thing to mend, The middle of middle and end of the end?
　　And finally give me the sound often heard During the search for a hard-to-find word.
　　Now string them together, and answer me this, Which creature would you be unwilling to kiss?"
　　Roberto gaped at her.
　　"Could I have it again . . . more slowly?" he asked tentatively. She blinked at him, smiled, and repeated the poem. "All the clues add up to a creature I wouldn't want to kiss?" Roberto asked.
　　She merely smiled her mysterious smile. Roberto took that for a "yes." Roberto cast his mind around. There were plenty of animals he wouldn't want to kiss; his immediate thought was a Blast-Ended Skrewt, but something told him that wasn't the answer. He'd have to try and work out the clues. . . .
　　"A person in disguise," Roberto muttered, staring at her, "who lies ... er ... that'd be a - an impostor. No, that's not my guess! A - a spy? I'll come back to that. . . could you give me the next clue again, please?"
　　She repeated the next lines of the poem.
　　"'The last thing to mend,'" Roberto repeated. "Er ... no idea . . . 'middle of middle' . .
　　. could I have the last bit again?"
　　She gave him the last four lines.
　　"'The sound often heard during the search for a hard-to-find word,'" said Roberto. "Er . .
　　. that'd be ... er ... hang on - 'er'! Er's a sound!"
　　The sphinx smiled at him.
　　"Spy ... er ... spy ... er ..." said Roberto, pacing up and down. "A creature I wouldn't want to kiss . . . a spider!"
　　The sphinx smiled more broadly. She got up, stretched her front legs, and then moved aside for him to pass.
　　"Thanks!" said Roberto, and, amazed at his own brilliance, he dashed forward.
　　He had to be close now, he had to be. ... His wand was telling him he was bang on course; as long as he didn't meet anything too horrible, he might have a chance. . . .
　　Roberto broke into a run. He had a choice of paths up ahead. "Point Me!" he whispered again to his wand, and it spun around and pointed him to the right-hand one. He dashed up this one and saw light ahead.
　　The Triwizard Cup was gleaming on a plinth a hundred yards away. Suddenly a dark figure hurtled out onto the path in front of him.
　　Nicolas was going to get there first. Nicolas was sprinting as fast as he could toward the cup, and Roberto knew he would never catch up, Nicolas was much taller, had much longer legs -Then Roberto saw something immense over a hedge to his left, moving quickly along a path that intersected with his own; it was moving so fast Nicolas was about to run into it, and Nicolas, his eyes on the cup, had not seen it -"
　　Nicolas!" Roberto bellowed. "On your left!"
　　Nicolas looked around just in time to hurl himself past the thing and avoid colliding with it, but in his haste, he tripped. Roberto saw Nicolas's wand fly out of his hand as a gigantic spider stepped into the path and began to bear down upon Nicolas.
　　"Stupefy!" Roberto yelled; the spell hit the spider's gigantic, hairy black body, but for all the good it did, he might as well have thrown a stone at it; the spider jerked, scuttled around, and ran at Roberto instead.
　　"Stupefy! Impedimenta! Stupefy!"
　　But it was no use - the spider was either so large, or so magical, that the spells were doing no more than aggravating it. Roberto had one horrifying glimpse of eight shining black eyes and razor-sharp pincers before it was upon him.
　　He was lifted into the air in its front legs; struggling madly, he tried to kick it; his leg connected with the pincers and next moment he was in excruciating pain. He could hear Nicolas yelling "Stupefy!" too, but his spell had no more effect than Roberto's - Roberto raised his wand as the spider opened its pincers once more and shouted "Expelliarmus!"
　　It worked - the Disarming Spell made the spider drop him, but that meant that Roberto fell twelve feet onto his already injured leg, which crumpled beneath him. Without pausing to think, he aimed high at the spider's underbelly, as he had done with the skrewt, and shouted "Stupefy!''just as Nicolas yelled the same thing.
　　The two spells combined did what one alone had not: The spider keeled over sideways, flattening a nearby hedge, and strewing the path with a tangle of hairy legs.
　　"Roberto!" he heard Nicolas shouting. "You all right? Did it fall on you?"
　　"No," Roberto called back, panting. He looked down at his leg. It was bleeding freely. He could see some sort of thick, gluey secretion from the spider's pincers on his torn robes. He tried to get up, but his leg was shaking badly and did not want to support his weight. He leaned against the hedge, gasping for breath, and looked around.
　　Nicolas was standing feet from the Triwizard Cup, which was gleaming behind him.
　　"Take it, then," Roberto panted to Nicolas. "Go on, take it. You're there."
　　But Nicolas didn't move. He merely stood there, looking at Roberto. Then he turned to stare at the cup. Roberto saw the longing expression on his face in its golden light.
　　Nicolas looked around at Roberto again, who was now holding onto the hedge to support himself. Nicolas took a deep breath.
　　"You take it. You should win. That's twice you've saved my neck in here."
　　"That's not how it's supposed to work," Roberto said. He felt angry; his leg was very painful, he was aching all over from trying to throw off the spider, and after all his efforts, Nicolas had beaten him to it, just as he'd beaten Roberto to ask Paula to the ball.
　　"The one who reaches the cup first gets the points. That's you. I'm telling you, I'm not going to win any races on this leg."
　　Nicolas took a few paces nearer to the Stunned spider, away from the cup, shaking his head.
　　"No," he said.
　　"Stop being noble," said Roberto irritably. "Just take it, then we can get out of here."
　　Nicolas watched Roberto steadying himself, holding tight to the hedge.
　　"You told me about the dragons," Nicolas said. "I would've gone down in the first task if you hadn't told me what was coming."
　　"I had help on that too," Roberto snapped, trying to mop up his bloody leg with his robes.
　　"You helped me with the egg - we're square."
　　"I had help on the egg in the first place," said Nicolas.
　　"We're still square," said Roberto, testing his leg gingerly; it shook violently as he put weight on it; he had sprained his ankle when the spider had dropped him.
　　"You should've got more points on the second task," said Nicolas mulishly. "You stayed behind to get all the hostages. I should've done that."
　　"I was the only one who was thick enough to take that song seriously!" said Roberto bitterly. "Just take the cup!"
　　"No," said Nicolas.
　　He stepped over the spider's tangled legs to join Roberto, who stared at him. Nicolas was serious. He was walking away from the sort of glory Hufflepuff House hadn't had in centuries.
　　"Go on," Nicolas said. He looked as though this was costing him every ounce of resolution he had, but his face was set, his arms were folded, he seemed decided.
　　Roberto looked from Nicolas to the cup. For one shining moment, he saw himself emerging from the maze, holding it. He saw himself holding the Triwizard Cup aloft, heard the roar of the crowd, saw Paula's face shining with admiration, more clearly than he had ever seen it before . . . and then the picture faded, and he found himself staring at Nicolas's shadowy, stubborn face.
　　"Both of us," Roberto said.
　　"What?"
　　"We'll take it at the same time. It's still a Hogwarts victory. We'll tie for it."
　　Nicolas stared at Roberto. He unfolded his arms.
　　"You - you sure?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto. "Yeah . . . we've helped each other out, haven't we? We both got here. Let's just take it together."
　　For a moment, Nicolas looked as though he couldn't believe his ears; then his face split in a grin.
　　"You're on," he said. "Come here."
　　He grabbed Robertos arm below the shoulder and helped Roberto limp toward the plinth where the cup stood. When they had reached it, they both held a hand out over one of the cup's gleaming handles.
　　"On three, right?" said Roberto. "One - two - three -"
　　He and Nicolas both grasped a handle.
　　Instantly, Roberto felt a jerk somewhere behind his navel. His feet had left the ground.
　　He could not unclench the hand holding the Triwizard Cup; it was pulling him onward in a howl of wind and swirling color, Nicolas at his side.
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-TWO - FLESH, BLOOD, AND BONE
　　Roberto felt his feet slam into the ground; his injured leg gave way, and he fell forward; his hand let go of the Triwizard Cup at last. He raised his head.
　　"Where are we?" he said.
　　Nicolas shook his head. He got up, pulled Roberto to his feet, and they looked around.
　　They had left the Hogwarts grounds completely; they had obviously traveled miles -perhaps hundreds of miles - for even the mountains surrounding the castle were gone.
　　They were standing instead in a dark and overgrown graveyard; the black outline of a small church was visible beyond a large yew tree to their right. A hill rose above them to their left. Roberto could just make out the outline of a fine old house on the hillside.
　　Nicolas looked down at the Triwizard Cup and then up at Roberto.
　　"Did anyone tell you the cup was a Portkey?" he asked.
　　"Nope," said Roberto. He was looking around the graveyard. It was completely silent and slightly eerie. "Is this supposed to be part of the task?"
　　"I dunno," said Nicolas. He sounded slightly nervous. "Wands out, d'you reckon?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, glad that Nicolas had made the suggestion rather than him.
　　They pulled out their wands. Roberto kept looking around him. He had, yet again, the
　　strange feeling that they were being watched.
　　"Someone's coming," he said suddenly.
　　Squinting tensely through the darkness, they watched the figure drawing nearer, walking steadily toward them between the graves. Roberto couldn't make out a face, but from the way it was walking and holding its arms, he could tell that it was carrying something.
　　Whoever it was, he was short, and wearing a hooded cloak pulled up over his head to obscure his face. And - several paces nearer, the gap between them closing all the time - Roberto saw that the thing in the persons arms looked like a baby ... or was it merely a bundle of robes?
　　Roberto lowered his wand slightly and glanced sideways at Nicolas. Nicolas shot him a quizzical look. They both turned back to watch the approaching figure.
　　It stopped beside a towering marble headstone, only six feet from them. For a second.
　　Roberto and Nicolas and the short figure simply looked at one another.
　　And then, without warning, Roberto's scar exploded with pain. It was agony such as he had never felt in all his life; his wand slipped from his fingers as he put his hands over his face; his knees buckled; he was on the ground and he could see nothing at all; his head was about to split open.
　　From far away, above his head, he heard a high, cold voice say, "Kill the spare."
　　A swishing noise and a second voice, which screeched the words to the night: "Avada Kedavra!"
　　A blast of green light blazed through Roberto's eyelids, and he heard something heavy fall to the ground beside him; the pain in his scar reached such a pitch that he retched, and then it diminished; terrified of what he was about to see, he opened his stinging eyes.
　　Nicolas was lying spread-eagled on the ground beside him. He was dead.
　　For a second that contained an eternity, Roberto stared into Nicolas's face, at his open gray eyes, blank and expressionless as the windows of a deserted house, at his half-open mouth, which looked slightly surprised. And then, before Roberto's mind had accepted what he was seeing, before he could feel anything but numb disbelief, he felt himself being pulled to his feet.
　　The short man in the cloak had put down his bundle, lit his wand, and was dragging Roberto toward the marble headstone. Roberto saw the name upon it flickering in the wandlight before he was forced around and slammed against it.
　　OSCAR CASTILLO The cloaked man was now conjuring tight cords around Roberto, tying him from neck to ankles to the headstone. Roberto could hear shallow, fast breathing from the depths of the hood; he struggled, and the man hit him - hit him with a hand that had a finger missing. And Roberto realized who was under the hood. It was Wormtail.
　　"You!" he gasped.
　　But Wormtail, who had finished conjuring the ropes, did not reply; he was busy checking the tightness of the cords, his fingers trembling uncontrollably, rumbling over the knots. Once sure that Roberto was bound so tightly to the headstone that he couldn't move an inch, Wormtail drew a length of some black material from the inside of his cloak and stuffed it roughly into Roberto's mouth; then, without a word, he turned from Roberto and hurried away. Roberto couldn't make a sound, nor could he see where Wormtail had gone; he couldn't turn his head to see beyond the headstone; he could see only what was right in front of him.
　　Nicolas's body was lying some twenty feet away. Some way beyond him, glinting in the starlight, lay the Triwizard Cup. Roberto's wand was on the ground at Nicolas's feet. The bundle of robes that Roberto had thought was a baby was close by, at the foot of the grave.
　　It seemed to be stirring fretfully. Roberto watched it, and his scar seared with pain again . . . and he suddenly knew that he didn't want to see what was in those robes ...
　　he didn't want that bundle opened....
　　He could hear noises at his feet. He looked down and saw a gigantic snake slithering through the grass, circling the headstone where he was tied. Wormtail's fast, wheezy breathing was growing louder again. It sounded as though he was forcing something heavy across the ground. Then he came back within Roberto's range of vision, and Roberto saw him pushing a stone cauldron to the foot of the grave. It was full of what seemed to be water - Roberto could hear it slopping around - and it was larger than any cauldron Roberto had ever used; a great stone belly large enough for a full-grown man to sit in.
　　The thing inside the bundle of robes on the ground was stirring more persistently, as though it was trying to free itself. Now Wormtail was busying himself at the bottom of the cauldron with a wand. Suddenly there were crackling names beneath it. The large snake slithered away into the darkness.
　　The liquid in the cauldron seemed to heat very fast. The surface began not only to bubble, but to send out fiery sparks, as though it were on fire. Steam was thickening, blurring the outline of Wormtail tending the fire. The movements beneath the robes became more agitated. And Roberto heard the high, cold voice again.
　　"Hurry!"
　　The whole surface of the water was alight with sparks now. It might have been encrusted with diamonds.
　　"It is ready. Master."
　　"Now ..." said the cold voice.
　　Wormtail pulled open the robes on the ground, revealing what was inside them, and Roberto let out a yell that was strangled in the wad of material blocking his mouth.
　　It was as though Wormtail had flipped over a stone and revealed something ugly, slimy, and blind - but worse, a hundred times worse. The thing Wormtail had been carrying had the shape of a crouched human child, except that Roberto had never seen anything less like a child. It was hairless and scaly-looking, a dark, raw, reddish black. Its arms and legs were thin and feeble, and its face - no child alive ever had a face like that - flat and snakelike, with gleaming red eyes.
　　The thing seemed almost helpless; it raised its thin arms, put them around Wormtail's neck, and Wormtail lifted it. As he did so, his hood fell back, and Roberto saw the look of revulsion on Wormtail's weak, pale face in the firelight as he carried the creature to the rim of the cauldron. For one moment, Roberto saw the evil, flat face illuminated in the sparks dancing on the surface of the potion. And then Wormtail lowered the creature into the cauldron; there was a hiss, and it vanished below the surface; Roberto heard its frail body hit the bottom with a soft thud.
　　Let it drown, Roberto thought, his scar burning almost past endurance, please. . . let it drown. . . .
　　Wormtail was speaking. His voice shook; he seemed frightened beyond his wits. He raised his wand, closed his eyes, and spoke to the night.
　　"Bone of the father, unknowingly given, you wil lrenew your son!"
　　The surface of the grave at Roberto's feet cracked. Horrified, Roberto watched as a fine trickle of dust rose into the air at Wormtail's command and fell softly into the cauldron. The diamond surface of the water broke and hissed; it sent sparks in all directions and turned a vivid, poisonous-looking blue.
　　And now Wormtail was whimpering. He pulled a long, thin, shining silver dagger from inside his cloak. His voice broke into petrified sobs.
　　"Flesh - of the servant - w-willingly given - you will - revive - your master. "
　　He stretched his right hand out in front of him - the hand with the missing finger. He gripped the dagger very tightly in his left hand and swung it upward.
　　Roberto realized what Wormtail was about to do a second before it happened - he closed his eyes as tightly as he could, but he could not block the scream that pierced the night, that went through Roberto as though he had been stabbed with the dagger too. He heard something fall to the ground, heard Wormtail's anguished panting, then a sickening splash, as something was dropped into the cauldron. Roberto couldn't stand to look . . .
　　but the potion had turned a burning red; the light of it shone through Roberto's closed eyelids. . . .
　　Wormtail was gasping and moaning with agony. Not until Roberto felt Wormtail's anguished breath on his face did he realize that Wormtail was right in front of him.
　　"B-blood of the enemy . . . forcibly taken .. . you will. . . resurrect your foe."
　　Roberto could do nothing to prevent it, he was tied too tightly. . .. Squinting down, struggling hopelessly at the ropes binding him, he saw the shining silver dagger shaking in Wormtails remaining hand. He felt its point penetrate the crook of his right arm and blood seeping down the sleeve of his torn robes. Wormtail, still panting with pain, rumbled in his pocket for a glass vial and held it to Roberto's cut, so that a dribble of blood fell into it.
　　He staggered back to the cauldron with Robertos blood. He poured it inside. The liquid within turned, instantly, a blinding white. Wormtail, his job done, dropped to his knees beside the cauldron, then slumped sideways and lay on the ground, cradling the bleeding
　　stump of his arm, gasping and sobbing.
　　The cauldron was simmering, sending its diamond sparks in all directions, so blindingly bright that it turned all else to velvety blackness. Nothing happened. . . .
　　Let it have drowned. Roberto thought, let it have gone wrong. . . ?
　　And then, suddenly, the sparks emanating from the cauldron were extinguished. A surge of white steam billowed thickly from the cauldron instead, obliterating everything in front of Roberto, so that he couldn't see Wormtail or Nicolas or anything but vapor hanging in the air. ... It's gone wrong, he thought. . . it's drowned. .. please . . . please let it be dead. ...
　　But then, through the mist in front of him, he saw, with an icy surge of terror, the dark outline of a man, tall and skeletally thin, rising slowly from inside the cauldron.
　　"Robe me," said the high, cold voice from behind the steam, and Wormtail, sobbing and moaning, still cradling his mutilated arm, scrambled to pick up the black robes from the ground, got to his feet, reached up, and pulled them one-handed over his master's head.
　　The thin man stepped out of the cauldron, staring at Roberto . . . and Roberto stared back into the face that had haunted his nightmares for three years. Whiter than a skull, with wide, livid scarlet eyes and a nose that was flat as a snakes with slits for nostrils . .
　　.
　　Lord Salvador had risen again.
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE - THE DEATH EATERS
　　Salvador looked away from Roberto and began examining his own body. His hands were like large, pale spiders; his long white fingers caressed his own chest, his arms, his face; the red eyes, whose pupils were slits, like a cats, gleamed still more brightly through the darkness. He held up his hands and flexed the fingers, his expression rapt and exultant. He took not the slightest notice of Wormtail, who lay twitching and bleeding on the ground, nor of the great snake, which had slithered back into sight and was circling Roberto again, hissing. Salvador slipped one of those unnaturally long-fingered hands into a deep pocket and drew out a wand. He caressed it gently too; and then he raised it, and pointed it at Wormtail, who was lifted off the ground and thrown against the headstone where Roberto was tied; he fell to the foot of it and lay there, crumpled up and crying. Salvador turned his scarlet eyes upon Roberto, laughing a high, cold, mirthless laugh.
　　Wormtail's robes were shining with blood now; he had wrapped the stump of his arm in them.
　　"My Lord . . ." he choked, "my Lord . . . you promised . . . you did promise ..."
　　"Hold out your arm," said Salvador lazily.
　　"Oh Master . . . thank you, Master ..."
　　He extended the bleeding stump, but Salvador laughed again.
　　"The other arm, Wormtail."
　　"Master, please . . .please ..."
　　Salvador bent down and pulled out Wormtail's left arm; he forced the sleeve of Wormtail's robes up past his elbow, and Roberto saw something upon the skin there, something like a vivid red tattoo - a skull with a snake protruding from its mouth - the image that had appeared in the sky at the Quidditch World Cup: the Dark Mark. Salvador examined it carefully, ignoring Wormtail's uncontrollable weeping.
　　"It is back," he said softly, "they will all have noticed it... and now, we shall see ...
　　now we shall know ..."
　　He pressed his long white forefinger to the brand on Wormtail's arm.
　　The scar on Roberto s forehead seared with a sharp pain again, and Wormtail let out a fresh howl; Salvador removed his fingers from Wormtail's mark, and Roberto saw that it had turned jet black.
　　A look of cruel satisfaction on his face, Salvador straightened up, threw back his head, and stared around at the dark graveyard.
　　"How many will be brave enough to return when they feel it?" he whispered, his gleaming red eyes fixed upon the stars. "And how many will be foolish enough to stay away?"
　　He began to pace up and down before Roberto and Wormtail, eyes sweeping the graveyard all the while. After a minute or so, he looked down at Roberto again, a cruel smile twisting his snakelike face.
　　"You stand, Roberto Gonzales, upon the remains of my late father," he hissed softly. "A
　　Muggle and a fool. . . very like your dear mother. But they both had their uses, did they not? Your mother died to defend you as a child . . . and I killed my father, and see how useful he has proved himself, in death. ..."
　　Salvador laughed again. Up and down he paced, looking all around him as he walked, and the snake continued to circle in the grass.
　　"You see that house upon the hillside, Gonzales? My father lived there. My mother, a witch who lived here in this village, fell in love with him. But he abandoned her when she told him what she was. ... He didn't like magic, my father . . .
　　"He left her and returned to his Muggle parents before I was even born. Gonzales, and she died giving birth to me, leaving me to be raised in a Muggle orphanage . . . but I vowed to find him ... I revenged myself upon him, that fool who gave me his name . . . Oscar Castillo. . . ."
　　Still he paced, his red eyes darting from grave to grave.
　　"Listen to me, reliving family history . . ." he said quietly, "why, I am growing quite sentimental. . . . But look, Roberto! My true family returns. . . ."
　　The air was suddenly full of the swishing of cloaks. Between graves, behind the yew tree, in every shadowy space, wizards were Apparating. All of them were hooded and masked. And one by one they moved forward . . . slowly, cautiously, as though they could hardly believe their eyes Salvador stood in silence, waiting for them. Then one of the Death Eaters fell to his knees, crawled toward Salvador and kissed the hem of his black robes.
　　Master . . . Master " he murmured.
　　The Death Eaters behind him did the same; each of them approaching Salvador on his knees and kissing his robes, before backing away and standing up, forming a silent circle, which enclosed Oscar Castillo s grave, Roberto, Salvador, and the sobbing and twitching heap that was Wormtail. Yet they left gaps in the circle, as though waiting for more people.
　　Salvador, however, did not seem to expect more. He looked around at the hooded faces, and though there was no wind rustling seemed to run around the circle, as though it had shivered.
　　"Welcome, Death Eaters," said Salvador quietly. "Thirteen years. . . thirteen years since last we met. Yet you answer my call as though it were yesterday, we are still united under the Dark Mark, then! Or are we?"
　　He put back his terrible face and sniffed, his slit-like nostrils widening.
　　"I smell guilt," he said. "There is a stench or guilt upon the air.
　　A second shiver ran around the circle, as though each member of it longed, but did not dare to step back from him.
　　"I see you all, whole and healthy, with your powers intact - such prompt appearances! and I ask myself . . . why did this band of wizards never come to the aid of their master, to whom they swore eternal loyalty?"
　　No one spoke. No one moved except Wormtail, who was upon the ground, still sobbing over his bleeding arm.
　　"And I answer myself," whispered Salvador, "they must have believed me broken, they thought I was gone. They slipped back among my enemies, and they pleaded innocence, and ignorance, and bewitchment. . . .
　　"And then I ask myself, but how could they have believed I would not rise again? They, who knew the steps I took, long ago, to guard myself against mortal death? They, who had seen proofs of the immensity of my power in the times when I was mightier than any wizard living?
　　"And I answer myself, perhaps they believed a still greater power could exist, one that could vanquish even Lord Salvador. . . perhaps they now pay allegiance to another . . .
　　perhaps that champion of commoners, of Mudbloods and Muggles, Alfonso Dominguez?"
　　At the mention of Dominguez's name, the members of the circle stirred, and some muttered and shook their heads. Salvador ignored them.
　　"It is a disappointment to me ... I confess myself disappointed. . . ."
　　One of the men suddenly flung himself forward, breaking the circle. Trembling from head to foot, he collapsed at Salvador's feet.
　　"Master!" he shrieked, "Master, forgive me! Forgive us all!"
　　Salvador began to laugh. He raised his wand.
　　"Crucio!"
　　The Death Eater on the ground writhed and shrieked; Roberto was sure the sound must carry to the houses around. . . . Let the police come, he thought desperately . . . anyone . ..
　　anything. . .
　　Salvador raised his wand. The tortured Death Eater lay flat upon the ground, gasping.
　　"Get up, Avery," said Salvador softly. "Stand up. You ask for forgiveness? I do not forgive. I do not forget. Thirteen long years ... I want thirteen years' repayment before I forgive you. Wormtail here has paid some of his debt already, have you not, Wormtail?"
　　He looked down at Wormtail, who continued to sob.
　　"You returned to me, not out of loyalty, but out of fear of your old friends. You deserve this pain, Wormtail. You know that, don't you?"
　　"Yes, Master," moaned Wormtail, "please. Master . . . please ..."
　　"Yet you helped return me to my body," said Salvador coolly, watching Wormtail sob on the ground. "Worthless and traitorous as you are, you helped me ... and Lord Salvador rewards his helpers... ."
　　Salvador raised his wand again and whirled it through the air. A streak of what looked like molten silver hung shining in the wand's wake. Momentarily shapeless, it writhed and then formed itself into a gleaming replica of a human hand, bright as moonlight, which soared downward and fixed itself upon Wormtails bleeding wrist.
　　Wormtail's sobbing stopped abruptly. His breathing harsh and ragged, he raised his head and stared in disbelief at the silver hand, now attached seamlessly to his arm, as though he were wearing a dazzling glove. He flexed the shining fingers, then, trembling, picked up a small twig on the ground and crushed it into powder.
　　"My Lord," he whispered. "Master ... it is beautiful. . . thank you... thank you. ..."
　　He scrambled forward on his knees and kissed the hem of Salvador's robes.
　　"May your loyalty never waver again, Wormtail," said Salvador.
　　"No, my Lord . . . never, my Lord . . ."
　　Wormtail stood up and took his place in the circle, staring at his powerful new hand, his face still shining with tears. Salvador now approached the man on Wormtail's right.
　　"Mariano, my slippery friend," he whispered, halting before him. "I am told that you have not renounced the old ways, though to the world you present a respectable face. You are still ready to take the lead in a spot of Muggle-torture, I believe? Yet you never tried to find me, Mariano. . . . Your exploits at the Quidditch World Cup were fun, I daresay. .
　　. but might not your energies have been better directed toward finding and aiding your master?"
　　"My Lord, I was constantly on the alert," came Mariano Sosa's voice swiftly from beneath the hood. "Had there been any sign from you, any whisper of your whereabouts, I would have been at your side immediately, nothing could have prevented me -"
　　"And yet you ran from my Mark, when a faithful Death Eater sent it into the sky last summer?" said Salvador lazily, and Mr. Sosa stopped talking abruptly. "Yes, I know all about that, Mariano. . . . You have disappointed me. ... I expect more faithful service in the future."
　　"Of course, my Lord, of course. . . . You are merciful, thank you. ..."
　　Salvador moved on, and stopped, staring at the space - large enough for two people -that separated Sosa and the next man.
　　"The Gimenezs should stand here," said Salvador quietly. "But they are entombed in Azkaban. They were faithful. They went to Azkaban rather than renounce me. . . . When Azkaban is broken open, the Gimenezs will be honored beyond their dreams. The dementors will join us ... they are our natural allies ... we will recall the banished giants ... I shall have all my devoted servants returned to me, and an army of creatures whom all fear. ..."
　　He walked on. Some of the Death Eaters he passed in silence, but he paused before others and spoke to them.
　　"Macnair . . . destroying dangerous beasts for the Ministry of Magic now, Wormtail tells me? You shall have better victims than that soon, Macnair. Lord Salvador will provide.
　　..."
　　"Thank you, Master . . . thank you," murmured Macnair.
　　"And here" - Salvador moved on to the two largest hooded figures - "we have Crabbe . . .
　　you will do better this time, will you not, Crabbe? And you, Goyle?"
　　They bowed clumsily, muttering dully.
　　"Yes, Master ..."
　　"We will, Master...."
　　"The same goes for you, Nott," said Salvador quietly as he walked past a stooped figure
　　in Mr. Goyles shadow.
　　"My Lord, I prostrate myself before you, I am your most faithful -"
　　"That will do," said Salvador.
　　He had reached the largest gap of all, and he stood surveying it with his blank, red eyes, as though he could see people standing there.
　　"And here we have six missing Death Eaters . . . three dead in my service. One, too cowardly to return ... he will pay. One, who I believe has left me forever ... he will be killed, of course . . . and one, who remains my most faithful servant, and who has already reentered my service."
　　The Death Eaters stirred, and Roberto saw their eyes dart sideways at one another through their masks.
　　"He is at Hogwarts, that faithful servant, and it was through his efforts that our young friend arrived here tonight. . . .
　　"Yes," said Salvador, a grin curling his lipless mouth as the eyes of the circle flashed in Roberto's direction. "Roberto Gonzales has kindly joined us for my rebirthing party. One might go so far as to call him my guest of honor."
　　There was a silence. Then the Death Eater to the right of Wormtail stepped forward, and Mariano Sosa's voice spoke from under the mask.
　　"Master, we crave to know ... we beg you to tell us ... how you have achieved this . . .
　　this miracle . . . how you managed to return to us. .. ."
　　"Ah, what a story it is, Mariano," said Salvador. "And it begins - and ends - with my young friend here."
　　He walked lazily over to stand next to Roberto, so that the eyes of the whole circle were upon the two of them. The snake continued to circle.
　　"You know, of course, that they have called this boy my downfall?" Salvador said softly, his red eyes upon Roberto, whose scar began to burn so fiercely that he almost screamed in agony. "You all know that on the night I lost my powers and my body, I tried to kill him. His mother died in the attempt to save him - and unwittingly provided him with a protection I admit I had not foreseen. ... I could not touch the boy."
　　Salvador raised one of his long white fingers and put it very close to Roberto's cheek.
　　"His mother left upon him the traces other sacrifice. . . . This is old magic, I should have remembered it, I was foolish to overlook it... but no matter. I can touch him now."
　　Roberto felt the cold tip of the long white finger touch him, and thought his head would burst with the pain. Salvador laughed softly in his ear, then took the finger away and continued addressing the Death Eaters.
　　"I miscalculated, my friends, I admit it. My curse was deflected by the woman's foolish sacrifice, and it rebounded upon myself. Aaah . . . pain beyond pain, my friends; nothing could have prepared me for it. I was ripped from my body, I was less than spirit, less than the meanest ghost. . . but still, I was alive. What I was, even I do not know... I, who have gone further than anybody along the path that leads to immortality. You know my goal - to conquer death. And now, I was tested, and it appeared that one or more of my experiments had worked ... for I had not been killed, though the curse should have done it. Nevertheless, I was as powerless as the weakest creature alive, and without the means to help myself... for I had no body, and every spell that might have helped me required the use of a wand. . . .
　　"I remember only forcing myself, sleeplessly, endlessly, second by second, to exist. ...
　　I settled in a faraway place, in a forest, and I waited. . . . Surely, one of my faithful Death Eaters would try and find me. . . one of them would come and perform the magic I could not, to restore me to a body . . , but I waited in vain. ..."
　　The shiver ran once more around the circle of listening Death Eaters. Salvador let the silence spiral horribly before continuing.
　　"Only one power remained to me. I could possess the bodies of others. But I dared not go where other humans were plentiful, for I knew that the Aurors were still abroad and searching for me.
　　I sometimes inhabited animals - snakes, of course, being my preference - but I was little better off inside them than as pure spirit, for their bodies were ill adapted to perform magic . . . and my possession of them shortened their lives; none of them lasted long. .
　　. .
　　"Then . . . four years ago . . . the means for my return seemed assured. A wizard -young, foolish, and gullible - wandered across my path in the forest I had made my home.
　　Oh, he seemed the very chance I had been dreaming of... for he was a teacher at
　　Dominguez's school... he was easy to bend to my will... he brought me back to this country, and after a while, I took possession of his body, to supervise him closely as he carried out my orders. But my plan failed. I did not manage to steal the Sorcerer's Stone. I was not to be assured immortal life. I was thwarted . . . thwarted, once again, by Roberto Gonzales. ..."
　　Silence once more; nothing was stirring, not even the leaves on the yew tree. The Death Eaters were quite motionless, the glittering eyes in their masks fixed upon Salvador, and upon Roberto.
　　"The servant died when I left his body, and I was left as weak as ever I had been,"
　　Salvador continued. "I returned to my hiding place far away, and I will not pretend to you that I didn't then fear that I might never regain my powers. . . . Yes, that was perhaps my darkest hour... I could not hope that I would be sent another wizard to possess . . . and I had given up hope, now, that any of my Death Eaters cared what had become of me. ..."
　　One or two of the masked wizards in the circle moved uncomfortably, but Salvador took no notice.
　　"And then, not even a year ago, when I had almost abandoned hope, it happened at last...
　　a servant returned to me. Wormtail here, who had faked his own death to escape justice, was driven out of hiding by those he had once counted friends, and decided to return to his master. He sought me in the country where it had long been rumored I was hiding . .
　　. helped, of course, by the rats he met along the way. Wormtail has a curious affinity with rats, do you not, Wormtail? His filthy little friends told him there was a place, deep in an Albanian forest, that they avoided, where small animals like themselves had met their deaths by a dark shadow that possessed them. . . .
　　"But his journey back to me was not smooth, was it, Wormtail? For, hungry one night, on the edge of the very forest where he had hoped to find me, he foolishly stopped at an inn for some food . . . and who should he meet there, but one Bertha Jorkins, a witch from the Ministry of Magic.
　　"Now see the way that fate favors Lord Salvador. This might have been the end of Wormtail, and of my last hope for regeneration. But Wormtail - displaying a presence of mind I would never have expected from him - convinced Bertha Jorkins to accompany him on a nighttime stroll. He overpowered her ... he brought her to me. And Bertha Jorkins, who might have ruined all, proved instead to be a gift beyond my wildest dreams ... for -with a little persuasion - she became a veritable mine of information.
　　"She told me that the Triwizard Tournament would be played at Hogwarts this year. She told me that she knew of a faithful Death Eater who would be only too willing to help me, if I could only contact him. She told me many things. . . but the means I used to break the Memory Charm upon her were powerful, and when I had extracted all useful information from her, her mind and body were both damaged beyond repair. She had now served her purpose. I could not possess her. I disposed of her."
　　Salvador smiled his terrible smile, his red eyes blank and pitiless.
　　"Wormtail's body, of course, was ill adapted for possession, as all assumed him dead, and would attract far too much attention if noticed. However, he was the able-bodied servant I needed, and, poor wizard though he is, Wormtail was able to follow the instructions I gave him, which would return me to a rudimentary, weak body of my own, a body I would be able to inhabit while awaiting the essential ingredients for true rebirth ... a spell or two of my own invention ... a little help from my dear Nagini," Salvadors red eyes fell upon the continually circling snake, "a potion concocted from unicorn blood, and the snake venom Nagini provided ... I was soon returned to an almost human form, and strong enough to travel.
　　"There was no hope of stealing the Sorcerer's Stone anymore, for I knew that Dominguez would have seen to it that it was destroyed. But I was willing to embrace mortal life again, before chasing immortality. I set my sights lower ... I would settle for my old body back again, and my old strength.
　　"I knew that to achieve this - it is an old piece of Dark Magic, the potion that revived me tonight - I would need three powerful ingredients. Well, one of them was already at hand, was it not, Wormtail? Flesh given by a servant. . . .
　　"My father's bone, naturally, meant that we would have to come here, where he was buried.
　　But the blood of a foe ... Wormtail would have had me use any wizard, would you not, Wormtail? Any wizard who had hated me ... as so many of them still do. But I knew the one I must use, if I was to rise again, more powerful than I had been when I had fallen.
　　I wanted Roberto Gonzaless blood. I wanted the blood of the one who had stripped me of power thirteen years ago . . . for the lingering protection his mother once gave him would then reside in my veins too. . . .
　　"But how to get at Roberto Gonzales? For he has been better protected than I think even he knows, protected in ways devised by Dominguez long ago, when it fell to him to arrange the boy's future. Dominguez invoked an ancient magic, to ensure the boy's protection as long as he is in his relations' care. Not even I can touch him there. . . . Then, of course, there was the Quidditch World Cup. ... I thought his protection might be weaker there, away from his relations and Dominguez, but I was not yet strong enough to attempt kidnap in the midst of a horde of Ministry wizards. And then, the boy would return to Hogwarts, where he is under the crooked nose of that Muggle-loving fool from morning until night. So how could I take him?
　　"Why ... by using Bertha Jorkins's information, of course. Use my one faithful Death Eater, stationed at Hogwarts, to ensure that the boy's name was entered into the Goblet of Fire. Use my Death Eater to ensure that the boy won the tournament - that he touched the Triwizard Cup first - the cup which my Death Eater had turned into a Portkey, which would bring him here, beyond the reach of Dominguez's help and protection, and into my waiting arms. And here he is ... the boy you all believed had been my downfall. ..."
　　Salvador moved slowly forward and turned to face Roberto. He raised his wand.
　　"Crucio!"
　　It was pain beyond anything Roberto had ever experienced; his very bones were on fire; his head was surely splitting along his scar; his eyes were rolling madly in his head; he wanted it to end ... to black out... to die ...
　　And then it was gone. He was hanging limply in the ropes binding him to the headstone of Salvador's father, looking up into those bright red eyes through a kind of mist. The night was ringing with the sound of the Death Eaters' laughter.
　　"You see, I think, how foolish it was to suppose that this boy could ever have been stronger than me," said Salvador. "But I want there to be no mistake in anybody's mind.
　　Roberto Gonzales escaped me by a lucky chance. And I am now going to prove my power by killing him, here and now, in front of you all, when there is no Dominguez to help him, and no mother to die for him. I will give him his chance. He will be allowed to fight, and you will be left in no doubt which of us is the stronger. Just a little longer, Nagini," he whispered, and the snake glided away through the grass to where the Death Eaters stood watching.
　　"Now untie him, Wormtail, and give him back his wand."
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-FOUR - PRIORI INCANTATEM
　　Wormtail approached Roberto, who scrambled to find his feet, to support his own weight before the ropes were untied. Wormtail raised his new silver hand, pulled out the wad of material gagging Roberto, and then, with one swipe, cut through the bonds tying Roberto to the gravestone.
　　There was a split second, perhaps, when Roberto might have considered running for it, but his injured leg shook under him as he stood on the overgrown grave, as the Death Eaters closed ranks, forming a tighter circle around him and Salvador, so that the gaps where the missing Death Eaters should have stood were filled. Wormtail walked out of the circle to the place where Nicolas's body lay and returned with Roberto's wand, which he thrust roughly into Roberto's hand without looking at him. Then Wormtail resumed his place in the circle of watching Death Eaters.
　　"You have been taught how to duel. Roberto Gonzales?" said Salvador softly, his red eyes glinting through the darkness.
　　At these words Roberto remembered, as though from a former life, the dueling club at Hogwarts he had attended briefly two years ago. ... All he had learned there was the Disarming Spell, "Expelliarmus". . . and what use would it be to deprive Salvador of his wand, even if he could, when he was surrounded by Death Eaters, outnumbered by at least thirty to one? He had never learned anything that could possibly fit him for this. He knew he was facing the thing against which Acosta had always warned . . . the unblockable Avada Kedavra curse - and Salvador was right - his mother was not here to die for him this time. ... He was quite unprotected. . . .
　　"We bow to each other. Roberto," said Salvador, bending a little, but keeping his snakelike face upturned to Roberto. "Come, the niceties must be observed. . . . Dominguez
　　would like you to show manners. . . . Bow to death, Roberto. ..."
　　The Death Eaters were laughing again. Salvadors lipless mouth was smiling. Roberto did not bow. He was not going to let Salvador play with him before killing him ... he was not going to give him that satisfaction. . . .
　　"I said, bow," Salvador said, raising his wand - and Roberto felt his spine curve as though a huge, invisible hand were bending him ruthlessly forward, and the Death Eaters laughed harder than ever.
　　"Very good," said Salvador softly, and as he raised his wand the pressure bearing down upon Roberto lifted too. "And now you face me, like a man . . . straight-backed and proud, the way your father died. . . .
　　"And now - we duel."
　　Salvador raised his wand, and before Roberto could do anything to defend himself, before he could even move, he had been hit again by the Cruciatus Curse. The pain was so intense, so all-consuming, that he no longer knew where he was. . . . White-hot knives were piercing every inch of his skin, his head was surely going to burst with pain, he was screaming more loudly than he'd ever screamed in his life -And then it stopped. Roberto rolled over and scrambled to his feet; he was shaking as uncontrollably as Wormtail had done when his hand had been cut off; he staggered sideways into the wall of watching Death Eaters, and they pushed him away, back toward Salvador.
　　"A little break," said Salvador, the slit-like nostrils dilating with excitement, "a little pause . . . That hurt, didn't it. Roberto? You don't want me to do that again, do you?"
　　Roberto didn't answer. He was going to die like Nicolas, those pitiless red eyes were telling him so ... he was going to die, and there was nothing he could do about it... but he wasn't going to play along. He wasn't going to obey Salvador... he wasn't going to beg. . . .
　　"I asked you whether you want me to do that again," said Salvador softly. "Answer me!
　　Imperial"
　　And Roberto felt, for the third time in his life, the sensation that his mind had been wiped of all thought. . . . Ah, it was bliss, not to think, it was as though he were floating, dreaming ...just answer no ... say no ... just answer no. .. .
　　I will not, said a stronger voice, in the back of his head, I won't answer. . . .
　　Just answer no. . . .
　　I won't do it, I won't say it. ...
　　Just answer no. . . .
　　"I WON'T!"
　　And these words burst from Roberto's mouth; they echoed through the graveyard, and the dream state was lifted as suddenly as though cold water had been thrown over him - back rushed the aches that the Cruciatus Curse had left all over his body - back rushed the realization of where he was, and what he was facing. . . .
　　"You won't?" said Salvador quietly, and the Death Eaters were not laughing now. "You won't say no? Roberto, obedience is a virtue I need to teach you before you die. . . .
　　Perhaps another little dose of pain?"
　　Salvador raised his wand, but this time Roberto was ready; with the reflexes born of his Quidditch training, he flung himself sideways onto the ground; he rolled behind the marble headstone of Salvador s father, and he heard it crack as the curse missed him.
　　"We are not playing hide-and-seek, Roberto," said Salvador's soft, cold voice, drawing nearer, as the Death Eaters laughed. "You cannot hide from me. Does this mean you are tired of our duel? Does this mean that you would prefer me to finish it now, Roberto?
　　Come out, Roberto . . . come out and play, then ... it will be quick ... it might even be painless ... I would not know... I have never died. . . ."
　　Roberto crouched behind the headstone and knew the end had come. There was no hope ... no help to be had. And as he heard Salvador draw nearer still, he knew one thing only, and it was beyond fear or reason: He was not going to die crouching here like a child playing hide-and-seek; he was not going to die kneeling at Salvador s feet... he was going to die upright like his father, and he was going to die trying to defend himself, even if no defense was possible. . . .
　　Before Salvador could stick his snakelike face around the headstone. Roberto stood up ...
　　he gripped his wand tightly in his hand, thrust it out in front of him, and threw himself around the headstone, facing Salvador.
　　Salvador was ready. As Roberto shouted, "Expelliarmus!" Salvador cried, "Avada Kedavra!"
　　A jet of green light issued from Salvadors wand just as a jet of red light blasted from Roberto's - they met in midair - and suddenly Roberto's wand was vibrating as though an electric charge were surging through it; his hand seized up around it; he couldn't have released it if he'd wanted to - and a narrow beam of light connected the two wands, neither red nor green, but bright, deep gold. Roberto, following the beam with his astonished gaze, saw that Salvador's long white fingers too were gripping a wand that was shaking and vibrating.
　　And then - nothing could have prepared Roberto for this - he felt his feet lift from the ground. He and Salvador were both being raised into the air, their wands still connected by that thread of shimmering golden light. They glided away from the tombstone of Salvador's father and then came to rest on a patch of ground that was clear and free of graves. . . . The Death Eaters were shouting; they were asking Salvador for instructions; they were closing in, reforming the circle around Roberto and Salvador, the snake slithering at their heels, some of them drawing their wands -The golden thread connecting Roberto and Salvador splintered; though the wands remained connected, a thousand more beams arced high over Roberto and Salvador, crisscrossing all around them, until they were enclosed in a golden, dome-shaped web, a cage of light, beyond which the Death Eaters circled like jackals, their cries strangely muffled now. . . .
　　"Do nothing!" Salvador shrieked to the Death Eaters, and Roberto saw his red eyes wide with astonishment at what was happening, saw him fighting to break the thread of light still connecting his wand with Roberto's; Roberto held onto his wand more tightly, with both hands, and the golden thread remained unbroken. "Do nothing unless I command you!"
　　Salvador shouted to the Death Eaters.
　　And then an unearthly and beautiful sound filled the air. ... It was coming from every thread of the light-spun web vibrating around Roberto and Salvador. It was a sound Roberto recognized, though he had heard it only once before in his life: phoenix song.
　　It was the sound of hope to Roberto. . . the most beautiful and welcome thing he had ever heard in his life. . . . He felt as though the song were inside him instead of just around him. ... It was the sound he connected with Dominguez, and it was almost as though a friend were speaking in his ear. . . .
　　Don't break the connection.
　　I know. Roberto told the music, I know I mustn't. . . but no sooner had he thought it, than the thing became much harder to do. His wand began to vibrate more powerfully than ever . . . and now the beam between him and Salvador changed too ... it was as though large beads of light were sliding up and down the thread connecting the wands - Roberto felt his wand give a shudder under his hand as the light beads began to slide slowly and steadily his way. . . . The direction of the beams movement was now toward him, from Salvador, and he felt his wand shudder angrily. . . .
　　As the closest bead of light moved nearer to Robertos wand tip, the wood beneath his fingers grew so hot he feared it would burst into flame. The closer that bead moved, the harder Roberto's wand vibrated; he was sure his wand would not survive contact with it; it felt as though it was about to shatter under his fingers -He concentrated every last particle of his mind upon forcing the bead back toward Salvador, his ears full of phoenix song, his eyes furious, fixed . . . and slowly, very slowly, the beads quivered to a halt, and then, just as slowly, they began to move the other way . . . and it was Salvador's wand that was vibrating extra-hard now . . .
　　Salvador who looked astonished, and almost fearful. . . .
　　One of the beads of light was quivering, inches from the tip of Salvadors wand. Roberto didn't understand why he was doing it, didn't know what it might achieve . . . but he now concentrated as he had never done in his life on forcing that bead of light right back into Salvador s wand . . . and slowly . . . very slowly ... it moved along the golden thread ... it trembled for a moment. . . and then it connected. . . .
　　At once, Salvadors wand began to emit echoing screams of pain . . . then - Salvador's red eyes widened with shock - a dense, smoky hand flew out of the tip of it and vanished . . . the ghost of the hand he had made Wormtail. . . more shouts of pain . . . and then something much larger began to blossom from Salvadors wand tip, a great, grayish something, that looked as though it were made of the solidest, densest smoke. ... It was a head . . . now a chest and arms . . . the torso of Nicolas Ortega.
　　If ever Roberto might have released his wand from shock, it would have been then, but instinct kept him clutching his wand tightly, so that the thread of golden light remained
　　unbroken, even though the thick gray ghost of Nicolas Ortega (was it a ghost? it looked so solid) emerged in its entirety from the end of Salvador s wand, as though it were squeezing itself out of a very narrow tunnel. . . and this shade of Nicolas stood up, and looked up and down the golden thread of light, and spoke.
　　"Hold on. Roberto," it said.
　　Its voice was distant and echoing. Roberto looked at Salvador ... his wide red eyes were still shocked ... he had no more expected this than Roberto had . . . and, very dimly.
　　Roberto heard the frightened yells of the Death Eaters, prowling around the edges of the golden dome. .
　　More screams of pain from the wand . . . and then something else emerged from its tip ...
　　the dense shadow of a second head, quickly followed by arms and torso ... an old man Roberto had seen only in a dream was now pushing himself out of the end of the wand just as Nicolas had done . . . and his ghost, or his shadow, or whatever it was, fell next to Nicolas's, and surveyed Roberto and Salvador, and the golden web, and the connected wands, with mild surprise, leaning on his walking stick. . . .
　　"He was a real wizard, then?" the old man said, his eyes on Salvador. "Killed me, that one did. . . . You fight him, boy. . . ."
　　But already, yet another head was emerging ... and this head, gray as a smoky statue, was a woman's. . . . Roberto, both arms shaking now as he fought to keep his wand still, saw her drop to the ground and straighten up like the others, staring. . . .
　　The shadow of Bertha Jorkins surveyed the battle before her with wide eyes.
　　"Don't let go, now!" she cried, and her voice echoed like Nicolass as though from very far away. "Don't let him get you, Roberto - don't let go!"
　　She and the other two shadowy figures began to pace around the inner walls of the golden web, while the Death Eaters flitted around the outside of it... and Salvador's dead victims whispered as they circled the duelers, whispered words of encouragement to Roberto, and hissed words Roberto couldn't hear to Salvador.
　　And now another head was emerging from the tip of Salvadors wand . . . and Roberto knew when he saw it who it would be ... he knew, as though he had expected it from the moment when Nicolas had appeared from the wand . . . knew, because the man appearing was the one he'd thought of more than any other tonight. . . .
　　The smoky shadow of a tall man with untidy hair fell to the ground as Bertha had done, straightened up, and looked at him . . . and Roberto, his arms shaking madly now, looked back into the ghostly face of his father.
　　"Your mother's coming . . ." he said quietly. "She wants to see you ... it will be all right.. . hold on. . . ."
　　And she came. . . first her head, then her body... a young woman with long hair, the smoky, shadowy form of Sofia Gonzales blossomed from the end of Salvador's wand, fell to the ground, and straightened like her husband. She walked close to Roberto, looking down at him, and she spoke in the same distant, echoing voice as the others, but quietly, so that Salvador, his face now livid with fear as his victims prowled around him, could not hear. . ..
　　"When the connection is broken, we will linger for only moments . . . but we will give you time. . . you must get to the Portkey, it will return you to Hogwarts ... do you understand, Roberto?"
　　"Yes," Roberto gasped, fighting now to keep a hold on his wand, which was slipping and sliding beneath his fingers.
　　"Roberto . . ." whispered the figure of Nicolas, "take my body back, will you? Take my body back to my parents, ..."
　　"I will," said Roberto, his face screwed up with the effort of holding the wand.
　　"Do it now," whispered his father's voice, "be ready to run . . . do it now. ..."
　　"NOW!" Roberto yelled; he didn't think he could have held on for another moment anyway -he pulled his wand upward with an almighty wrench, and the golden thread broke; the cage of light vanished, the phoenix song died - but the shadowy figures of Salvador's victims did not disappear - they were closing in upon Salvador, shielding Roberto from his gaze -And Roberto ran as he had never run in his life, knocking two stunned Death Eaters aside as he passed; he zigzagged behind headstones, feeling their curses following him, hearing them hit the headstones - he was dodging curses and graves, pelting toward Nicolas's body, no longer aware of the pain in his leg, his whole being concentrated on what he had to do -
　　"Stun him!" he heard Salvador scream.
　　Ten feet from Nicolas, Roberto dived behind a marble angel to avoid the jets of red light and saw the tip of its wing shatter as the spells hit it. Gripping his wand more tightly, he dashed out from behind the angel -"
　　Impedimenta!" he bellowed, pointing his wand wildly over his shoulder at the Death Eaters running at him.
　　From a muffled yell, he thought he had stopped at least one of them, but there was no time to stop and look; he jumped over the cup and dived as he heard more wand blasts behind him; more jets of light flew over his head as he fell, stretching out his hand to grab Nicolas's arm...
　　"Stand aside! I will kill him! He is mine!" shrieked Salvador. Roberto's hand had closed on Nicolas's wrist; one tombstone stood between him and Salvador, but Nicolas was too heavy to carry, and the cup was out of reach -Salvador's red eyes flamed in the darkness. Roberto saw his mouth curl into a smile, saw him raise his wand.
　　"Accio!" Roberto yelled, pointing his wand at the Triwizard Cup. It flew into the air and soared toward him. Roberto caught it by the handle -He heard Salvador s scream of fury at the same moment that he felt the jerk behind his navel that meant the Portkey had worked - it was speeding him away in a whirl of wind and color, and Nicolas along with him. . . . They were going back.
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-FIVE - VERITASERUM
　　Roberto felt himself slam flat into the ground; his face was pressed into grass; the smell of it filled his nostrils. He had closed his eyes while the Portkey transported him, and he kept them closed now. He did not move. All the breath seemed to have been knocked out of him; his head was swimming so badly he felt as though the ground beneath him were swaying like the deck of a ship. To hold himself steady, he tightened his hold on the two things he was still clutching: the smooth, cold handle of the Triwizard Cup and Nicolas's body. He felt as though he would slide away into the blackness gathering at the edges of his brain if he let go of either of them. Shock and exhaustion kept him on the ground, breathing in the smell of the grass, waiting . . . waiting for someone to do something . . . something to happen . . . and all the while, his scar burned dully on his forehead. . . .
　　A torrent of sound deafened and confused him; there were voices everywhere, footsteps, screams. ... He remained where he was, his face screwed up against the noise, as though it were a nightmare that would pass. . . .
　　Then a pair of hands seized him roughly and turned him over.
　　"Roberto! Roberto!"
　　He opened his eyes.
　　He was looking up at the starry sky, and Alfonso Dominguez was crouched over him. The dark shadows of a crowd of people pressed in around them, pushing nearer; Roberto felt the ground beneath his head reverberating with their footsteps.
　　He had come back to the edge of the maze. He could see the stands rising above him, the shapes of people moving in them, the stars above.
　　Roberto let go of the cup, but he clutched Nicolas to him even more tightly. He raised his free hand and seized Dominguez's wrist, while Dominguez's face swam in and out of focus.
　　"He's back," Roberto whispered. "He's back. Salvador."
　　"What's going on? What's happened?"
　　The face of Cornelius Fudge appeared upside down over Roberto; it looked white, appalled.
　　"My God - Ortega!" it whispered. "Dominguez - he's dead!"
　　The words were repeated, the shadowy figures pressing in on them gasped it to those around them . . . and then others shouted it - screeched it - into the night - "He's dead!" "He's dead!" "Nicolas Ortega! Dead!"
　　"Roberto, let go of him," he heard Fudge's voice say, and he felt fingers trying to pry him from Nicolas's limp body, but Roberto wouldn't let him go. Then Dominguez's face, which was still blurred and misted, came closer.
　　"Roberto, you can't help him now. It's over. Let go."
　　"He wanted me to bring him back," Roberto muttered - it seemed important to explain this.
　　"He wanted me to bring him back to his parents. ..."
　　"That's right. Roberto . . . just let go now. . . ."
　　Dominguez bent down, and with extraordinary strength for a man so old and thin, raised Roberto from the ground and set -him on his feet. Roberto swayed. His head was pounding.
　　His injured leg would no longer support his weight. The crowd around them jostled, fighting to get closer, pressing darkly in on him - "What's happened?" "What's wrong with him?" "Ortegas dead!"
　　"He'll need to go to the hospital wing!" Fudge was saying loudly. "He's ill, he's injured - Dominguez, Ortega's parents, they're here, they're in the stands. ..."
　　"I'll take Roberto, Dominguez, I'll take him -"
　　"No, I would prefer-"
　　"Dominguez, Amos Ortegas running . . . he's coming over. . . . Don't you think you should tell him - before he sees - ?"
　　"Roberto, stay here -"
　　Girls were screaming, sobbing hysterically.... The scene flickered oddly before Roberto's eyes. . . .
　　"Its all right, son, I've got you . . . come on ... hospital wing . . ."
　　"Dominguez said stay," said Roberto thickly, the pounding in his scar making him feel as though he was about to throw up; his vision was blurring worse than ever.
　　"You need to lie down. . .. Come on now...."
　　Someone larger and stronger than he was was half pulling, half carrying him through the frightened crowd. Roberto heard people gasping, screaming, and shouting as the man supporting him pushed a path through them, taking him back to the castle. Across the lawn, past the lake and the Durmstrang ship, Roberto heard nothing but the heavy breathing of the man helping him walk.
　　"What happened. Roberto?" the man asked at last as he lifted Roberto up the stone steps.
　　Clunk. Clunk. Clunk. It was Mad-Eye Acosta.
　　"Cup was a Portkey," said Roberto as they crossed the entrance hall. "Took me and Nicolas to a graveyard . . . and Salvador was there . . . Lord Salvador..."
　　Clunk. Clunk. Clunk. Up the marble stairs . . .
　　"The Dark Lord was there? What happened then?"
　　"Killed Nicolas . . . they killed Nicolas. . . ."
　　"And then?"
　　Clunk. Clunk. Clunk. Along the corridor . . .
　　"Made a potion . . . got his body back. . . ."
　　"The Dark Lord got his body back? He's returned?"
　　"And the Death Eaters came . . . and then we dueled. ..."
　　"You dueled with the Dark Lord?"
　　"Got away . . . my wand . . . did something funny. ... I saw my mum and dad . . . they came out of his wand. ..."
　　"In here. Roberto ... in here, and sit down. . . . You'll be all right now . . . drink this. ..."
　　Roberto heard a key scrape in a lock and felt a cup being pushed into his hands.
　　"Drink it... you'll feel better . . . come on, now. Roberto, I need to know exactly what happened. ..."
　　Acosta helped tip the stuff down Robertos throat; he coughed, a peppery taste burning his throat. Acosta's office came into sharper focus, and so did Acosta himself. ... He looked as white as Fudge had looked, and both eyes were fixed unblinkingly upon Roberto's face.
　　"Salvador's back, Roberto? You're sure he's back? How did he do it?"
　　"He took stuff from his father's grave, and from Wormtail, and me," said Roberto. His head felt clearer; his scar wasn't hurting so badly; he could now see Acostas face distinctly, even though the office was dark. He could still hear screaming and shouting from the distant Quidditch field.
　　"What did the Dark Lord take from you?" said Acosta.
　　"Blood," said Roberto, raising his arm. His sleeve was ripped where Wormtail's dagger had torn it.
　　Acosta let out his breath in a long, low hiss.
　　"And the Death Eaters? They returned?"
　　"Yes," said Roberto. "Loads of them . . ."
　　"How did he treat them?" Acosta asked quietly. "Did he forgive them?"
　　But Roberto had suddenly remembered. He should have told Dominguez, he should have said it straightaway -
　　"There's a Death Eater at Hogwarts! There's a Death Eater here - they put my name in the Goblet of Fire, they made sure I got through to the end -"
　　Roberto tried to get up, but Acosta pushed him back down.
　　"I know who the Death Eater is," he said quietly.
　　"Morales?" said Roberto wildly. "Where is he? Have you got him? Is he locked up?"
　　"Morales?" said Acosta with an odd laugh. "Morales fled tonight, when he felt the Dark Mark burn upon his arm. He betrayed too many faithful supporters of the Dark Lord to wish to meet them . . . but I doubt he will get far. The Dark Lord has ways of tracking his enemies."
　　"Morales's gone? He ran away? But then - he didn't put my name in the goblet?"
　　"No," said Acosta slowly. "No, he didn't. It was I who did that."
　　Roberto heard, but didn't believe.
　　"No, you didn't," he said. "You didn't do that. . . you can't have done..."
　　"I assure you I did," said Acosta, and his magical eye swung around and fixed upon the door, and Roberto knew he was making sure that there was no one outside it. At the same time, Acosta drew out his wand and pointed it at Roberto.
　　"He forgave them, then?" he said. "The Death Eaters who went free? The ones who escaped Azkaban?"
　　"What?" said Roberto.
　　He was looking at the wand Acosta was pointing at him. This was a bad joke, it had to be.
　　"I asked you," said Acosta quietly, "whether he forgave the scum who never even went to look for him. Those treacherous cowards who wouldn't even brave Azkaban for him. The faithless, worthless bits of filth who were brave enough to cavort in masks at the Quidditch World Cup, but fled at the sight of the Dark Mark when I fired it into the sky."
　　"You fired . . . What are you talking about. . . ?"
　　"I told you. Roberto ... I told you. If there's one thing I hate more than any other, it's a Death Eater who walked free. They turned their backs on my master when he needed them most. I expected him to punish them. I expected him to torture them. Tell me he hurt them, Roberto. . . ." Acosta's face was suddenly lit with an insane smile. "Tell me he told them that I, I alone remained faithful... prepared to risk everything to deliver to him the one thing he wanted above all... you"
　　"You didn't... it - it can't be you. ..."
　　"Who put your name in the Goblet of Fire, under the name of a different school? I did.
　　Who frightened off every person I thought might try to hurt you or prevent you from winning the tournament? I did. Who nudged Villalba into showing you the dragons? I did.
　　Who helped you see the only way you could beat the dragon? I did"
　　Acosta's magical eye had now left the door. It was fixed upon Roberto. His lopsided mouth leered more widely than ever.
　　"It hasn't been easy, Roberto, guiding you through these tasks without arousing suspicion.
　　I have had to use every ounce of cunning I possess, so that my hand would not be detectable in your success. Dominguez would have been very suspicious if you had managed everything too easily. As long as you got into that maze, preferably with a decent head start - then, I knew, I would have a chance of getting rid of the other champions and leaving your way clear. But I also had to contend with your stupidity.
　　The second task . . . that was when I was most afraid we would fail. I was keeping watch on you, Gonzales. I knew you hadn't worked out the egg's clue, so I had to give you another hint -"
　　"You didn't," Roberto said hoarsely. "Nicolas gave me the clue -"
　　"Who told Nicolas to open it underwater? I did. I trusted that he would pass the information on to you. Decent people are so easy to manipulate, Gonzales. I was sure Nicolas would want to repay you for telling him about the dragons, and so he did. But even then, Gonzales, even then you seemed likely to fail. I was watching all the time ... all those hours in the library. Didn't you realize that the book you needed was in your dormitory all along? I planted it there early on, I gave it to the Silva boy, don't you remember? Magical Water Plants of the Mediterranean. It would have told you all you needed to know about gillyweed. I expected you to ask everyone and anyone you could for help. Silva would have told you in an instant. But you did not. . . you did not. .
　　. . You have a streak of pride and independence that might have ruined all.
　　"So what could I do? Feed you information from another innocent source. You told me at
　　the Yule Ball a house-elf called Dobby had given you a Christmas present. I called the elf to the staffroom to collect some robes for cleaning. I staged a loud conversation with Professor Romero about the hostages who had been taken, and whether Gonzales would think to use gillyweed. And your little elf friend ran straight to Peralta's office and then hurried to find you..."
　　Acostas wand was still pointing directly at Roberto's heart. Over his shoulder, foggy shapes were moving in the Foe-Glass on the wall.
　　"You were so long in that lake, Gonzales, I thought you had drowned. But luckily, Dominguez took your idiocy for nobility, and marked you high for it. I breathed again.
　　"You had an easier time of it than you should have in that maze tonight, of course," said Acosta. "I was patrolling around it, able to see through the outer hedges, able to curse many obstacles out of your way. I Stunned Camila Saenz as she passed. I put the Imperius Curse on Krum, so that he would finish Ortega and leave your path to the cup clear."
　　Roberto stared at Acosta. He just didn't see how this could be. ... Dominguez's friend, the famous Auror. . . the one who had caught so many Death Eaters ... It made no sense ... no sense at all. ...
　　The foggy shapes in the Foe-Glass were sharpening, had become more distinct. Roberto could see the outlines of three people over Acosta's shoulder, moving closer and closer. But Acosta wasn't watching them. His magical eye was upon Roberto.
　　"The Dark Lord didn't manage to kill you. Gonzales, and he so wanted to," whispered Acosta.
　　"Imagine how he will reward me when he finds I have done it for him. I gave you to him -the thing he needed above all to regenerate - and then I killed you for him. I will be honored beyond all other Death Eaters. I will be his dearest, his closest supporter . .
　　. closer than a son. ..."
　　Acosta's normal eye was bulging, the magical eye fixed upon Roberto. The door was barred, and Roberto knew he would never reach his own wand in time. . . .
　　"The Dark Lord and I," said Acosta, and he looked completely insane now, towering over Roberto, leering down at him, "have much in common. Both of us, for instance, had very disappointing fathers . . . very disappointing indeed. Both of us suffered the indignity, Roberto, of being named after those fathers. And both of us had the pleasure .
　　. . the very great pleasure ... of killing our fathers to ensure the continued rise of the Dark Order!"
　　"You're mad," Roberto said - he couldn't stop himself- "you're mad!"
　　"Mad, am I?" said Acosta, his voice rising uncontrollably. "We'll see! We'll see who's mad, now that the Dark Lord has returned, with me at his side! He is back, Roberto Gonzales, you did not conquer him - and now - I conquer you!"
　　Acosta raised his wand, he opened his mouth; Roberto plunged his own hand into his robes -"
　　Stupefy!" There was a blinding flash of red light, and with a great splintering and crashing, the door of Acosta's office was blasted apart -Acosta was thrown backward onto the office floor. Roberto, still staring at the place where Acosta's face had been, saw Alfonso Dominguez, Professor Peralta, and Professor Romero looking back at him out of the Foe-Glass. He looked around and saw the three of them standing in the doorway, Dominguez in front, his wand outstretched.
　　At that moment, Roberto fully understood for the first time why people said Dominguez was the only wizard Salvador had ever feared. The look upon Dominguez's face as he stared down at the unconscious form of Mad-Eye Acosta was more terrible than Roberto could have ever imagined. There was no benign smile upon Dominguez's face, no twinkle in the eyes behind the spectacles. There was cold fury in every line of the ancient face; a sense of power radiated from Dominguez as though he were giving off burning heat.
　　He stepped into the office, placed a foot underneath Acostas unconscious body, and kicked him over onto his back, so that his face was visible. Peralta followed him, looking into the Foe-Glass, where his own face was still visible, glaring into the room. Professor Romero went straight to Roberto.
　　"Come along, Gonzales," she whispered. The thin line of her mouth was twitching as though she was about to cry. "Come along . . . hospital wing ..."
　　"No," said Dominguez sharply.
