　　"Dominguez, he ought to - look at him - he's been through enough tonight -"
　　"He will stay, Elena, because he needs to understand," said Dominguez curtly.
　　"Understanding is the first step to acceptance, and only with acceptance can there be recovery. He needs to know who has put him through the ordeal he has suffered tonight,
　　and why,"
　　"Acosta," Roberto said. He was still in a state of complete disbelief. "How can it have been Acosta?"
　　"This is not Alastor Acosta," said Dominguez quietly. "You have never known Alastor Acosta. The real Acosta would not have removed you from my sight after what happened tonight. The moment he took you, I knew - and I followed."
　　Dominguez bent down over Acosta's limp form and put a hand inside his robes. He pulled out Acosta's hip flask and a set of keys on a ring. Then he turned to Professors Romero and Peralta.
　　"Carlos, please fetch me the strongest Truth Potion you possess, and then go down to the kitchens and bring up the house-elf called Winky. Elena, kindly go down to Villalba's house, where you will find a large black dog sitting in the pumpkin patch. Take the dog up to my office, tell him I will be with him shortly, then come back here."
　　If either Peralta or Romero found these instructions peculiar, they hid their confusion. Both turned at once and left the office. Dominguez walked over to the trunk with seven locks, fitted the first key in the lock, and opened it. It contained a mass of spell-books. Dominguez closed the trunk, placed a second key in the second lock, and opened the trunk again. The spellbooks had vanished; this time it contained an assortment of broken Sneako-scopes, some parchment and quills, and what looked like a silvery Invisibility Cloak. Roberto watched, astounded, as Dominguez placed the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth keys in their respective locks, reopening the trunk each time, and revealing different contents each time. Then he placed the seventh key in the lock, threw open the lid, and Roberto let out a cry of amazement.
　　He was looking down into a kind of pit, an underground room, and lying on the floor some ten feet below, apparently fast asleep, thin and starved in appearance, was the real Mad-Eye Acosta. His wooden leg was gone, the socket that should have held the magical eye looked empty beneath its lid, and chunks of his grizzled hair were missing. Roberto stared, thunderstruck, between the sleeping Acosta in the trunk and the unconscious Acosta lying on the floor of the office.
　　Dominguez climbed into the trunk, lowered himself, and fell lightly onto the floor beside the sleeping Acosta. He bent over him.
　　"Stunned - controlled by the Imperius Curse - very weak," he said. "Of course, they would have needed to keep him alive. Roberto, throw down the imposter's cloak - he's freezing. Madam Pomfrey will need to see him, but he seems in no immediate danger."
　　Roberto did as he was told; Dominguez covered Acosta in the cloak, tucked it around him, and clambered out of the trunk again. Then he picked up the hip flask that stood upon the desk, unscrewed it, and turned it over. A thick glutinous liquid splattered onto the office floor.
　　"Polyjuice Potion, Roberto," said Dominguez. "You see the simplicity of it, and the brilliance. For Acosta never does drink except from his hip flask, he's well known for it. The imposter needed, of course, to keep the real Acosta close by, so that he could continue making the potion. You see his hair ..." Dominguez looked down on the Acosta in the trunk. "The imposter has been cutting it off all year, see where it is uneven?
　　But I think, in the excitement of tonight, our fake Acosta might have forgotten to take it as frequendy as he should have done ... on the hour . . . every hour. . . . We shall see."
　　Dominguez pulled out the chair at the desk and sat down upon it, his eyes fixed upon the unconscious Acosta on the floor. Roberto stared at him too. Minutes passed in silence... .
　　Then, before Roberto's very eyes, the face of the man on the floor began to change. The scars were disappearing, the skin was becoming smooth; the mangled nose became whole and started to shrink. The long mane of grizzled gray hair was withdrawing into the scalp and turning the color of straw. Suddenly, with a loud clunk, the wooden leg fell away as a normal leg regrew in its place; next moment, the magical eyeball had popped out of the man's face as a real eye replaced it; it rolled away across the floor and continued to swivel in every direction.
　　Roberto saw a man lying before him, pale-skinned, slightly freckled, with a mop of fair hair. He knew who he was. He had seen him in Dominguez's Pensieve, had watched him being led away from court by the dementors, trying to convince Mr. Crouch that he was innocent. . . but he was lined around the eyes now and looked much older. . . .
　　There were hurried footsteps outside in the corridor. Peralta had returned with Winky at his heels. Professor Romero was right behind them.
　　"Crouch!" Peralta said, stopping dead in the doorway. "Barty Crouch!"
　　"Good heavens," said Professor Romero, stopping dead and staring down at the man on the floor.
　　Filthy, disheveled, Winky peered around Peralta's legs. Her mouth opened wide and she let out a piercing shriek.
　　"Master Barty, Master Barty, what is you doing here?"
　　She flung herself forward onto the young man's chest.
　　"You is killed him! You is killed him! You is killed Master's son!"
　　"He is simply Stunned, Winky," said Dominguez. "Step aside, please. Carlos, you have the potion?"
　　Peralta handed Dominguez a small glass bottle of completely clear liquid: the Veritaserum with which he had threatened Roberto in class. Dominguez got up, bent over the man on the floor, and pulled him into a sitting position against the wall beneath the Foe-Glass, in which the reflections of Dominguez, Peralta, and Romero were still glaring down upon them all. Winky remained on her knees, trembling, her hands over her face. Dominguez forced the mans mouth open and poured three drops inside it. Then he pointed his wand at the mans chest and said, "Ennervate."
　　Crouch's son opened his eyes. His face was slack, his gaze unfocused. Dominguez knelt before him, so that their faces were level.
　　"Can you hear me?" Dominguez asked quietly.
　　The man's eyelids flickered.
　　"Yes," he muttered.
　　"I would like you to tell us," said Dominguez softly, "how you came to be here. How did you escape from Azkaban?"
　　Crouch took a deep, shuddering breath, then began to speak in a flat, expressionless voice.
　　"My mother saved me. She knew she was dying. She persuaded my father to rescue me as a last favor to her. He loved her as he had never loved me. He agreed. They came to visit me. They gave me a draft of Polyjuice Potion containing one of my mother's hairs.
　　She took a draft of Polyjuice Potion containing one of my hairs. We took on each other's appearance."
　　Winky was shaking her head, trembling.
　　"Say no more. Master Barty, say no more, you is getting your father into trouble!"
　　But Crouch took another deep breath and continued in the same flat voice.
　　"The dementors are blind. They sensed one healthy, one dying person entering Azkaban.
　　They sensed one healthy, one dying person leaving it. My father smuggled me out, disguised as my mother, in case any prisoners were watching through their doors.
　　"My mother died a short while afterward in Azkaban. She was careful to drink Polyjuice Potion until the end. She was buried under my name and bearing my appearance. Everyone believed her to be me."
　　The man's eyelids flickered.
　　"And what did your father do with you, when he had got you home?" said Dominguez quietly.
　　"Staged my mother's death. A quiet, private funeral. That grave is empty. The house-elf nursed me back to health. Then I had to be concealed. I had to be controlled.
　　My father had to use a number of spells to subdue me. When I had recovered my strength, I thought only of finding my master . . . of returning to his service."
　　"How did your father subdue you?" said Dominguez.
　　"The Imperius Curse," Acosta said. "I was under my fathers control. I was forced to wear an Invisibility Cloak day and night. I was always with the house-elf. She was my keeper and caretaker. She pitied me. She persuaded my father to give me occasional treats.
　　Rewards for my good behavior."
　　"Master Barty, Master Barty," sobbed Winky through her hands. "You isn't ought to tell them, we is getting in trouble. ..."
　　"Did anybody ever discover that you were still alive?" said Dominguez softly. "Did anyone know except your father and the house-elf?"
　　"Yes," said Crouch, his eyelids flickering again. "A witch in my father's office.
　　Bertha Jorkins. She came to the house with papers for my father s signature. He was not at home. Winky showed her inside and returned to the kitchen, to me. But Bertha Jorkins heard Winky talking to me. She came to investigate. She heard enough to guess who was hiding under the Invisibility Cloak. My father arrived home. She confronted him. He
　　put a very powerful Memory Charm on her to make her forget what she'd found out. Too powerful. He said it damaged her memory permanently."
　　"Why is she coming to nose into my masters private business?" sobbed Winky. "Why isn't she leaving us be?"
　　"Tell me about the Quidditch World Cup," said Dominguez.
　　"Winky talked my father into it," said Crouch, still in the same monotonous voice. "She spent months persuading him. I had not left the house for years. I had loved Quidditch.
　　Let him go, she said. He will be in his Invisibility Cloak. He can watch. Let him smell fresh air for once. She said my mother would have wanted it. She told my father that my mother had died to give me freedom. She had not saved me for a life of imprisonment. He agreed in the end.
　　"It was carefully planned. My father led me and Winky up to the Top Box early in the day. Winky was to say that she was saving a seat for my father. I was to sit there, invisible. When everyone had left the box, we would emerge. Winky would appear to be alone. Nobody would ever know.
　　"But Winky didn't know that I was growing stronger. I was starting to fight my father's Imperius Curse. There were times when I was almost myself again. There were brief periods when I seemed outside his control. It happened, there, in the Top Box. It was like waking from a deep sleep. I found myself out in public, in the middle of the match, and I saw, in front of me, a wand sticking out of a boys pocket. I had not been allowed a wand since before Azkaban. I stole it. Winky didn't know. Winky is frightened of heights. She had her face hidden."
　　"Master Barty, you bad boy!" whispered Winky, tears trickling between her fingers.
　　"So you took the wand," said Dominguez, "and what did you do with it?"
　　"We went back to the tent," said Crouch. "Then we heard them. We heard the Death Eaters. The ones who had never been to Azkaban. The ones who had never suffered for my master. They had turned their backs on him. They were not enslaved, as I was. They were free to seek him, but they did not. They were merely making sport of Muggles. The sound of their voices awoke me. My mind was clearer than it had been in years. I was angry. I had the wand.
　　I wanted to attack them for their disloyalty to my master. My father had left the tent; he had gone to free the Muggles. Winky was afraid to see me so angry. She used her own brand of magic to bind me to her. She pulled me from the tent, pulled me into the forest, away from the Death Eaters. I tried to hold her back. I wanted to return to the campsite. I wanted to show those Death Eaters what loyalty to the Dark Lord meant, and to punish them for their lack of it. I used the stolen wand to cast the Dark Mark into the sky.
　　"Ministry wizards arrived. They shot Stunning Spells everywhere. One of the spells came through the trees where Winky and I stood. The bond connecting us was broken. We were both Stunned.
　　"When Winky was discovered, my father knew I must be nearby. He searched the bushes where she had been found and felt me lying there. He waited until the other Ministry members had left the forest. He put me back under the Imperius Curse and took me home.
　　He dismissed Winky. She had failed him. She had let me acquire a wand. She had almost let me escape."
　　Winky let out a wail of despair.
　　"Now it was just Father and I, alone in the house. And then . . . and then . . ."
　　Crouch's head rolled on his neck, and an insane grin spread across his face. "My master came for me.
　　"He arrived at our house late one night in the arms of his servant Wormtail. My master had found out that I was still alive. He had captured Bertha Jorkins in Albania. He had tortured her. She told him a great deal. She told him about the Triwizard Tournament.
　　She told him the old Auror, Acosta, was going to teach at Hogwarts. He tortured her until he broke through the Memory Charm my father had placed upon her. She told him I had escaped from Azkaban. She told him my father kept me imprisoned to prevent me from seeking my master. And so my master knew that I was still his faithful servant - perhaps the most faithful of all. My master conceived a plan, based upon the information Bertha had given him. He needed me. He arrived at our house near midnight. My father answered the door."
　　The smile spread wider over Crouch's face, as though recalling the sweetest memory of his life. Winky's petrified brown eyes were visible through her fingers. She seemed too
　　appalled to speak.
　　"It was very quick. My father was placed under the Imperius Curse by my master. Now my father was the one imprisoned, controlled. My master forced him to go about his business as usual, to act as though nothing was wrong. And I was released. I awoke. I was myself again, alive as I hadn't been in years.
　　"And what did Lord Salvador ask you to do?" said Dominguez.
　　"He asked me whether I was ready to risk everything for him. I was ready. It was my dream, my greatest ambition, to serve him, to prove myself to him. He told me he needed to place a faithful servant at Hogwarts. A servant who would guide Roberto Gonzales through the Triwizard Tournament without appearing to do so. A servant who would watch over Roberto Gonzales. Ensure he reached the Triwizard Cup. Turn the cup into a Portkey, which would take the first person to touch it to my master. But first -"
　　"You needed Alastor Acosta," said Dominguez. His blue eyes were blazing, though his voice remained calm.
　　"Wormtail and I did it. We had prepared the Polyjuice Potion beforehand. We journeyed to his house. Acosta put up a struggle. There was a commotion. We managed to subdue him just in time. Forced him into a compartment of his own magical trunk. Took some of his hair and added it to the potion. I drank it; I became Acosta's double. I took his leg and his eye. I was ready to face Raul Lopez when he arrived to sort out the Muggles who had heard a disturbance. I made the dustbins move around the yard. I told Raul Lopez I had heard intruders in my yard, who had set off the dustbins. Then I packed up Acosta's clothes and Dark detectors, put them in the trunk with Acosta, and set off for Hogwarts. I kept him alive, under the Imperius Curse. I wanted to be able to question him. To find out about his past, learn his habits, so that I could fool even Dominguez.
　　I also needed his hair to make the Polyjuice Potion. The other ingredients were easy. I stole boom-slang skin from the dungeons. When the Potions master found me in his office, I said I was under orders to search it."
　　"And what became of Wormtail after you attacked Acosta?" said Dominguez.
　　"Wormtail returned to care for my master, in my father's house, and to keep watch over my father."
　　"But your father escaped," said Dominguez.
　　"Yes. After a while he began to fight the Imperius Curse just as I had done. There were periods when he knew what was happening. My master decided it was no longer safe for my father to leave the house. He forced him to send letters to the Ministry instead. He made him write and say he was ill. But Wormtail neglected his duty. He was not watchful enough. My father escaped. My master guessed that he was heading for Hogwarts. My father was going to tell Dominguez everything, to confess. He was going to admit that he had smuggled me from Azkaban.
　　"My master sent me word of my father's escape. He told me to stop him at all costs. So I waited and watched. I used the map I had taken from Roberto Gonzales. The map that had almost ruined everything."
　　"Map?" said Dominguez quickly. "What map is this?"
　　"Gonzales's map of Hogwarts. Gonzales saw me on it. Gonzales saw me stealing more ingredients for the Polyjuice Potion from Peralta's office one night. He thought I was my father. We have the same first name. I took the map from Gonzales that night. I told him my father hated Dark wizards. Gonzales believed my father was after Peralta.
　　"For a week I waited for my father to arrive at Hogwarts. At last, one evening, the map showed my father entering the grounds. I pulled on my Invisibility Cloak and went down to meet him. He was walking around the edge of the forest. Then Gonzales came, and Krum.
　　I waited. I could not hurt Gonzales; my master needed him. Gonzales ran to get Dominguez.
　　I Stunned Krum. I killed my father."
　　"Noooo!" wailed Winky. "Master Barty, Master Barty, what is you saying?"
　　"You killed your father," Dominguez said, in the same soft voice. "What did you do with the body?"
　　"Carried it into the forest. Covered it with the Invisibility Cloak. I had the map with me. I watched Gonzales run into the castle. He met Peralta. Dominguez joined them. I watched Gonzales bringing Dominguez out of the castle. I walked back out of the forest, doubled around behind them, went to meet them. I told Dominguez Peralta had told me where to come.
　　"Dominguez told me to go and look for my father. I went back to my father's body.
　　Watched the map. When everyone was gone, I Transfigured my father's body. He became a
　　bone ... I buried it, while wearing the Invisibility Cloak, in the freshly dug earth in front of Villalba's cabin."
　　There was complete silence now, except for Winky's continued sobs. Then Dominguez said, "And tonight. . ."
　　"I offered to carry the Triwizard Cup into the maze before dinner," whispered Barty Crouch. "Turned it into a Portkey. My master's plan worked. He is returned to power and I will be honored by him beyond the dreams of wizards."
　　The insane smile lit his features once more, and his head drooped onto his shoulder as Winky wailed and sobbed at his side.
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-SIX - THE PARTING OF THE WAYS
　　Dominguez stood up. He stared down at Barty Crouch for a moment with disgust on his face. Then he raised his wand once more and ropes flew out of it, ropes that twisted themselves around Barty Crouch, binding him tightly. He turned to Professor Romero.
　　"Elena, could I ask you to stand guard here while I take Roberto upstairs?"
　　"Of course," said Professor Romero. She looked slightly nauseous, as though she had just watched someone being sick. However, when she drew out her wand and pointed it at Barty Crouch, her hand was quite steady.
　　"Carlos" - Dominguez turned to Peralta - "please tell Madam Pomfrey to come down here; we need to get Alastor Acosta into the hospital wing. Then go down into the grounds, find Cornelius Fudge, and bring him up to this office. He will undoubtedly want to question Crouch himself. Tell him I will be in the hospital wing in half an hour's time if he needs me."
　　Peralta nodded silently and swept out of the room.
　　"Roberto?" Dominguez said gently.
　　Roberto got up and swayed again; the pain in his leg, which he had not noticed all the time he had been listening to Crouch, now returned in full measure. He also realized that he was shaking. Dominguez gripped his arm and helped him out into the dark corridor.
　　"I want you to come up to my office first. Roberto," he said quiedy as they headed up the passageway. "Gustavo is waiting for us there."
　　Roberto nodded. A kind of numbness and a sense of complete unreality were upon him, but he did not care; he was even glad of it. He didn't want to have to think about anything that had happened since he had first touched the Triwizard Cup. He didn't want to have to examine the memories, fresh and sharp as photographs, which kept flashing across his mind. Mad-Eye Acosta, inside the trunk. Wormtail, slumped on the ground, cradling his stump of an arm. Salvador, rising from the steaming cauldron. Nicolas. . . dead . . .
　　Nicolas, asking to be returned to his parents. . . .
　　"Professor," Roberto mumbled, "where are Mr. and Mrs. Ortega?"
　　"They are with Professor Sprout," said Dominguez. His voice, which had been so calm throughout the interrogation of Barty Crouch, shook very slightly for the first time.
　　"She was Head of Nicolas's house, and knew him best."
　　They had reached the stone gargoyle. Dominguez gave the password, it sprang aside, and he and Roberto went up the moving spiral staircase to the oak door. Dominguez pushed it open. Gustavo was standing there. His face was white and gaunt as it had been when he had escaped Azkaban. In one swift moment, he had crossed the room.
　　"Roberto, are you all right? I knew it - I knew something like this - what happened?"
　　His hands shook as he helped Roberto into a chair in front of the desk.
　　"What happened?" he asked more urgently.
　　Dominguez began to tell Gustavo everything Barty Crouch had said. Roberto was only half listening. So tired every bone in his body was aching, he wanted nothing more than to sit here, undisturbed, for hours and hours, until he fell asleep and didn't have to think or feel anymore.
　　There was a soft rush of wings. Fawkes the phoenix had left his perch, flown across the office, and landed on Roberto's knee.
　　"'Lo, Fawkes," said Roberto quietly. He stroked the phoenix's beautiful scarlet-and-gold plumage. Fawkes blinked peacefully up at him. There was something comforting about his warm weight.
　　Dominguez stopped talking. He sat down opposite Roberto, behind his desk. He was looking at Roberto, who avoided his eyes. Dominguez was going to question him. He was going to make Roberto relive everything.
　　"I need to know what happened after you touched the Portkey in the maze. Roberto," said Dominguez.
　　"We can leave that till morning, can't we, Dominguez?" said Gustavo harshly. He had put a hand on Robertos shoulder. "Let him have a sleep. Let him rest."
　　Roberto felt a rush of gratitude toward Gustavo, but Dominguez took no notice of Gustavo's words. He leaned forward toward Roberto.
　　Very unwillingly, Roberto raised his head and looked into those blue eyes.
　　"If I thought I could help you," Dominguez said gently, "by putting you into an enchanted sleep and allowing you to postpone the moment when you would have to think about what has happened tonight, I would do it. But I know better. Numbing the pain for a while will make it worse when you finally feel it. You have shown bravery beyond anything I could have expected of you. I ask you to demonstrate your courage one more time. I ask you to tell us what happened."
　　The phoenix let out one soft, quavering note. It shivered in the air, and Roberto felt as though a drop of hot liquid had slipped down his throat into his stomach, warming him, and strengthening him.
　　He took a deep breath and began to tell them. As he spoke, visions of everything that had passed that night seemed to rise before his eyes; he saw the sparkling surface of the potion that had revived Salvador; he saw the Death Eaters Apparating between the graves around them; he saw Nicolas's body, lying on the ground beside the cup.
　　Once or twice, Gustavo made a noise as though about to say something, his hand still tight on Roberto's shoulder, but Dominguez raised his hand to stop him, and Roberto was glad of this, because it was easier to keep going now he had started. It was even a relief; he felt almost as though something poisonous were being extracted from him. It was costing him every bit of determination he had to keep talking, yet he sensed that once he had finished, he would feel better.
　　When Roberto told of Wormtail piercing his arm with the dagger, however, Gustavo let out a vehement exclamation and Dominguez stood up so quickly that Roberto started. Dominguez walked around the desk and told Roberto to stretch out his arm. Roberto showed them both the place where his robes were torn and the cut beneath them.
　　"He said my blood would make him stronger than if he'd used someone else's," Roberto told Dominguez. "He said the protection my - my mother left in me - he'd have it too. And he was right - he could touch me without hurting himself, he touched my face."
　　For a fleeting instant, Roberto thought he saw a gleam of something like triumph in Dominguez's eyes. But next second. Roberto was sure he had imagined it, for when Dominguez had returned to his seat behind the desk, he looked as old and weary as Roberto had ever seen him.
　　"Very well," he said, sitting down again. "Salvador has overcome that particular barrier. Roberto, continue, please."
　　Roberto went on; he explained how Salvador had emerged from the cauldron, and told them all he could remember of Salvador's speech to the Death Eaters. Then he told how Salvador had untied him, returned his wand to him, and prepared to duel.
　　But when he reached the part where the golden beam of light had connected his and Salvador's wands, he found his throat obstructed. He tried to keep talking, but the memories of what had come out of Salvador's wand were flooding into his mind. He could see Nicolas emerging, see the old man, Bertha Jorkins ... his father . . . his mother . .
　　.
　　He was glad when Gustavo broke the silence.
　　"The wands connected?" he said, looking from Roberto to Dominguez. "Why?"
　　Roberto looked up at Dominguez again, on whose face there was an arrested look.
　　"Priori Incantatem," he muttered.
　　His eyes gazed into Roberto's and it was almost as though an invisible beam of understanding shot between them.
　　"The Reverse Spell effect?" said Gustavo sharply.
　　"Exactly," said Dominguez. "Roberto's wand and Salvadors wand share cores. Each of them contains a feather from the tail of the same phoenix. This phoenix, in fact," he added, and he pointed at the scarlet-and-gold bird, perching peacefully on Roberto's knee.
　　"My wand's feather came from Fawkes?" Roberto said, amazed.
　　"Yes," said Dominguez. "Mr. Ollivander wrote to tell me you had bought the second wand, the moment you left his shop four years ago."
　　"So what happens when a wand meets its brother?" said Gustavo.
　　"They will not work properly against each other," said Dominguez. "If, however, the owners of the wands force the wands to do battle ... a very rare effect will take place.
　　One of the wands will force the other to regurgitate spells it has performed - in reverse. The most recent first. . . and then those which preceded it. . . ."
　　He looked interrogatively at Roberto, and Roberto nodded.
　　"Which means," said Dominguez slowly, his eyes upon Roberto's face, "that some form of Nicolas must have reappeared."
　　Roberto nodded again.
　　"Ortega came back to life?" said Gustavo sharply.
　　"No spell can reawaken the dead," said Dominguez heavily. "All that would have happened is a kind of reverse echo. A shadow of the living Nicolas would have emerged from the wand . . . am I correct, Roberto?"
　　"He spoke to me," Roberto said. He was suddenly shaking again. "The . . . the ghost Nicolas, or whatever he was, spoke."
　　"An echo," said Dominguez, "which retained Nicolas's appearance and character. I am guessing other such forms appeared . . . less recent victims of Salvador's wand...."
　　"An old man," Roberto said, his throat still constricted. "Bertha Jorkins. And . . ."
　　"Your parents?" said Dominguez quietly.
　　"Yes," said Roberto.
　　Gustavo's grip on Roberto's shoulder was now so tight it was painful.
　　"The last murders the wand performed," said Dominguez, nodding. "In reverse order. More would have appeared, of course, had you maintained the connection. Very well, Roberto, these echoes, these shadows . .. what did they do?"
　　Roberto described how the figures that had emerged from the wand had prowled the edges of the golden web, how Salvador had seemed to fear them, how the shadow of Roberto's mother had told him what to do, how Nicolas's had made its final request.
　　At this point. Roberto found he could not continue. He looked around at Gustavo and saw that he had his face in his hands.
　　Roberto suddenly became aware that Fawkes had left his knee. The phoenix had fluttered to the floor. It was resting its beautiful head against Roberto's injured leg, and thick, pearly tears were falling from its eyes onto the wound left by the spider. The pain vanished. The skin mended. His leg was repaired.
　　"I will say it again," said Dominguez as the phoenix rose into the air and resettled itself upon the perch beside the door. "You have shown bravery beyond anything I could have expected of you tonight. Roberto. You have shown bravery equal to those who died fighting Salvador at the height of his powers. You have shouldered a grown wizard's burden and found yourself equal to it - and you have now given us all we have a right to expect. You will come with me to the hospital wing. I do not want you returning to the dormitory tonight. A Sleeping Potion, and some peace . . . Gustavo, would you like to stay with him?"
　　Gustavo nodded and stood up. He transformed back into the great black dog and walked with Roberto and Dominguez out of the office, accompanying them down a flight of stairs to the hospital wing.
　　When Dominguez pushed open the door. Roberto saw Mrs. Lopez, Bill, Diego, and Carolina grouped around a harassed-looking Madam Pomfrey. They appeared to be demanding to know where Roberto was and what had happened to him. All of them whipped around as Roberto, Dominguez, and the black dog entered, and Mrs. Lopez let out a kind of muffled scream.
　　"Roberto! Oh Roberto!"
　　She started to hurry toward him, but Dominguez moved between them.
　　"Alicia," he said, holding up a hand, "please listen to me for a moment. Roberto has been through a terrible ordeal tonight. He has just had to relive it for me. What he needs now is sleep, and peace, and quiet. If he would like you all to stay with him," he added, looking around at Diego, Carolina, and Bill too, "you may do so. But I do not want you questioning him until he is ready to answer, and certainly not this evening."
　　Mrs. Lopez nodded. She was very white. She rounded on Diego, Carolina, and Bill as though they were being noisy, and hissed, "Did you hear? He needs quiet!"
　　"Headmaster," said Madam Pomfrey, staring at the great black dog that was Gustavo, "may I ask what - ?"
　　"This dog will be remaining with Roberto for a while," said Dominguez simply. "I assure you, he is extremely well trained. Roberto - I will wait while you get into bed."
　　Roberto felt an inexpressible sense of gratitude to Dominguez for asking the others not to
　　question him. It wasn't as though he didn't want them there; but the thought of explaining it all over again, the idea of reliving it one more time, was more than he could stand.
　　"I will be back to see you as soon as I have met with Fudge, Roberto," said Dominguez. "I would like you to remain here tomorrow until I have spoken to the school." He left.
　　As Madam Pomfrey led Roberto to a nearby bed, he caught sight of the real Acosta lying motionless in a bed at the far end of the room. His wooden leg and magical eye were lying on the bedside table.
　　"Is he okay?" Roberto asked.
　　"He'll be fine," said Madam Pomfrey, giving Roberto some pajamas and pulling screens around him. He took off his robes, pulled on the pajamas, and got into bed. Diego, Carolina, Bill, Mrs. Lopez, and the black dog came around the screen and settled themselves in chairs on either side of him. Diego and Carolina were looking at him almost cautiously, as though scared of him.
　　"I'm all right," he told them. "Just tired."
　　Mrs. Lopezs eyes filled with tears as she smoothed his bed-covers unnecessarily.
　　Madam Pomfrey, who had bustled off to her office, returned holding a small bottle of some purple potion and a goblet.
　　"You'll need to drink all of this. Roberto," she said. "It's a potion for dreamless sleep."
　　Roberto took the goblet and drank a few mouthfuls. He felt himself becoming drowsy at once. Everything around him became hazy; the lamps around the hospital wing seemed to be winking at him in a friendly way through the screen around his bed; his body felt as though it was sinking deeper into the warmth of the feather matress. Before he could finish the potion, before he could say another word, his exhaustion had carried him off to sleep.
　　Roberto woke up, so warm, so very sleepy, that he didn't open his eyes, wanting to drop off again. The room was still dimly lit; he was sure it was still nighttime and had a feeling that he couldn't have been asleep very long.
　　Then he heard whispering around him.
　　"They'll wake him if they don't shut up!"
　　"What are they shouting about? Nothing else can have happened, can it?"
　　Roberto opened his eyes blearily. Someone had removed his glasses. He could see the fuzzy outlines of Mrs. Lopez and Bill close by. Mrs. Lopez was on her feet.
　　"That's Fudge's voice," she whispered. "And that's Elena Romero's, isn't it? But what are they arguing about?"
　　Now Roberto could hear them too: people shouting and running toward the hospital wing.
　　"Regrettable, but all the same, Elena -" Cornelius Fudge was saying loudly.
　　"You should never have brought it inside the castle!" yelled Professor Romero. "When Dominguez finds out -"
　　Roberto heard the hospital doors burst open. Unnoticed by any of the people around his bed, all of whom were staring at the door as Bill pulled back the screens, Roberto sat up and put his glasses back on.
　　Fudge came striding up the ward. Professors Romero and Peralta were at his heels.
　　"Where's Dominguez?" Fudge demanded of Mrs. Lopez.
　　"He's not here," said Mrs. Lopez angrily. "This is a hospital wing. Minister, don't you think you'd do better to -"
　　But the door opened, and Dominguez came sweeping up the ward.
　　"What has happened?" said Dominguez sharply, looking from Fudge to Professor Romero.
　　"Why are you disturbing these people? Elena, I'm surprised at you - I asked you to stand guard over Barty Crouch -"
　　"There is no need to stand guard over him anymore, Dumble-dore!" she shrieked. "The Minister has seen to that!"
　　Roberto had never seen Professor Romero lose control like this. There were angry blotches of color in her cheeks, and a hands were balled into fists; she was trembling with fury.-"
　　When we told Mr. Fudge that we had caught the Death Eater responsible for tonight's events," said Peralta, in a low voice; he seemed to feel his personal safety was in question. He insisted on summoning a dementor to accompany him into the castle. He brought it up to the office where Barty Crouch -"
　　"I told him you would not agree, Dominguez!" Romero fumed. "I told him you would never allow dementors to set foot inside the castle, but -"
　　"My dear woman!" roared Fudge, who likewise looked angrier than Roberto had ever seen him, "as Minister of Magic, it is my decision whether I wish to bring protection with me when interviewing a possibly dangerous -"
　　But Professor Romero's voice drowned Fudge's.
　　"The moment that - that thing entered the room," she screamed, pointing at Fudge, trembling all over, "it swooped down on Crouch and - and -"
　　Roberto felt a chill in his stomach as Professor Romero struggled to find words to describe what had happened. He did not need her to finish her sentence. He knew what the dementor must have done. It had administered its fatal kiss to Barty Crouch. It had sucked his soul out through his mouth. He was worse than dead.
　　"By all accounts, he is no loss!" blustered Fudge. "It seems he has been responsible for several deaths'."
　　"But he cannot now give testimony, Cornelius," said Dominguez. He was staring hard at Fudge, as though seeing him plainly for the first time. "He cannot give evidence about why he killed those people."
　　"Why he killed them? Well, that's no mystery, is it?" blustered Fudge. "He was a raving lunatic! From what Elena and Carlos have told me, he seems to have thought he was doing it all on You-Know-Who's instructions!"
　　"Lord Salvador was giving him instructions, Cornelius," Dominguez said. "Those peoples deaths were mere by-products of a plan to restore Salvador to full strength again. The plan succeeded. Salvador has been restored to his body."
　　Fudge looked as though someone had just swung a heavy weight into his face. Dazed and blinking, he stared back at Dominguez as if he couldn't quite believe what he had just heard. He began to sputter, still goggling at Dominguez.
　　"You-Know-Who . . . returned? Preposterous. Come now, Dominguez ..."
　　"As Elena and Carlos have doubtless told you," said Dominguez, "we heard Barty Crouch confess. Under the influence of Veritaserum, he told us how he was smuggled out of Azkaban, and how Salvador - learning of his continued existence from Bertha Jorkins -went to free him from his father and used him to capture Roberto. The plan worked, I tell you. Crouch has helped Salvador to return."
　　"See here, Dominguez," said Fudge, and Roberto was astonished to see a slight smile dawning on his face, "you - you can't seriously believe that You-Know-Who - back? Come now, come now . . . certainly, Crouch may have believed himself to be acting upon You-Know-Who's orders - but to take the word of a lunatic like that, Dominguez ..."
　　"When Roberto touched the Triwizard Cup tonight, he was transported straight to Salvador,"
　　said Dominguez steadily. "He witnessed Lord Salvador's rebirth. I will explain it all to you if you will step up to my office."
　　Dominguez glanced around at Roberto and saw that he was awake, but shook his head and said, "I am afraid I cannot permit you to question Roberto tonight."
　　Fudge's curious smile lingered. He too glanced at Roberto, then looked back at Dominguez, and said, "You are - er - prepared to take Roberto's word on this, are you, Dominguez?"
　　There was a moment's silence, which was broken by Gustavo growling. His hackles were raised, and he was baring his teeth at Fudge.
　　"Certainly, I believe Roberto," said Dominguez. His eyes were blazing now. "I heard Crouch's confession, and I heard Roberto's account of what happened after he touched the Triwizard Cup; the two stories make sense, they explain everything that has happened since Bertha Jorkins disappeared last summer."
　　Fudge still had that strange smile on his face. Once again, he glanced at Roberto before answering.
　　"You are prepared to believe that Lord Salvador has returned, on the word of a lunatic murderer, and a boy who . . . well..."
　　Fudge shot Roberto another look, and Roberto suddenly understood.
　　"You've been reading Rita Skeeter, Mr. Fudge," he said quietly.
　　Diego, Carolina, Mrs. Lopez, and Bill all jumped. None of them had realized that Roberto was awake.
　　Fudge reddened slightly, but a defiant and obstinate look came over his face.
　　"And if I have?" he said, looking at Dominguez. "If I have discovered that you've been keeping certain facts about the boy very quiet? A Parselmouth, eh? And having funny turns all over the place -"
　　"I assume that you are referring to the pains Roberto has been experiencing in his scar?"
　　said Dominguez coolly.
　　"You admit that he has been having these pains, then?" said Fudge quickly. "Headaches?
　　Nightmares? Possibly - hallucinations?"
　　"Listen to me, Cornelius," said Dominguez, taking a step toward Fudge, and once again, he seemed to radiate that indefinable sense of power that Roberto had felt after Dominguez had Stunned young Crouch. "Roberto is as sane as you or I. That scar upon his forehead has not addled his brains. I believe it hurts him when Lord Salvador is close by, or feeling particularly murderous."
　　Fudge had taken half a step back from Dominguez, but he looked no less stubborn.
　　"You'll forgive me, Dominguez, but I've never heard of a curse scar acting as an alarm bell before. ..."
　　"Look, I saw Salvador come back!" Roberto shouted. He tried to get out of bed again, but Mrs. Lopez forced him back. "I saw the Death Eaters! I can give you their names!
　　Mariano Sosa -"
　　Peralta made a sudden movement, but as Roberto looked at him, Peralta's eyes flew back to Fudge.
　　"Sosa was cleared!" said Fudge, visibly affronted. "A very old family - donations to excellent causes -"
　　"Macnair!" Roberto continued.
　　"Also cleared! Now working for the Ministry!"
　　"Avery - Nott - Crabbe - Goyle -"
　　"You are merely repeating the names of those who were acquitted of being Death Eaters thirteen years ago!" said Fudge angrily. "You could have found those names in old reports of the trials! For heavens sake, Dominguez - the boy was full of some crackpot story at the end of last year too - his tales are getting taller, and you're still swallowing them - the boy can talk to snakes. Dominguez, and you still think he's trustworthy?"
　　"You fool!" Professor Romero cried. "Nicolas Ortega! Mr. Crouch! These deaths were not the random work of a lunatic!"
　　"I see no evidence to the contrary!" shouted Fudge, now matching her anger, his face purpling. "It seems to me that you are all determined to start a panic that will destabilize everything we have worked for these last thirteen years!"
　　Roberto couldn't believe what he was hearing. He had always thought of Fudge as a kindly figure, a little blustering, a little pompous, but essentially good-natured. But now a short, angry wizard stood before him, refusing, point-blank, to accept the prospect of disruption in his comfortable and ordered world - to believe that Salvador could have risen.
　　"Salvador has returned," Dominguez repeated. "If you accept that fact straightaway.
　　Fudge, and take the necessary measures, we may still be able to save the situation. The first and most essential step is to remove Azkaban from the control of the dementors -"
　　"Preposterous!" shouted Fudge again. "Remove the dementors? I'd be kicked out of office for suggesting it! Half of us only feel safe in our beds at night because we know the dementors are standing guard at Azkaban!"
　　"The rest of us sleep less soundly in our beds, Cornelius, knowing that you have put Lord Salvador's most dangerous supporters in the care of creatures who will join him the instant he asks them!" said Dominguez. "They will not remain loyal to you, Fudge!
　　Salvador can offer them much more scope for their powers and their pleasures than you can! With the dementors behind him, and his old supporters returned to him, you will be hard-pressed to stop him regaining the sort of power he had thirteen years ago!"
　　Fudge was opening and closing his mouth as though no words could express his outrage.
　　"The second step you must take - and at once," Dominguez pressed on, "is to send envoys to the giants."
　　"Envoys to the giants?" Fudge shrieked, finding his tongue again. "What madness is this?"
　　"Extend them the hand of friendship, now, before it is too late," said Dominguez, "or Salvador will persuade them, as he did before, that he alone among wizards will give them their rights and their freedom!"
　　"You - you cannot be serious!" Fudge gasped, shaking his head and retreating further from Dominguez. "If the magical community got wind that I had approached the giants -people hate them, Dominguez - end of my career -"
　　"You are blinded," said Dominguez, his voice rising now, the aura of power around him palpable, his eyes blazing once more, "by the love of the office you hold, Cornelius!
　　You place too much importance, and you always have done, on the so-called purity of blood! You fail to recognize that it matters not what someone is born, but what they grow to be! Your dementor has just destroyed the last remaining member of a pure-blood family as old as any - and see what that man chose to make of his life! I tell you now-take the steps I have suggested, and you will be remembered, in office or out, as one of the bravest and greatest Ministers of Magic we have ever known. Fail to act - and history will remember you as the man who stepped aside and allowed Salvador a second chance to destroy the world we have tried to rebuild!"
　　"Insane," whispered Fudge, still backing away. "Mad . . ."
　　And then there was silence. Madam Pomfrey was standing frozen at the foot of Roberto's bed, her hands over her mouth. Mrs.Lopez was still standing over Roberto, her hand on his shoulder to prevent him from rising. Bill, Diego, and Carolina were staring at Fudge.
　　"If your determination to shut your eyes will carry you as far as this, Cornelius," said Dominguez, "we have reached a parting of the ways. You must act as you see fit. And I - I shall act as I see fit."
　　Dominguez's voice carried no hint of a threat; it sounded like a mere statement, but Fudge bristled as though Dominguez were advancing upon him with a wand.
　　"Now, see here, Dominguez," he said, waving a threatening finger. "I've given you free rein, always. I've had a lot of respect for you. I might not have agreed with some of your decisions, but I've kept quiet. There aren't many who'd have let you hire werewolves, or keep Villalba, or decide what to teach your students without reference to the Ministry. But if you're going to work against me -"
　　"The only one against whom I intend to work," said Dominguez, "is Lord Salvador. If you are against him, then we remain, Cornelius, on the same side."
　　It seemed Fudge could think of no answer to this. He rocked backward and forward on his small feet for a moment and spun his bowler hat in his hands. Finally, he said, with a hint of a plea in his voice, "He can't be back, Dominguez, he just can't be ..."
　　Peralta strode forward, past Dominguez, pulling up the left sleeve of his robes as he went. He stuck out his forearm and showed it to Fudge, who recoiled.
　　"There," said Peralta harshly. "There. The Dark Mark. It is not as clear as it was an hour or so ago, when it burned black, but you can still see it. Every Death Eater had the sign burned into him by the Dark Lord. It was a means of distinguishing one another, and his means of summoning us to him. When he touched the Mark of any Death Eater, we were to Disapparate, and Apparate, instantly, at his side. This Mark has been growing clearer all year. Morales s too. Why do you think Morales fled tonight? We both felt the Mark burn. We both knew he had returned. Morales fears the Dark Lord's vengeance. He betrayed too many of his fellow Death Eaters to be sure of a welcome back into the fold."
　　Fudge stepped back from Peralta too. He was shaking his head. He did not seem to have taken in a word Peralta had said. He stared, apparently repelled by the ugly mark on Peralta's arm, then looked up at Dominguez and whispered, "I don't know what you and your staff are playing at, Dominguez, but I have heard enough. I have no more to add. I will be in touch with you tomorrow, Dominguez, to discuss the running of this school. I must return to the Ministry."
　　He had almost reached the door when he paused. He turned around, strode back down the dormitory, and stopped at Roberto's bed.
　　"Your winnings," he said shortly, taking a large bag of gold out of his pocket and dropping it onto Robertos bedside table. "One thousand Galleons. There should have been a presentation ceremony, but under the circumstances .. ."
　　He crammed his bowler hat onto his head and walked out of the room, slamming the door behind him. The moment he had disappeared, Dominguez turned to look at the group around Roberto's bed.
　　"There is work to be done," he said. "Alicia... am I right in thinking that I can count on you and Raul?"
　　"Of course you can," said Mrs. Lopez. She was white to the lips, but she looked resolute. "We know what Fudge is. It's Raul's fondness for Muggles that has held him back at the Ministry all these years. Fudge thinks he lacks proper wizarding pride."
　　"Then I need to send a message to Raul," said Dominguez. "All those that we can persuade of the truth must be notified immediately, and he is well placed to contact
　　those at the Ministry who are not as shortsighted as Cornelius."
　　"I'll go to Dad," said Bill, standing up. "I'll go now."
　　"Excellent," said Dominguez. "Tell him what has happened. Tell him I will be in direct contact with him shortly. He will need to be discreet, however. If Fudge thinks I am interfering at the Ministry -"
　　"Leave it to me," said Bill.
　　He clapped a hand on Roberto's shoulder, kissed his mother on the cheek, pulled on his cloak, and strode quickly from the room.
　　"Elena," said Dominguez, turning to Professor Romero, "I want to see Villalba in my office as soon as possible. Also - if she will consent to come - Madame Maxime."
　　Professor Romero nodded and left without a word.
　　"Poppy," Dominguez said to Madam Pomfrey, "would you be very kind and go down to Professor Acostas office, where I think you will find a house-elf called Winky in considerable distress? Do what you can for her, and take her back to the kitchens. I think Dobby will look after her for us."
　　"Very - very well," said Madam Pomfrey, looking startled, and she too left.
　　Dominguez made sure that the door was closed, and that Madam Pomfrey's footsteps had died away, before he spoke again.
　　"And now," he said, "it is time for two of our number to recognize each other for what they are. Gustavo ... if you could resume your usual form."
　　The great black dog looked up at Dominguez, then, in an instant, turned back into a man.
　　Mrs. Lopez screamed and leapt back from the bed.
　　"Gustavo Martinez!" she shrieked, pointing at him.
　　"Mum, shut up!" Diego yelled. "It's okay!"
　　Peralta had not yelled or jumped backward, but the look on his face was one of mingled fury and horror.
　　"Him!" he snarled, staring at Gustavo, whose face showed equal dislike. "What is he doing here?"
　　"He is here at my invitation," said Dominguez, looking between them, "as are you, Carlos. I trust you both. It is time for you to lay aside your old differences and trust each other."
　　Roberto thought Dominguez was asking for a near miracle. Gustavo and Peralta were eyeing each other with the utmost loathing.
　　"I will settle, in the short term," said Dominguez, with a bite of impatience in his voice, "for a lack of open hostility. You will shake hands. You are on the same side now. Time is short, and unless the few of us who know the truth do not stand united, there is no hope for any us.
　　Very slowly - but still glaring at each other as though each wished the other nothing but ill - Gustavo and Peralta moved toward each other and shook hands. They let go extremely quickly.
　　"That will do to be going on with," said Dominguez, stepping between them once more.
　　"Now I have work for each of you. Fudge's attitude, though not unexpected, changes everything. Gustavo, I need you to set off at once. You are to alert Pedro Cardozo, Arabella Figg, Mundungus Fletcher - the old crowd. Lie low at Cardozo's for a while; I will contact you there."
　　"But -" said Roberto.
　　He wanted Gustavo to stay. He did not want to have to say goodbye again so quickly.
　　"You'll see me very soon. Roberto," said Gustavo, turning to him. "I promise you. But I must do what I can, you understand, don't you?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto. "Yeah . . . of course I do."
　　Gustavo grasped his hand briefly, nodded to Dominguez, transformed again into the black dog, and ran the length of the room to the door, whose handle he turned with a paw. Then he was gone.
　　"Carlos," said Dominguez, turning to Peralta, "you know what I must ask you to do. If you are ready . . . if you are prepared ..."
　　"I am," said Peralta.
　　He looked slightly paler than usual, and his cold, black eyes glittered strangely.
　　"Then good luck," said Dominguez, and he watched, with a trace of apprehension on his face, as Peralta swept wordlessly after Gustavo.
　　It was several minutes before Dominguez spoke again.
　　"I must go downstairs," he said finally. "I must see the Ortegas. Roberto - take the rest of your potion. I will see all of you later."
　　Roberto slumped back against his pillows as Dominguez disappeared. Carolina, Diego, and Mrs. Lopez were all looking at him. None of them spoke for a very long time.
　　"You've got to take the rest of your potion. Roberto," Mrs. Lopez said at last. Her hand nudged the sack of gold on his bedside cabinet as she reached for the bottle and the goblet. "You have a good long sleep. Try and think about something else for a while . .
　　. think about what you're going to buy with your winnings!"
　　"I don't want that gold," said Roberto in an expressionless voice. "You have it. Anyone can have it. I shouldn't have won it. It should've been Nicolas's."
　　The thing against which he had been fighting on and off ever since he had come out of the maze was threatening to overpower him. He could feel a burning, prickling feeling in the inner corners of his eyes. He blinked and stared up at the ceiling.
　　"It wasn't your fault. Roberto," Mrs. Lopez whispered.
　　"I told him to take the cup with me," said Roberto.
　　Now the burning feeling was in his throat too. He wished Diego would look away.
　　Mrs. Lopez set the potion down on the bedside cabinet, bent down, and put her arms around Roberto. He had no memory of ever being hugged like this, as though by a mother.
　　The full weight of everything he had seen that night seemed to fall in upon him as Mrs.
　　Lopez held him to her. His mother s face, his father's voice, the sight of Nicolas, dead on the ground all started spinning in his head until he could hardly bear it, until he was screwing up his face against the howl of misery fighting to get out of him.
　　There was a loud slamming noise, and Mrs. Lopez and Roberto broke apart. Carolina was standing by the window. She was holding something tight in her hand.
　　"Sorry," she whispered.
　　"Your potion, Roberto," said Mrs. Lopez quickly, wiping her eyes on the back of her hand.
　　Roberto drank it in one gulp. The effect was instantaneous. Heavy, irresistible waves of dreamless sleep broke over him; he fell back onto his pillows and thought no more.
　　CHAPTER THIRTY-SEVEN - THE BEGINNING
　　When he looked back, even a month later, Roberto found he had only scattered memories of the next few days. It was as though he had been through too much to take in any more.
　　The recollections he did have were very painful. The worst, perhaps, was the meeting with the Ortegas that took place the following morning.
　　They did not blame him for what had happened; on the contrary, both thanked him for returning Nicolas's body to them. Mr. Ortega sobbed through most of the interview. Mrs.
　　Ortega's grief seemed to be beyond tears.
　　"He suffered very little then," she said, when Roberto had told her how Nicolas had died.
　　"And after all, Amos ... he died just when he'd won the tournament. He must have been happy."
　　When they got to their feet, she looked down at Roberto and said, "You look after yourself, now."
　　Roberto seized the sack of gold on the bedside table.
　　"You take this," he muttered to her. "It should've been Nicolas's, he got there first, you take it -"
　　But she backed away from him.
　　"Oh no, it's yours, dear, I couldn't. . . you keep it."
　　Roberto returned to Gryffindor Tower the following evening. From what Carolina and Diego told him, Dominguez had spoken to the school that morning at breakfast. He had merely requested that they leave Roberto alone, that nobody ask him questions or badger him to tell the story of what had happened in the maze. Most people, he noticed, were skirting him in the corridors, avoiding his eyes. Some whispered behind their hands as he passed.
　　He guessed that many of them had believed Rita Skeeter's article about how disturbed and possibly dangerous he was. Perhaps they were formulating their own theories about how Nicolas had died. He found he didn't care very much. He liked it best when he was with Diego and Carolina and they were talking about other things, or else letting him sit in silence while they played chess. He felt as though all three of them had reached an understanding they didn't need to put into words; that each was waiting for some sign, some word, of what was going on outside Hogwarts - and that it was useless to speculate
　　about what might be coming until they knew anything for certain. The only time they touched upon the subject was when Diego told Roberto about a meeting Mrs. Lopez had had with Dominguez before going home.
　　"She went to ask him if you could come straight to us this summer," he said. "But he wants you to go back to the Carrizos, at least at first."
　　"Why?" said Roberto.
　　"She said Dominguez's got his reasons," said Diego, shaking his head darkly. "I suppose we've got to trust him, haven't we?"
　　The only person apart from Diego and Carolina that Roberto felt able to talk to was Villalba.
　　As there was no longer a Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, they had those lessons free. They used the one on Thursday afternoon to go down and visit Villalba in his cabin.
　　It was a bright and sunny day; Fang bounded out of the open door as they approached, barking and wagging his tail madly.
　　"Who's that?" called Villalba, coming to the door. "Roberto!"
　　He strode out to meet them, pulled Roberto into a one-armed hug, ruffled his hair, and said, "Good ter see yeh, mate. Good ter see yeh."
　　They saw two bucket-size cups and saucers on the wooden table in front of the fireplace when they entered Villalba's cabin.
　　"Bin havin' a cuppa with Olympe," Villalba said. "She's jus' left."
　　"Who?" said Diego curiously.
　　"Madame Maxime, o' course!" said Villalba.
　　"You two made up, have you?" said Diego.
　　"Dunno what yeh're talkin' about," said Villalba airily, fetching more cups from the dresser. When he had made tea and offered around a plate of doughy cookies, he leaned back in his chair and surveyed Roberto closely through his beetle-black eyes.
　　"You all righ'?" he said gruffly "Yeah," said Roberto.
　　"No, yeh're not," said Villalba. "Course yeh're not. But yeh will be."
　　Roberto said nothing.
　　"Knew he was goin' ter come back," said Villalba, and Roberto, Diego, and Carolina looked up at him, shocked. "Known it fer years. Roberto. Knew he was out there, bidin' his time. It had ter happen. Well, now it has, an' we'll jus' have ter get on with it. We'll fight.
　　Migh' be able ter stop him before he gets a good hold. That's Dominguezs plan, anyway.
　　Great man, Dominguez. 'S long as we've got him, I'm not too worried."
　　Villalba raised his bushy eyebrows at the disbelieving expressions on their faces.
　　"No good sittin' worryin' abou' it," he said. "What's comin' will come, an we'll meet it when it does. Dominguez told me wha' you did. Roberto."
　　Villalba's chest swelled as he looked at Roberto.
　　"Yeh did as much as yer father would've done, an' I can' give yeh no higher praise than that."
　　Roberto smiled back at him. It was the first time he'd smiled in days. "What's Dominguez asked you to do, Villalba?" he asked. "He sent Professor Romero to ask you and Madame Maxime to meet him - that night."
　　"Got a little job fer me over the summer," said Villalba. "Secret, though. I'm not s'pposed ter talk abou' it, no, not even ter you lot. Olympe - Madame Maxime ter you -might be comin' with me. I think she will. Think I got her persuaded."
　　"Is it to do with Salvador?"
　　Villalba flinched at the sound of the name.
　　"Migh' be," he said evasively. "Now . . . who'd like ter come an' visit the las' skrewt with me? I was jokin' - jokin'!" he added hastily, seeing the looks on their faces.
　　It was with a heavy heart that Roberto packed his trunk up in the dormitory on the night before his return to Privet Drive. He was dreading the Leaving Feast, which was usually a cause for celebration, when the winner of the Inter-House Championship would be announced. He had avoided being in the Great Hall when it was full ever since he had left the hospital wing, preferring to eat when it was nearly empty to avoid the stares of his fellow students.
　　When he, Diego, and Carolina entered the Hall, they saw at once that the usual decorations were missing. The Great Hall was normally decorated with the winning House's colors for the Leaving Feast. Tonight, however, there were black drapes on the wall behind the teachers' table. Roberto knew instantly that they were there as a mark of respect to
　　Nicolas.
　　The real Mad-Eye Acosta was at the staff table now, his wooden leg and his magical eye back in place. He was extremely twitchy, jumping every time someone spoke to him. Roberto couldn't blame him; Acostas fear of attack was bound to have been increased by his ten-month imprisonment in his own trunk. Professor Morales s chair was empty. Roberto wondered, as he sat down with the other Gryffindors, where Morales was now, and whether Salvador had caught up with him.
　　Madame Maxime was still there. She was sitting next to Villalba. They were talking quietly together. Further along the table, sitting next to Professor Romero, was Peralta. His eyes lingered on Roberto for a moment as Roberto looked at him. His expression was difficult to read. He looked as sour and unpleasant as ever. Roberto continued to watch him, long after Peralta had looked away.
　　What was it that Peralta had done on Dominguezs orders, the night that Salvador had returned? And why. . . why . . . was Dominguez so convinced that Peralta was truly on their side? He had been their spy, Dominguez had said so in the Pensieve. Peralta had turned spy against Salvador, "at great personal risk." Was that the job he had taken up again? Had he made contact with the Death Eaters, perhaps? Pretended that he had never really gone over to Dominguez, that he had been, like Salvador himself, biding his time?
　　Roberto's musings were ended by Professor Dominguez, who stood up at the staff table. The Great Hall, which in any case had been less noisy than it usually was at the Leaving Feast, became very quiet.
　　"The end," said Dominguez, looking around at them all, "of another year."
　　He paused, and his eyes fell upon the Hufflepuff table. Theirs had been the most subdued table before he had gotten to his feet, and theirs were still the saddest and palest faces in the Hall.
　　"There is much that I would like to say to you all tonight," said Dominguez, "but I must first acknowledge the loss of a very fine person, who should be sitting here," he gestured toward the Hufflepuffs, "enjoying our feast with us. I would like you all, please, to stand, and raise your glasses, to Nicolas Ortega."
　　They did it, all of them; the benches scraped as everyone in the Hall stood, and raised their goblets, and echoed, in one loud, low, rumbling voice, "Nicolas Ortega."
　　Roberto caught a glimpse of Paula through the crowd. There were tears pouring silently down her face. He looked down at the table as they all sat down again.
　　"Nicolas was a person who exemplified many of the qualities that distinguish Hufflepuff house," Dominguez continued. "He was a good and loyal friend, a hard worker, he valued fair play. His death has affected you all, whether you knew him well or not. I think that you have the right, therefore, to know exactly how it came about."
　　Roberto raised his head and stared at Dominguez.
　　"Nicolas Ortega was murdered by Lord Salvador."
　　A panicked whisper swept the Great Hall. People were staring at Dominguez in disbelief, in horror. He looked perfectly calm as he watched them mutter themselves into silence.
　　"The Ministry of Magic," Dominguez continued, "does not wish me to tell you this. It is possible that some of your parents will be horrified that I have done so - either because they will not believe that Lord Salvador has returned, or because they think I should not tell you so, young as you are. It is my belief, however, that the truth is generally preferable to lies, and that any attempt to pretend that Nicolas died as the result of an accident, or some sort of blunder of his own, is an insult to his memory."
　　Stunned and frightened, every face in the Hall was turned toward Dominguez now... or almost every face. Over at the Slytherin table. Roberto saw Javier Sosa muttering something to Crabbe and Goyle. Roberto felt a hot, sick swoop of anger in his stomach. He forced himself to look back at Dominguez.
　　"There is somebody else who must be mentioned in connection with Nicolass death,"
　　Dominguez went on. "I am talking, of course, about Roberto Gonzales."
　　A kind of ripple crossed the Great Hall as a few heads turned in Roberto's direction before flicking back to face Dominguez.
　　"Roberto Gonzales managed to escape Lord Salvador," said Dominguez. "He risked his own life to return Nicolas's body to Hogwarts. He showed, in every respect, the sort of bravery that few wizards have ever shown in facing Lord Salvador, and for this, I honor him."
　　Dominguez turned gravely to Roberto and raised his goblet once more. Nearly everyone in
　　the Great Hall followed suit. They murmured his name, as they had murmured Nicolas's, and drank to him. But through a gap in the standing figures. Roberto saw that Sosa, Crabbe, Goyle, and many of the other Slytherins had remained defiantly in their seats, their goblets untouched. Dominguez, who after all possessed no magical eye, did not see them.
　　When everyone had once again resumed their seats, Dominguez continued, "The Triwizard Tournament's aim was to further and promote magical understanding. In the light of what has happened - of Lord Salvadors return - such ties are more important than ever before."
　　Dominguez looked from Madame Maxime and Villalba, to Camila Saenz and her fellow Beauxbatons students, to Viktor Krum and the Durmstrangs at the Slytherin table. Krum, Roberto saw, looked wary, almost frightened, as though he expected Dominguez to say something harsh.
　　"Every guest in this Hall," said Dominguez, and his eyes lingered upon the Durmstrang students, "will be welcomed back here at any time, should they wish to come. I say to you all, once again - in the light of Lord Salvador's return, we are only as strong as we are united, as weak as we are divided. Lord Salvadors gift for spreading discord and enmity is very great. We can fight it only by showing an equally strong bond of friendship and trust. Differences of habit and language are nothing at all if our aims are identical and our hearts are open.
　　"It is my belief- and never have I so hoped that I am mistaken - that we are all facing dark and difficult times. Some of you in this Hall have already suffered directly at the hands of Lord Salvador. Many of your families have been torn asunder. A week ago, a student was taken from our midst.
　　"Remember Nicolas. Remember, if the time should come when you have to make a choice between what is right and what is easy, remember what happened to a boy who was good, and kind, and brave, because he strayed across the path of Lord Salvador. Remember Nicolas Ortega."
　　Roberto's trunk was packed; Hedwig was back in her cage on top of it. He, Diego, and Carolina were waiting in the crowded entrance hall with the rest of the fourth years for the carriages that would take them back to Hogsmeade station. It was another beautiful summer's day. He supposed that Privet Drive would be hot and leafy, its flower beds a riot of color, when he arrived there that evening. The thought gave him no pleasure at all.
　　"'Arry!"
　　He looked around. Camila Saenz was hurrying up the stone steps into the castle. Beyond her, far across the grounds. Roberto could see Villalba helping Madame Maxime to back two of the giant horses into their harness. The Beauxbatons carriage was about to take off.
　　"We will see each uzzer again, I 'ope," said Camila as she reached him, holding out her hand. "I am 'oping to get a job 'ere, to improve my Eenglish."
　　"It's very good already," said Diego in a strangled sort of voice. Camila smiled at him; Carolina scowled.
　　"Good-bye, 'Arry," said Camila, turning to go. "It 'az been a pleasure meeting you!"
　　Robertos spirits couldn't help but lift slightly as he watched Camila hurry back across the lawns to Madame Maxime, her silvery hair rippling in the sunlight.
　　Wonder how the Durmstrang students are getting back," said Diego. "D' you reckon they can steer that ship without Morales?"
　　"Morales did not steer," said a gruff voice. "He stayed in his cabin and let us do the vork."
　　Krum had come to say good-bye to Carolina. "Could I have a vord?" he asked her.
　　"Oh . . . yes ... all right," said Carolina, looking slightly flustered, and following Krum through the crowd and out of sight.
　　"You'd better hurry up!" Diego called loudly after her. "The carriages'll be here in a minute!"
　　He let Roberto keep a watch for the carriages, however, and spent the next few minutes craning his neck over the crowd to try and see what Krum and Carolina might be up to.
　　They returned quite soon. Diego stared at Carolina, but her face was quite impassive.
　　"I liked Ortega," said Krum abruptly to Roberto. "He vos alvays polite to me. Alvays.
　　Even though I vos from Durmstrang - with Morales," he added, scowling.
　　"Have you got a new headmaster yet?" said Roberto Krum shrugged. He held out his hand as Camila had done, shook Roberto's hand, and then Diego's. Diego looked as though he was suffering some sort of painful internal struggle.
　　Krum had already started walking away when Diego burst out, "Can I have your autograph?"
　　Carolina turned away, smiling at the horseless carriages that were now trundling toward them up the drive, as Krum, looking surprised but gratified, signed a fragment of parchment for Diego.
　　The weather could not have been more different on the journey back to King's Cross than it had been on their way to Hogwarts the previous September. There wasn't a single cloud in the sky. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina had managed to get a compartment to themselves.
　　Pigwidgeon was once again hidden under Diegos dress robes to stop him from hooting continually; Hedwig was dozing, her head under her wing, and Crookshanks was curled up in a spare seat like a large, furry ginger cushion. Roberto, Diego, and Carolina talked more fully and freely than they had all week as the train sped them southward. Roberto felt as though Dominguez's speech at the Leaving Feast had unblocked him, somehow. It was less painful to discuss what had happened now. They broke off their conversation about what action Dominguez might be taking, even now, to stop Salvador only when the lunch trolley arrived.
　　When Carolina returned from the trolley and put her money back into her schoolbag, she dislodged a copy of the Daily Prophet that she had been carrying in there. Roberto looked at it, unsure whether he really wanted to know what it might say, but Carolina, seeing him looking at it, said calmly, "There's nothing in there. You can look for yourself, but there's nothing at all. I've been checking every day. Just a small piece the day after the third task saying you won the tournament. They didn't even mention Nicolas.
　　Nothing about any of it. If you ask me. Fudge is forcing them to keep quiet."
　　"He'll never keep Rita quiet," said Roberto. "Not on a story like this."
　　"Oh, Rita hasn't written anything at all since the third task," said Carolina in an oddly constrained voice. "As a matter of fact," she added, her voice now trembling slightly, "Rita Skeeter isn't going to be writing anything at all for a while. Not unless she wants me to spill the beans on her."
　　"What are you talking about?" said Diego.
　　"I found out how she was listening in on private conversations when she wasn't supposed to be coming onto the grounds," said Carolina in a rush.
　　Roberto had the impression that Carolina had been dying to tell them this for days, but that she had restrained herself in light of everything else that had happened.
　　"How was she doing it?" said Roberto at once.
　　"How did you find out?" said Diego, staring at her.
　　"Well, it was you, really, who gave me the idea. Roberto," she said.
　　"Did I?" said Roberto, perplexed. "How?"
　　"Bugging," said Carolina happily.
　　"But you said they didn't work -"
　　"Oh not electronic bugs," said Carolina. "No, you see ... Rita Skeeter" - Carolinas voice trembled with quiet triumph - "is an unregistered Animagus. She can turn -"
　　Carolina pulled a small sealed glass jar out other bag.
　　"- into a beetle."
　　"You're kidding," said Diego. "You haven't.. . she's not..."
　　"Oh yes she is," said Carolina happily, brandishing the jar at them.
　　Inside were a few twigs and leaves and one large, fat beetle.
　　"That's never - you're kidding -" Diego whispered, lifting the jar to his eyes.
　　"No, I'm not," said Carolina, beaming. "I caught her on the windowsill in the hospital wing. Look very closely, and you'll notice the markings around her antennae are exactly like those foul glasses she wears."
　　Roberto looked and saw that she was quite right. He also remembered something.
　　"There was a beetle on the statue the night we heard Villalba telling Madame Maxime about his mum!"
　　"Exactly," said Carolina. "And Viktor pulled a beetle out of my hair after we'd had our conversation by the lake. And unless I'm very much mistaken, Rita was perched on the windowsill of the Divination class the day your scar hurt. She's been buzzing around for stories all year."
　　"When we saw Sosa under that tree ..." said Diego slowly.
　　"He was talking to her, in his hand," said Carolina. "He knew, of course. That's how she's been getting all those nice little interviews with the Slytherins. They wouldn't care that she was doing something illegal, as long as they were giving her horrible stuff
　　about us and Villalba."
　　Carolina took the glass jar back from Diego and smiled at the beetle, which buzzed angrily against the glass.
　　"I've told her I'll let her out when we get back to London," said Carolina. "I've put an Unbreakable Charm on the jar, you see, so she can't transform. And I've told her she's to keep her quill to herself for a whole year. See if she can't break the habit of writing horrible lies about people."
　　Smiling serenely, Carolina placed the beetle back inside her schoolbag.
　　The door of the compartment slid open.
　　"Very clever. Fernandez," said Javier Sosa.
　　Crabbe and Goyle were standing behind him. All three of them looked more pleased with themselves, more arrogant and more menacing, than Roberto had ever seen them.
　　"So," said Sosa slowly, advancing slightly into the compartment and looking slowly around at them, a smirk quivering on his lips. "You caught some pathetic reporter, and Gonzales's Dominguez's favorite boy again. Big deal."
　　His smirk widened. Crabbe and Goyle leered.
　　"Trying not to think about it, are we?" said Sosa softly, looking around at all three of them. "Trying to pretend it hasn't happened?"
　　"Get out," said Roberto.
　　He had not been this close to Sosa since he had watched him muttering to Crabbe and Goyle during Dominguezs speech about Nicolas. He could feel a kind of ringing in his ears. His hand gripped his wand under his robes.
　　"You've picked the losing side, Gonzales! I warned you! I told you you ought to choose your company more carefully, remember? When we met on the train, first day at Hogwarts?
　　I told you not to hang around with riffraff like this!" He jerked his head at Diego and Carolina. "Too late now. Gonzales! They'll be the first to go, now the Dark Lord's back!
　　Mudbloods and Muggle-lovers first! Well - second - Ortega was the f-"
　　It was as though someone had exploded a box of fireworks within the compartment. Blinded by the blaze of the spells that had blasted from every direction, deafened by a series of bangs, Roberto blinked and looked down at the floor.
　　Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle were all lying unconscious in the doorway. He, Diego, and Carolina were on their feet, all three of them having used a different hex. Nor were they the only ones to have done so.
　　"Thought we'd see what those three were up to," said Pablo matter-of-factly, stepping onto Goyle and into the compartment. He had his wand out, and so did Luis, who was careful to tread on Sosa as he followed Pablo inside.
　　"Interesting effect," said Luis, looking down at Crabbe. "Who used the Furnunculus Curse?"
　　"Me," said Roberto.
　　"Odd," said Luis lightly. "I used Jelly-Legs. Looks as though those two shouldn't be mixed. He seems to have sprouted little tentacles all over his face. Well, let's not leave them here, they don't add much to the decor."
　　Diego, Roberto, and Luis kicked, rolled, and pushed the unconscious Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle - each of whom looked distinctly the worse for the jumble of jinxes with which they had been hit - out into the corridor, then came back into the compartment and rolled the door shut.
　　"Exploding Snap, anyone?" said Pablo, pulling out a pack of cards.
　　They were halfway through their fifth game when Roberto decided to ask them.
　　"You going to tell us, then?" he said to Luis. "Who you were blackmailing?"
　　"Oh," said Luis darkly. "That."
　　"It doesn't matter," said Pablo, shaking his head impatiently. "It wasn't anything important. Not now, anyway."
　　"We've given up," said Luis, shrugging.
　　But Roberto, Diego, and Carolina kept on asking, and finally, Pablo said, "All right, all right, if you really want to know ... it was Ludo Bagman."
　　"Bagman?" said Roberto sharply. "Are you saying he was involved in -"
　　"Nah," said Luis gloomily. "Nothing like that. Stupid git. He wouldn't have the brains."
　　"Well, what, then?" said Diego.
　　Pablo hesitated, then said, "You remember that bet we had with him at the Quidditch World Cup? About how Ireland would win, but Krum would get the Snitch?"
　　"Yeah," said Roberto and Diego slowly.
　　"Well, the git paid us in leprechaun gold he'd caught from the Irish mascots."
　　"So?"
　　"So," said Pablo impatiently, "it vanished, didn't it? By next morning, it had gone!"
　　"But - it must've been an accident, mustn't it?" said Carolina.
　　Luis laughed very bitterly.
　　"Yeah, that's what we thought, at first. We thought if we just wrote to him, and told him he'd made a mistake, he'd cough up. But nothing doing. Ignored our letter. We kept trying to talk to him about it at Hogwarts, but he was always making some excuse to get away from us."
　　"In the end, he turned pretty nasty," said Pablo. "Told us we were too young to gamble, and he wasn't giving us anything."
　　"So we asked for our money back," said Luis glowering.
　　"He didn't refuse!" gasped Carolina.
　　"Right in one," said Pablo.
　　"But that was all your savings!" said Diego.
　　"Tell me about it," said Luis. "'Course, we found out what was going on in the end.
　　Lee Jordan's dad had had a bit of trouble getting money off Bagman as well. Turns out he's in big trouble with the goblins. Borrowed loads of gold off them. A gang of them cornered him in the woods after the World Cup and took all the gold he had, and it still wasn't enough to cover all his debts. They followed him all the way to Hogwarts to keep an eye on him. He's lost everything gambling. Hasn't got two Galleons to rub together.
　　And you know how the idiot tried to pay the goblins back?"
　　"How?" said Roberto.
　　"He put a bet on you, mate," said Pablo. "Put a big bet on you to win the tournament. Bet against the goblins."
　　"So that's why he kept trying to help me win!" said Roberto. "Well - I did win, didn't I?
　　So he can pay you your gold!"
　　"Nope," said Luis, shaking his head. "The goblins play as dirty as him. They say you drew with Ortega, and Bagman was betting you'd win outright. So Bagman had to run for it. He did run for it right after the third task."
　　Luis sighed deeply and started dealing out the cards again.
　　The rest of the journey passed pleasantly enough; Roberto wished it could have gone on all summer, in fact, and that he would never arrive at King's Cross . . . but as he had learned the hard way that year, time will not slow down when something unpleasant lies ahead, and all too soon, the Hogwarts Express was pulling in at platform nine and three-quarters. The usual confusion and noise filled the corridors as the students began to disembark. Diego and Carolina struggled out past Sosa, Crabbe, and Goyle, carrying their trunks. Roberto, however, stayed put.
　　"Pablo - Luis - wait a moment."
　　The twins turned. Roberto pulled open his trunk and drew out his Triwizard winnings.
　　"Take it," he said, and he thrust the sack into Luis's hands.
　　"What?" said Pablo, looking flabbergasted.
　　"Take it," Roberto repeated firmly. "I don't want it."
　　"You're mental," said Luis, trying to push it back at Roberto.
　　"No, I'm not," said Roberto. "You take it, and get inventing. It's for the joke shop."
　　"He is mental," Pablo said in an almost awed voice.
　　"Listen," said Roberto firmly. "If you don't take it, I'm throwing it down the drain. I don't want it and I don't need it. But I could do with a few laughs. We could all do with a few laughs. I've got a feeling we're going to need them more than usual before long."
　　"Roberto," said Luis weakly, weighing the money bag in his hands, "there's got to be a thousand Galleons in here."
　　"Yeah," said Roberto, grinning. "Think how many Canary Creams that is."
　　The twins stared at him.
　　"Just don't tell your mum where you got it... although she might not be so keen for you to join the Ministry anymore, come to think of it. . . ."
　　"Roberto," Pablo began, but Roberto pulled out his wand.
　　"Look," he said flatly, "take it, or I'll hex you. I know some good ones now. Just do me one favor, okay? Buy Diego some different dress robes and say they're from you."
　　He left the compartment before they could say another word, stepping over Sosa, Crabbe,
　　and Goyle, who were still lying on the floor, covered in hex marks.
　　Uncle Francisco was waiting beyond the barrier. Mrs. Lopez was close by him. She hugged Roberto very tightly when she saw him and whispered in his ear, "I think Dominguez will let you come to us later in the summer. Keep in touch, Roberto."
　　"See you. Roberto," said Diego, clapping him on the back.
　　"'Bye, Roberto!" said Carolina, and she did something she had never done before, and kissed him on the cheek.
　　"Roberto - thanks," Luis muttered, while Pablo nodded fervently at his side.
　　Roberto winked at them, turned to Uncle Francisco, and followed him silently from the station.
　　There was no point worrying yet, he told himself, as he got into the back of the Carrizos' car.
　　As Villalba had said, what would come, would come ... and he would have to meet it when it did.
